  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:28:28 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Here's the section on language from the first preface: The forms of thought are, in the first instance, displayed and stored as human language. Nowadays we cannot be too often reminded that it is thinking which distinguishes man from the beasts. Into all that becomes something inward for men, an image or conception as such, into all that he makes his own, language has penetrated, and everything that he has transformed into language and expresses in it contains a category ‚Äì concealed, mixed with other forms or clearly determined as such, so much is Logic his natural element, indeed his own peculiar nature... That's the beginning of section 14.

  • minimaltomMon Sep 25 2023 16:28:55 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @douglain#0 read on, i found out myself üòÑ

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:32:04 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    What's important to understand about this first workshop is that Hegel is pointing to the deficiencies in scientific thinking that he experienced in his era. While the reference to computer science may seem like a nonsequitur, it was in fact a predictable response in a way as there is a commonly held belief that the sciences have advanced since Hegel's time. The question is whether scientific understanding has overcome the impasse that Hegel is attempting to address in his Science of Logic or not.

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:33:11 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    The science of logic is a book about discovering the metaphysics of logic and the logic of metaphysics. That is, it an attempt to ground science, to rediscover its substance.

  • minimaltomMon Sep 25 2023 16:34:47 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:53:03 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Consider this: Though these two sciences have been universally and abundantly cultivated, the latter even up to our own day, the interest taken in the speculative side has been only slight; in fact, on the whole, the same material has been just repeated over and over again, sometimes being thinned out to the point of being trivial and superficial and sometimes more of the old ballast has been hauled out afresh and trailed along with logic. From such efforts, often purely mechanical, the philosophical import of the science could gain nothing.

  • minimaltomMon Sep 25 2023 16:54:02 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @douglain#0 great this is exactly what i want!

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:54:06 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    So, the two sciences are logic and metaphysics. Hegel is saying that these sciences have become hollow shells, unrelated to the world of appearance. Relegated off from serious attempts at understanding. Trivial and superficial.

  • minimaltomMon Sep 25 2023 16:54:26 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I want to talk about this

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:54:48 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    One way to understand what he means is that the sciences are self-contained, self-referential, only concerned with their own inner nature and unrelated to truth.

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:55:15 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Logic is valid if it is internally consistent, but an untrue argument can be consistent like that.

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:55:33 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Metaphysics is ignored.

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:56:11 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    nobody has a good understanding of what science is except for a consistent model. nobody knows how we get closer to truth through the sciences.

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 16:56:16 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Anyhow, now I have to go.

  • douglainMon Sep 25 2023 18:10:24 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 So, what Thomas claimed was that computer science has a method for arriving at Truth or at least developing toward it that relies on negation. That is, he basically restated Popper's falsification theory of science as an answer to Hegel.

  • douglainTue Sep 26 2023 03:44:00 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • firedog235Tue Sep 26 2023 04:03:24 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Okay, The infamous Thomas Here --- Just read this... Don't worry, I did read the prefaces. And various sections of the book previously when trying to understand a secondary source, though never the entire book in a single go. So there are a couple of things going on with my stock market interpretation --- The first is I would point out that capitalism, as interpreted by Zizek, is itself a religious movement as well as a material one and the movements of the stock market are thus themselves metaphysical in nature. So when capitalists speak of speculation on the stock market... that is a metaphysical statement as well as a 'physical statement'. I am not dumping or giving up on the original concern with 'god' rather I'm concerned with god (or rather the social gheist) as it actually exists in our modern society: i.e. with capitalism itself. I am circling back, as well, however, and making a somewhat different claim from Popper's --- Popper says that in order for a theory to be a scientific one it must be falsifiable, however I would add to that, that we also need to know the conditions of falsification itself (i.e. logic/contradiction) which takes the question further than Popper.

  • firedog235Tue Sep 26 2023 04:06:58 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Second, as for my presuppositions --- I would point to the text itself: As for bringing in my own understanding I would point to the prefaces themselves and we can explore if what I'm doing is a bad method. The first is the entry point of the second preface: "To exhibit the realm of thought philosophically, that is, in its own immanent activity or what is the same, in its necessary development,¬Æ had therefore to be a fresh undertaking, one that had to be started right from the beginning; but this traditional material, the familiar forms of thought, must be regarded as an extremely important source, indeed as a necessary condition and as a presupposition to be gratefully acknowledged even though what it offers is only here and there a meagre shred or a disordered heap of dead bones ¬Æ." I don't read this as saying we need to dump all our presuppositions but rather we need to surface them, make them conscious --- so I am doing that for myself and in the proces hopefully drawing them out for others. Another statement from the text: "This restriction to what is simple gives scope for the free play of caprice which does not want to remain simple but brings in its own reflections on the subject matter. Having good right to occupy itself at first only with the principle and in doing so not to concern itself with what lies beyond it, this thoroughness actually proceeds to do the opposite of this, for it does bring in what lies beyond, that is, categories other than those which constitute the principle itself, other presuppositions and prejudices." --- the way I read this, it is not actually possible for us to proceed without presupposition, rather we must bring them into the discussion if we are to proceed at all. The only way to proceed analytically is to actually work through the linguistic knots as they exist for the participants.

  • firedog235Tue Sep 26 2023 04:11:06 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Finally, I don't think that the idea that we are going to go through the whole text line by line is actually a goal of the reading group (though It is open to patrons and so we can make of it what we will by participating...) I don't think that would necessarily be a very enlightening or interesting discussion because the text is available, you can read it, what's the value add? What is important, educational, and entertaining (these things are not all in complete contradiction with each other) is the commentary on the various parts of the text. My question here would be... are you simply trying to get us to read the text for you? Because if so, we cannot.

  • firedog235Tue Sep 26 2023 04:32:59 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    P.S. also on the Kant stuff --- I either misspoke or was misheard: my point wasn't that Kant tells us what the thing-in-itself is, that he gives us access to truth. My point is that he's always *attempting* to do so and failing through some kind of a deterministic logic. He keeps circling this thing-in-itself in the pattern of 'Here I will attempt to find the thing-in-itself.... [theory noises]... I was unable to find the thing-in-itself' and Hegel's response is, 'there will always be a necessary phenominal-neumenal gap and that gap *is* the thing-in-itself, i.e. being-in-itself/contingency/contradiction'.

  • minimaltomTue Sep 26 2023 07:50:07 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

Or again, to speak of things, we call the nature or the essence of things their notion, and this is only for thought; but still less shall we say of the notions of things that we dominate them, or that the determinations of thought of which they are the complex are at our service; on the contrary, it is our thinking that must accommodate itself to them and our caprice or freedom ought not to want to mould them to suit itself."

Or again, when we speak of things, we call their nature or essence their concept, and this concept is only for thought; but still less shall we say of the concepts of things that we dominate them, or that the thought determinations of which they are the complex are at our service. On the contrary, our thought must accord with them, and our choice or freedom ought not to want to fit them to its purposes.

  • minimaltomTue Sep 26 2023 21:19:52 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I finished the video off anyway and think i grasped most of what you cover kind of. I see in it what I found in Zizek initially and what changed my life for the better. Its a remedy to the kind of nihilism that says - whats the point, were just a drop in the ocean and theres a whole dead lifeless empty space out there with nothing in it, we dont even exist ourselves, were just a mind trapped in a body thats gonna die and we'll disappear, itll be like nothing ever existed. For one thing that dead lifeless empty space is only a subjective representation, theres nothing behind it so its like youre making it up. Theres really not some actual empty void, its purely theoretical. Also Nothing exists without our thinking it into being because existing is a concept in our minds, it doesnt mean anything without us to think it. I'd become completely cynical about music which I'd previously thought was the most important thing in my life that its just a fantasy, its meaningless sound but when I started hearing Zizek I realised if thats all there is, our perceptions and our fantasies then the answer lies within them which includes music and art and philosophy etc and then I realised we have a huge legacy of incredible art and thought to draw on that id never thought about before, classical music, poetry and philosophy, like the greatest minds of all time have created this edifice of work for not only escaping that nihilism but pointing out that its false. Philosophy became my kind of religion. ü§©

  • minimaltomTue Sep 26 2023 21:22:14 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • firedog235Tue Oct 03 2023 09:19:08 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I mean, saying god is freedom is a statment I'll accept but it doesn't strike me as being so different from 'the absolute is pure contingency'. However, If I steelman his argument I think that the difference is that he was emphasizing possibility against contingency (with contingency being total noise/randomness while possibility is that noise and randomness + a negative determiniation that says 'but the noise doesn't go here'). And I think that's fair except my actual difficulty then would be with Doug because while I think the words 'the absolute is pure contingency' did come out of my mouth I was trying to emphasis this pure contingency as being more the starting point (the being-in-itself) than the end --- the end I would say is perhaps that 'the absolute is pure possibility' where possibility means contingency subject to negative determination (but this is also my fault for not quite getting the difference between 'the absolute' and 'being-in-itself').

  • firedog235Tue Oct 03 2023 09:21:45 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    The algorithms don't represent progress bit was a bit annoying if only because... there was a clear elision occuring where I'm saying something like the development of the algorithm my go in the direction of progress (i.e. might move towards the labor theory of value over time, for example) if that was how one wanted to develop it but also probably most people running stock algorithms are likely motivated reasoners who won't make that kind of move and then of course that doesn't make it into the translation.

    @minimaltom#0 So It seems to me that Hegel elides thing-in-itself into being-in-itself (but when he does he usually capitalizes it to Thing-in-itself) --- as in, the thing-in-itself (where 'thing' is taken not as a specific sensuous object, but rather, as the category of all things) is also being-in-itself

  • andru0358Fri Oct 20 2023 17:31:22 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    There is with "The Absolute", what the question means and what the answer is that we find, right? What is "the absolute"? What are we even asking? Here is from the MIA Hegel GLossary: "Absolute and Relative are philosophical terms concerning the mutual interdependence of things, processes and knowledge. ‚ÄòAbsolute‚Äô means independent, permanent and not subject to qualification. ‚ÄòRelative‚Äô means partial or transient, dependent on circumstances or point-of-view. For dialectics, the Absolute is only the whole movement through various relative stages of understanding, but the progress of knowledge never comes to an end, so the absolute is relative. However, even a relative truth may nevertheless contain some grain of truth, so there is an absolute within the relative." So when we talk about "The Absolute", we are asking, what is this "independent, permanent and not subject to qualification"? So for Absolute may be something like the lay term, the "ultimate", or Jasper's term "the comprehensive", the everything. Pure Being? What can we say about pure being? At the outset, "It is pure indeterminateness and emptiness. There is nothing to be intuited in it, if one can speak here of intuiting" (Chapter 1, first paragraph). I think there's a truth in what Thomas is saying about contingency or possibility, in Hegel's language, indeterminate. I think where we are disagreeing is around randomness as an adequate description, which maybe is not his position (anymore?). Freedom is not random, randomness, nor psuedo-randomness; in my opinion, randomness is only a modeling tool for the unmodelable. I don't think Hegel is interested in modeling, and that is also the problem with the stock-market metaphor, which I brought up originally as a counter-example. Modeling is empirical; what I understood from Thomas was he was staking a claim that through iterative modeling and correcting, we could get at the "thing-in-itself" of the economy; ie moving towards LTV. and thereby [tbc]

  • andru0358Fri Oct 20 2023 17:59:25 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    ...there ascertaining "metaphysical" truths, ie about the economy. I think this whole approach misses what Hegel is intersted it, but I think we can get back to it, following it through. The idea of an algorithm attempting to ascertain the "thing-in-itself" of the economy through iterative falsification and revision, would have to include a theory of algorithmic modeling. Otherwise it would be making assumptions it is unable to revise; ie, my contention about randomness as a modelling assumption above. The algorithm would have to engage in self critique of its own methodology in response to falsifications at some point, otherwise it would be trapped within a confined set of possible theories. This is my attempt at a version of Kant's critique of empiricism. For him space & time were assumptions necessarily prior to experience. The "thing-in-itself", Hegel explains in the Introduction, is also a pure product of thought. So the algorithm, in attempting to get at "the real economy", assumes there is such a thing; assumes a thing to be modeled. Models assume quantity, quality, etc.. All which cannot be ascertained through senses or modeling. So where do these concepts come from? How do we justify using them at all? I think that's what Hegel is developing. We go out and try to understand the world and realize we are folding it into concepts with already carry, then we need to go inward and examine these concepts and critique them. Where do we start? How do we develop and critique concepts without making untenable assumptions? If we require a conceptual framework to be assumed before empirical investigation, can this conceptual framework be developed and justified within itself, independent of sensual experience? I think this is what Hegel means by speculative reason and metaphysics. We can examine thought itself directly; whereas the world of our sense is understood through thought, through abstraction, conceptualization. But thought is not arbitrary and has [tbc]

  • andru0358Fri Oct 20 2023 17:59:52 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    thought has internal laws which can be understood and through that, can develop a system of thought interanlly consistent and immanently justified

  • andru0358Fri Oct 20 2023 18:00:12 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Very interested to hear if anyone disagrees with this, thank you if you bothered to read it.

  • johnmcguire13Sat Oct 21 2023 20:31:17 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @andru0358#0 <@476561351167311872> I found your comments quite helpful here, especially towards the end when you begin asking questions about where do we start thinking about thought and how do we go about thinking about it on its own terms without bringing in unwarranted assumptions. In a way it reminds me of what Descartes attempted in his metaphysical thinking. Of course Hegel goes worlds beyond Descartes because while Descartes takes thinking for granted, and the brute fact of his own thinking activity as a clear indication that he can be certain at the very least that he himself exists as a thinking thing, Hegel refuses to let the brute fact of the existence of thought itself be taken for granted and that it‚Äôs foundation must be examined on its own terms. Maybe the reference to Descartes is unwarranted but I see a similarity in his attempt to evacuate the mind as much as possible to reach some kind of foundation for mental activity and Hegel‚Äôs attempt to evacuate thought itself of all determinations to try to reach an understanding of thought itself. Or maybe I have no idea what I‚Äôm talking about and am completely misunderstanding the text. I have literally spent hours trying to come up with something to contribute here and keep deleting everything I write because at a certain point it seems to get tied up in a knots and stops making sense.

  • dve.h_37844Sun Oct 22 2023 16:07:45 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @johnmcguire13#0 I know what you mean! <@1163640766598479882> I spent a lot of time as a serious monestary visiting Buddhist for a while so I‚Äôve studied the phenomenon of thought quite thoroughly. In my experience there is the kind of thought that tends to accompany speech when there is tension. This is usually because one has not practiced gratitude for the wisdom of the Buddha or the monks and all the lay people. I‚Äôm not sure if ‚Äúwhere thought comes from‚Äù is what you‚Äôre driving at, but thought I‚Äôd share.

  • johnmcguire13Sun Oct 22 2023 18:42:53 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 ‚ÄúWhere thought comes from‚Äù is close to what I mean, but I think more precisely I mean ‚Äúwhat has to be true about being for thought to arise such as it does in our minds.‚Äù

  • minimaltomMon Oct 23 2023 19:17:50 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @douglain#0 Im enjoying reading the introduction, but it is also hard

  • andru0358Tue Oct 24 2023 00:56:35 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @johnmcguire13#0 <@1163640766598479882> I'm really glad you found my comments helpful. At some point I was also continually thinking of Descartes. Descartes found thought as that which cannot be doubted in its existence, whereas that of sensual reality can. Hegel, I think, does not doubt the existence of sensual reality, but we know it only mediately through thought - I think, based on my understanding of PoS. Hegel's interest in thought is not to prove existence, but to understand (not in his terminological sense) thought in-itself towards thought understanding itself: for itself. I looked into Hegel's writings on Descartes: so far this quote was helpful: "Descartes started by saying that thought must necessarily commence from itself; all the philosophy which came before this, and specially what proceeded from the authority of the Church, was for ever after set aside. But since here thought has properly speaking grasped itself as abstract understanding only, in relation to which the more concrete content still stands over on the other side, the determinate conceptions were not yet deduced from the understanding, but taken up only empirically. " https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/hegel/works/hp/hpdescar.htm

  • andru0358Tue Oct 24 2023 01:14:16 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    My understanding of Buddhist meditation is that it is a different type of self-consciousness. But idk how it is different besides seeming more "intuitive", which hegel seems to not like (still figuring out why).

  • andru0358Tue Oct 24 2023 01:14:47 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Another quote on Descartes I found super helpful, hope it doesn't bother people I am posting a lot: "The thinking subject as the simple immediacy of being-at-home-with-me is the very same thing as what is called Being; and it is quite easy to perceive this identity. As universal, thought is contained in all that is particular, and thus is pure relation to itself, pure oneness with itself. We must not make the mistake of representing Being to ourselves as a concrete content, and hence it is the same immediate identity which thought likewise is. Immediacy is, however, a one-sided determination; thought does not contain it alone, but also the determination to mediate itself with itself, and thereby ‚Äî by the mediation being at the same time the abrogation of the mediation ‚Äî it is immediacy. In thought we thus have Being; Being is, however, a poor determination, it is the abstraction from the concrete of thought. This identity of Being and Thought, which constitutes the most interesting idea of modern times, has not been further worked out by Descartes; he has relied on consciousness alone, and for the time being placed it in the forefront. For with Descartes the necessity to develop the differences from the ‚ÄòI think‚Äô is not yet present; Fichte first applied himself to the deduction of all determinations from this culminating point of absolute certainty."

  • dve.h_37844Tue Oct 24 2023 01:44:43 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @andru0358#0 Buddhist meditation is about recognizing when one is thinking, rather than thinking about thinking. The training is meant to help people stay in the moment, and ultimately be so comfortable in the moment that they can enjoy the boredom and stillness of the moment. It takes a few years to get good at it but it really does work.

  • dve.h_37844Tue Oct 24 2023 01:52:18 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    The philosophy of Buddhism is about kindness. Much like Marx, Buddha and his disciples made systems of kindness that involved various things like ‚Äúright action‚Äù ‚Äúright speech‚Äù and meditation, which I would call the material aspect of Buddhism or, practicing kindness. Transcendental meditation I have never done though. Buddha rejected this kind of meditation, as well as ascetic traditions and traditions of complete resignation and passivity. Buddhism is also known as the ‚Äúmiddle way‚Äù between these two traditions.

  • minimaltomThu Oct 26 2023 20:07:57 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    So subjectivity is objectivity but objectivity is also subjectivity. Does that mean that inanimate objects have subjectivity? Like they are living thinking things like us, kind of like Alan whats says that everything has conciousness even rocks and so on.

  • douglainThu Oct 26 2023 20:11:57 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 It means that the external world is a category of our perception. And that, when realize our subjectivity is the basis of the objective world we take up our subjectivity as objective and lose our freedom in the process. We become fixed, reified, and a product of caprice and causation. There is no material world but our consciousness is objective and fixed. We are not ghosts in a machine, there is no machine, but rather as ghosts we are as mechanical and machinelike as ever, even if we no longer have any foundation or access to truth or reality.

  • minimaltomThu Oct 26 2023 20:23:44 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @douglain#0 by category do you and Hegel mean a Kantian category?

  • minimaltomThu Oct 26 2023 20:26:57 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Hegel seems to accept Kants categorical description of perception right but he talks about it a lot more loosely, like he doesnt want to define what the categories are in such a rigid way as Kant who based them on the only 12 aristotelian categories of logic that comprised logic at the time

  • minimaltomThu Oct 26 2023 20:30:19 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    or is he using the word in a more general way do you think?

  • douglainThu Oct 26 2023 20:43:23 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yes. A Kantian category.

  • douglainThu Oct 26 2023 20:44:11 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I don't know if Hegel is using them in a more general way. And I don't recall if materiality is one of Kant's categories or not.

  • minimaltomThu Oct 26 2023 20:50:53 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @douglain#0 cool, would it come under substance? I've got a feeling Hegel is refering to Kants categories but I dont think he wants to limit them to only the 12 that Kant came up with because hes not happy with how kant prooved them in the trancendental deduction. I may be wrong, I think I heard it from a jumble of secondary material ive seen, maybe the Stephen Houlgate lectures.

  • minimaltomThu Oct 26 2023 20:55:28 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    The Categories, from my kant book ive got: Unity, Plurality, Totality Reality, Negation, Limitation Substance, Causality, Reciprocity Possibility, Existence, Necessity

  • dve.h_37844Sat Oct 28 2023 21:16:30 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I wanted to bring up this bit, but I kept thinking it would drag the conversation backwards a little bit. Nevertheless, here is what I think the essence, maybe, of the Science of Logic is all about. > ~54 > Anaxagoras is praised as the man who first declared that Nous, thought, is the principle of the world, that the essence of the world is to be defined as thought. In so doing he laid the foundation for an intellectual view of the universe, the pure form of which must be logic. > > What we are dealing with in logic is not a thinking about something which exists independently as a base for our thinking and apart from it, nor forms which are supposed to provide mere signs or distinguishing marks of truth; on the contrary, the necessary forms and self-determinations of thought are the content and the ultimate truth itself.

  • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:01:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 I'm still on my super slow read through the Greek classics from step one basically, but I have a mini comment re: Mac McManus and his views on Aristotle.   • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:02:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He seemed to be complaining about A. because seems to focus on elite glory or excellence, and he just kind of accepted this as divorced from the masses, but I'm not at all sure the Ancient Greeks at all would have thought like this.

  • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:03:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    They maybe would have viewed it, at least some of them, as the standard to which all could rise, or a very high percentage of people, rather than something that was just sort of exclusive, superior, and very rare like your more sort of Ubermenchy-type theories.

  • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:04:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    My evidence for this different view is basically Sparta, the concept of the Homoioi and their strange traning. Essentially they tried to make all of their citizens, this excellent kind of hero. Not that the heros were rare and you sought them out, but that with adequate training, pretty much everyone could get there.

  • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:04:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I just finished Xenophon's Anabasis so next comes le Republique

  • douglainSun Oct 29 2023 14:05:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @angelus888#0 I believe we should put aside moral judgments of Aristotle especially as we try to take up just what Hegel had in mind when he referred to "metaphysics" in the Prefaces and Introduction to the Science of Logic.

  • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:08:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    An insane part of my brain wants to write something about it, but Aristophane's *the Clouds* is the current landscape of media. In the Clouds, the main character, Strepsiades goes to a phrontestery or "thinkery" in order to learn from one of the many crazy schools of greek thought, all of which are insane, all of which are in contest with each other. In order to learn the argument of "wrong" which can win against "right."

  • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:08:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    To me, this is a pretty good mirror to the era of X / Twitter/ Youtube/ FB where there are myriad different "phrontesteries" or schools of thought that are just as crazy, or right, or wrong, as those in The Clouds.

  • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:09:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Ultimately this time of intellectual diversity parrodied by Aristophanes comes crashing down somewhat 20+ years later as Socrates goes on trial

  • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:09:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    In other words the Clouds is about all the talking heads in contention, sort of, which we have now.

  • angelus888Sun Oct 29 2023 14:16:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But when I was reading Aristophanes back in let's say 2009, I didn't get it. Now I do though, no matter what school you want, there is a school for it. Some right, some wrong, some in between. The Clouds is back üò∂‚Äçüå´Ô∏è ‚òÅÔ∏è üê¶

  • firedog235Tue Oct 31 2023 21:33:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Sorry I wasn't able to make it to the workshop on saturday, My sleep cycle get's flipped around occasionally and I would have been a zombie üò¶ (I was especially sad because I even read the introduction twice and took notes to prove i'd read it this time, lol). There were a few parts of the document I wished you guys had touched on --- the first bit is this: "Because the result, the negation, is a specific negation, it has content. It is a fresh Notion but higher and richer than its predecessor; for it is richer by the negation or opposite of the latter, therefore contains it, but also something more, and is the unity of itself and its opposite. " This, to me, means that the first important step in dialectics relies on realizing that while there is 'contradiction' as an abstract universal, there is also the need to treat every contradiction as its own contradiction. What is more, there is also a need to understand that new contradictions contrain or enclose previous contradictions. This is what I mean when I say something like 'capitalism *is* a feudalism' or 'communism *is* a capitalism' --- or even what I meant during a far previous interview when I said 'theory *is* violence': i.e. theory sublates violence, and must contain violence if it is to be a superior contradictory stance (superior Notion). Next, there is an appearance of petit objet a in the text when Hegel mentions that kant shows us: "objectivity of the illusion and the necessity of the contradiction" --- i.e. that kant shows us that illusion takes on a life of its own (is objective) and contradiction is necessary. This ties into a further statement that Hegel makes where he says:

  • firedog235Tue Oct 31 2023 21:33:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "The philosophising which is most widespread among us does not go beyond the Kantian results, that Reason cannot acquire knowledge of any true content or subject matter and in regard to absolute truth must be directed to faith. But what with Kant is a result, forms the immediate starting-point in this philosophising, so that the preceding exposition from which that result issued and which is a philosophical cognition, is cut away beforehand. " Here we should emphasize the *immediate starting point* of this *failure* --- that is what I mean when I say that being-in-itself is pure contingency. What Hegel is talking about here, I feel, is that there is a permanent irreducible non-relation between the thing-in-itself and our perception of it, a non-relation which enters into our perception because our perception is also a thing-in-itself. Thus towards the end we get to the bit that doug tried to touch on but which Alex seemed to reject? I would like to discuss that more because it seemed to me that Doug's reading was basically correct but maybe I don't understand Alex's objection completely.

I do admit tho I dont totally understand what Hegel is saying here yet.   • firedog235Thu Nov 02 2023 00:04:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 by contingent I mean something like arbitrary or random (contingent in the sense that the reason its happening is some stupid contingent reason you didn't think of that doesn't have any connection to a grand story or narrative). A better term might be non-relation or rather un-relation: i.e. a bunch of relation + some extra nonsense that can't be accounted for completely except to say that it is random or arbitrary in some sense (so even a constantly repeating pattern, like an oscillation, might be an unrelation compared to something more complicated that isn't an oscillation because the oscillation repeats constantly while the more complicated thing doesn't). Kant shows that we can't ever have access to the thing-in-itself (i.e. we can't be in direct relation to it, there is a non-relation) and Hegel says, 'ah, but that lack of relation is the relation' and that's what I mean by an 'un-relation': it returns back from non-relation like the undead return from the dead.

  • firedog235Thu Nov 02 2023 00:04:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    or how the unconscious returns from the conscious

  • minimaltomFri Nov 03 2023 13:02:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    it is necessary because our world wouldnt make sense without it?

    like causation is necessarily true because the world would be topsy turvy without it even tho we cant epistemically see or verify it

  • minimaltomFri Nov 03 2023 13:22:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    by illusion is he talking about the illusion of dialectic reason? From what I've read, before Kant, dialectic meant reasoning without a foundation, so it was baseless assumptions that were argued for purely rhetorical reasons, but Kant I think elevated dialectical reasoning to having a 'semblance of truth'. this is from the entry on dialectic in 'A Kant Dictionary' by Howard Caygill: "His dialectic no longer offers rules for executing convincing judgements, but teaches how to detect and uncover judgements that bear a semblance of truth but are infact illusionary. It is a 'critique of dialectical illusion' and not (as previously) 'an art of producing such illusion dogmatically (an art unfortunately very commonly practiced by metaphysical jugglers)'" and "The illusions which Kant will criticize are not simply sophisms born of the desire to convince, but follow from the 'natural and inevitable illusion' of human reason." Im thinking Hegel might be talking about this when he mentions illusion? And the objectivity of illusion, I'm not quite sure what he means by objective, that its not just subjective illusion but objectively true?

  • joser__bFri Nov 03 2023 18:31:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 This is outside of what we‚Äôve read and what we plan to read for the workshop, but you might want to have a look at ¬ß91ff of the Encyclopedia Logic (which corresponds to section 1, chapter 2.A.bff of the SoL). There, Hegel elaborates his definition of being-in-itself as the ‚Äúbeing of quality‚Äù vis-a-vis quality as the relation of otherness that determines being-there (Dasein, existence) (¬ß91). At this point in the development of the immanent unfolding of thought that is Hegel‚Äôs logic, he seems to be elaborating thought‚Äôs apprehension of that which renders something to be-there (Dasein) as distinct from another, with the being-in-itself of the former its thisness as immediate determinateness, as becoming that has internalized negation as its qualifying limit.

  • joser__bFri Nov 03 2023 18:31:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think I follow what you mean by being-in-itself as contingency (is the following an accurate paraphrase: that it is random, or unknowable ahead of the determination, what constitutes the otherness that relates to and determines the quality of being-there?), but I am unsure whether this illuminates Hegel‚Äôs concept. On the one hand, Hegel seems to stress necessity as guiding these movements. In other words, determinateness doesn‚Äôt enter into becoming and sublate it into Dasein from just anywhere but necessarily originates from within becoming itself: ‚Äúself-alteration is involved in the concept of being-there [Dasein], and is only the manifestation of what being-there is in-itself‚Äù (EL ¬ß92 149). On the other, his elaboration of being-in-itself (as the being of quality) serves to demonstrate simply a structure of thought that allows us to conceive, as he describes in the opening sentence of EL ¬ß91, the reality of being-there. To put it (perhaps too) simply, Hegel‚Äôs being-in-itself seems to refer to the moment in thought when we conceive of an object as distinct from that which it is not: the object‚Äôs being as this, distinct from another.

  • joser__bFri Nov 03 2023 18:31:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The real payoff of this claim seems to arrive when Hegel later defines being-for-itself as the sublation of quality, being-for-itself as the ideality of Dasein: ‚Äúthe truth of the finite‚Äù (EL ¬ß95, page 152) that determines becoming as existence, being-in-itself. Because we can reason the in-itself of Dasein, its reality as a distinct quality, we can in thought arrive at its truth, the for-itself: ‚Äúbeing-for-itself has to be interpreted generally as ideality. . . . the concept of ideality expressly consists in its being the truth of reality, or in other words, reality posited as what it is in-itself proves itself to be ideality‚Äù (EL ¬ß96, page 153). I offer these thoughts with the reservation that I may have just entirely missed the larger point you‚Äôre making.

  • firedog235Sat Nov 04 2023 02:34:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @joser__b#0 So paraphrase is basically accurate. However, I'm not a Heidigarrian so I don't have as strong an understanding of Dasein as some others might. I think the important thing not to stumble over is that, at least in my understanding, what is going is *the necessity of a unnecessity* --- or the necessity of contradiction. So to say 'ah but Hegel emphasizes necessity' misses the point: the necessity that Hegel is emphasizing is contradiction which both/and and thus radically open/free. To me the sublation in Hegel is this moment where we realize that it was always-already the case that this freedom was necesary from the beginning of a process, persisted through the process as free, and remains as a point of freedom even after its eventual demise/failure and then undead repitition. So tldr; the reason I emphasize the contingency as illuminating is precisely because the *liberal* and *right* reading of Hegel, it seems to me, wants to read Hegel as 'well he's talking about logic and determinations and necessity so that means what he's talking about is *determinism*' and that just isn't it. He's talking about the necessity of a lack of necessity and the necessary consequences of that: so a kind of determinism, but a strange one, a speculative and constantly self failing necessity.

  • andru0358Sat Nov 04 2023 14:41:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 When Hegel uses 'objective' versus subjective, it is not an epistemology sense. Objective does not mean "objectively true" but rather ontologically objective. It exists outside of our agency. He frequently refers to objective logic, meaning the immanent laws of thought independent of the thinker/subject. I think in that passage on illusion he contrasts it to subject illusions, which he speaks of in the way he elsewhere talks about sophistry: the problem is not an honest mistake or a moment of thought necessarily incomplete and under illusion. Subjective illusion is based in desires other than to know the truth, and subordinating knowledge so as to create illusions. Objective illusion is a necessary moment; it's problem is that it is not yet recognized as illusory in Kant. In my translation, they actually use the term "reflective shine' instead of illusion. Reflective shine is developed in chapter 2 or 3 I think

  • andru0358Sat Nov 04 2023 14:56:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Dasein here is not Heidegger's existentialism. Existence is the topic of chapter two, determinate being. I still think what you are getting at with the word contingent should be indeterminate. Determinations for Hegel are not the same as determinism of mechanical physics. Contingency as randomness or arbitrariness feels incorrect because it seems to point to causality in time and space, or a-causality, unnecessity. Indeterminacy is a much broader concept in the realm of ontology, even prior to physical world. Hegel develops from being to existence to .... A bunch of steps.. to develop concepts of space and time from scratch within thought. When he talks about the indeterminacy of being, he doesn't mean that being necessarily is undetermined. He means that we have a complete abstraction, with no content of thought. We have not specified any 'thing' but the mere possibility of thing-ness. Not even existence (determinate being), but pure being. It really feels like you're wanting to skip ahead to Hegel's conclusions when we have not even gotten to his starting place. I will agree with you and I think it's super important and insightful and I thank you. Kant's empty concept of "thing-in-itself" is indeterminate and the radical indeterminacy which I believe helps understand why Hegel starts with being - pure, indeterminate being. This takes the emptiness of thing-in-itself and goes further, to fully empty out the thought (not even concept, he says). We can't yet speak of the world as it is; we are analyzing the simplest thoughts possible to develop them immanently to a system of thought capable of grounding perception and understanding of the world of our senses.

  • andru0358Sat Nov 04 2023 15:02:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think what Joseph says about the determinate movement of thought, is very important. In a sense, the necessity in unnecessity is inverted. We see the necessity out of unnecessity. Being is immediately indeterminate, but thereby determines nothing. Nothing is immediately indeterminate, but thereby determines being. These are the fundamental determinations of everything else. Ie, everything is, at bottom in some sense, has it's determination in the pure indeterminate

  • minimaltomSat Nov 04 2023 15:11:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Can you explain your understanding of the word necessity a bit please? I found this bit very informative ‚ÄúBeing is immediately indeterminate, but thereby determines nothing. Nothing is immediately indeterminate, but thereby determines being.‚Äùüëç

  • minimaltomSat Nov 04 2023 15:13:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Also what is the opposite of necessity? That might be helpful

  • andru0358Sat Nov 04 2023 15:27:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think we agree about illusion. I just wanted to clarify the term objective in relation to it. That subjective illusion is sophistry as opposed to illusion as a stage of reflection - which I do not yet understand (it's section 2, not chapter 2, much further along). My attempt: Necessity - could not be otherwise. Following laws or causal patterns. In philosophy of history at least, necessity is opposed to accident; Hegel and plekhanov write about the dialectical unity of historical necessity and accident, ie WW1 triggered by accident but as a symptom of larger historical forces/laws. Necessity in the (natural and historical) world is used by hegel/Marxists to mean by the laws of nature or history. So in the logic, necessity is following the laws of thought. In internal, inherent patterns of movement. Does that help?

  • andru0358Sat Nov 04 2023 15:27:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Obv I could be wrong too

  • minimaltomSat Nov 04 2023 15:46:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yes that does help, I guess you could say the opposite of necessity is contingency also? right, I think Hegel also links subjective to understanding and objective to reason although I dont quite grasp it atm and subjective is related to everyday abstract logic wheras objective is to specualtive logic.

  • minimaltomSat Nov 04 2023 15:55:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    by the way, I got this last bit from random googling üòÑ

  • andru0358Sat Nov 04 2023 16:01:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Understanding is the way thought comprehends something. It is static; and it's development, is critique or sublation, the movement is reason. They're both moments of thought. I don't think subjective has the negative connotation of everyday usage. I might have misrepresented it before. He doesn't mean that subjectivity is contingent or Caprice. At the end of the introduction he refers to "misconception" of subjective as "accident" and "arbitrary". Subjective just means it's depends on the subject or thinker. The last third of the book is Subjective Logic. Which is when he develops the concept of concept/notion. Last reading group I got the idea of notion all wrong; it's just an alternative translation to concept. Concept for hegel is explicit, determinate thought. Thought which is clear to itself. That's what makes it subjective logic. It's an achievement of 560 pages of developing thought. I mean - I think he also uses subjective for things like intentionality. And sophistry is determined by intentionality or desire to convince, rather than thought itself or the desire for truth of thought. So subjective can refer to determinations from without which interfere with the immanent development of thought; but subjectivity also develops from this development. Just to say subjective is understood independent of this idea of it being problematic. It's problematic when it's premature or out of place in logic

  • minimaltomSat Nov 04 2023 16:12:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ok, I think I need to read the last bit of the intro properly anyway, I haven't really read the general division of logic which i think talks about subject/object

  • minimaltomSat Nov 04 2023 16:25:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 yes I also found out the meaning of notion recently, it is a misleading translation of begriff also translated as concept which is probably a more familiar and useful term for us

  • minimaltomSat Nov 04 2023 16:26:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    and it seems to refer to the concepts such as Being, Nothing, Becoming, and so on right?

  • firedog235Sun Nov 05 2023 18:49:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I'm not certain that notion just means concept --- I think that indeterminate (without difference) is an okay step in terms of what I mean when I say contingency but if it is its because I want to emphasize the underlying point which is contradiction. Contradiction is the object of pure indeterminiteness (literally, it is both a and not a, as in you can't separate out or determine the difference between oppositions). This is why I don't think 'concept' is a sufficient notion for 'notion'. My understanding is that notion is what happens when concept moves all the way to the point of understanding the necessity of a contradiction in the operation of the object under consideration with 'Notion' (capital 'N', the Notion) being the historical and transcendental movement of contradiction itself. (also, the reason I focus on randomness and contingency is because both are important forms of contradiction which I think are ignored by a lot of theorists, not the best theorists, but a lot of simpler readings, and I'm a scientist so its especially important for my work). I also thinking its fun, with that sentence 'being is indeterminate and therefore determines nothing, nothing is indeterminate and therefore determines being' to read it this way: 'being is indeterminate and therefore determines contradiction, contradiction is indeterminate and therefore determines being' --- and also to swap out contingency sometimes for this nothing-contradiction. The reason being that it gets to the deeper point, I feel, which is that, in a dialectical system, what is truly 'stripped out' of reality is only contradiction itself and what separates out a metaphysics from a dialectics is the demand that we strip something more than contradiction out of reality.

  • minimaltomMon Nov 06 2023 16:20:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Is contingency a form of contradiction tho? From what ive found contingency contradiction and tautology are 3 different things?

  • minimaltomMon Nov 06 2023 16:23:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And contingency is when something is neither a tautology or a contradiction, sometimes it one or the other

    I‚Äôm that case indeterminate seems to make more sense, the other 2 tautology or contradiction are necessarily so, contingent is un-necessity

  • andru0358Tue Nov 07 2023 18:58:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 Last night I was reading the Encyclopedia Logic which seems to have a much more explanation building up to the starting point, and he discussed what he means by metaphysics. A lot things which were previously unclear to me became clear. By metaphysics, he means getting the truth/essence/self of things; what Kant cut off by calling it "unknowable thing-in-itself", right. Previously, "The Metaphysic of the past assumed, as unsophisticated belief always does, that thought apprehends the very self of things, and that things, to become what they truly are, require to be thought." As I write this, it seems almost banal. But what felt clear is the sense of an "essence", the core aspect of a thing. I think this is a difficult concept only because modern thought has abandoned it or at least has deep skepticism about the possibility of ever knowing it (Kantian). I think this it the link - also going back to last discussion - between is and ought - both within the logic (how it moves) and how it applies to political problems. Personally, this has reenergized my desire to understand all this. The Kantian conclusion - and overall modernist assumption - that we cannot know essences because of the mediation of appearance, is falsified in thought. If we can understand the essence of thought itself, we know correct from incorrect thought, we can know truth of thought. "The forms of thought must be studied in their essential nature and complete development: they are at once the object of research and the action of that object. Hence they examine themselves: in their own action they must determine their limits, and point out their defects. This is that action of thought, which will hereafter be specially considered under the name of Dialectic, and regarding which we need only at the outset observe that, instead of being brought to bear upon the categories from without, it is Immanent in their own action." https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/hegel/works/sl/sl_iv.htm

  • andru0358Tue Nov 07 2023 18:59:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 this chapter also explains a lot in terms of Subjective/Objective since it was a key demarcation for Kanst (according to Hegel)

  • andru0358Tue Nov 07 2023 20:02:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I'm curious why you consider it "deeper" to change out 'contradiction' with 'nothing'? Similarly, you say "underlying point", as though its more fundamental. In what sense is it? I don't follow what you're saying by "Contradiction is the object of pure indeterminateness". I don't think this is the same as what Hegel means by "indeterminateness"; contradictions are determined in the two sides, the two objects or aspects in the contradiction. Contradiction is necessarily determinate, it cannot stand on its own, it is contradiction of/in something. I also do not see how randomness nor contingency are forms of contradiction.

  • minimaltomTue Nov 07 2023 21:27:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 thanks andrew ill give it a look üëç

  • firedog235Wed Nov 08 2023 01:49:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 So the 'deeper' point here, and I may be being a Zizekian in this interpretation, is that contradiction is the *only* thing which it is to be nothing, every other determinate thing or description of nothing beyond contradiction is immediately something, and the problem with what Marxists call metaphysics (which is based in Hegelian philosophy, but which is both more developed and misdeveloped in Marxism) is the tendency to want to add foreclosures to contradiction --- i.e. strip out non-contradictions from reality, i.e. engage in 'realism'. That's the 'deeper' point. What's more, it is a 'necessary illusion' to say that a contradiction is determined in its two sides (object and anti-thesis) --- That's what a contradiction appears as from the perspective of reality: as the 'collision' or 'oscillation about', or 'dynamical tension' or 'random noise out of' a particular concrete object in 'reality' as the object attempts to be both 'a' and 'not a' in some way. In that sense, once a particular contradiction is embodied in reality then it takes on this distinct form... but 'The Contradiction' (capital 'T' capital 'C') is not so differentiated, the thing behind the things, is an indeterminate no-thing and this is how I read that nothing, i.e. no-thing, i.e. contradiction determines being (i.e. reality). Random noise is an instance of the the contradiction of contradiction, its the first moment of an object which is both a contradiction (moves between various opposing points, now the value is 10.21, now its 7.39, not its 15.392, etc.) and not a contradiction (i.e. there is no smoth gaurunteed oscillation between any number of particular points, in fact it could just randomly repeat 10.21 over and over forever and still be generated by a random process that just happened to come up all 10.21).

  • firedog235Wed Nov 08 2023 01:49:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0@minimaltom#0 <@589918821729566721> <@476561351167311872> ^

  • minimaltomWed Nov 08 2023 15:37:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Ok this seems to be an eccentric take on things, it seems to me you might be conflating terms from different fields that might not be equivalent actually. So theres a Contradiction big C? 2 types of contradiction? hmm. Does Hegel think there are 2 meanings of contradiction in this text? You may be on to something, maybe not I dont know and I do want to understand Zizek etc but I think its a distraction from what were trying to achieve in this reading ATM and doesnt contribute anything useful at this time. Im kind of doing 2 things at once, trying to read Zizek to understand you and trying to go back to ancient and pre-Hegelian philosophy to understand Hegel and I think the later is the most pressing for this group. TBH Ill probably keep reading the Zizek stuff too tho just cos I want to see whether theres something to what youre saying but I kind of wish youd park your contingency/contradiction-is-nothing stuff for a bit and get involved in the group, or if you really think it is directly applicable to what were doing then clarify it for us and where in the text this is. Like for example you talk about the 'necessary illusion' that Hegel mentions. What is your understanding of what that means? This is something Hegel has taken from Kant right? What does this mean in Kantian terms? Do you know?

    If anyone needs a break from speculative thought for a laugh: https://www.reddit.com/r/badphilosophy/comments/d87iot/my_33f_husbands_35m_career_in_academic_philosophy/

  • firedog235Thu Nov 09 2023 00:42:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Sorry the phrase is 'objectivity of the illusion and the necessity of the contradiction' (I messed that up) So yeah that's something Hegel says about Kant. For me the necessity of contradiction is the necessity of contradiction as an explanation for why there are things at all (i.e. the exclusion of contradiction means the exclusion of nothing from reality --- that's the necessity here: nothing-contradiction is excluded from reality and therefore there are things). Kant showed that we always stumble back into this contradiction/nothing and thus that it is necessary: Hegel is going to apply the contradiction to itself and show that it is also the case that there are contradictions of contradiction that necessarily produce objects. For me this is the 'let there be light' moment contained in the first chapter. The objectivity of illusion: here I take this to mean that while there is solipsism, the very fact that there is solipsism means that there is a necessessity to illusion: that objects themselves don't quite know what they're doing. There are many possible interpretations of this but basically if your physicist minded it would mean that an atom doesn't know its own future as much as the person looking at the atom doesn't know the future (that is, the misapprehension of reality extends into reality itself, is not merely a subjective phenomenon).

  • minimaltomThu Nov 09 2023 14:02:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 From what I see what Hegel means by the 'objectivity of the illusion' is that the so called illusion isnt only in reason as Kant thought but, as his own philosophy actually vindicated (unbeknownst to himself according to Hegel), the contradiction is actually in the object itself as well and therefore isnt an illusion either. I think the way Hegel is using the word illusion might be misleading because he doesnt actually think its an illusion, only Kant did.

  • minimaltomThu Nov 09 2023 14:09:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    'necessity of contradiction' is more difficult for me but the word necessity for Kant and Hegel has a definate meaning and isnt just used vaguely to mean 'is necessay for this or that'. It means its necessary for our common sense understanding of the world to be true and therefore must be known a priori. I think he means that contradiction is necessary and therefore known a priori, as or part of a category of the understanding.

  • minimaltomThu Nov 09 2023 14:15:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    from here https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/hegel-dialectics/ > Hegel adopts Kant‚Äôs dialectical conception of reason, but he liberates reason for knowledge from the tyranny of the understanding. Kant was right that reason speculatively generates concepts on its own, and that this speculative process is driven by necessity and leads to concepts of increasing universality or comprehensiveness. Kant was even right to suggest‚Äîas he had shown in the discussion of the antinomies‚Äîthat reason is dialectical, or necessarily produces contradictions on its own. Again, Kant‚Äôs mistake was that he fell short of saying that these contradictions are in the world itself. He failed to apply the insights of his discussion of the antinomies to ‚Äúthings in themselves‚Äù (SL-M 56; SL-dG 35; see also section 4). Indeed, Kant‚Äôs own argument proves that the dialectical nature of reason can be applied to things themselves. The fact that reason develops those contradictions on its own, without our heads to help it, shows that those contradictions are not just in our heads, but are objective, or in the world itself. Kant, however, failed to draw this conclusion, and continued to regard reason‚Äôs conclusions as illusions. Still, Kant‚Äôs philosophy vindicated the general idea that the contradictions he took to be illusions are both objective‚Äîor out there in the world‚Äîand necessary. As Hegel puts it, Kant vindicates the general idea of ‚Äú**the objectivity of the illusion and the necessity of the contradiction which belongs to the nature of thought determinations‚Äù** (SL-M 56; cf. SL-dG 35), or to the nature of concepts themselves.

  • firedog235Fri Nov 10 2023 00:18:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yes, I agree with that witht he proviso that we have to remember that this negation includes the thesis: what we call illusion or subjective illusion is an instance of the contradiction appearing in the object itself (i.e. in the subject) and then hegel says 'ah but that also applies to objects as well as subjects'.

  • firedog235Fri Nov 10 2023 00:22:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I don't think that takes it far enough, that it leaves it in the realm of epistimology: or at least one could read what you're saying that way... I read it as saying that ontologically the conradiction must ex-sist (exist... but not in reality, as the gap within reality) in order for reason to function as it does.

  • minimaltomFri Nov 10 2023 05:47:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 How do you mean it leaves it in the realm of epistemology?

  • firedog235Fri Nov 10 2023 09:54:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I fear that saying that its part of the category of understanding leaves in epistemology, its more fundamental than understanding.

  • minimaltomFri Nov 10 2023 09:57:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 not 'the' category of the understanding but 'a' category as in there are numerous categories of the understanding, which is how Kant thinks we know things a priori. I think Hegel thinks there are more than Kant does tho.

  • minimaltomFri Nov 10 2023 09:57:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think the understanding is supposed to be involved in every thought determination we have

  • minimaltomFri Nov 10 2023 09:59:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    the understanding takes things appart and reason universalizes and put things together I think

  • minimaltomFri Nov 10 2023 10:00:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    thats the initial thing anyway I think its more complex than that tho

  • douglainFri Nov 17 2023 16:40:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I had thought it would be more theory heavy but while writing I decided to just clarify one key concept about the reality of thought. Science should begin with the reality of logic I think. And at the end of the first introduction he explains that at the beginning of study the system of logic must be studied as an abstract while accepting that it will feel as though what one learns has no significance. Like learning grammar, learning logic will seem arbitrary and a matter of mere memorization, until one has the "experience of a lifetime" behind you will you see that logic is connected to living reality just as grammar is an product of a living linguistic culture.

  • douglainFri Nov 17 2023 16:43:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel points out that one of the categories of understanding is existence or being itself, and that we are in a peculiar position of knowing that our thoughts exist are in this sense true even as we also know that they are also at the same time necessarily unreal and without existence. Our thoughts exist as true things because being is a category of our understanding, but they are also necessarily unreal due to the same category of our understanding called being.

  • minimaltomFri Nov 17 2023 17:05:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 I‚Äôll just add a passing comment that our thoughts are no more or less unreal than anything else we perceive because they are all under the category of existence, so to say we are just a ghost in a machine privileges the machine as being more real than our subjectivity. I think this really challenges the idea of nihilism. Products of the mind are no less real than so called material objects. Would you agree with that?

  • minimaltomFri Nov 17 2023 17:07:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Saying there is a noumenal realm of objects is no less speculative than saying there is a soul

  • minimaltomFri Nov 17 2023 17:12:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I feel like the problem of the beggining of the science tho is that the beggining is actually the end product of the logic so to know where to begin is to have already completed the logic in a way. Hegel says the beggining and the principle of philosophy are, or should be, the same but finding the principle is exactly the end goal of the project itself.

  • minimaltomFri Nov 17 2023 17:14:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Then he goes on to talk about the circular nature of the process, the end result is also the beggining

  • minimaltomFri Nov 17 2023 17:15:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Again I‚Äôm only in the first half of the reading so there‚Äôs more to this

  • douglainFri Nov 17 2023 17:16:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • dve.h_37844Wed Nov 22 2023 17:10:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I kind of feel like we're treating Hegel like Aristotle or some ancient Greek mystic. I'm not sure Hegel is really concerned about the nature or phenomenon of thought, but rather how the "new" revolutionary subject ought to think about themselves and how they should begin thinking about their actions. This seems to be what Cutrone keeps repeating in all of his podcast appearances. I think if you're interested in what thought "is" or where it comes from, you should just take up Buddhism or mindfullness, because you would need a keen sense of awareness to really observe yourself.

  • douglainWed Nov 22 2023 17:24:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Ancient metaphysics had in this respect a higher conception of thinking than is current today. For it based itself on the fact that the knowledge of things obtained through thinking is alone what is really true in them, that is, things not in their immediacy but as first raised into the form of thought, as things thought. Thus this metaphysics believed that thinking (and its determinations) is not anything alien to the object, but rather is its essential nature, or that things and the thinking of them ‚Äî our language too expresses their kinship ‚Äî are explicitly in full agreement, thinking in its immanent determinations and the true nature of things forming one and the same content.

  • douglainWed Nov 22 2023 17:28:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • douglainWed Nov 22 2023 17:44:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Maybe try quoting the text

  • dve.h_37844Wed Nov 22 2023 17:44:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Now whatever may have been accomplished for the form and content of philosophy in other directions, the science of logic which constitutes metaphysics proper or purely speculative philosophy, has hitherto still been much neglected. What it is exactly that I understand by this science and its standpoint, I have stated provisionally in the Introduction. The fact that it has been necessary to make a completely fresh start with this science, the very nature of the subject matter and the absence of any previous works which might have been utilised for the projected reconstruction of logic, may be taken into account by fair-minded critics, even though a labour covering many years has been unable to give this effort a greater perfection. The essential point of view is that what is involved is an altogether new concept of scientific procedure. Philosophy, if it would be a science, cannot, as I have remarked elsewhere, borrow its method from a subordinate science like mathematics, any more than it can remain satisfied with categorical assurances of inner intuition, or employ arguments based on grounds adduced by external reflection. On the contrary, it can be only the nature of the content itself which spontaneously develops itself in a scientific method of knowing, since it is at the same time the reflection of the content itself which first posits and generates its determinate character. ¬Æ

  • dve.h_37844Wed Nov 22 2023 17:44:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    preface, section 8

  • douglainWed Nov 22 2023 17:46:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • dve.h_37844Wed Nov 22 2023 18:12:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

Yes, but where we end up may not be the utopia of our dreams, but rather the next contradiction. Which is fine. If Buddhism teaches anything it's that the deeper you go, the more you get out of it. The utility of Hegel is in why he thinks we ought to re-examine the science of logic as we are, not as detached beings from the world, am i right?

  • dve.h_37844Wed Nov 22 2023 18:30:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    On the one hand, I kind of feel like as someone who has already put a lot of effort into understanding the nature and phenomenon of thought that I can. I don't find if very difficult to comprehend what he means by the dialectic because others defined it without really realizing it 2000 years earlier.     necessarily

  • dve.h_37844Wed Nov 22 2023 21:18:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 So what do you make of section 19 in the second preface <@386755556817240065> ? > 'In so many respects', says Aristotle in the same context, 'the nature of man is in bondage; but this science, which is not studied for its utility, is the only absolutely free science and seems therefore to be a more than human possession.' Philosophical thinking in general is still concerned with concrete objects ‚Äî God, nature, spirit; but logic is concerned only and solely with these thoughts as thoughts, in their complete abstraction. For this reason it is customary, to include logic in the curriculum of youth, for youth is not yet involved in the practical affairs of life, living at leisure so far as they are concerned; and it is only for its own subjective ends that it has to busy itself with acquiring the means to enable it to become actively engaged with the objects of those practical interests ‚Äî and still theoretically even with these. Contrary to Aristotle's view just mentioned, the science of logic is included in these means; the study of logic is a preliminary labour to be carried out in school and it is not until later that the serious business of life and the pursuit of substantial ends begins. > I would say he's not interested in where a thought comes from, but rather how to interrogate the thinking behind the thought. Although it would seem he wrote another book that might care about how thoughts arise. Maybe he does care about the mist, or the bubbles that flow upwards from the river of consciousness?

  • minimaltomThu Nov 23 2023 11:28:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 in some ways isn't the understanding itself actually 'not' about thinking? isn't it more about immediate intuition? The categories allow us to intuit things immediately like this rose is red, there doesn't seem to be any thinking involved there. I think reason is more on the side of thinking as it mediates the understanding.

    where does Hegel make the distinction between Logic and thinking? I think there is a difference between everyday thinking and logical thinking, both are thinking though.

    @minimaltom#0 It‚Äôs in the last sentence.

  • angelus888Thu Nov 23 2023 16:13:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 > Like learning grammar, learning logic will seem arbitrary and a matter of mere memorization, until one has the "experience of a lifetime" behind you will you see that logic is connected to living reality just as grammar is an product of a living linguistic culture. The "Living Linguistic Culture" stuff becomes so insane at times as to forget what language is and does. It's a communication vehicle for thoughts, the language itself is constructed out of sounds, represented in images, that at first describe very ordinary physical realities that are shared referents between interlocutors. Later, these become somewhat, but not entirely, abstracted. The more they become abstracted the more difficult communication becomes, because the signal you are sending, whether written or oral, may become unreadable by the recipient. So there is a material basis to language.

  • johnmcguire13Sun Nov 26 2023 05:13:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Looking forward to watching the workshop when it gets posted. I finally just watched the Henson video and as a matter of sheer coincidence had immediately before that been watching Eisenstein‚Äôs ‚ÄúStrike‚Äù. Maybe it has something to do with the logical structure of The Absolute? üôÉ I will have to read his essay on the dialectical nature of film sometime. The section of Doug‚Äôs video covering his ideas on the subject helped illuminate something about Hegel that I‚Äôd been having a hard time articulating, basically that just like a film is not a series of unrelated images one after another but a sequence of images ‚Äúon top of one another‚Äù or in each others afterimage bringing a sense of coherence behind the images that need not necessarily actually be there so too our perceptions of the world are not disjointed and unrelated but seem to have a coherence the more we try to understand them even thought that coherence maybe only be a function of our perception rather than an aspect of reality in itself. And it seems to me the overall point is that to ask about reality in itself is to miss the point, the fact that our thought requires some sort of coherent structure from the outset is the point we need to grasp. If they makes sense üòÖ. Anyway looking forward to watching the workshop!

  • nameiwillforgetSun Nov 26 2023 15:21:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I also had a lot of fun, but there are some things I forgot to bring up that I really should have in my discussion with Thomas: About paraconsistent logic I think it's really important to note that linear logic is paraconsistent: https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/paraconsistent+logic#linear_logic "Thus, both ways to deduce ex contradictione quodlibet founder precisely on the finer analysis of connectives provided by linearity. From a linear point of view, one could say that ex contradictione quodlibet arises from a failure to appreciate that ‚äï is different from ‚Öã, and that 0 is different from ‚ä•." Why is that important? Well, it really looks like linear logic is the enigmatic "quantum logic" that people sought after: https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/quantum+logic#LinearLogicAndDependentLinearTypeTheory Urs Schreiber even uses this for a description of quantum computing dependent on classical interactions: https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02382 So my defense of paraconsistent logics was actually way weaker than it should have been, because it really seems paraconsistent logic is at the heart of quantum theory. The other thing is about the nature of the empty set and the one-element set/category/type, which we both identify with pure nothing and being respectively: for one, even in normal set theory one couldn't just remain with the one-element set, as in particular the operation of forming power sets, which I'd say is the most essential operation in set theory, immediately generates the empty set as an element of the power set of the one-element set. So no, even in normal set theory you can't remain with the one-element set. Within category theory/homotopy type theory though, it becomes even more obvious that the one-object type is more essential, as, even if we just start with the empty type, the equality of that type to itself is a structure, namely the one-object type. In more prosaic terms‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetSun Nov 26 2023 15:22:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Even if we assume that nothing exists, nothing is equal to itself, and that equality is something, so something has to exist.

  • firedog235Mon Nov 27 2023 23:34:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 So I think I'll work backwards --- the first problem I have is with the appeal to the power set, this is an assumptive foundational move of set theory? But then you have to assume you can make power sets to escape, there is nothing in a set of one object, sans access to the powerset, that gives you another object. I think that linear logic is really nice. If given access to infinite duplications we collapse back into classical logic (i.e. if we decide that we can, in fact, clone things, we have classical logic back and contradiction becomes one thing) --- however as long as we maintain that we aren't going to duplicate things infinitely we are left with a logic where contradiction is both ground *and* limited in its ability to produce outcomes along a particular computational path (but if we are dealing with infinite resources we get the explosion back). This paraconsistent logic is nice because it limits things in a way that doesn't limit them (i.e. we can have classical logic and eat it too, as it were).

  • firedog235Mon Nov 27 2023 23:35:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (And having contradiction as ground is important because it allows you to pull any particular path out of the contradiction that you might want).

  • firedog235Mon Nov 27 2023 23:35:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (i.e. it allows for speculative logic).

  • nameiwillforgetTue Nov 28 2023 01:39:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "the first problem I have is with the appeal to the power set, this is an assumptive foundational move of set theory?" Yes, having the ability to form power sets/objects is what distinguishes set-like from other objects: one can form products, coproducts and any other limits and colimits of abelian groups, for instance, as well as even function spaces between them. What makes sets so powerful is that one can classify their subsets by propositions that are true on them. This classification of subsets through truth of propositions is equivalent to the existence of power sets.
