But even without that one can generate all sets by forming arbitrary coproducts, meaning disjoint sums in set-theoretic jargon, from the one-element set. This is somewhat tautological as forming those arbitrary coproducts requires index sets over which they can be formed, but using just generation by binary coproducts gives you all finite sets except the empty set. In category-theoretic terms binary coproducts are a categorification of simple sums a + b, and indeed the natural numbers with addition are a decategorification of the category of finite sets with binary coproducts, corresponding to the simple intuition that forming a coproduct of two sets conists of adding the elements of those sets into another one. Note that the empty set is not generating anything under coproducts, nor under products (which correspond to multiplication], rather it acts like the categorification of zero that it is: it is the neutral element of the coproduct and it trivializes every object to itself through the cartesian product.

  • nameiwillforgetTue Nov 28 2023 01:40:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "I think that linear logic is really nice‚Ä¶" Linear logic is not just no-cloning, but you're ignoring th bigger point: linear logic is quantum logic.

  • nameiwillforgetTue Nov 28 2023 01:41:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "limited in its ability to produce outcomes along a particular computational path" That's because it is the syntax of quantum computers

  • nameiwillforgetTue Nov 28 2023 01:53:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Also note that the way you get other sets from ‚àÖ in the usual set-theoretic framework is by forming the set {‚àÖ}, which is the set containing all subsets of ‚àÖ aka its power set. In fact, that's the only way to get other sets from ‚àÖ. Who would have thought nothing would be so hard to make things out of?

  • firedog235Tue Nov 28 2023 21:21:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think that my point would be that ‚àÖ is inherently a contradiction.

  • nameiwillforgetTue Nov 28 2023 21:50:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 What does this mean though, precisely?

  • firedog235Wed Nov 29 2023 06:04:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 It is a contradiction in that it is a less than nothing --- i.e. both a contradiction and not. As a mere gap it is not a contradiction, but as a pointer towards all other possible sets it is contradictory (i.e. it is nothing and it is the material that all somethings are built out of).

  • nameiwillforgetThu Nov 30 2023 13:25:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 That only holds in ZFC though. Use ETCS (https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/ETCS) and the generating element is the point. Use homotopy type theory and it is the point as well. In naive set theory you just assume every set exists. You can really disentangle the question from set theory completely and just look at the natural numbers: it is true that you obtain all natural numbers by applying the successor operation to 0, but the successor operation is just taking out the thing that comes after the previous thing. There is no reason to assume such a thing exists. Basically, ZFC is built on the postulate that it does. Meanwhile, if you take 1 you can obtain all other positive natural numbers through adding it to itself. Why should the sum of 1's exist? Well, it's kind of what distinguishes 1 from 0 that one is a the first non-neutral element under addition, so it is somewhat intrinsic to the nature of 1 itself. The existence of 1 also insures that the successor operation exists, since then it is given by +1. So at best it is a wash between addition and the successor operation. But while the metaphysics of addition are completely clear (take pure being and add several instances of it), those of "the successor of nothing/next to nothing" are not clear at all. Why would it exist?

  • nameiwillforgetThu Nov 30 2023 13:34:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It is also not clear at all how ZFC should relate to the physical universe. It is clear for naive set theory (every collection of objects in the universe is a set) and it is clear to me for homotopy type theory (the physical universe is an object in something like an (‚àû, 1)-topos), but for ZFC there is no reason to assume a connection at all. Note that no collection of objects in the physical universe is a set in ZFC! It is a purely mathematical structure.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 02 2023 00:28:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 It should exist because it ex-sists, because its a wrapper over contradiction (which is the case for all these values that are isomorphic to zero like point, empty set, null, etc.) These are all the ground that forms the basis of 'possibility' in the respective systems as an opposition to impossibility. (i.e. ultimately because nothing is only ever exactly equal to a contradiction/a contradiction equals nothing, thus nothing is impossible/can't ever actuall exist but must ex-sist as an excluded object). Though, I realized after we spoke that in a lot of these systems the real point is that the system itself is the ultimate grounding object and the zero isomorphism is implied by the system for it to make any sense as a system (or else the system becomes incomplete and thus ends up implying zero anyway: without the empty set there are no sets and hence there is no reason for set theory, without zero, multiplication doesn't make sense and thus addition doesn't make sense and thus numbers don't make sense, without a point there is no way to contuct any geometrical objects, and thus geometry doesn't make sense, etc). That is, these zero guys end up implied by the theory itself for it to bootstrap its own ground.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 02 2023 00:52:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (Also contradiction of zero --- it is both positive and negative and it is neither positive nor negative, i.e. it takes on properties of both sides, or not, depending upon the context in a manner designed to squeeze the most from the contradiction of positive and negative without actually making that contradiction immanent or immediate).

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 02 2023 20:29:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 That's a lot of claims! Let's go through them: "it should exist because it ex-sists" that's the kind of wordplay that I'm really skeptical of because it hides more than it reveals. "because its a wrapper over contradiction" that says a little more, but what does it mean? I also feel like contradiction is becoming a god-like entity being simultaneously responsible for everything and wrapped over by the empty set. I always thought it was a logical concept, but what do I know? Alright, I'll turn down the snark. "(which is the case for all these values that are isomorphic to zero like point, empty set, null, etc.)" Except the point is *not* isomorphic to the empty set. Let's think of it in a simple setup: a point in a vector space V is an element of that vector space (in a set-theoretic setting), which is equivalent to a function * ‚Üí V from the *one-element* set to V. Thus, *the* point in Set is the one-element set. More generally, in every category of structures without distinguished elements the point is always the terminal object while the initial object in "geometric/set-like" structures functions like the empty set. A point is also 0-dimensional, unlike the empty set, which functions like its dimension is negative infinity. It has nothing in it, thus it is not even 0-dimensional. "ultimately because nothing is only ever exactly equal to a contradiction/a contradiction equals nothing" It is not though. But I'm trying understand this. It is true that in classical logic, which we've already established we can't assume if we want to understand quantum theory, a contradiction implies that every possible sentence is true. But lots of sentences aren't true if we take the empty set as a model, such as "something exists". In any case, these are logical implications, not equalities. "thus nothing is impossible/can't ever actuall exist but must ex-sist as an excluded object" Since it is not inconsistent as a model I don't see any reason nothing shouldn't exist‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 02 2023 20:39:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    even in classical logic. Generally speaking, "nothing" i.e. the empty set i.e. an initial object can be identified with the truth value of falsity for a variety of reasons. In that sense I could see that in a non-paraconsistent logic it cannot follow that falsity is true, which does follow from contradiction, thus falsity *as a truth* value cannot be true in a theory that should have any models. However, that is distinct from using the empty set as a model. "Though, I realized after we spoke that in a lot of these systems the real point is that the system itself is the ultimate grounding object and the zero isomorphism is implied by the system for it to make any sense as a system." Alright, to interpret this as best as I can, a foundational system, such as ZFC, ETCS or homotopy type theory (Hott) is used as a grounding for all of mathematics (and in Badiou all of everything), thus it has to be isomorphic to zero since zero is the grounding for everything. Except that the last part is what is to be established. "(or else the system becomes incomplete and thus ends up implying zero anyway:" All of these systems are incomplete, otherwise they would violate G√∂del's incompleteness theorem. But what does completeness have to do with anything? "without the empty set there are no sets and hence there is no reason for set theory" Except that I gave you several ways to generate all sets from, say, the one-element set. "without zero, multiplication doesn't make sense" That's an odd statement. You can do multiplication just fine without ever touching zero, just using the positive natural numbers. Zero is important for *addition* because it's its neutral element. Why start with multiplication. I'm assuming because zero cancels everything out when multiplying which is important for some reason in your philosopy, but it's not something particularly useful when doing multiplication‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 02 2023 20:44:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "and thus addition doesn't make sense and thus numbers don't make sense," People have been adding and multiplying long before zero became used in number systems. Again, it's formally important to have a neutral element under addition in a variety of ways but you can do most elementary stuff without it. "without a point there is no way to contuct any geometrical objects, and thus geometry doesn't make sense, etc)." Again, the point is not equivalent to zero. "(Also contradiction of zero --- it is both positive and negative and it is neither positive nor negative, i.e. it takes on properties of both sides, or not, depending upon the context in a manner designed to squeeze the most from the contradiction of positive and negative without actually making that contradiction immanent or immediate)." Again, a contradiction is a logical concept. There can be a thing in the middle of two other things without any contradiction implied whatsoever.

  • firedog235Sun Dec 03 2023 09:39:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 I guess I'll have to go through line by line as well: Ex-sists is a word that Zizek borrows from someone else in 'Less than Nothing' --- it means, at least far as I can tell, that there is some object which is necessarily false and/or partial for other objects to exist. I.e. it isn't about 'existing' things (this thing doesn't exist, in normal reality as a total complete object) but rather it must ex-sists, be excluded. For myself (and I suspect Zizek, but who knows) Contradiction is a precisely god like entity --- i.e. God is a contradiction, God is nothing, God ex-sists, God doesn't exist.

  • firedog235Sun Dec 03 2023 09:42:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Sorry, point is isomorphic in that it has no measure, however this is a sidetrack that proves my point at a large scale even as it it proves I'm not perfect at a small scale (:D) --- i.e. the fact that point is being/terminal point just points to how being and nothing are both contradictory (i.e. point appears as zero like object because its isomorphic to 1, not zero and 1, of course, has a whole host of contradictory properties as well as zero, not the least of which is the fact that it is neither prime, nor composite, and its both prime and composite under various conditions and various situations: i.e. to make it into neither you have to claim it as a kind of weird exception in the definition so the math is pretty and perfect + an ugly gross exception don't look over here). My point with the whole nothing is a contradiction and contradiction is nothing is simply that... that's what nothing is, even in quantum theory the whole point of the multiverse theory is that everything which isn't nothing exists, and nothing is the meeting point of all these things (the contradiction of superposition is a real nothing until you entangle with it, until then these thing don't actually have a pinned down value)... If we take the empty set as a starting point the sentence 'something exists' is true --- because there exists a power-set of the empty set (i.e. the set with just the empty set). I think that the missing point here is that implications become part of the original object: that is the 'a is not a' that is missing, that an apple isn't just a stupid fleshy apple but also the apple tree that grows from implicitly from its seeds. You have to include these implications because possibility is inherent in the object *as a possibility* (i.e. it is a property of apples that they can possibly grow into trees, this possibility function is a way for inconsistent systems to avoid their contradiction and re-cohere themselves and have things both ways).

  • firedog235Sun Dec 03 2023 09:45:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 It is possible to have falsity as a truth value: as possibility (that is what true falsity looks like). Zero as contradictory would need to be shown, but the point is that the only way to show it would be by tying it to every other object in the space like the empty set in set theory (however if I come up with an addition space, zero as ground does make sense in that union with the empty set is an identity operation same as addition with zero). In set theory at least, I think we can say that the empty set is + ZFC is a ground. What I mean by it implying zero is that usually there is some kind of what I would call a *prohibition* on thought occuring to stop us from discovering zero, otherwise it is directly implied by the system. By this I mean you can of course come to me and say 'I give you only 1 and +1 as objects, you can have the number 1 and you can add 1 to it and that's it). And then I can spin my wheels generating all the natural numbers however there is nothing stopping me, outside of your demand that these be the only two things, from using symmetry after I've calculated the first infinity or so numbers, from saying 'hey, maybe there is a symmetry here' and eventually ending up with zero. In that sense I can't even do *addition* without finding zero at some point (though I admit it seems it took western mathematics nearly 10k years to actually discover zero so...)

  • firedog235Sun Dec 03 2023 10:02:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    As for Goedel's incompleteness theorem, yes they all have to be incomplete, which isn't a problem: in fact its a positive good as far as I'm concerned. Incompleteness implies the truth of falsity, i.e. possibility, i.e. one of the primal contradictions hiding in all objects (that you claim you have an object, a whole object, and yet you need a little bit more of the object to be able to recognize the object as such, i.e. its incomplete). And finally I think the final statement is the point that isn't translating: all of these things other things (being in between two things, oscillating between two things, randomly jumping between things) these all speak to a contradiction that ex-sists: is excluded. My point isn't that zero is *directly* a contradiction but rather that it is a wrapper around a contradiction: it is the closest thing to what it would be for something to be both positive and negative (where positive and negative are taken as absolute logical opposites, which is what they happen to be). It is an exception to a universal (the universal being 'all numbers are either positive or negative') that exists precisely because there is a contradiction behind all the numbers that they are excluding and the weld point in reality of that exclusion is 0.

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 16:18:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I'm not surprised this comes from Zizek. Honestly, it might as well come from Badiou himself, I'm sure he'd like it. "Sorry, point is isomorphic in that it has no measure" Well, sure, you can introduce an equivalence relation on objects that identifies them if they have the same measure, then a point *in the real line* has no measure. But, by the same measure, all the natural numbers have no measure. While a line in two-dimensional space has no measure, and any finite-dimensional object in an infinite-dimensional space has zero measure. So I guess it's all isomorphic to zero, rendering all of mathematics meaningless. Strangely, we can still do mathematics though‚Ä¶ find the error. "the fact that point is being/terminal point just points to how being and nothing are both contradictory" Not a contradiction. What it is is a unity of opposites in the sense of Lawvere: https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Aufhebung This is what I don't get about you Badiouians: Lawvere treated some of the same material, but much more meaningfully and formally stringent! Yet, the kids are running after Badiou/Zizek because he's the hip new thing while the only people who remember Lawvere are, funny enough, category theorists! "not the least of which is the fact that it is neither prime, nor composite, and its both prime and composite under various conditions and various situations: i.e. to make it into neither you have to claim it as a kind of weird exception in the definition so the math is pretty and perfect + an ugly gross exception don't look over here)." Except it isn't: 1 is a unit in a ring: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unit_(ring_theory) Units in rings are fairly well-understood and not at all ugly exceptions but integral parts of the structure. In other words, what makes 1 not a prime number is that it is *invertible*. It just looks weird if you only know the natural numbers because it is the only unit in the ring of natural numbers.

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 16:25:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "even in quantum theory the whole point of the multiverse theory is that everything which isn't nothing exists," Well, everything which is physically possible, with perhaps the physical constants and maybe even some laws varying over For everything that is actually possible to exist you have to have a much more encompassing mathematicism that you really have to base on category theory. different dimensions, but the basics are actually assumed to be constant. This is quite a bit more restrictive than "everything which isn't nothing". For instance, assuming M-theory is correct and spacetime is 11-dimensional, no "parallel universe" (though I don't love that term because it's actually part of the same universe, just a bit up or down in another dimension) could have more than 11 dimensions. If everything that is possible is supposed to exist you have to assume a mathematicism that only really works with category theory. "and nothing is the meeting point of all these things" Well, no, even if we assume that everything that is possible exists, the meeting point is that they all *exist*. "the contradiction of superposition is a real nothing until you entangle with it" Well, no, because if something exists in a state of superposition it *still exists* and *is something*, actually several things, but not *nothing*. This is actually practically relevant because in quatum computers you use that the particles involved exist in a state of superposition, meaning they take on every *physically possible* configuration, but they're still something, they don't disappear and don't even take on physically impossible configurations. "If we take the empty set as a starting point the sentence 'something exists' is true --- because there exists a power-set of the empty set (i.e. the set with just the empty set)." What you're saying here is that, if we assume the empty set exists in the set-theoretic universe and assume the usual set-theoretic axioms, we can derive the other sets‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 16:39:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    but in that case you're assuming the empty set exists *as an object of the surrounding universe*. What I'm saying is that, first of all, you can take any other set as well, but more importantly, you can also assume that nothing exists *in your universe*, meaning *no object exists in your universe*, meaning your universe *is* but does not *contain* the empty set, meaning it itself is a model, and this model is consistent and doesn't fulfill sentences like "something exists". "I think that the missing point here is that implications become part of the original object: that is the 'a is not a' that is missing" Except that we actually have a way of conveying that: the sentence "a has the possibility to become b", which is different from saying "a is not a". Nothing contradictory about it. "It is possible to have falsity as a truth value: as possibility (that is what true falsity looks like)." Of course that is possible, what I'm saying is you can't have a consistent theory from which it follows that falsity is true. "but the point is that the only way to show it would be by tying it to every other object in the space like the empty set in set theory" Well, sure, every object in a category derives its properties from every other object, but that isn't something special to zero. "In set theory at least, I think we can say that the empty set is" sure, just as we can say that every other set is. " + ZFC is a ground." Again, the metaphysics of ZFC aren't clear at all. Why would it have any relation at all to our physical universe? It is a purely mathematical structure. "What I mean by it implying zero is that usually there is some kind of what I would call a prohibition on thought occuring to stop us from discovering zero" I don't see at all why zero would be harder to think than, say, ◊ë one (there is however a prohibition to sanely using Hebrew letters in Discord, apparently), the cardinality of the continuum‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 16:54:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "I can't even do addition without finding zero at some point" Sure, because it is a mathematical object. What's under discussion is whether it enjoys an ontologically prior status to, particularly, 1. "Incompleteness implies the truth of falsity" *No it doesn't!* People keep using G√∂del's incompleteness theorems as if they imply some sort of contradiction within mathematics, but they *decidedly* don't. What they state is that any formal theory powerful enough to do arithmetic in cannot prove its own consistency within itself unless it is inconsistent (in which case one can prove anything in it). This does *not* imply falsity, in fact it gives you exact conditions a system has to fulfill to avoid implying falsity. "that you claim you have an object, a whole object, and yet you need a little bit more of the object to be able to recognize the object as such" One step at a time: G√∂del's incompleteness theorems are about mathematical theories, not objects. They do provide limits to what you can discover about all objects fulfilling the theory in question without assuming a more powerful background theory, in that sense they are elementary logical contstraints, but *they do not imply that it follows for those theories that they imply the truth of falsity*. "all of these things other things (being in between two things, oscillating between two things, randomly jumping between things) these all speak to a contradiction that ex-sists: is excluded." So it exists but doesn't exist but it is also responsible for every edge case and everything that has several properties and also everything that isn't completely stationary (how can it do that if it doesn't exist?). But what then is the explanatory power of any of it? It isn't about logical contradictions, because those aren't logical contradictions. It is about some vague concept that is nothing and everything at the same time, but then why not treat each one of these cases as one would without the philosophical baggage?

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 16:59:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "It is an exception to a universal (the universal being 'all numbers are either positive or negative') that exists precisely because there is a contradiction behind all the numbers that they are excluding and the weld point in reality of that exclusion is 0." Except I can give you a thousand sentences that apply to *almost all* integers except one number. For instance "every integer is either smaller or larger than 1", which applies to all numbers except 1. You can say the sets of positive and negative integers are special in some ways, but that is still true for lots and lots of such sentences. And how are positive and negative numbers defined, after all? Usually by being smaller or larger than 0.

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 17:00:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Every natural number is multiplicatively non-invertible" is also a good one among such sentences, applying to all natural numbers except 1.

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 17:08:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm going to argue against myself here for a moment and say that probably a paraconsistent logic could be derived that gives a "true" truth value to exactly those kinds of sentences, which could, in classical logic, be interpreted as saying "true for almost all" or something. My issue isn't that such a logic might not exist or even be useful but that "contradiction" is taken to mean everything and nothing which renders it meaningless as an explanation. Why do stones keep falling? Contradiction. Why does the universe exist? Contradiction. What would a universe be like if contradiction didn't simultaneously exist and not exist? That's a contradiction because you can't make that assumption without contradiction. If contradiction is simultaneously everything and nothing at all, if everything is implied by contradiction and also nothing is, then we might as well leave it away as a hypothesis because it has no consequences whatsoever!

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 17:15:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This is why formalization is so important, particularly when dealing with exotic concepts: unless you make it completely clear what you're talking about you can use big words and apparently sound reasoning to arrive at any conclusion whatsoever! It's only when you say that "this is what I mean, this is my hypothesis, these are the consequences, this is what cannot follow, *this is the system*" that you can really say something *reasonable*!

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 18:05:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Alright, here I'll try to argue against myself, both to steelman the case, to show the hidden assumptions and because my position is actually not that far removed from it: if you assume that *logical* contradiction œÜ ‚àß ¬¨ œÜ *semantically* means "both the state œÜ is taken and some other state that is unstable with œÜ in that it cannot be held by anything more than a small amount", then you can see this pattern as one or maybe even the driving motor of development in the physical universe. Furthermore, maybe the prototypical example of this state of affairs is that between positive and negative numbers (though that is very arguable). Since contradiction is the driving motor of our physical universe, we can assume it is also that of mathematics (I'd certainly argue *that*), so we can assume that the thing that embodies this contradiction the most, zero, is the "first" mathematical object to exist (again, a pretty big jump). This is borne out precisely because zero is the initial object of *Set* and other "spatial" categories, meaning the object at the start. Furthermore, zero "is" in this sense in every other object in that a morphism ‚àÖ ‚Üí X exists for every object in every one such category.

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 03 2023 18:17:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    My issues are several: 1. as noted, there are some pretty big jumps in there. 2. Even to assume that zero exists in, say, a model of ZFC is to assume that *a model of ZFC* exists, so you're assuming *something before nothing*. You can assume that *nothing* exists in that you use the empty set, or "emptiness" to not assume sets exist, as a model, but in that model nothing is generated.

  • firedog235Sun Dec 03 2023 20:18:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 The steelmanning is basically correct (though incomplete :D). I don't think the jumps are impossible but the point of 2. is that the model of ZFC has come into being through basically the process of excluding contradictions from mathematics over historical time, which would be annoying (as in, please write several dissertations) to show here so I won't. It's because we're dealing with the ground of things (that‚Äôs why it has this ‚ÄòI‚Äôm pulling my hair out, it seems to apply to everything, property: because it does apply to everything) --- this isn't just my point but as far as I can tell it's Hegel's as well: that this whole, 'you have to loop back from the model to the ground and from the ground to the model' --- i.e. zero is the grounding mathematical object, but it is only discovered *after* you fully exhaust a previous grounding object (which would have been ‚Äò1‚Äô for like the Sumerians or Babylonians and even the Greeks I think). The predictive power of contradiction is this: that whenever you think you have a good consistent complete mathematical (metaphysical) system where you know how everything works and how everything relates to everything else --- you don't. I.e. that the universe is always going to have to be in motion in order to avoid a contradiction, the most primary of which is the contradiction of nothing which forces (some)things into being (incompleteness is a kind of acceptance of this contradiction by placing a *consistent wrapper* of 'incompleteness' around the system rather than saying 'my system is perfect' which would be impossible). Its predictive power (after the fact, i.e. just like how zero is found after all the numbers or at least after all the positives) is that you don't have to run around wondering why there is something rather than nothing. There is something *because* Nothing is contradiction itself --- you could never be in a universe where nothing existed because then reality would be inconsistent.

  • firedog235Sun Dec 03 2023 20:31:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This appears in the point where you say that 'the real meeting point is that they all exist' --- yes, exactly, the real meeting point is that they are all *not nothing* --- i.e. that they are all attempts to avoid the contradiction, all constantly moving to avoid that contradiction (or as we get into chapter 1, all becoming). It's the constant demand that things be put in motion. (Also, if you read the axiom of the power-set --- it doesn't say that you *may* create these power-sets, it says that if S exists then the power set of S exists, period...) But besides this, the more fundamental point is that negation is a more powerful and fundamental relation than equality. After all, equality is merely a special case of double negation (where the double negation returns you to where you started rather than jumping you into something random in that c = not not a when ‚Äònot a‚Äô doesn‚Äôt include the whole universe, as in a car is not an apple and a cat is not a car so not not an apple is a cat). This is the kind of ‚Äòformalization' of possibility that Badoiu and Zizek are working with. The reason the kids like them is because they are not foreclosing possibility at the fundamental philosophical level because they accept negation as the fundamental object of their dialectics (which is the metaphysics of pure negation or we should say the metaphysics of contradiction) rather than trying to move only through equality (which admittedly is nice to do if you are, for example, in the academy, because if anyone comes up to you and says ‚Äòhey this move is wrong‚Äô you can point at the *equality* of the move and say ‚Äòno I just followed the rules ma‚Äôam‚Äô --- but that isn‚Äôt how a revolutionary movement will move --- a revolutionary movement will always have this moment of pure negation where there isn‚Äôt equality but only ‚Äònot the current state of things‚Äô and the particular negation has to be speculatively chosen by the people in that moment, with the move chosen becoming the new ground).

  • firedog235Sun Dec 03 2023 21:42:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think this might help --- what is meant by 'contradiction, the contradiction, etc' in Hegel, as far as I can tell, is proof by contradiction with two addendums: 1. All constructive proofs are ultimately proofs by contradiction at their base (i.e. in reality these axioms are actually metaphysical objects ultimately derived through proof by contradiction from contradiction itself, they aren't really 'assumed' but instead 'developed' out of contradiction and the reason why people say 'assume x' is because they either don't want to go through their reasoning from contradiction because it would be tedious or else they are using intuitive calculation --- calculation based on all their previous observations --- to get to the point but they don't know *why* they think this true, just that they do). 2. Contradictions themselves can also be treated as objects (i.e. you can just call them 'C' or 'C1' and treat them like any other element) and subjected to the self-same proof by contradiction as other objects.

  • nameiwillforgetMon Dec 04 2023 22:38:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "the point of 2. is that the model of ZFC has come into being through basically the process of excluding contradictions from mathematics over historical time, which would be annoying (as in, please write several dissertations) to show here so I won't. " Yeah, but we're talking about ontology, not history. If you go by historical progress, then, again, 1 was used before 0. Furthermore, ZFC enjoys no particularly excellent status. It was a hastily thrown-together model to avoid Russell's paradox. Its metaphysics are unclear, as I underlined several times, and within mathematics it is only used as a kind of standard that one might follow or not. It's really not in any way firm ground to stand on. Regardless, the point stands: if you assume that nothing exists within a context, any context, you assume the context exists, thus you assume something exists. If you take nothing as a context, it is not generative, it simply remains nothing. "It's because we're dealing with the ground of things (that‚Äôs why it has this ‚ÄòI‚Äôm pulling my hair out, it seems to apply to everything, property: because it does apply to everything)" I get that, but it still has to say, well, something, or it's meaningless. "this isn't just my point but as far as I can tell it's Hegel's as well: " Well, no, because Hegel assumes that "the ground"/"the beginning" is *being*. "zero is the grounding mathematical object, but it is only discovered after you fully exhaust a previous grounding object (which would have been ‚Äò1‚Äô for like the Sumerians or Babylonians and even the Greeks I think). " Then really you couldn't say whether it was actually "the ground" or only the next in a ladder of objects discovered as mathematics gets explored. "The predictive power of contradiction is this: that whenever you think you have a good consistent complete mathematical (metaphysical) system where you know how everything works and how everything relates to everything else " It's easy to prove that impossible‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetMon Dec 04 2023 22:47:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    without any metaphysical assumptions other than that we can do mathematics in some way. However, that's not a contradiction, not even in the extended logical sense I outlined yesterday. Mathematics is literally infinite, there are always propositions that aren't proven. The Greeks probably knew that! "that the universe is always going to have to be in motion in order to avoid a contradiction, the most primary of which is the contradiction of nothing which forces (some)things into being " Except, again, that it is perfectly possible to use "nothing"/the empty set as a model, without it contradicting itself in any way. You still haven't dealt with that! In fact, that would even be a complete system! "(incompleteness is a kind of acceptance of this contradiction by placing a consistent wrapper of 'incompleteness' around the system rather than saying 'my system is perfect' which would be impossible)" Again, no it is not. As I just wrote, the empty model would be complete. Incompleteness only comes into play *once* you have the natural numbers. Simple systems like the empty system are complete. The incompleteness theorems have become fetishized by people who don't understand them and are trodded out to provide superficial justifications for metaphysical concepts that have nothing to do with them. They are statements about the inability of finite beings to reason about infinite systems, to (perhaps overly) simplify, not about contradiction. "There is something because Nothing is contradiction itself --- you could never be in a universe where nothing existed because then reality would be inconsistent." Again, no. You can have a model using the nothing. You can only generate things out of nothing if that "nothing" is treated as an object in a larger context, which assumes the context.

  • nameiwillforgetMon Dec 04 2023 22:58:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "that they are all attempts to avoid the contradiction, all constantly moving to avoid that contradiction (or as we get into chapter 1, all becoming). " Except that you don't have a contradiction. "Also, if you read the axiom of the power-set --- it doesn't say that you may create these power-sets, it says that if S exists then the power set of S exists, period" Well, yes, though I don't get the point. Mathematicians talk all the time as if they simultaneously created and discovered the objects they investigate. "But besides this, the more fundamental point is that negation is a more powerful and fundamental relation than equality" Well that's certainly not true! You can have a logic without negation just fine, a logic without equality however wouldn't work at all! "After all, equality is merely a special case of double negation" Again, absolutely not. Double negation is only even equivalent to truth of the original proposition if you assume the law of the excluded middle (LEM). If you don't, and there are good reasons not to, you couldn't even identify it with *logical equivalence*, nevermind equality! "(where the double negation returns you to where you started rather than jumping you into something random in that c = not not a when ‚Äònot a‚Äô doesn‚Äôt include the whole universe, as in a car is not an apple and a cat is not a car so not not an apple is a cat)." That's more usually just called faulty reasoning. "The reason the kids like them is because they are not foreclosing possibility at the fundamental philosophical level because they accept negation as the fundamental object of their dialectics" I think more the reason kids like them is because Zizek is funny and most of his stuff doesn't require much theoretical setup, nevermind rigor‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetMon Dec 04 2023 23:04:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "(which admittedly is nice to do if you are, for example, in the academy, because if anyone comes up to you and says ‚Äòhey this move is wrong‚Äô you can point at the equality of the move and say ‚Äòno I just followed the rules ma‚Äôam‚Äô --- but that isn‚Äôt how a revolutionary movement will move --- a revolutionary movement will always have this moment of pure negation where there isn‚Äôt equality but only ‚Äònot the current state of things‚Äô and the particular negation has to be speculatively chosen by the people in that moment, with the move chosen becoming the new ground" Yeah, sure, those evil academics using their equality, why can't they accept the fundamental truth of double negation? We're talking about ontology here, not revolution. I know Badiou wants to prove that revolution is ontologically required, but that would have to be proven and can thus not be used as an argument. You're really just throwing stuff together here while trying to claim the revolutionary mantle. But if you fancy yourself a revolutionary that would be all the more reason to have your fundamentals correct. Finally, the reason mathematicians do the stuff they do is not because they're dusty academics who just repeat dogma but because they *don't* and *can't* dictate the rules of their ontology to the object of their study.

  • nameiwillforgetMon Dec 04 2023 23:12:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "All constructive proofs are ultimately proofs by contradiction at their base (i.e. in reality these axioms are actually metaphysical objects ultimately derived through proof by contradiction from contradiction itself, they aren't really 'assumed' but instead 'developed' out of contradiction and the reason why people say 'assume x' is because they either don't want to go through their reasoning from contradiction because it would be tedious or else they are using intuitive calculation --- calculation based on all their previous observations --- to get to the point but they don't know why they think this true, just that they do)." As far as I can tell what you are really saying is that people start with some assumptions, find the flaw in those assumptions, then change their setup and continue. Yes, but that's not a proof by contradiction except in that you found a contradiction in your previous system, so you move on to another one. "‚Ä¶from contradiction itself" You just take that as an article of faith. "Contradictions themselves can also be treated as objects (i.e. you can just call them 'C' or 'C1' and treat them like any other element) and subjected to the self-same proof by contradiction as other objects." In what setup? I'd even be inclined to grant you that that is possible because you can do similar things with equalities, proofs or formulas, but you need to define the setup in which you do it! And also, to define that you need lots of other mathematical objects so you can't use it as a base of your ontology.

  • nameiwillforgetMon Dec 04 2023 23:15:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Regardless, the point stands: if you assume that nothing exists within a context, any context, you assume the context exists, thus you assume something exists. If you take nothing as a context, it is not generative, it simply remains nothing." That's really the point where the whole thing fails. The other points are comparatively minor, but this is deadly.

  • firedog235Mon Dec 04 2023 23:54:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 My point here: "Also, if you read the axiom of the power-set --- it doesn't say that you may create these power-sets, it says that if S exists then the power set of S exists, period" Well, yes, though I don't get the point. Mathematicians talk all the time as if they simultaneously created and discovered the objects they investigate. ... Is that it is inherent in the definition of 'set' that you have powersets and thus you already have the reality explosion even if you just try to reach for only the empty set. Also, the metaphysics of ZFC is precisely the hegelian metaphysics --- an ungodly hack placed over a contradiction (which you can quibble here and there over other things but Russell's paradox is a traditional god's honest contradiction, and in fact, now that I think about it, it is *the* contradiction of early 20th century mathematics).

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 00:02:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So you can't have the empty set sans a context.

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 00:59:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    However, if we consider what you want 'nothing without any other context' --- my point is that the only thing which is always nothing, without any other context, is a contradiction (i.e. the thing which always can't exist, the thing which always fails to exist --- a failure which persists in paraconsistency by simply making contradictions into not contradictions through various limitations on contradiction that make it literally para*consistent* and thus allow it to pop back into existence as something less than a contradiction, less than nothing). I challenge you to show me a nothing that is both intelligible as nothing --- that definitely is nothing and definitely doesn‚Äôt exist --- and also something other than a contradiction. I don‚Äôt think Hegel would agree that it's something else... In chapter 1, when Hegel says that nothing is not any particular determination (not any of the A or not A that could exist) He‚Äôs saying its ‚Äònot (A or not A‚Äô) i.e. ‚Äònot A and not not A‚Äô... and since we‚Äôre dealing with totality here and the LEM holds because everything falls into either ‚ÄòA or not A‚Äô for some determinations A (and here ‚ÄòA‚Äô is just a stand in for all possible determinations) that means that ‚Äònot A and not not A‚Äô = ‚Äònot A and A‚Äô, or... a contradiction. The difference between being and nothing, as I read it is that being is tautologically opposed, so its ‚ÄòA or not A‚Äô without the negation which amounts to something equally trivial (a different kind of explosion), which means that becoming becomes C1 (nothing) and not C1 (being)... making becoming into a repetition of the original nothing (this point hegel is not clear on but I think that‚Äôs for ideological reasons having to do with God and other nonsense... he desperately wants to start with being rather than nothing, which is the more materialist place to start, I believe, because it emphasizes negation and difference as primary rather than tautology which is, I think, the difference between idealism and materialism).

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 01:07:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This is the surplus in nothing which allows us to actually get off the ground, the thing nothing must be for there to be something (the I am therefore nothing is a contradiction and not just some nebulous other thing without any form or function). And yes this is a speculative position, (which might be called a kind of faith, though speculation is what faith is when it's done by scientists and mathematicians --- i.e. a theory that must withstand attack) but its the kind of speculative position which I feel for me at least has withstood the constant collision with reality --- once again, give me a nothing without any other context that isn‚Äôt contradiction --- I don't think you can and I don't think you have other than simply asserting that you have (and as I pointed out, if you just say its ‚Äònot everything else‚Äô... you‚Äôre dealing with a contradiction because 'neither' is a contradiction in any context where nothing is the only context --- i.e. if your context is 'no context but nothing' then your context is not context_1 and not context_2 and... and not context_n for all possible n, and since all possible n are opposed to each other (i.e. for every context Cx there is a not Cx) you're creating a contradiction simply by stating you don't want a context at all, though as the meme says 'change my mind').

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 01:09:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Finally, there are a bunch of other things which I think are miscommunications that I object to but I don't have time to address them all --- I will note as an example that when I say negation is more fundamental than equality your response is that I'm dumb because I don't know about LEM is strange when my whole point with the chain of reasoning --- not not apple = cat, is what happens when you drop LEM and how equality goes to shit while negation keeps plugging on happily. The disagreement is that I view the chain of reasoning thus produced as a feature and a bug rather than merely a bug: it tells us more about how the universe functions than the chain of mere equalities because it tells us that our whole framework for thinking can be wrong, that our equalities are always based on speculative divisions that exclude some object in order to function, though if you want a better version --- not an apple is fertilizer and not fertilizer is an orange and thus not not an apple is an orange --- which is the (oversimplified but basically correct) logic of things when over long time an orchard replaces its apple trees with orange trees that are fertilized with the remains of the old apples.

  • dve.h_37844Tue Dec 05 2023 01:16:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So where is the potential in contradiction? How do we think about that logically?

  • dve.h_37844Tue Dec 05 2023 01:19:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôm thinking of the potential of the working class.

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 01:20:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 The potential in contradiction is negation --- contradiction requires negation to function, i.e. 'false' is a required outcome of contradiction (which is, in my understanding, what becoming amounts to --- mere falseness). The reason 'false' is important is because the distinction between contradiction and 'false' is that 'false' *could* be true, is *possible* but 'merely' false and thus opens the path to things being true.

  • dve.h_37844Tue Dec 05 2023 01:27:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So it is the material reality that creates contradiction, or, the fact that something is alive that gives it its inate contradiction?

  • dve.h_37844Tue Dec 05 2023 01:27:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Life -> Death -> Life again.

  • dve.h_37844Tue Dec 05 2023 01:28:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Like trees to soil.

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 01:31:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Its material reality, quantum mechanics is everything but contradictory (i.e. its not contradiction which means that contradiction is in its definition).

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 01:31:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But as for the working class: Well the way I read it, the point is that we need to stop saying that capitalism is contradictory and thus will end itself in crises. Everything contains these contradictory movements, whatever comes after will also have a contradictory movement. Rather, its about the stability or ‚Äòdevelopment out of‚Äô contradiction which is important. Capitalism requires constant development out of its own contradiction rather than having some kind of stabilized loop. For me, this is driven by the fact that the contradiction lies in the realm of political-economy, the economic contradiction constantly destabilizes the political one which then constantly attempts to recuperate the economic contradiction (in various failed ways). Under socialism, I believe that the political contradiction must remain (so the things which are meant to deal with political contradiction, things like freedom of speech, religion, association, etc. must be maintained and bolstered) --- however I think this can only be done by recognizing contradiction in the realm of theory (i.e. recognizing that we will have to force workers to be the master, and we will have to wrap their mastery in a system that is opaque enough,indirect enough, and arbitrary enough that we don‚Äôt get the explosion of rule by experts that is endemic to Stalinism, this is the theoretical contradiction).

  • dve.h_37844Tue Dec 05 2023 01:36:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I agree with everything except the term ‚Äúforce‚Äù that you used. I think it is precisely the realm of politics in which this tango is danced. This is what I get from Cutrone and it‚Äôs pretty consistent with the ideals of the bolsheviks.

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 01:48:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I mean there's force and there's force. By this I mean that in every situation there is a forcing function (even a dance is defined by the force of consent of the parties dancing, excluding other possibilities like fighting): here the point is that the only mastery left to the volunteeristic left is the mastery of getting the non-volunteeristic working class to rule themselves. Because the system we are dealing with is so large this will involve an appeal to reason every where (least force), politics in most places (next least), economics in many places (next least after that) but also civil war in some places (i.e. the idea that global socialist revolution won't involve some actual force is also a mistake). Its just that I don't think it will involve as much force as people who look at 1917 tend to think.

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 03:48:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 I think that ultimately the problem has to do with totality: totality, I think, is the LEM, once you have totality you have some determination where everything can be broken into either A or not A, that's what it means to have a totality (you've accounted for totally everything in some determination, everything either is one thing or it isn't --- in this case everything either is in your model of nothing or it isn't in your model of nothing). And so when you ask for a model of pure nothing --- with not context, I read that as asking for a totality, which means that you have to have the LEM in your pure nothing which means there has to, implicitly, be some kind of determination that splits the the pure nothing (total nothing) into A vs. not A but then if the nothing comes down on either side of that, then it doesn't consume the whole space (i.e. it acquires the property of being either A or not A, it acquires the property of being self-equal as one or the other) and if its tautological (A or not A), then whatever it is it definitely exists which doesn't seem like a nothing to me (nothing shouldn't exist). Thus the only thing it could be, while being total and being nothing, is both A and not A (which is fine because, A and not A actually is a nothing in that it doesn't ever exist) and the nothing loses even the property of being self-equal and remains only total (which was what you demanded in the first place) even while being not total (because, of course, now that its a contradiction, it starts to generate other objects).

  • nameiwillforgetTue Dec 05 2023 12:57:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Also, the metaphysics of ZFC is precisely the hegelian metaphysics" Well, if so, time-traveling Hegel would have been wrong, so I'm really hoping he has more to offer than ZFC. Also, ZFC is traditionally generated from the empty set, as you noted, Hegel starts with *being*. I feel like you're all too quick to opportunistically claim Hegel. "Russell's paradox is a traditional god's honest contradiction, and in fact, now that I think about it, it is the contradiction of early 20th century mathematics)." It's only a contradiction if you want your model to have a presence within itself, and even then only if you assume it obeys the rules of a set. If you consider it as a class, such as in Von Neumann‚ÄìBernays‚ÄìG√∂del set theory, you don't arrive at a contradiction. But really, what you should take it as saying is that each mathematical structure large enough to house most of mathematics generates and is nested in even larger structures, like Russian nesting dolls. You never arrive at a fixed point. That would be a defendable version of your point. "So you can't have the empty set sans a context." Not as a *set* but you can consider *nothing* without a context. "However, if we consider what you want 'nothing without any other context' --- my point is that the only thing which is always nothing, without any other context, is a contradiction" And my point is that it is not contradictory (which usually people take as the hallmark of a contradiction). "I challenge you to show me a nothing that is both intelligible as nothing --- that definitely is nothing and definitely doesn‚Äôt exist" Why would I assume it doesn't exist? Zoom in on spacetime until you only have point. Then remove the point. Voila, you have nothing. "when Hegel says that nothing is not any particular determination (not any of the A or not A that could exist) He‚Äôs saying its ‚Äònot (A or not A‚Äô) i.e. ‚Äònot A and not not A‚Äô."

  • nameiwillforgetTue Dec 05 2023 13:32:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "when Hegel says that nothing is not any particular determination (not any of the A or not A that could exist) He‚Äôs saying its ‚Äònot (A or not A‚Äô) i.e. ‚Äònot A and not not A‚Äô." First, what Hegel is saying exactly is "Nichts, das reine Nichts; es ist einfache Gleichheit mit sich selbst, vollkommene Leerheit, Bestimmungs- und Inhaltslosigkeit; Ununterschiedenheit in ihm selbst" So Hegel says *not* that nothing is without determination but that nothing is *complete lack of determination*. However, when you're saying when you're saying "its (A or not A‚Äô)", you're saying *nothing is without determination*. However, then the entire section of SoL wouldn't make sense, since it is precisely determining what nothing *is* through giving some determinations. Nothing itself isn't *undetermined* it is *undeterminedness*. It itself determined precisely by this section and this sentence in particular. That's not contradictory. Also, only a side note, but note that Hegel writes "so ist (existiert) Nichts in unserem Anschauen oder Denken; oder vielmehr ist es das leere Anschauen und Denken selbst" "so nothing *exists* in our ‚Ä¶ thinking‚Ä¶" So Hegel certainly thinks you can think nothing. "this point hegel is not clear on but I think that‚Äôs for ideological reasons having to do with God and other nonsense... he desperately wants to start with being rather than nothing" No, you desparately want to start from nothing even though it doesn't make sense. "which is the more materialist place to start" Materialism is assuming everything is matter. Believing everything springs from nothing would be more like nihilism. In any case, I don't see what it has to do with any even remotely practical or even philosophically defensible notion of materialism. "because it emphasizes negation and difference as primary rather than tautology which is, I think, the difference between idealism and materialism" It is if you completely redefine the terms for your point.

  • nameiwillforgetTue Dec 05 2023 13:53:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    " a theory that must withstand attack" Correct, you have to defend your model, I only have to point out its incoherence. So even if I *couldn't* (and I can) give you a model of "nothing without context", it suffices to point out that if you're assuming that nothing exists in a context, you're assuming the context exists, and thus assuming something exists. "if your context is 'no context but nothing' then your context is not context_1 and not context_2 and... and not context_n for all possible n, and since all possible n are opposed to each other (i.e. for every context Cx there is a not Cx) you're creating a contradiction simply by stating you don't want a context at all, though as the meme says 'change my mind')." No, because "nothing" doesn't have to be defined as a negation, it can simply be defined as the simplest possible model of the empty theory (which is both a positive determination and a universal property). "your response is that I'm dumb" I'm not saying you're dumb, I'm saying you're sloppy and use reasoning that doesn't acknowledge all its premises to arrive at conclusions you want to reach. You're doing what I said before: you're letting your ontological assumptions dictate to the object of your study. Also, you strawman your counterpositions. Your "better version" is exactly an example of that: "not an apple is fertilizer not fertilizer is an orange thus not not an apple is an orange" Aristotle has already explained the failures of such flawed syllogisms. But in modern language, and going through it in some detail: saying "x is not an apple" means, "x does not have the property of being an apple", it doesn't mean "x is defined by or the only thing that is not an apple. In modern, set-theoretic language, (which you should know since you like ZFC so much) "fertilizer is in the set of things that are not fertilizer". Similarly then "oranges are in the set of things that are not apples". Thus, you cannot draw the interference

  • nameiwillforgetTue Dec 05 2023 14:01:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "not not an apple is an orange" since the set of things that are not fertilizer might contain more than one element. The key is that the word "is" can be used to describe both equality and subset inclusion, which allows for such constructions that people could and have quickly found the flaw in but that superficially look like syllogisms. This is precisely why I disdain when people use wordplay to make their points. In any case, LEM or the failure of LEM doesn't say that this construction would be possible but the failure of LEM claims that things could exist for which it is neither true that they are either apples or (completely) not apples, such as perhaps hybrids of apples with some other fruit or very exotic apples that are almost another fruit. "which is the (oversimplified but basically correct) logic of things when over long time an orchard replaces its apple trees with orange trees that are fertilized with the remains of the old apples." Logic is precisely defined by the fact that it doesn't depend on special cases but that its conclusions are valid whenever it is semantically applicable.

  • nameiwillforgetTue Dec 05 2023 14:20:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Also, you're using unnecessarily complicated vocabulary to make your arguments unapproachable. The successive discussion is an example of that. What the hell is a "forcing function" and why would anyone ever use that term instead of just saying "there is some force involved in everything" except to appear more sophisticated than they are? And you're connecting questions of political relevance to those of logic *without getting the logic right*. That's what worries me. Marxism came into being by applying Hegelian logic to current politics, but Marx never was that sloppy and wherever he was sloppy it became a huge problem for successive generations. It is not just a question of aesthetics to keep your political arguments as simple as possible but one of ethics. So when I see someone using mathematical vocabulary almost nobody knows to make political points there better be a good reason for it and they better get the mathematics right, otherwise it is confusing sophistry.

  • nameiwillforgetTue Dec 05 2023 14:23:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Again, no, but see my refutations above

  • nameiwillforgetTue Dec 05 2023 14:31:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Ok, in more detail: "totality, I think, is the LEM" That's an unwarrented identification. "you've accounted for totally everything in some determination" Not LEM doesn't say that every thing doesn't have some unique property "And so when you ask for a model of pure nothing --- with not context, I read that as asking for a totality, which means that you have to have the LEM" That falls away if you don't make the above identification, but you can assume lem and still have nothing as a model. "which means there has to, implicitly, be some kind of determination that splits the the pure nothing (total nothing) into A vs. not A" Lem says "for every x and property œÜ either x fulfills œÜ or it fulfills ¬¨œÜ". In the empty model, no x exists, so no property œÜ can split it into parts. "then it doesn't consume the whole space" There is no space in the empty model. The rest falls apart because, again, there is no split.

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 18:34:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 No, there is a split because there is a totality. There's a split because there is a you to do the splitting, the empty theory stands in contradistinction to you. When you demand 'the simplest possible model of the empty theory ' you are already performing the split in that starting determination and then wrapping the contradiction that the starting determination creates in an assumption to protect the determination from the contradiction it entails (i.e. you've moved the negation into 'empty theory' --- i.e. theory which *doesn't* (negation) have axioms --- in order to make nothing into not a negation) and you want to pretend you aren't doing that which is the metaphysical move of totality (or, in politics, totalitarianism) par excellence --- i.e. setting the terms of the debate and removing its assumptions from consideration before the debate even occurs. And I'm telling you can have your totality, but only if its a contradiction, you don't get a happy smooth harmonious totality. I'm saying nothing is undeterminedness (lack of difference in some other object) which is also undetermined (lack of difference in this object). Its both. The reason being that there is no firm determination between 'thing' and 'property' --- so to say a thing lacks a property is also to say that there is a lack of a thing, there is a thing that doesn't exist (or to put it another way, to say a thing doesn't exist is to say that totality lacks the *property* of the thing that doesn't exist). Or to put it even another way, undetermitedness is a determination without a determination, a difference without a difference (because it applies to everything, everything lacks a determination w.r.t. to itself at least).

  • firedog235Tue Dec 05 2023 18:37:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And finally I'd go a step further and point out --- A and not A, this *is* lack of determination in formal terms. When I say that I have a vector in 3 space and then ask about its properties in 4 space, those properties have to hold no matter what the value of the fourth dimension happens to be: if the 3 space happens to be at t = 0 or t = 1000 (using t because there isn't a number after z, don't assume time). The lack of determination in the 3 space, its failure to pin down a difference in the fourth dimension, *is also* a statement that what we're saying about this 3 space applies to all 4 spaces in which it could be embedded. That lack of determination on where we are in 4 space simply says 'we are everywhere in 4 space'. If I put a sphere at 0, 0, 0 in 3 space then it is at all possible values of t in 4 space until I specify (determine) where it actually is in 4 space. i.e. I have a sphere with a center at multiple distinct location, i.e. a contradiction.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Dec 06 2023 03:25:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "No, there is a split because there is a totality" If by totality you mean a closed model, then no, because it's empty. "There's a split because there is a you to do the splitting," That's not at all the point you've made before. But as a point it doesn't make sense: I exist, therefore something exists, therefore not just nothing exists, therefore the empty model can't *describe reality*, therefore "nothing" doesn't exist, therefore there is a contradiction is not a valid chain of reasoning because it again precludes its result, because there wouldn't be a contradiction *if you didn't assume "nothing" existed*. Furthermore, a model not being real doesn't mean it isn't *consistent* in itself. This one certainly is. "you've moved the negation into 'empty theory' --- i.e. theory which doesn't (negation) have axioms --- in order to make nothing into not a negation" No, the empty theory is actually the most natural one. But I can also give you a thousand theories that are *not* empty and whose initial model is empty. Say, the theory given by one axiom: ‚àÄx: x = x Forall x holds, x equals x Since there are no existence assumptions in that theory, it applies to the empty structure, even though it has axioms. "‚Ä¶or, in politics, totalitarianism‚Ä¶" Real classy. "setting the terms of the debate and removing its assumptions from consideration before the debate even occurs." Sorry, I didn't set up how logic works. Also, again, I don't need to show that an empty model exists for your position to be inconsistent. Even if it wouldn't my objection that you're already assuming something by assuming the context around your nothing along which its rules, which is what you use to actually generate things out of that, is *something*. "I'm saying nothing is undeterminedness (lack of difference in some other object) which is also undetermined (lack of difference in this object)" No, you just determined it‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetWed Dec 06 2023 03:35:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "The reason being that there is no firm determination between 'thing' and 'property' That is actually not completely untrue but the property of being indeterminateness can itself be determined. "Or to put it even another way, undetermitedness is a determination without a determination, a difference without a difference (because it applies to everything, everything lacks a determination w.r.t. to itself at least)." Everything you say determines indeterminateness even more. "When I say that I have a vector in 3 space and then ask about its properties in 4 space, those properties have to hold no matter what the value of the fourth dimension happens to be: if the 3 space happens to be at t = 0 or t = 1000 (using t because there isn't a number after z, don't assume time). The lack of determination in the 3 space, its failure to pin down a difference in the fourth dimension, is also a statement that what we're saying about this 3 space applies to all 4 spaces in which it could be embedded." Well, yes, that is again kind-of true and we have ways to talk about that. "That lack of determination on where we are in 4 space simply says 'we are everywhere in 4 space'." No, it says "we are nowhere in particular in any 4-dimensional space". It *doesn't* say "we are everywhere at once". That would be literally considering the family of all embeddings of that 3-space into any 4-space at the same time. You can actually give some meaning to your statement but if approached naively it isn't what you claim. Note also that I'm not saying "4 space" because there isn't just one. " If I put a sphere at 0, 0, 0 in 3 space then it is at all possible values of t in 4 space until I specify (determine) where it actually is in 4 space. i.e. I have a sphere with a center at multiple distinct location, i.e. a contradiction." No it's not. What it is though is a category, with a sphere S, spaces T and morphisms S ‚Üí T.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Dec 06 2023 03:37:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And that's why you should know category theory.

  • firedog235Wed Dec 06 2023 04:32:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 No, I think we should tarry with this one a bit --- you don't get category theory. What you get is an object in 3 space which is undetermined in 4 space. Both of which are stupid boring euclidian spaces without any twisting or topological nonsense going on. That's the nothing that you wanted correct, you want a lack of determination of some kind? My point is you don't get to take my perfectly fine 3 space sphere and apply a function or morph-ism to it to force consistency and split it into a set or even worse a category of multiple spheres in multiple spaces or any of that. That's all for the future when we're desperately trying to make the contradiction go away again, because we need a way to consistently relate boring stupid euclidean 4 space and euclidean 3 space (at which point our sphere won't be undetermined, because its 4th dimension will be 't for some t' or something like that --- which is a determination). Right now we are in a world where all that beautiful *development* hasn't occurred and the response to make it consistent *could* be any of the ones you've given (i.e. we do a morphism, or we say actually objects in 3 space are never in 4 space or etc. etc.) or it could even be, objects in 3 space always enter 4 space at t = 0 by convention. But we haven't done these things yet. We are before these choices. Right now, the 3 space object is at location <0, 0, 0, ‚àÑ>, correct? And my point is that the way to make sense of this ‚àÑ is as a contradiction first, then later we fix it, and part of that is that we don't have to fix it through the generalization (the morphism from space to another), we could fix it by convention to 0. Or we could say that its a 3-sphere moving through a limited set of points in 4 space. Or whatever. But before any of those choices are made, this ‚àÑ is any and all of those mutually exclusive paths forward, its all the points in 4 space and all the ways of escaping the very question of it being all the points in 4 space.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Dec 06 2023 13:28:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "What you get is an object in 3 space which is undetermined in 4 space." That's not a thing. What is a thing is a category wherein this makes sense. "Both of which are stupid boring euclidian spaces without any twisting or topological nonsense going on ‚Ä¶ you want a lack of determination of some kind?" That's a huge determination. "That's the nothing that you wanted correct" No, the nothing I'm saying is a consistent complete model contains *no* points and has *no* dimension (not even 0 but you could also say it has dimension -‚àû). "My point is you don't get to take my perfectly fine 3 space sphere" You don't get to embed your sphere into every point of "4-space" just to call it "inconsistent". Why would I assume there exists a 4-space at all? Or that the default case would be somehow that a 3-dimensional object would be in 4-dimensional space, or actually anywhere else than in itself? What would that even mean without a category to make it meaningful? See, the lazy way is to scream "contradiction" each time there is something which has to be explained. The much harder way is to sit down, learn the theory, understand what the thing you're saying actually means and why it's probably not a contradiction (certainly this example isn't) and actually *think*. But who wants to do that? Particularly when you have all the answers already? Great developmental program, btw, you can really see how this contradictory philosophy spurs one to excellence! "Right now, the 3 space object is at location <0, 0, 0, ‚àÑ>, correct?" No, because I'm not automatically assuming objects are nested in each other, nevermind in undetermined locations. That's a way unwarranted assumption. "And my point is that the way to make sense of this ‚àÑ is as a contradiction first" It's only a contradiction if you first make unwarrented assumptions to make it a contradiction. Again letting your ontological assumptions dictate to the object of your study.
