  • firedog235Wed Dec 06 2023 17:17:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 "No, because I'm not automatically assuming objects are nested in each other, never-mind in undetermined locations. That's a way unwarranted assumption." Neither am I, that's not careful or correct reading of what I'm saying (which is the case for a lot of the responses at this point)... Perhaps it would be helpful if I wrote it like this <0, 0, 0>, ‚àÑ. "It's only a contradiction if you first make unwarranted assumptions to make it a contradiction. Again letting your ontological assumptions dictate to the object of your study." --- no, its the reverse, its only *not* a contradiction if you make unwarranted assumptions to make it *not* a contradiction. Before ‚àö2 can be recognized as a real it must first be recognized as a contradiction under the rationals. What is the ontological consequence of the fact that the empty theory entails self contradictory theories as models which satisfy it?

  • firedog235Wed Dec 06 2023 17:45:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (because looking at category theory, I'm happy to buy the empty theory as nothing --- to me it seems to be indifference itself or as Hegel calls it 'nothing', Its indifferent to all models, but the consequence is that this means that its indifferent also to the contradictory models, in some sense it entails the contradictory models, and the only thing that entails a contradiction is a contradiction...). The empty model however, to me, looks more like being. Its not indifferent, in fact its the strictest model in some sense (maybe its the strictest period? Not certain), it only likes degenerate theories (like ‚àÄx: x = x). Thus I would actually say that ‚àÖ:‚àÖ is becoming, not nothing (because the very idea, really notion, of this relationship between model and theory is foundational for category theory itself, as I understand it, and that notion is the becoming called category theory).

  • nameiwillforgetThu Dec 07 2023 04:50:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Neither am I, that's not careful or correct reading of what I'm saying" Well, then there's no contradiction! The contradiction you wrote was "If I put a sphere at 0, 0, 0 in 3 space then it is at all possible values of t in 4 space until I specify (determine) where it actually is in 4 space. i.e. I have a sphere with a center at multiple distinct location, i.e. a contradiction" If the sphere isn't automatically assumed to be in 4-space, then it also isn't "at all possible values in 4-space". Problem solved! One could, however, write a much clearer and more meaningful sentence: "A sphere can be embedded into ‚Ñù‚Å¥ with any possible value as its center!" Glad we got that cleared up! Though, and admittedly that's a minor nitpick, but when you claim that the sphere "is" at location " <0, 0, 0, ‚àÑ>" or "<0, 0, 0>, ‚àÑ" you're not just implicitly assuming an embedding of the sphere with the word "is" but also an embedding of 3-dimensional space into 4-dimensional space, otherwise you couldn't identify the axes of ‚Ñù¬≥ with those of ‚Ñù‚Å¥. If you don't assume that embedding, you can map the sphere at any point into ‚Ñù‚Å¥. Also, again with the poetic descriptions! "<0, 0, 0>, ‚àÑ" or <0, 0, 0, ‚àÑ> can be nicely interpreted if taken with some poetic flair, but literally it is meaningless. It is again a play to make a point, just with signs, not words. See, things like these are diabolical not because they are dumb but because they are clever. They are mere suggestions, leaving it to the mind of the reader to ascertain a meaning, like a frame in one of Doug's critical cuts, appropriate for art perhaps, but science‚Ä¶ in science, clarity *is* the art! Presentation should be a mere window through which its object can be glimpsed, at its best when it is completely transparent, *never* should it leave its meaning to the reader or allow for multiple interpretations‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetThu Dec 07 2023 04:52:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Flourishes like these speak of a mind that is too much in love with itself to prioritize clarity of presentation over displays of brilliance. Such a mind is dangerous, not least to itself. After all, what quelches the pain of merciless inquiry easier than a clever snippet?

  • nameiwillforgetThu Dec 07 2023 04:59:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "‚Ä¶but the consequence is that this means that its indifferent also to the contradictory models‚Ä¶" What is a contradictory model? A logical theory can exhibit contradiction, but what would it mean for a model? "Its not indifferent, in fact its the strictest model in some sense (maybe its the strictest period? Not certain), it only likes degenerate theories (like ‚àÄx: x = x)." Ah, it's a mathematical object, I don't think it "likes" anything. To be fair, mathematicians anthropomorphize mathematical objects too, but, again, reasoning from the likings of a thing is not exactly safe logical ground. More importantly however, the emptiness is actually a model for more than half of all axioms, namely those that start with a forall-quantifier and the empty axiom. Who would have thought the only thing nothing wouldn't fulfill is "there exists something‚Ä¶"?

  • nameiwillforgetThu Dec 07 2023 05:27:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Actually, why don't you read a bit of Lawvere? https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/2450/0d0eea4696bf53f13a9a3080054645ab77b1.pdf Most of his writings aren't particularly long and you already know a bit of category theory‚Ä¶ sure there is some time investment but if you want to get to the truth of existence that has to be expected, and it's probably not harder than making sense of a Zizek-book, and much more stringent and‚Ä¶ well, actual math and mathematical physics, iron-clad in its formalism, and learning it might steel your spirit. And at some point you might move on and read the nlab-entry of Science of Logic https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Science+of+Logic to see what Schreiber did with it‚Ä¶ and even if perhaps you don't agree with some of it as a formalization of Hegel, there is no denying its truth as mathematical theory. And it comes along with lots of useful techniques that can be applied to a variety of considerations. Plus, it comes with its own lexicon, the nlab itself, which contains most category-theoretic vocabulary. And if at some point you manage to understand it even just a bit, you'll have understood a lot because the constructions bring you fairly close to current-day physics (keep in mind that Schreiber is a string-theorist first, mathematician second and philosopher only on the side).

  • firedog235Thu Dec 07 2023 06:10:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 "Well, then there's no contradiction! The contradiction you wrote was" No what wasn't a careful reading (nor is your next reading careful either). The failure was you saying that I was assuming that items are nested in my second statement. I did assume that in the first (because I was trying to achieve simplicity and clarity but you threw that out by saying 'what about all the possible ways of fixing things' --- so by the second statement I am talking about not just the simple contradiction but the contradiction of 'all the ways to fix things, taken simultaneously, including both nesting of spaces and a lack of nesting of spaces, and setting things to zero and not setting things to zero, etc.) What I'm saying that any move I (or rather, probably you) make here is a *choice* --- whether we put it in 4 space or don't, or put it at zero, or put in 5 space. But, most importantly, its a *choice* spurred on by a contradiction (the only reason we have to make a choice is because there is a contradiction, if we didn't have a contradiction we could move smoothly through tautology to the next point). That's what I'm saying. "Flourishes like these speak of a mind that is too much in love with itself to prioritize clarity of presentation over displays of brilliance. Such a mind is dangerous, not least to itself. After all, what quelches the pain of merciless inquiry easier than a clever snippet?" I don't know anything about that, I'm too busy determining indeterminism with every word I speak... "What is a contradictory model? A logical theory can exhibit contradiction, but what would it mean for a model?" A contradictory model would be a category of axioms that when interpreted as a theory are self-contradictory but when interpreted as a model are just some stupid text. After all there is nothing that forbids treating theories as models.

  • firedog235Thu Dec 07 2023 06:17:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Ah, it's a mathematical object, I don't think it "likes" anything. To be fair, mathematicians anthropomorphize mathematical objects too, but, again, reasoning from the likings of a thing is not exactly safe logical ground." Almost makes one wonder if one is talking to a mathematician, logician, or computer scientist when one is talking to someone who like to anthropomorphize mathematical objects... But it is interesting to think of how ‚àÖ:‚àÖ might generate the natural numbers --->‚àÖ:‚àÖ -> ‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:‚àÖ) -> ‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:‚àÖ)) -> ‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:‚àÖ))), etc....

  • firedog235Thu Dec 07 2023 06:25:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "More importantly however, the emptiness is actually a model for more than half of all axioms, namely those that start with a forall-quantifier and the empty axiom. Who would have thought the only thing nothing wouldn't fulfill is "there exists something‚Ä¶"? " I think that this isn't quite it --- it would accept some axioms with there exists (as long as they are in an conditional that insures nothing ever has to actually exist)... but really I suspect its all tautological theories? But if only tautological theories are satisfied by it (if only top is satisfied by it) then that would seem to indicate it is not nothing but rather being... And its actually the empty *theory*, not model, as this strange meeting point of tautology and contradiction that stands up as nothing...

  • firedog235Thu Dec 07 2023 07:45:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I mean I can see why people don't read Lawvere --- when he was talking about '200 or so researchers in category theory' in his pamphlet he might as well have said 'and if you aren't one of them don't bother reading this'. Like we're reading hegel chapter by chapter, that pamphlet wants to be read paragraph by paragraph...

  • nameiwillforgetThu Dec 07 2023 16:21:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "No what wasn't a careful reading‚Ä¶ so by the second statement I am talking about not just the simple contradiction but the contradiction of‚Ä¶" Well, how was I supposed to know you were switching contradictions between statements? It would be a lot harder for me to "not read you carefully" if you were writing clearer. Or start side-remarks with a quotation sign and end them with a bracket. "What I'm saying that any move I (or rather, probably you) make here is a choice‚Ä¶ have to make a choice is because there is a contradiction" Granted, though I don't have to make any move at all, since I can just assume the sphere in question exists happily in itself, with the potential to be embedded in other spaces. No contradiction in sight, or at least I don't see one. " if we didn't have a contradiction we could move smoothly through tautology to the next point " We can, as far as I'm concerned! "I don't know anything about that, I'm too busy determining indeterminism with every word I speak..." I'm not sure whether to take that as an insult, but if so it does have some truth to it. It's not like I don't know the temptation of the behavior I'm describing, that's why I'm attuned to it. Still, I'm not trying to be obtuse on purpose. I'd love to explain why the quality of being indeterminate is itself determined in an iron-clad mathematical context that strips away the ambiguities of everyday language and demonstrates its statement without any ambiguity. But I'm trying to strike a balance here between the things I know, the things that can be read without much theoretical setup, the things that can be written without a latex-environment and the time I have. "A contradictory model would be a category of axioms that when interpreted as a theory are self-contradictory but when interpreted as a model are just some stupid text. After all there is nothing that forbids treating theories as models." That second part is certainly true and is how I can think‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetThu Dec 07 2023 16:25:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    of emptiness as both a model containing nothing and a theory that is completely indeterminate in that all structures are its models. However, note that those axioms you speak of are only contradictory when interpreted as a theory, as a model of some meta-theory the category of such axioms would be unremarkable‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetThu Dec 07 2023 16:46:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "Almost makes one wonder if one is talking to a mathematician, logician, or computer scientist when one is talking to someone who like to anthropomorphize mathematical objects..." Well, you mentioned before you were a computer scientist and I kept that in mind. In fact, I would not have written some things if not since I couldn't have assumed you had the vocabulary to understand them. "But it is interesting to think of how ‚àÖ:‚àÖ might generate the natural numbers --->‚àÖ:‚àÖ -> ‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:‚àÖ) -> ‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:‚àÖ)) -> ‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:(‚àÖ:‚àÖ))), etc...." Well, yes, there are two extremal possibilities, I think: one is that each successive number contains all the previous ones, as you wrote down, and one that each only contains its predecessor. But is there really much of a difference? To me it seems like both are just particular encodings of the successor function. I guess if you squint hard you can identify the first with a "cardinal" understanding saying "each set of cardinality x contains as many objects as there are numbers below x" and one "ordinal" one saying "each order whose ordinality is x is a chain as long as the chain of element inclusions into x", and their equivalence exhibits the equivalence of finite ordinals to cardinals. " think that this isn't quite it --- it would accept some axioms with there exists" That's why I said they have to start with a ‚àÄ-quantifier (or have no quantifiers, meaning it is the empty axiom): a chain like ‚àÄx:Ey‚Ä¶ is perfectly acceptable while a chain like ‚àÉx:‚àÄy‚Ä¶ assumes the existence of x and therefore can't be true if nothing exists. "but really I suspect its all tautological theories?" No, no, no, think of, say, the theory of all partial orders, or the theory of all semigroups or commutative semigroups‚Ä¶ you just can't have distinguished elements, like neutral elements or top/bottom elements‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetThu Dec 07 2023 16:46:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "And its actually the empty theory, not model, as this strange meeting point of tautology and contradiction that stands up as nothing... " Well, see, but here I'm with what you wrote above, that emptiness can be interpreted both as a model and as a theory!

  • nameiwillforgetThu Dec 07 2023 16:55:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "I mean I can see why people don't read Lawvere --- when he was talking about '200 or so researchers in category theory' in his pamphlet he might as well have said 'and if you aren't one of them don't bother reading this'. Like we're reading hegel chapter by chapter, that pamphlet wants to be read paragraph by paragraph..." I admit the amount of vocabulary is a problem. Note though that this is due to the nature of the material, Lawvere is actually trying to keep it as accessible as possible, as you can see by the clarity of his prose and the, heroic but maybe actually more confusing than clarifying, effort to avoid mathematical notation. I actually wrote an exposition of Schreiber's treatment of Hegel about 1.5 years ago that introduces all the vocabulary in itself: https://gitlab.com/nameiwillforget/nheehegel-in-mathematicshe I recently re-edited it and thought it held up fairly well, with the caveat that it is about Schreiber's interpretation (which builds on Lawvere's but isn't the same) and tries only to convey it without comment on how close it held to the original text. Also, Lawvere wrote an introductory book to category theory and adjecent areas called "Conceptual Mathematics", which can be downloaded here: https://ia801005.us.archive.org/30/items/F.WilliamLawvereStephenH.SchanuelConceptualMathematicsAFirstIntroductionToCatego/F.%20William%20Lawvere%2C%20Stephen%20H.%20Schanuel%20-%20Conceptual%20Mathematics_%20A%20First%20Introduction%20to%20Categories%20%282009%2C%20Cambridge%20University%20Press%29%20%281%29_text.pdf

  • firedog235Thu Dec 07 2023 18:16:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 "We can, as far as I'm concerned!" And I think that's really my basic point, is that we can move forward as far as you're concerned because you're operating with a foreclosure (a pinning point that covers up a contradiction) in the form of category theory created by the fact that you've already been given all these tools by history. If not for that (like if you were one of the first people to think this idea) you would have to painfully derive the idea of a category of spheres out of the contradiction (or say something like 'without loss of generality, set t = 0' and hope your audience accepts that statement), it wouldn't come immediately or naturally (which we know because even with division the Babylonians were running around without generalized division algorithms for thousands of years, because for them it was *division* which was the contradiction). "I don't know anything about that, I'm too busy determining indeterminism with every word I speak..." I'm just laughing because the pot is calling the kettle black. Don't take it as an insult though, It's a compliment. The line made me laugh when I first read it. "However, note that those axioms you speak of are only contradictory when interpreted as a theory, as a model of some meta-theory the category of such axioms would be unremarkable‚Ä¶" I'm not convinced that this true... I'm convinced the first half is true, but the second part, there's something much more interesting going on there that I wouldn't call 'unremarkable': i.e. this notion of 'model' where we don't have to interpret the text (or where we might say we have a program but we aren't forced to run it). This is, I think, the generalized form of the wrapper around contradiction (like the thing which protects from a contradiction written on paper is the paper itself, the thing which protects it in our mind is that the place which thinks the words of the contradiction is separated from the place which 'does' the contradiction). So be careful...

  • firedog235Thu Dec 07 2023 18:30:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Well, yes, there are two extremal possibilities, I think: one is that each successive number contains all the previous ones, as you wrote down, and one that each only contains its predecessor. But is there really much of a difference? To me it seems like both are just particular encodings of the successor function. I guess if you squint hard you can identify the first with a "cardinal" understanding saying "each set of cardinality x contains as many objects as there are numbers below x" and one "ordinal" one saying "each order whose ordinality is x is a chain as long as the chain of element inclusions into x", and their equivalence exhibits the equivalence of finite ordinals to cardinals." Actually I think at some point the arrow -> becomes usable and then that becomes the successor function (at which point you really are off to the races), but a more interesting question might be how do the negative numbers make their way into this: they could be packed in as every other number but I wonder if its possible to construct a theory like this (((‚àÖ:‚àÖ):‚àÖ)):‚àÖ):‚àÖ <- ((‚àÖ:‚àÖ):‚àÖ):‚àÖ) <- (‚àÖ:‚àÖ):‚àÖ) <- ‚àÖ:‚àÖ (with zero as just :‚àÖ:, i.e. as a petit objet a that fluctuates between model and theory). What ever (‚àÖ:‚àÖ) means as a theory it would have to tautological to function? I'm not saying I know what this means (if anything) just playing with symbols but I have a suspicion...

  • firedog235Thu Dec 07 2023 18:51:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "No, no, no, think of, say, the theory of all partial orders, or the theory of all semigroups or commutative semigroups‚Ä¶ you just can't have distinguished elements, like neutral elements or top/bottom elements‚Ä¶" But aren't these theories all tautological (i.e. because they lack an distinguishing base object that must exist, they're all just describing tautological moves like a‚â§a, if a‚â§b and b‚â§a, then a=b). Here I *don't* want to fetishize the fact that for normal math these things are tautological, I understand there may be a theory where a‚â§a, if a‚â§b and b‚â§a, then a=b might be false somehow when combined with other appropriate axioms... What I mean is that I'm speculating that ‚àÉx is the non-tautological move par-excellence and all of these other things are just tautology without ‚àÉx to tie them down to something less than tautology (or something more, since my big dialectical realization was that tautology and contradiction aren't the farthest concepts to each but rather the closest concepts to each other so that bottom and top are right next to each other: tautologies are always almost false --- one half the tautology is false and its only barely holding on through the other half --- and contradictions are always almost true --- same thing, one half is always true and its only barred by the other half). However, this reading maybe involves accepting or understanding that the model is an ‚àÉx (i.e. the moment you propose a model, M, every object in the model could be entered into the theory as ‚àÄO‚ààM‚àÉO, without changing the satisfaction of the theory) which then makes the empty *model* equal to tautology because if I say ‚àÑx, then I can say whatever nonsense I want about x and I'm protected (wrapper!) by the does not exist.

  • firedog235Thu Dec 07 2023 18:53:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'll take a look at that pdf, already starting it out its a much more comprehensible piece of text.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 08 2023 17:25:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "And I think that's really my basic point‚Ä¶" I'm not denying that there is historical development, or that that development often comes from the attempt to answer an open question or systematize a heuristic, what I'm saying is that those aren't contradictions, logically speaking, and I don't really know what else a contradiction is. And every once in a while there is development based on a recognized inconsistency of the old system, but that's by no means all mathematical development. "I'm convinced the first half is true, but the second part, there's something much more interesting going on there that I wouldn't call 'unremarkable" Well, I also think such meta-theories aren't unremarkable. But notice that to prove that such theories are models of a meta-theory as I outlined, one does need to check them for consistency. Consider the meta-theory consisting of one sentence: "For T [a model of the meta-theory] it holds that the there exists a sentence œÜ such that both œÜ and ¬¨œÜ can be derived from T." This can only be checked by trying to derive sentences from T and looking if for any of them one can also prove its negation. "‚Ä¶ but a more interesting question might be how do the negative numbers make their way into this" You're actually hitting on something really interesting there, which is that it seems negative numbers are impossible to categorify. To understand this note that the class of finite sets (to say it set-theoretically) with disjoint union and cartesian product on it yields addition and multiplication of natural numbers if one forgets about other set-theoretic properties (and in particular the functions between finite sets) and only considers sets up to their isomorphism class (so as equivelnt if a bijection exists between them). In category-theoretic terms this means that the category of finite sets is a categorification of the natural numbers and, inversely, that the natural numbers are a decategorification of finite sets‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 08 2023 17:34:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What's interesting now is that no similar such structure seems to exist that would be a categorification of the integers. Indeed, it is much simpler to categorify the positive rational numbers or even positive reals than negative numbers. I have my own theory about that: I think we are usually interested in negative numbers to model inputs of processes, such as the money required to do something. In category theory, a process can be identified with a morphisms ‚Üí. If one starts with a category, I hold that it is not necessary to consider negative numbers, one can just assign to each morphism a source that is a finite set and a target that is a finite set, and two morphisms f, g can be composed if and only if the source of g is equal to the target of f (or, in a more involved setup, if they overlap partially: s(g) = t(f). Note that if we decategorify this, so that s(g) and t(f) are natural numbers, corresponding to some in- and output quantities, then that means exactly that s(g) - t(f) = 0. So I kind of think if one starts with a category, then negative quantities aren't necessary anymore, since they are usually only useful to model inputs of processes that then can be assigned directly. I hope that was decently understandable.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 08 2023 17:45:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "But aren't these theories all tautological" Well, what do you mean by a theory being tautological? I thought you meant that every structure is a model for that theory. But there are lots of, say, magmas that aren't semigroups, or lots of semigroups that aren't commutative. "However, this reading maybe involves accepting or understanding that the model is an ‚àÉx (i.e. the moment you propose a model, M, every object in the model could be entered into the theory as ‚àÄO‚ààM‚àÉO," Careful there, a theory is defined relative to a signature of symbols that can be used to construct sentences from it, and the constant M corresponding to a model isn't part of that signature (at least usually it isn't and I don't think it can be). "I'll take a look at that pdf‚Ä¶" Great to hear you're open to a different perspective!

  • firedog235Fri Dec 08 2023 18:14:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 "Careful there, a theory is defined relative to a signature of symbols that can be used to construct sentences from it, and the constant M corresponding to a model isn't part of that signature (at least usually it isn't and I don't think it can be)." Well this would be a meta-theory (a theory of a theory and model together) so M doesn't exist T but that doesn't stop us from creating another theory that says there is an equivalence class on all other theory-model pairs such that Existance can be pulled into and out of T.

  • firedog235Fri Dec 08 2023 18:23:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 "What's interesting now is that no similar such structure seems to exist that would be a categorification of the integers" As I'm thinking about it more, I like (((‚àÖ:‚àÖ):‚àÖ)):‚àÖ):‚àÖ <- ((‚àÖ:‚àÖ):‚àÖ):‚àÖ) <- (‚àÖ:‚àÖ):‚àÖ) <- ‚àÖ:‚àÖ more and more as a categorification of negative, I'm just not certain of how to interpret ‚àÖ:‚àÖ as a theory opposed to a model (like ‚àÖ:‚àÖ as a mode is straightforward, its a model that contains the empty theory and empty model)... but it has the feel of something interesting to me (and its wonky like negative numbers are as well). As for ‚àÖ:‚àÖ as nothing, I would say that its not so much nothing as '0' --- which is nothing interpreted as a 'one' in philosophical speak (i.e. its both nothing and the name for nothing, which inflates it to a bit more than nothing). I think ‚àÖ: (empty theory, no model including not even the empty model) is nothing proper.

  • minimaltomFri Dec 08 2023 18:50:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    how do you feel about this? Something I gathered from Houlgates podcast. Am I right in this understanding which gets me to being vanishing into nothing? We have something in mind that 'is' such as a table. Then we subtract the thing, the table, giving us pure being but that just gives us nothing because there's nothing there anymore, therefore being has just turned into nothing. If this is correct tho I don't see how nothing goes back to being.

  • firedog235Fri Dec 08 2023 19:09:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 So based off what I'm saying, nothing goes back into being because of its indifference to itself (i.e. the empty theory is indifferent to the empty model, it will accept it or be satisfied by it). Or another way to put it that if you have 'nothing' you still have a 'one' because you have 'nothing' and nothing is indifferent to or will accept this one.

  • firedog235Fri Dec 08 2023 19:38:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think ‚àÖ:‚àÖ, interpreted as a theory might be: G‚üπ0

  • minimaltomFri Dec 08 2023 20:49:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 are you saying in other words nothing 'is' nothing so its being something (its being nothing), therefore its being?

  • firedog235Fri Dec 08 2023 21:22:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 yeah, I'm sorry I don't think I was very clear. What I got out of our discussion was that its important to think of Nothing as a totality to understand why being has to explode out of it. So if Nothing is a totality, then that means we end up with these two axioms: En (exists nothing) and ‚àÄx, n ‚â† x (this is the indifference of nothing, whatever x is, nothing isn't it) and together these imply that n ‚â† n which is a contradiction in the case where nothing is a totality (i.e. where nothing is a determination that follows the LEM). But if its a contradiction then it generates every possible thing which means that it generates being.

  • firedog235Fri Dec 08 2023 23:13:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Actually I'll take it even further... n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x) (i.e. the mere statment that nothing is indifferent is the sum total of what nothing is because it couldn't be anything else, i.e. what Alex said, this is the determination of n and that determination is *all* that n is). However, it is also the case that in fact ‚àÄx, n ‚â† x so therefore: ‚àÉn which means that n ‚â† n.

  • firedog235Fri Dec 08 2023 23:14:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x) ‚àÄx, n ‚â† x ----------- ‚àÉn, n ‚â† n

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 00:25:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    First line is ‚àÖ as theory (i.e. when you call ‚àÖ as theory a nothing, in reality you are saying that nothing is equal to this total exclusion). Second line is ‚àÖ as model (i.e. in the empty model ‚àÑx, x = n, which then negates into ‚àÄx, n ‚â† x).

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 21:55:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 "ok I will look into this but why can't you say anything that isn't in maths/logic?" I tried that and was punished "btw what is your meaning of totality here? Is it a mathmatical/logical term or a Philisophical one? Where can I read something about this this? " It's both logical and philosophical and its developed above (i.e. I'm not pulling from anyone in particular I'm just pointing out that LEM implies a totality in that it is basically saying that every determination we *already* have is sufficient to describe every possible state: we can exclude middles because we already have all possible in-between states described in our logical system: or else our logical system is contradictory in some way --- of course the actual answer, as is usually the case, is that if we have a total system, then it is contradictory because of incompleteness).

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 09 2023 22:31:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Sure, you can create another theory whose signature contains the name of M, but then M wouldn't be a model of T but of the new theory.

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 09 2023 22:33:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 By ‚àÖ:‚àÖ you mean {‚àÖ}, right? I don't see at all how "(((‚àÖ:‚àÖ):‚àÖ)):‚àÖ):‚àÖ <- ((‚àÖ:‚àÖ):‚àÖ):‚àÖ) <- (‚àÖ:‚àÖ):‚àÖ) <- ‚àÖ:‚àÖ" is a categorification of "the negative", but whatever.

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 09 2023 22:37:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "En (exists nothing) and ‚àÄx, n ‚â† x" Well, that would be a contradiction, "totality" or not, but in that case you couldn't apply it to ZFC because in ZFC an object exists that is "nothing", namely the empty set ‚àÖ. If you use ‚àÖ itself as a model though, the first axiom isn't fulfilled: nothing might certainly exist, but it doesn't exist *in* nothing, so again you don't arrive at a contradiction and can't magically create all of everything from nothing.

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 09 2023 22:40:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Well, except that a theory can't make statements about itself. Furthermore, if "nothing as a theory" would be "n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x)", then it wouldn't have an axiom and thus would not be the empty theory. You gotta make up your mind, either "nothing" is the empty theory, in which case it doesn't make any assumptions about its models, or it is a theory that contains a sentence, in which case the identification with ‚àÖ from ZFC falls apart.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 22:45:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Actually I think I can put this in category theoretic terms... If T1:M1 and T2:M1 then T1 and T2 are often termed 'consistent' --- this makes sense for example (‚àÄx, x = 2):{2} and (‚àÄx, x even):{2} are consistent with each other. A futher point is that when we merge these theories we also get a consistent theory --- i.e. [(‚àÄx, x = 2), (‚àÄx, x even)] is a totally happy and self-consistent theory. However for ‚àÖ, n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x) :‚àÖ and ‚àÄx, n ‚â† x :‚àÖ which means that [n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x) , ‚àÄx, n ‚â† x] *should* be consistent... but it isn't. This is the inconsistency of ‚àÖ stated in category theoretic terms.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 22:45:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (Sorry M1 and M2 where just supposed to be M1 above, edited)

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 22:48:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I should Make the first line better ‚àÄn, n nothing (n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x))

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 22:50:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Actually I don't think I need that last edit --- its okay to state an equality without triggering it.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 22:50:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The problem is that the merged theory ends up triggering the equality

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 22:54:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Or to put it another way --- there is no *Complete* *Consistent* theory of nothing.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 22:56:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    No, I'm misusing that... but it has something to do with implications and specifically with a different move --- the idea of dragging existence and non-existence through between model and theory

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 09 2023 22:57:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Take your time, no need to hurry

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:01:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Because I can say that because ‚àÑx, x = n:‚àÖ there's a kind of equivalence class such that ‚àÖ = ‚àÑx, x = n. Meaning that it should be the case that I can go n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x):‚àÑx, x = n ... which is inconsistent. Its about the simultaneous movement through the ':' barrier and equivalent consistency of theories on a single model that causes the contradiction.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:01:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And I don't think this applies to, for example, the {2} case

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:02:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ‚àÑx, x = n being equal to (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x)

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 09 2023 23:05:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Well, basically, yes, though he might have written introduction books that use a simpler language, but when he'd develop his theory itself I'm hoping at least he'd use strict vocabulary. Also note how often Hegel uses mathematical expressions or references mathematics throughout the book, we'll see a lot of that going forward. But formalization is also important because it removes ambiguity, so even if it's not clear what Hegel was saying, we can at least make clear what we are thinking Hegel is saying and trace the differences in that. For me, a lot of the Hegelese that has come up in the last century is a kind of defensive reaction to the analytics' dismissal of Hegel by taking things that I regard as cumbersome necessities for formulating his theory in his time and going "yeah, that's right, and that's what's good about them!". Like, "yeah, it doesn't make sense, and that's why it's actually genius!" or "yeah, it's logically incoherent, and that's why it's a theory of everything!".

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 09 2023 23:06:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 As I like to quip, Hegel called his book "Science of Logic", not "Heuristics for Politics", which most Marxists seem to want to view it as. But I'm trying my hardest to not use challenging vocabulary in general. This discussion though is about minutiae that with a cursory glance seem plausible strung together to reach metaphysical conclusions so we really have to go through them with a fine tooth come.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:13:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Okay, I think what I need is theory which contains a rule for what I'm going to call a 'total' theory as opposed to a 'complete' theory. A total theory is a theory where every implication from the axioms of the theory is forced into the the theory (so rather than every statement being provable, every statement occurs on the theory side of T:M). And then the point is that there is no Total consistent theory of ‚àÖ which contains all the satisfying theories of ‚àÖ which in terms of predictability I don't think applies to {2} (i.e. there is some kind of determination there).

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:15:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Let's say we would want to prove this over first order predicate logic: certainly its the case there (already proven).

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:15:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (for ‚àÖ, not for {2}, I *speculate* about {2} but not certain) --- or maybe there simply is no such thing as a total consistent theory (which would be interesting in its own right).

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 09 2023 23:21:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "A total theory is a theory where every implication from the axioms of the theory is forced into the the theory (so rather than every statement being provable, every statement occurs on the theory side of T:M)." This actually exists in discourse among logicians. I think it's called the *syntactic closure* of a theory T: you start with T, then add every logical interference from the axioms in T to . Note that is often not recursively enumerable though, or, in other words, often there can't exist an algorithm that lists every axiom in . This is basically a restatement of the incompleteness theorem. "And then the point is that there is no Total consistent theory of ‚àÖ which contains all the satisfying theories of ‚àÖ" Sure there is: simply list every sentence A of every signature S without constants such that A doesn't start with an existence quantifier ‚àÉx:‚Ä¶ . Those are infinitely many sentences, but I think the set in question is even recursively enumerable in the sense that you can write an algorithm that if running for infinitely long produces every such sentence at some point.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:33:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It might be recursively enumerable but my point is that if you list these sentences you end up with an existence anyway because of the statement: ‚àÄn, n nothing (n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x)) --- I think I can also list it without the for all (i.e. because it is an if and only if without a claim to existence it would satisfy ‚àÖ) so that the syntactic closure of ‚àÖ would have to include ‚àÉn, n ‚â† n.

  • nameiwillforgetSat Dec 09 2023 23:37:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I feel like I'm having trouble with your notation. When you write "‚àÄn, n nothing (n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x))", do you mean "For all n, if n is nothing, then n is equal to the set of all x that aren't equal to n"? Do I parse that correctly?

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:39:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Yeah

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:54:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hmmm, still a problem. Its because you can include some ‚àÉ if you protect them. So If I take this statement and unroll it a bit: (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x) -> ‚àÉn and (‚àÉx, n = x) -> ‚àÑn... Okay, I know what's going on here -- if you perform your syntactic closure *and* you add to that closure the notion that n = ‚àÖ (i.e. you add the determination of indetermineness) then it falls apart: i.e. its syntactic closure over ‚àÖ + n = ‚àÖ that equals a contradictory theory. (I think that the statement would have to be withdrawn as satisfying because both sides of the negation end up have an existence in them if you re-kerjigger them). My problem is that Hegel is trying to come up with syntactic closure for being so that means that this determination of indeterminateness has to be included on the theory side or else what he's saying doesn't make sense, however, it also means that what he's saying doesn't make sense unless you accept contradictions as real objects that can be manipulated in the theory.

  • firedog235Sat Dec 09 2023 23:55:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (or really n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x))

  • firedog235Sun Dec 10 2023 00:09:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Actually its just the statement n = (‚àÄx, n ‚â† x) which is contradictory, unless n ‚â† n

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 10 2023 00:32:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 So n here is supposed to function both as a theory and as a structure, correct? As a theory, given by a set of axioms, it contains only one, which says that "For all x it holds that x is not equal to n". So first off, let's note that generally speaking, you can't have a theory with axioms that refer to the theory. Otherwise, you can form theories like the theory T consisting of one axiom "T does not apply to this model". If you do that, then T applies to any model it doesn't apply to. In other words, you can reformulate the liar's paradox. But you could still try to apply T to the empty set. But for the sentence above to be a sentence, n would have to be a constant, and if the theory contains a constant, it can't apply to the empty set because the constant has to be mapped to something (I was actually slightly wrong before when I said that "emptiness" is a model for any theory that doesn't contain axioms that start with an existence quantifier, sorry, the theory can't be in a signature that contains any constants, because those would always have to be mapped to elements in a model per definition of an interpretation"). Finally though, if n is the empty set, it can't as a theory, contain a sentence, because that would be an element of n and therefore n couldn't be the empty set. So I think you have several problems with this.

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 10 2023 00:34:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Well, I'm not against treating contradictions as objects, the question is objects in what context? A natural number is not the same thing as a real number is not the same thing as a model is not the same thing as a sentence is not the same thing as a contradiction. All of these are objects *in some context* but each time the context is different.

  • firedog235.Sun Dec 10 2023 01:02:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Well, even as not a theory but an element in a model with first order predicate logic as the theory --- it causes an explosion

  • firedog235.Sun Dec 10 2023 01:09:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But I agree the context matters

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 10 2023 22:29:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 If you only understand them "on some level", then I'd say rather say ignore them completely. Part of why I'm doing this is because it's very easy to be misguided by something that sounds plausible. I'd rather you avoid all of that than take in something you don't really understand because it sounds good and maybe supports your ideological preconceptions. I don't expect *Science of Logic* to be immediately politically relevant any more than I would expect a biology textbook to be: of course you should have biologists in your movement, and logicians alike, but a training in either won't tell you how to build a socialist movement. I'm following this reading group because I'm personally interested, attempts like Badiou's to "prove" revolution are anathema to me, as they cheapen both theoretical and political work. Insofar as *SoL*'s usefulness for the left is concerned it is mostly because Marx read him and thus subsequent Marxists did, so it might be easier to read their works with it in the background, but the work itself I don't think is useful in anything but explaining logic and setting up later thinking of Hegel, and we all know Hegel was a full-throated supporter of the nation state, so it doesn't seem his logic made his politics particularly secure.

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 10 2023 22:34:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 "I need more of a ‚Äúwe can do it‚Äù attitude that‚Äôs rooted in serious logical rigour, otherwise I would be railing against capitalists, rather than trying to change capitalism. This is probably the best lesson I‚Äôve learned from Cutrone. Though the party fucking hates Adorno üòÇ" This though makes me question what you learned from Cutrone. We've had "Yes we Can" for 16 years now. What makes you think you can transcend capitalism? Why would your party not simply be another funnel siphoning up the hopes and efforts of its members to continue an elaborate pyramid scheme? If we're gonna talk Cutrone, let's talk Cutrone: "Workers are seldom in the position to indulge in the enthusiasms of true belief. But the Left are nothing if not true believers‚Äî they can afford their illusions, however disposable they prove to be, blown from one passing fad to the next. The working class knows the difference between entertainment and real life. The Left are hucksters ‚Äî who are themselves the most easily bamboozled. But socialism will not be a swindle ‚Äî that is, if it is not merely another capitalist ideology. ‚ÄúSocialism‚Äù today is just that, what Marx criticized ruthlessly as a pernicious illusion of capitalism by another name." [Dogmatization and Thought Taboos on the "Left"] Why would that not apply to your party? Do you think he was only talking about woke college kids? Consider this though: maybe it's just currently not possible to transcend capitalism. Maybe it will never be again. Maybe the moment has passed or maybe there never was actually a moment. The greatest thing the socialist movement could do was flip a backward aristocracy, not very impressive on the global scale of things. And Cutrone will openly say that, btw. He'll say that maybe there never was an opportunity. He *thinks* there was, but he doesn't know. Nobody knows. And he'll also say that maybe he's doing now theory for people forty years down the line, like Adornos message in a bottle‚Ä¶

  • nameiwillforgetSun Dec 10 2023 22:37:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I've personally misled people by convincing them to vote for Bernie. I'll eat some crow for that, unlike pretty much everyone of the public speakers of that movement. I funneled their efforts into a movement that only used them to re-establish capitalist politics. I made a mistake. But this is going to repeat. Again and again. With the same rationality: well, we gotta do something! We have to try this thing, or that thing or whatever. Have we thought about if any of them work? No, but, "we can do it!". If we only believe hard enough we can make it happen. I'm with Benjamin Studebaker: to move forward, we have to first embrace the despair of the current moment.

  • nameiwillforgetMon Dec 11 2023 01:23:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 "Embracing the despair how though?" There was a quick moment of reflection there. It's a shame to see it immediately closed off by arguments. "Bear in mind that Chris and Benjamin are not politically active." That's not true. Cutrone has started the Campaign for a Socialist Party. He just keeps it separate from his intellectual work. "My party has comrades in it all over the world. You think I‚Äôm going to stop supporting them because Benjamin Studebaker says so? Should I tell my comrades in Haiti to ‚Äúembrace the dispair‚Äù?" Why do you think communism doesn't hold much sway in the developing world? Could it be that those people have been sold false hope once too often. "Irregardless of all this blather though, the number 1 rule is standing with the oppressed. It just is." You'd actually owe it particularly to the most oppressed to have a sober understanding of the situation and put some thought into how to fix it. "I would caution against developing your mental fortitude before engaging with any political organization." We certainly take very different things from Cutrone.

  • nameiwillforgetMon Dec 11 2023 01:36:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 To answer the question though: terrible things are going to happen and there will be nothing we can do about it for the longest time. A political organization that could seriously threaten capitalism will need a lot of time to be build, years at least, probably decades. Embracing the despair means that you have to be clear about that the work you're putting into politics might not pay off in your lifetime or might never pay off and not falling to blind actionism, which is usually counterproductive. What we need to do is basically develop a parallel society in which participation carries an advantage for the individual. On a social level, as opposed to an intellectual one, this will have to start by solving immediate social problems and will have to remain isolated from polarized political issues for some time. Though concrete crisis points will be unpredictable, the large-scale trends that will trigger crises, such as climate change are somewhat predictable, so they can be planned for. Apart from that, Cutrone noted that a lot of immediate work will not look like political work at all and that one of the first things we need to do is get some perspective on the working class and what it actually thinks by, basically, hanging out with that, and Derick Varn would note that Lenin already recommended having a working understanding of all social classes, what they think and how they are motivated, and, again, that can only be had by having met them.

  • dve.h_37844Mon Dec 11 2023 01:42:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    No I mean, the party IS where you learn. That is its purpose. I‚Äôm just cautioning against joining something before you have a stance on it. You should do both at once imo because that‚Äôs the point of the party for the working class. Trotsky said that all one needs is the desire for socialism to be a socialist. If you‚Äôve got that, you should join. Don‚Äôt beat yourself up for making mistakes or not knowing enough because that‚Äôs gonna keep happening.

  • minimaltomMon Dec 11 2023 15:55:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Im just reading vol 1 of Houlgate's "Hegel on Being" and Im pretty surprised to learn that according to him Hegel thinks that the categories are acquired through language and as babies before we learn language we only perceive light impressions through our senses that aren't conceptualised as objects yet. "initially the child has only a sensation of light by which things are manifested to it." (EPM 56 / 80 [¬ß 396 A]) To me, if this is the case, this seems like a sharp distinction from Kant who Id assumed thought we were primordially equipped with categories and concepts of space and time such that we would perceive something we see as an object as soon as we opened our eyes. Also that language is of such fundamental importance to Hegel too seems to lend credit to the linguistic turn in the 20th century.

  • minimaltomMon Dec 11 2023 16:04:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Personally I actually find it a bit far fetched üòÑ I find it hard to believe babies dont have some concepts pre-language because they show clear signs of intelligence and comprehension before they can speak, at least verbal communication anyway.

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 13:30:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This is an example of a sentence that I think could be more clearly expressed in a neat logical expression. "Nothing is usually opposed to something; but the being of something is already determinate and is distinguished from another something; and so therefore the nothing which is opposed to the something is also the nothing of a particular something, a determinate nothing."

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 14:27:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 <@638122715668152320> Hegel says in the first remark of Being that in the words non-being and nothing "both being and its negation are enunciated in a single term". But he also says "as it is in becoming" which is not true. Is this a translation thing? Does the word werden (translated to becoming) contain being and its negation?

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 18:26:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I don't see any remarks on being. Do you think the first remark on becoming? Here is a sentence that kind of sounds like what you wrote:!!

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 18:27:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Wollte man es f√ºr richtiger halten, da√ü statt des Nichts dem Sein das Nichtsein entgegengesetzt w√ºrde, so w√§re in R√ºcksicht auf das Resultat nichts dawider zu haben, denn im Nichtsein ist die Beziehung auf das Sein enthalten; es ist beides, Sein und die Negation desselben, in einem ausgesprochen, das Nichts, wie es im Werden ist."

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:27:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    oh sorry I meant becoming yes

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:28:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    thats the one i think, first paragraph of the 1st remark

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 18:29:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Translated by me: If one wanted to oppose being with notbeing instead of nothing, then that would not be objectionable from the perspective of the result, for in notbeing is the relation to being contained, both being and its negation are pronounced in one, nothing as it is in becoming.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 18:29:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    That's the third sentence though.

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:30:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Oh!! thats different to the miller translation!

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:30:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Should it be held more correct to oppose to being, non-being instead of nothing, there would be no objection to this so far as the result is concerned, for in non-being the relation to being is contained: both being and its negation are enunciated in a single term, nothing, as it is in becoming."

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:30:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    oh actually no its similar

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:31:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think i misread. üò©

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 18:31:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Oh ok

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:31:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    thanks anyway

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 18:31:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    No problem

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:36:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    its this bit that threw me "both being and its negation are enunciated in a single term, nothing, as it is in becoming." I thought hes saying being and its negation are contained in the word nothing, as they are also in the word becoming.

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:37:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    as in no-thing, the thing and its negation

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 18:41:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ok I think I get it now. Being and its negation are contained in the 'word' nothing (and non-being) as they are also contained in the 'concept' becoming, not the word becoming.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 19:02:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Well, they are contained in the word notbeing, which means literally the negation of being, they are not contained in the word nothing

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 19:03:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 I guess, if you dont take the word thing as synonomous to being

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 19:05:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I guess not, thing is closer to something, so nothing is more like something and its negation

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 19:05:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 In German, the word nothing is "nichts", not "no-thing"

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 19:05:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    nichts just means not right?

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 19:06:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yes, the closest in English would be "nots": not and an s as an objectivication

  • minimaltomFri Dec 15 2023 19:07:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    right so nichts has no being in it

  • nameiwillforgetFri Dec 15 2023 19:07:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Yes

  • minimaltomSun Dec 24 2023 03:04:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    As I said at the end, although I got it a bit muddled, I still think there may be a subtle difference between Becoming and Determinate Being. I think Determinate being is Becoming taken in its immediacy. Becoming is dynamic whereas Determinate Being is Becoming taken as being fixed by the understanding.

  • minimaltomSun Dec 24 2023 03:06:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    this is a quote from BURBIDGE, RELIGION, supra note 22, at 22 (Determinate Being "is an immediate concept whose mediating 'becoming' has disappeared from view").

  • dve.h_37844Sun Dec 24 2023 04:37:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    That sounds about right to me.

  • minimaltomSun Dec 24 2023 13:32:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    in fact, in the 3rd paragraph of 'Determinate Being' Hegel says so himself ¬ß 191 From becoming there issues determinate being, which is the simple oneness of being and nothing. Because of this oneness it has the form of immediacy. Its mediation, becoming, lies behind it; it has sublated itself and determinate being appears, therefore, as a first, as a starting-point for the ensuing development. It is first of all in the one-sided determination of being; the other determination, nothing, will likewise display itself and in contrast to it.

  • minimaltomSun Dec 24 2023 13:40:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    the way I'm seeing it atm is that becoming is the third term in the dialectic of Being, it has to change to Determinate Being in order to become the first term of the next dialectic, Determinate being. Each dialectic starts out with something immediate and is sublated to something mediated through Reason, it has to again be taken as fixed and immediate by the understanding to become the first term in the next dialectic. The book thats really helped me to see it this way is David Gray Carlson - A Commentary on Hegel's Science of Logic which is where I got the bromian knot diagrams.

    üìé Carlson.A_Commentary_on_Hegels_Science_of_Logic_2007.pdf?ex=680e33d0&is=680ce250&hm=d20234228407d01e36229877c63ac99b28c48269ea818118eb879d259110a29d&

  • minimaltomSun Dec 24 2023 15:39:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I havent read the whole book BTW only most of the first chapter on Being Nothing Becoming so far

  • dve.h_37844Sun Dec 24 2023 17:13:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    A lot more popped out at me, or made sense, about the first three paragraphs after the discussion. The rest kind of flowed for me once I really understood what Hegel was talking about, or rather when I understood how he wanted me to think.

  • minimaltomSun Dec 24 2023 17:28:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 Which three paragraphs you talking about?

  • dve.h_37844Sun Dec 24 2023 17:35:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 The first three. I heard Terry Pinkard once say about philosophy that it‚Äôs like trying to find your way around a room that you can‚Äôt see in. And so Hegel starts in the dark room, with nothing, and then shows you how to make something out of nothing. For me the difference between nothing and being is the first important step, then the next step is to realize that even in understanding that there is a difference, it doesn‚Äôt actually get you anywhere. Difference just kind of is. And so you have to speculate that they‚Äôre the same. And in so doing you realize they‚Äôre the same and different and that this still doesn‚Äôt get you anywhere. So finally you have to arrive at the conclusion, out of necessity, that they‚Äôre related in becoming their opposite because they‚Äôre the same. That it‚Äôs really becoming - what we call determinate being, or being that is arrived at through the process of logical thought, that is the grounding for knowing anything. And so with that confidence you can begin to think, or feel your way out of the room.

  • minimaltomMon Dec 25 2023 00:09:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 First three of which chapter? üòÑ

  • dve.h_37844Mon Dec 25 2023 02:07:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 1. I‚Äôm not skipping ahead.

  • minimaltomMon Dec 25 2023 18:14:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 Oh I see being nothing and becoming üëç

  • minimaltomWed Dec 27 2023 11:47:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 thats pretty good but also I think at this point we can only have a fairly vague understanding of what Hegel totally means til we read through the whole book and then maybe come back and fill in the gaps which could probably be a lifes work.

  • minimaltomWed Dec 27 2023 14:14:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    also, I havent read much Marx at all but already I feel like through this reading I see Marx in a different way that helps me understand him so much better.

  • dve.h_37844Wed Dec 27 2023 15:21:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I don‚Äôt doubt it. You could read Marx‚Äôs critique of Hegel‚Äôs philosophy of right. Or The Poverty of Philosophy(critique of Proudhon) to get a better idea of where he‚Äôs coming from before he starts writing capital.

  • actualvargasThu Dec 28 2023 14:51:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Or his 1844 Manuscripts. üòâ

  • firedog235Fri Dec 29 2023 06:20:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 <@476561351167311872> One thing came up in the stream about materialism vs. idealism that I didn't have time to address --- I was not saying that materialism = an infinitely growing and complex list of meditations that make contact with the thing in itself impossible. Rather, that is an idealist send-up of the materialist point I was making: that you do reach a point where you are no longer mediating but that point is a pure contradiction. The difference between the first and second being that the mediating list assumes that there is always a further mediation to grant meaning and connection to the previous signifiers in the chain, while in what I was saying there is a terminating contradiction which is meaningless in its content (because it is a contradiction) and which causes the whole chain to lose its quality of meaning --- i.e. in the idealist send up we have 'everything is caused by something else' *period* while in the actual materialist structure you end up with 'everything is caused by something else, except the contradiction'. That is what is meant, for me at least, by the phrase 'the contradiction is the thing-in-itself' --- there is no thing-in-itself, we slam into a contradictory oscillation, as opposed to the idealist send up which still assumes a non-contradictory thing-in-itself in the very process of its infinite mediating chain (i.e. the mediating chain attempts to prove that we actually are totally cut off from the thing-in-itself in that it has no impact on the rest of the chain: however we do contact it in the form of a contradiction). This was the disagreement that Alex and I were having about completeness, contradiction, and totality --- my claim was that if you encounter such an infinite mediating chain then you are dealing with a contradiction and you're allowed to say as much.

  • dve.h_37844Sun Jan 21 2024 16:51:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Thought I'd put this here for fun: https://www.sublationmag.com/post/the-poverty-of-philosophy-what-class-might-mean-today

  • dve.h_37844Tue Jan 23 2024 16:01:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    How is Chapter 2 coming for folks reading it in the Zoom group with Doug?

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 16:19:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 I found it almost impossible to read chapter 2 on its own so Im reading Houlgates chapter on it in his book Hegel on Being Vol.1.

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 16:22:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    For one thing he points out that there is a difference between Determinate Being as such and Quality. Determinate being as such is being in the form of non-being and quality is non-being in the from of being.

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 16:23:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    also he claims that Being is being when it is in becoming but when becoming changes into determinate being, being becomes non-being instead.

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 16:24:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    and that becoming is not fully sublated until it turns into determinate being. In becoming being and nothing are continuously vanishing into each other, when it turns to Determinate Being the vanishing disappears and becoming settles into a simple oneness.

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 16:25:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    How are you finding it?

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 16:28:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    if anyone wants the Houlgate book PDF I can share it

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 16:29:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    if it werent for his book id be totally lost

  • actualvargasTue Jan 23 2024 16:40:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Please DM me it if you‚Äôd like.

  • dve.h_37844Tue Jan 23 2024 16:44:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm on A - Determinate being as such. Haven't found it too terribly difficult yet. But we'll see how I do on B and C. What I determined from the first chapter was that the flow of the book is actually supposed to make you feel lost, since he's walking you through how to think. And so I've kind of embraced the void. I also re-read Marx's 18th Brumaire this month in preparation for a short speech that I gave on Lenin's Rights of Nations to Self Determination. As the Platypus pedagogues have pointed out numerous times, understanding the dialectic of the revolutionary party and the working class is extremely important in helping us all understand capitalism's "freedom problem" and how we might solve it. So, I've made it my duty to get a firm grasp on dialectical thinking and, tbh, it's really paying off; I leave the wittiest comments imaginable on Gabriel Rockhill videos now!

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 16:48:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 wittiest comments üòÇ

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 16:49:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 I would rather argue that its supposed to be understandable, as Houlgate says in this chapter I'm reading "Nonetheless, despite its abstractness, Hegel‚Äôs account of quality and determinate being is clear and precise."

  • actualvargasTue Jan 23 2024 17:21:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    If anything Hegel is always very precise. Just also incredibly verbose about it.

  • dve.h_37844Tue Jan 23 2024 18:44:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Well, my answer to that would be the *feeling* of being lost, or, being in a necessary meditative state, while reading the chapter is an outcome of Hegels‚Äô precision, with one caveat: it need not be outside of the academy (in which he taught).

  • dve.h_37844Tue Jan 23 2024 18:58:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Like, his descriptions are great. But that doesn‚Äôt mean getting the point is going to be easy. The book was designed to teach logic through the act of rigorous thinking. It‚Äôs a weird thing to read in a capitalist society post-Marx. But if we understand how to historically place it, then we can get some insight into why this was necessary for the society that Hegel thought he was living in, and take it seriously.

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 19:10:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 I agree with you to an extent, not sure what you mean about it being outside the academy?

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 19:12:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Its certainly not easy but it can be made easier by having a firm foundation in German idealism I think (something I havent got) and I believe its sensible to read other peoples interpretations too, otherwise its like reinventing the wheel!

  • dve.h_37844Tue Jan 23 2024 19:16:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Oh, I just mean because the book is academic in nature, it‚Äôs going to naturally try to prove something as precisely as possible. If you want to understand the nature of reality in other ways, or how to be in the world, you don‚Äôt need Hegel for that.

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 19:19:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 I agree in a way. I totally think you can deepen your understanding of his writing away from it through letting it seep into you. I don't think Hegel claimed he wanted to show how to be in the world necessarily tho.

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 19:20:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He wants to understand it scientifically, not so much spiritually, in our sense of that word anyway

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 19:21:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think you do need Hegel to forge a socialist society tho, no amount of meditation is going to achieve that

  • minimaltomTue Jan 23 2024 19:27:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I practice zen meditation daily also, I think that and reading Hegel compliment each other incredibly actually

I think less about how I feel because I spend more time reading and writing - in fact it's kind of fucked up my daily practice and I do it maybe two or three times a week now haha
