  • dve.h_37844Sat Jan 27 2024 21:52:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    > ¬ß 240 > > 3. Being-for-other is the indeterminate, affirmative community of something with its other; in the limit the non-being-for-other becomes prominent, the qualitative negation of the other, which is thereby kept apart from the something which is reflected into itself. We must observe the development of this Notion, which manifests itself, however, rather as an entanglement and a contradiction. This contradiction is at once to be found in the circumstance that the limit, as something's negation reflected into itself, contains ideally in it the moments of something and other, and these, as distinguished moments, are at the same time posited in the sphere of determinate being as really, qualitatively distinct.

  • dve.h_37844Sat Jan 27 2024 21:53:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ^Where he defines "contradiction" in relation to "limit" Side note: I think there is something to his use of the word "reflection", I wonder what the German word that is being used there is?

  • dve.h_37844Sat Jan 27 2024 21:53:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Good talk guys!

  • nameiwillforgetSat Jan 27 2024 22:17:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 That's not really a definition of contradiction though, just an instance of it

  • nameiwillforgetSat Jan 27 2024 22:17:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He used contradiction a few times in the text already, but I don't think he defined it

  • firedog235Sat Jan 27 2024 22:17:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So this is the important line for resolution vs. contradiction for me --- its section 252 (Hegel doesn't quite 'define' contradiction, but there is a development here): "With this nothing, however, which is supposed to be only nothing, and which at the same time is granted an existence in thought, imagination or speech, there occurs the same contradiction as has just been indicated in connection with the finite, but with this difference, that in the case of that first nothing it only occurs, whereas in finitude it is explicitly stated. There it appears as subjective; here it is asserted that the finite stands perpetually opposed to the infinite, that what is in itself null is, and is as in itself null. We have to become conscious of this; and the development of the finite shows that, having this contradiction present within it, it collapses within itself, yet in doing so actually resolves the contradiction, that not only is the finite transitory and ceases to be, but that the ceasing-to-be, the nothing, is not the final determination, but itself ceases to be." He goes on in the infinite to develop this dialectic of contradiction and resolution --- as far as I can tell contradiction appears in resolution and resolution is a taking up of the contradiction as a positive object at every step he performs this operation.

  • nameiwillforgetSat Jan 27 2024 22:19:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 The German word is "reflected" as well

  • nameiwillforgetSat Jan 27 2024 22:19:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Reflektiert

  • firedog235Sat Jan 27 2024 22:20:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It does seem to indicate that he thinks contradiction ‚äÜ nullity?

  • firedog235Sat Jan 27 2024 22:21:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (whatever nullity is)

  • firedog235Sat Jan 27 2024 22:24:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Also the logic of the democrats as armor --- is very interesting to me because I feel like the response might actually be 'yes but the point of defeating the armor (obstacle) is not *to become* the armor but rather to figure out how to disolve it'. The guy wasn't wrong in thinking that we need to *something* about the democrats (or that the path forward must run *through* the democrats) but 'runs through' is maybe meant to be like in the phrase 'a sword runs through armor'.

  • firedog235Sat Jan 27 2024 22:36:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Derp sorry, I meant nullity ‚äÜ contradiction

  • nameiwillforgetWed Jan 31 2024 22:14:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I mean, that was what the Bernie campaigns were supposed to be: a single concentrated attack that would cut through the armor. But we ended up becoming the armor instead. What should we do differently? It's hard to say, and I think we're far from actually mounting any considerable attack on capitalism at the moment, but I'll just say what Cutrone and also Studebaker like to say about these things, which is that even if we, as independent socialists, would see it necessary to participate in politics through the two party system, it would necessarily be one that runs candidates in both parties.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Jan 31 2024 22:15:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Well, I'll just highlight again that a point is not nothing. It's far from nothing, in fact, being, well, a point.

  • firedog235Sun Feb 04 2024 23:47:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Or, nothing contains it as a constituent element (as one if its internal limits and determinations)

  • firedog235Sun Feb 04 2024 23:49:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (I think one of the difficulties now is that whenever I see 'x is not y' these days I always read it as 'x is the limit (negative determination) of y) meaning that x ends up included into the defintion and structure of y through the very move of 'is not'.

  • firedog235Sun Feb 04 2024 23:52:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 So I don't think this breaks the original metaphore, just that we have to see that the bernie campaign wasn't what we thought it was... the problem was that there was no sword to stab through the armor of the democrats at the time of the campaign (bernie as a personality notwithstanding --- he wasn't such a sword himself). Such a sword, in my thinking, is the worker's firm directed by the worker's party (which didn't and still doesn't exist). So yeah, the metaphore breaks down if instead of using a sword you just like... hit it with a hammer.

  • andru0358Mon Feb 05 2024 20:37:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The original point with saying that Hegel does not define contradiction what that contradiction is not a moment of the movement of Logic. It's either considered not necessary for the movement or not yet able to be elaborated. Or both. The whole idea of building a metaphysics of contradiction seems bizarre to me; contradictions are extremely mediated by what are in contradiction. It feels like a distraction, adding confusion, and fools errand to try to be defining contradiction. The passage you quote as "developing" contradiction, it says is a repitition of the contradiction of Being and Nothing, in chap 1; and the word nullity on German is "Nichtiges", adjective of night, nothing. Both "contradictions" he says are of the understanding; that is being *appears* rigidly separate from nothing. Finite "stands perpetually opposed to the infinite"; if you read it in context, he is saying with the last sentence that the understanding is wrong in perpetually opposing them. That the contradiction is subjective, for us, for the understanding. Anyway. It's just not about contradiction it's about finitude.

  • andru0358Mon Feb 05 2024 20:40:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Nothing does not have constituent elements or limits or determinations.

  • andru0358Mon Feb 05 2024 20:42:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think all this just demonstrates how misguided it is to translate Hegels text into other ideas. He's not "bad poet" like Thomas said. He is extremely precise and it simply takes the discipline to *not* introduce pre-conecieved ideas into his text in order to understand it

  • andru0358Mon Feb 05 2024 20:42:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The idea of "reading" it a certain way is contrary to the very point of the book

  • andru0358Tue Feb 06 2024 17:46:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    If there's any representation thought of contradiction, it seems like it would be the unity of opposites; the dialectic of opposition as not rigidly separate but also not identical, united and different. And in this unity, a becoming of a third. The unity of Being and Nothing become existence; and similarly in repitition, we the Something and Other are united in Being-for-itself. In the shorter logic, he says "Being-for-itself ... As the relation of the negative to itself it is a being that is for itself, the One"; he goes on to discuss it as "the One", "it does not relate as something does to other but instead, as the unity of something and an other". This unity creates contradiction for the understanding because looking at the opposition as such, their unity seems impossible. But their opposition is sublated in the unity, it's still there, but not visible. I think to translate it into set theory or something is not only to mediate it from outside; it also, to me seems to be trying to flatten it in a single understanding. To use a spacial metaphor; I think the understanding is like a 2 dimensional snapshot, and dialectics is trying to understand things in 3 dimensions. So we see a couple 2-d images and see things which appear contradictory and have to Reason into the depth, the third dimension, to see how the contradiction is only apparent, ie resolves

  • nameiwillforgetTue Feb 06 2024 21:39:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Lawvere treated the issue of unities of opposites: https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Aufhebung However, he doesn't require contradictions. This goes to the fact that opposites aren't contradictions. Warm and cold are opposites but an object can be both warm and cold at the same time. Two points of a line are opposite to each other but unified in the line. This is already formally strictly described by Lawvere's formalism. No, a contradiction is in fact more similar to a boundary: an unstable point at which two things that generically exclude each other are momentarily existent at the same time. My go-to example are the vacuum states of the universe: it is not a given that our vacuum is a global energy minimum. At each moment, a piece of spacetime could reach a lower vacuum through quantum fluctuations. In this case, the resulting lower vacuum would either collapse almost immediately or spread with near light speed and destroy everything in its path.

  • nameiwillforgetTue Feb 06 2024 21:40:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Also, forget set theory, category theory is Hegel's domain!

  • andru0358Tue Feb 06 2024 23:52:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I definitely do think this is what Hegel is doing. The attempt to translate his system into formal concepts defeats the point to me; however interesting it might be for some as an intellectual exercise. I just don't get it, what is the attraction??

  • andru0358Tue Feb 06 2024 23:55:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The problem with boundary is that there is no boundary between finite and infinite. I can elaborate my understanding of that section later; I have no idea how one would capture it in formalism. To me, formalism is always in the realm of Understanding. Reason has left the picture, however necessary it was to develop the formalism; it is now a static system

  • andru0358Tue Feb 06 2024 23:57:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The Immediacy of any of these ideas is lost; and for Being and Nothing, that's pretty crucial

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 11:13:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Formalism is the mind of God, it is truth becoming aware of itself, it is both technique and its study, and it is in every page of Hegel's book. You will never see Hegel bitch against it for he knew of its importance, and indeed a lot of the concepts he's talking about have been formalized, independently or through Lawvere/Schreiber. Those who can't see the formalism in Hegel are mathematically illiterate, those who reject it are fetishizing the worst aspects of Hegel: as he was wresting objects from the darkness at considerable intellectual effort they are celebrating the darkness and ignoring the object. The rejection of formalism was a counterreaction against the analytics, it can't stand to their demands for formal rigor so it tries to deny its necessity. But only rigorous thought can be trusted to be true and only formalized thought can be trusted to concern something true. Insofar as something is true in the science of logic, it can be formalized, because that's what logic is: the formalization of thought.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 11:16:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Of course, finitude and infinity are mathematical concepts, as is that of a boundary, and the relation between at least finitude and Hegel's bad infinity can easily be captured using Peano's axioms and some elementary topological considerations.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 11:19:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Note that Hegel identifies the "bad infinity" with the infinity of "Verstand", which is what would most closely translate to reason in English, whereas the other infinity is that of "Vernunft", which is more closely translated to "rationality".

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 11:22:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So it's exactly the other way around to what one would think: it's not the "good" reason against the "bad" rationality with the former being the light of the spirit and the latter being the bean-counter's perspective on the world, not at all.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 11:37:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What I don't get is how someone can read a title like "Science of Logic" and think "well, that can't possibly be formalized!"? It's not like logic has from its very inception been about formalization!

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 16:11:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 As someone reading thru the classical logicians this has the ring of truth to me. When I get to Hegel I'll see what I think....

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 16:11:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm also interested in Feuerbach on his own account, so that will be a snack as well.

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 16:47:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'd also add until the above comment I didn't think there was much here to Hegel other than some blather about how nothing exists. I could read any obscurantist to get that. Okay, maybe that's too strong - but something around there. Maybe it's just that Hegel is being read by people so steeped in Postmodernism that everything comming out the other end is encomia to postmodern relativism.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 17:07:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @angelus888#0 That's probably what I would have thought too had I not been exposed to Lawvere before actually looking into Hegel (Lawvere is pretty famous among category theorists), but it's really not that. It's actually surprising what a firm grip Hegel had of logical and mathematical concepts of his time and even to some extent in anticipation. There are constant allusions to mathematics, some explicit, some more implicit but clearly noticeable, and overall his deductions are, for the most part, fairly careful. There are some where I'm not sure how he arrives there, but so far nothing that was central to his arguments. I read a bit ahead and there are fairly involved mathematical arguments he makes later on about infinitesimal calculus. It is kind of impressive. I don't know that any philosopher after him had such a good grasp of logic and mathematics. Russell and Whitehead would be candidates, but I'm much less impressed with Russell's philosophical contributions and Whitehead was a mathematician first and foremost and a philosopher second.

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 17:25:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 What is the most crucial companion by Lawvere to read in consultation with Hegel in order to not miss these things? <@638122715668152320>

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 18:18:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 I think you got those translations backwards; bad infinity of "Verstand" is that of Understanding. Vernuft is the one translated as Reason.

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 18:36:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It's telling to me that you have to distort what I'm saying as though I see no value in formalization where I am merely trying to point out the limits of formalization. One can formalize something only after it's understood, after it's thought through. So to say Logic merely is formalization of thought would be to cut out the thinking itself. A formal system is necessarily mediated. The definition that formalist gives of Being is based in a number of technical concepts elsewhere defined. It becomes turtles all the way down. Being for Hegel is conceivable in its Immediacy. And Hegel frequently refers to the immediate of many concepts; ie back to the immediacy of the finite. That passage clearly gives a sense of finite and infinite beyond mathematics. One has to base ones system of formalization in something else. Hegel is actually MORE rigorous than Lawverve's formalization because it's grounded in something more immediate than formalism. Hegel is developing concepts necessary before one can formalize the way math does. Math assumes too much; or rather, it closes itself off from thought itself, satisfied w formalizations. It loses its metaphysical significance, I would say, to translate it into math

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 18:36:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I know they are translated like this, what I'm saying is that in actual usage "reason" is more closely correspondent to "verstand" and "rationality" to "vernunft". I'm also annoyed that they translate Kant's "Kritik der reinen Vernunft" as "Critique of pure Reason" for the same reason.

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 18:38:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I remember Hegel being critical of Mathematical models of thought in his writings on Spinoza I am going to read it later

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 18:38:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/hegel/works/hp/hpspinoz.htm

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 18:38:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    My understanding of understanding vs reason is from reading hegel

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 18:39:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm curious what you take the terms to mean in common English

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 18:53:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "One can formalize something only after it's understood, after it's thought through. So to say Logic merely is formalization of thought would be to cut out the thinking itself." No, because one can think without knowing anything without logic. Logic is the comprehension of thought through strict formalization. "One has to base ones system of formalization in something else." The same is true for any kind of consideration, really. See also the next point "Hegel is actually MORE rigorous than Lawverve's formalization because it's grounded in something more immediate than formalism." No, because Hegel is using language, and language is already a formalization and certainly not immediate or at least no more immediate than, say, a mathematical calculation. That's the unspoken background: that Hegel is not really, and could never, just develop his logic completely out of nothing. He is already using language to define the terms he is using in his system. Also, he is using logical reasoning all the time even when he hasn't set it up yet. He isn't, and cannot, start from nothing, at best he's describing a self-causing system. "Math assumes too much; or rather, it closes itself off from thought itself, satisfied w formalizations. It loses its metaphysical significance." No one who knows real math could ever say it is closed off from thought. In any case, rather than losing its metaphysical significance, it gives the precise mechanism for why the system Hegel is describing can work at all. The key word here being "precise".

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 18:59:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But he doesn't actually use language to define Being and Nothing. He only uses it to convey the thoughts; it's really not a formalism as it couldn't be

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 18:59:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Precision is not the same as rigor

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 19:00:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Verstand in German means the faculty of thinking, pretty closely aligned with the English "reason", except that it doesn't have the dual meaning of "cause" that the English word has. The lexical meaning of Vernunft is similar, but it carries with itself a note of temperation and in colloquial usage is almost never used to refer to the faculty of thinking but rather to the making of reasonable decisions: we would say "Sei vern√ºnftig" to someone on the verge of making a bad decision, similar to "be reasonable". But "use your reason!" would be translated as "Benutz deinen Verstand!".

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 19:00:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm not sure there is any actual basis to equate rigor and formalization. Economics uses formalization to obscure the content

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 19:03:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 So you're saying the descriptions he gives should not be taken as definitions? In any case, I don't see the difference to formalization, as the same is also meant to "convey thoughts", apart from facilitating thinking and ensuring that its results are valid.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 19:04:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I'm actually saying that they are not. Language is already a formalization but it isn't rigorous. In any case, economics usually does said is a rigorous way, it is the base assumptions that are invalid not the steps of reasoning.

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 19:04:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ""The whole of Spinoza's philosophy is contained in these definitions, which, however, taken as a whole are formal; it is really a weak point in Spinoza that he begins thus with definitions. In mathematics this method is permitted, because at the outset we there make assumptions, such as that of the point and line; but in Philosophy the content should be known as the absolutely true. It is all very well to grant the correctness of the name-definition, and acknowledge that the word ‚Äúsubstance‚Äù corresponds with the conception which the definition indicates, but it is quite another question to determine whether this content is absolutely true. ""

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 19:06:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I'm also not saying, and have never said, that we should assume all of mathematics from the beginning. Neither does, for instance, the formalization of logic.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 19:27:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @angelus888#0 It's kind of hard to pick, particularly while keeping it approachable. I acutually think the nlab-entry that I linked to before (which wasn't written by him) is a good starting point: https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Aufhebung Also the beginning of the nlab-entry of Sol: https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Science+of+Logic In these, as well as the below papers, there might come a point where you can't read any further because of the mathematical jargon (even though Lawvere tries his best to keep it as understandable as possible). I suggest that when you come to that point to skim a bit ahead and if it doesn't get better leave the paper aside for now. The beginning of "Categories of Space and Quantity" should be fairly understandable and is important, "Unity and Identity of Opposites in Calculus and Physics" https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Unity+and+Identity+of+Opposites+in+Calculus+and+Physics is also important, as well as "Cohesive Toposes and Cantor's "lauter Einsen" https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Cohesive+Toposes+and+Cantor%27s+%22lauter+Einsen%22 I've given links for two of these but I know for a fact that the third is obtainable using the usual means to obtain scientific publications.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 19:31:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Oh, wait, actually, I can just add it as an attachment. I'll just have to find it‚Ä¶ ah, here it is!

    üìé Lawvere_-_1992_-_Categories_of_Space_and_of_Quantity.pdf?ex=680ddd63&is=680c8be3&hm=bb040b75cb0e36e7d54b2779508c037801aec23e9953d0fd1d44c9d39c8bd812&

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 20:03:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Oh, and if at some point you want to learn more about the underlying mathematics, Lawvere wrote a book "Conceptual Mathematics"

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 20:38:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Is some previous background necessary? I'm vaugely aware that understanding some of this requires basically a tutor.

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 20:39:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 To separate the "steps of reasoning" from its rigor is to limit the concept of rigor to mere formality. I think this is precisely the impoverished notion of rigor, logic, and truth. You said before that "only formalized thought can be trusted to concern something true". That seems in contradiction to what you are saying now; that it's formal but not true. That's the problem. Formalism does not guarantee truth; nor do I agree it's a condition for apprehending truth. Nor do I think Hegel believes it is; Hegel clearly believes Christianity is true but that he is the first to formalize it. The value in formalization is in clarifying the truth after it has been apprehended; through such clarity, the truth is increased by specificity and the acknowledgement of it's limits. Any truth taken too far passes into falsity, and formalization & rigor helps identify those limits. But formalization can do the opposite; for example in Econ of analytic philosophy, formalization obscures the truth by trying to reduce it down to definitions. Dependence on definitions, to me, is the essence of formalism. That's why I took issue with your claim that Hegel depends on language as formalization. He does not. In maths, you can depend simply on definitions. The definitions are *precise* and sufficient; not so with meta-physcis/philosophy precisely because it is not a self contained system. Whereas math is about conceptual constructs which may or may not be applied to the world. Metaphysics is about existence. That's why Being is not the universal set. The universal set only exists hypothetically in theory. Being not only exists, it's more fundamental than existence or 'actuality'. Actuality, the material world, is grounded in Being. That's why the thought of Being is immediate; because thought exists in the material world, in our brains and minds. The idea of being partakes in being. When you divide logic from being, as Maths and bourgeois Econ do, and consider rigor merely to be..

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 20:39:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I've accepted I'm not going to be a mathstar, but being mid is sufficient to understand, so I am willing to go to the math gym to get math swole insofar as I am able to do so with my poor abilities in that regard.

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 20:39:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Formal correctness in steps, it's not rigor in a philosophical sense. It lays no claim to apprehend being

    Formal arguments in Plato and Aristotle are a method of quickly discovering, independent of the substance of an argument, if it can *ever* even *possibly* be accurate or provide conclusions based on its organisation.

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 20:47:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/aristotle-logic/

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 20:49:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Decent discussion without reading the whole goddam Organon. Though I also have to add translation matters for Aristotle. Essentially you can get several different translations for all of the source texts because it seems incredibly condensed. In general it's best to not obsess over mot-a-mot ness but to look for the idea indicated by the combination of words used. This is a bedrock concept of translation in general, which is about the transmission of ideas not words.

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 20:50:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Others have done much much better jobs of showing what Aristotelian logic is and how it works than I will be able to do here. And they all know more about it than me given that command of Greek here seems significant.

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 20:51:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Looking at the translations they remind me of translating Classical Chinese, which I am directly familiar with. It's very difficult due to it's compression, style, difference to target language, changes in grammar, and lack of word equivalence. So you are going to shoot for what the text means and how it means it rather than trying to repeat preicse words.

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 21:01:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 "*The mathematical method is, however, ill-adapted for speculative content*, and finds its proper place only in the finite sciences of the understanding. In modern times Jacobi has asserted (Werke, Vol. IV. Section I. pp. 217-223) that all demonstration, all scientific knowledge leads back to Spinozism, which alone is a logical method of thought; and because it must lead thither, it is really of no service whatever, *but immediate knowledge is what we must depend on*. It may be conceded to Jacobi that the method of demonstration leads to Spinozism, if we understand thereby *merely the method of knowledge belonging to the understanding*. But the fact is that Spinoza is made a testing-point in modern philosophy, so that it may really be said: You are either a Spinozist or not a philosopher at all. This being so, the mathematical and demonstrative method of Spinoza would seem to be only a defect in the external form; but it is the fundamental defect of the whole position. In this method the nature of philosophic knowledge and the object thereof, are entirely misconceived, for mathematical knowledge and *method are merely formal in character and consequently altogether unsuited for philosophy*. Mathematical knowledge exhibits its proof on the existent object as such, not on the object as conceived; *the Notion is lacking throughout*; the content of Philosophy, however, is simply the Notion and that which is comprehended by the Notion. " https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/hegel/works/hp/hpspinoz.htm

  • angelus888Wed Feb 07 2024 21:01:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I do think you need truth to get anywhere, by the way. Otherwise there's no reason to do anything at all, and also no criteria to judge politics by.

    So in that, I agree with Plato.

  • minimaltomWed Feb 07 2024 21:03:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 I think Reason is the correct term to use. Reason in technical English isn't just like the colloquial word reasonable. Think of the phrase the age of Reason. Reason is higher than the facility of understanding. Hegel use of the words Reason and Understanding come straight from Kant (in german obviously) .

  • minimaltomWed Feb 07 2024 21:11:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Although Kant may have actually thought Reason was lower than Understanding in a way because it lead to nonsense

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 21:15:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Here Hegel explains a bit what he means by Understanding: "If the t*hought-forms are vitiated by a fixed antithesis, i.e. if they are only of a finite character*, they are unsuitable for the self-centred universe of truth, and truth can find no adequate receptacle in thought. Such thought, which can produce only limited and partial categories and proceed by their means, is what in *the stricter sense of the word is termed Understanding*. The finitude, further, of these categories lies in two points. Firstly, they are only subjective, and the antithesis of an objective permanently clings to them. Secondly, they are always *of restricted content*, and so persist in antithesis to one another and still more to the Absolute." https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/hegel/works/sl/sl_ii.htm#SL19

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 21:18:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think any formalization is necessarily finite

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 21:19:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hence, why he said in the Spinoza chapter of HoP (quoted above): ""The mathematical method is, however, ill-adapted for speculative content, and finds its proper place only in the finite sciences of the understanding."

  • andru0358Wed Feb 07 2024 21:20:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    In Reason, any conception is necessarily dynamic and changing; formalization makes them static, and thereby finite

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 23:21:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @angelus888#0 Well, again, in most of these you'll get to a point where reading forward will become hard. If you really want to get into it, you could read "Conceptual Mathematics" first, then the others, which should help you a lot with the Lawvere-papers. I also wrote an exposition here, which I tried to keep readable, but was maybe a bit too optimistic about: https://github.com/nameiwillforget/hegel-in-mathematics Note that this, though, is about Schreiber's formalization, which builds on Lawvere's but is a bit different and maybe more speculative.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 23:36:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "o separate the "steps of reasoning" from its rigor is to limit the concept of rigor to mere formality." Which I'm not doing. Again, the steps are usually rigorous, the premises aren't. "You said before that "only formalized thought can be trusted to concern something true". That seems in contradiction to what you are saying now; that it's formal but not true." No, though I was admittedly a little unclear for the sake of rhetoric: a conclusion is valid if and only if both its premises and its reasoning steps are. It is necessesary, not sufficient. Although that should really be common knowledge. "That's the problem. Formalism does not guarantee truth; nor do I agree it's a condition for apprehending truth. Nor do I think Hegel believes it is; Hegel clearly believes Christianity is true but that he is the first to formalize it." Well, you can believe what you want, though I doubt you are actually acting on your belief. It would be very unreasonable. In any case, I don't see how out of the second sentence it would follow that Hegel didn't believe it. "The value in formalization is in clarifying the truth after it has been apprehended; through such clarity, the truth is increased by specificity and the acknowledgement of it's limits. Any truth taken too far passes into falsity, and formalization & rigor helps identify those limits." Well, great. You are forgetting that formalization also helps with further thinking and communication, but, sure, usually you have an insight first (built on your prior vocabulary), then formalize it. And that's what we should do with Hegel. "But formalization can do the opposite; for example in Econ of analytic philosophy, formalization obscures the truth by trying to reduce it down to definitions." Again, the problem is not that axioms are taken but that they are supposed but do not correspond to reality.

  • nameiwillforgetWed Feb 07 2024 23:46:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "Dependence on definitions, to me, is the essence of formalism. That's why I took issue with your claim that Hegel depends on language as formalization. He does not." Except that, well, he does. He uses language to convey his thoughts, which he has has thought about with language and maybe some other intuition, and he reasons logically. I don't see how you could deny that at all. "In maths, you can depend simply on definitions. The definitions are precise and sufficient; not so with meta-physcis/philosophy precisely because it is not a self contained system." They are also precise in logic. And logic is metaphysics. "That's why Being is not the universal set. The universal set only exists hypothetically in theory." I don't even know what the "universal set" is. It is the terminal object though. Or rather, the terminal object is a structure in our common mathematical theory that corresponds to the metaphysical role of pure being. "Actuality, the material world, is grounded in Being. That's why the thought of Being is immediate; because thought exists in the material world, in our brains and minds." Except both Tom and Thomas said pure being cannot be intuited. Which one is it: is it so pure we can't actually comprehend it or is it immediate because it is in us anyway? Regardless, I'll just note that if it's a thought it's not really immediate. Only direct experience is.

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 00:49:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Alright, I did some more research and I think the terms were less divergent to in the past. Basically, in German "Vernunft" came to mean more what Kant called "praktische Vernunft" whereas in English "reason" came to mean more what he called "theoretische Vernunft", tendentially.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 01:22:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 I think we have come upon the source of our disagreement which upon clarifying other points will be more clear. You say: "Regardless, I'll just note that if it's a thought it's not really immediate. Only direct experience is." This is not true (for Hegel). Hegel lays out the direct experience of thought in the first few paragraphs of the Encyclopedia Logic: "The objects of philosophy, it is true, are upon the whole the same as those of religion. In both the object is Truth, in that supreme sense in which God and God only is the Truth. ... the mind makes general images of objects, long before it makes notions of them, and that it is only *through these mental images, and by recourse to them, that the thinking mind rises to know and comprehend thinkingly.* But with the rise of this thinking study of things, it soon becomes evident that thought will be satisfied with nothing short of showing the necessity of its facts, of demonstrating the existence of its objects, as well as their nature and qualities. Our original acquaintance with them is thus discovered to be inadequate.""" So we have the immediacy of thought by holding it in our consciousness as "mental images", however, this does NOT mean they are adequate. But this is clearly a moment for him, one which the pass Tom quote about the immediacy of finite demonstrates; immediacy there means the understanding of finite represented in mental image / understanding shows its inadequacy.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 01:22:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    In parage 2: "Philosophy, on the other hand, is a peculiar mode of thinking ‚Äî a mode in which thinking becomes knowledge, and knowledge through notions. ... the strictly human and thought-induced phenomena of consciousness do not originally appear in the form of a thought, but as a feeling, a perception, or mental image ‚Äî all of which aspects must be distinguished from the form of thought proper." So we have here, most thoughts derive from "a feeling, a perception, or mental image", but must be distinguished from "thought" proper. Paragraph 3: ""The **Content**, of whatever kind it be, with which our consciousness is taken up, is what constitutes the qualitative character of our feelings, perceptions, fancies, and ideas; of our aims and duties; and of our thoughts and notions. From this point of view, feeling, perception, etc., are the **forms **assumed by these contents. The contents remain one and the same, whether they are felt, seen, represented, or willed, and whether they are merely felt, or felt with an admixture of thoughts, or merely and simply thought. In any one of these forms, or in the admixture of several, the contents confront consciousness, or are its **object**."" ... "The several modes of feeling, perception, desire, and will, so far as we are aware of them, are in general called ideas (mental representations): and it may be roughly said that philosophy puts thoughts, categories, or, in more precise language, adequate notions, in the place of the generalised images we ordinarily call ideas. Mental impressions such as these may be regarded as the metaphors of thoughts and notions. But to have these figurate conceptions does not imply that we appreciate their intellectual significance, the thoughts and rational notions to which they correspond."

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 01:27:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "... for abstract thinking; i.e. in an inability to get hold of pure thoughts and move about in them. In our ordinary state of mind, the thoughts are clothed upon and made one with the sensuous or spiritual material of the hour; and in reflection, meditation, and general reasoning, we introduce a blend of thoughts into feelings, percepts, and mental images. But it is a very different thing to make the thoughts pure and simple our object."

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 01:31:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So there is an immediacy of thought, a "direct experience of it". This is a crucial aspect of Hegel's dialectic and what distinguishes it from formalism. Particularly, what distinguishes it form a reliance on definitions. You continue to conflate use of language with definitions. A definition in math or *formal* logic is when the term is no other than the definition; its completed by it; the definition set the form of the idea and the form determines entirely its content. This has significant limits which I have tried to explain. What Hegel does is different in that he uses language to construct a mental image or intuition and then clarifies it bit by bit with the Remarks and the rest of the text. These are ways of developing a Notion (admittedly not entirely clear what that means), which is beyond language and at best conveyed, not defined, by it. How we may come to have a particularly idea in our mind is its mediation, but we just as well may have it immediately *in our mind*. Okay i wanted to say more but i have to go for now

  • angelus888Thu Feb 08 2024 02:55:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 When I get there, I'll do it. When I do a thing, I try to do it correctly.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 17:12:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôm also not sure that thought can‚Äôt be immediate. Once something is sublated I think it becomes immediate again. Or at least that‚Äôs how it‚Äôs been so far. Science of Logic, Determinate Being ¬ß 191 ‚ÄúFrom becoming there issues determinate being, which is the simple oneness of being and nothing. Because of this oneness it has the form of immediacy. Its mediation, becoming, lies behind it; it has sublated itself and determinate being appears, therefore, as a first, as a starting-point for the ensuing development.‚Äù https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/hegel/works/hl/hl109.htm#HL1_109 From what I‚Äôve seen logic proceeds by splitting apart dialectically then through sublation coming together as one again. And as Hegel says above the oneness is what makes it immediate. So things are being mediated and then made immediate again over and over through the course of the logic. At least that‚Äôs what‚Äôs happened so far from what I‚Äôve read, maybe that will change. I may be wrong.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 17:25:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Im not totally confident about this but I think the final move to immediacy is made by the faculty of the Understanding, the initial Dialectical move by Reason. another thing ive read in David Gray Carlsons book is that the first step, the immediacy of Being or Determinate Being for Example, is the understanding. The negation of that (Nothing, Negativity) is a move by 'Dialectical Reason' and the third move (Becoming, ??Something?? (im not sure this is right in chapter 2)) is the move of 'Speculative Reason'. I havent seen Hegel say this himself anywhere yet, maybe its in the Encyclopedia.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 17:39:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    or in the 'vulgar' üòÑ presentation of dialectics, Understanding corresponds to Thesis, Dialectical Reason to Anti-Thesis and Speculative Reason to Synthesis. I've seen this refered to also as "The Specualtive Moment" here https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/hegel-dialectics/

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 17:39:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "The third moment‚Äîthe ‚Äúspeculative‚Äù or ‚Äúpositively rational‚Äù (EL ¬ß¬ß79, 82) moment‚Äîgrasps the unity of the opposition between the first two determinations, or is the positive result of the dissolution or transition of those determinations"

    Actually, here is Hegel saying it directly in the Encyclopedia:-

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 17:42:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ¬ß 79 "In point of form Logical doctrine has three sides: [a] the Abstract side, or that of understanding; [b] the Dialectical, or that of negative reason; [c] the Speculative, or that of positive reason."

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 17:42:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/hegel/works/sl/sl_vi.htm

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 17:43:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "These three sides do not make three parts of logic, but are stages or ‚Äòmoments‚Äô in every logical entity, that is, of every notion and truth whatever. They may all be put under the first stage, that of understanding, and so kept isolated from each other; but this would give an inadequate conception of them. The statement of the dividing lines and the characteristic aspects of logic is at this point no more than historical and anticipatory."

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 18:23:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I absolutely agree things are mediated and then immediate again over and over again in the Logic. I think the question is what that means . I think you have it backwards in your first sentence; when something is sublated it moves out of immediacy and becomes a mediated moment in the new thought-object The whole passage I was cutting quotes from and explaining is what he means by immediate abstraction: holding pure thoughts in one's awareness. That is what I take to be immediacy in the movement from mediation to immediacy and back. We know becoming through coming-to-be and ceasing-to-be; their unity is becoming. In their unity we can think - hold the thought in our mind - becoming as it's own thought. Just as coming-to-be and ceasing-to-be are unities of Being and Nothing; being and nothing in them are sublated, ie moments, not the immediate thought held in awareness. When we try to hold being or Nothing in our mind, they pass into each other. Here is a key difference between conveying thoughts versus definition. Hegel refers to the thought of being as "empty intuiting"; that is not what being *is* it's mere how to *think* being. He said "There *is nothing* to be intuited". This is easily misunderstood as that one cannot Intuit it so don't bother; but with metaphysics, you have to be very careful with words like "is" and "nothing". There really *"is"* nothing. That's exactly how Nothing passes into Being. He says Nothing is "meaningful" and that is why it has Being. So if for no other content of meaning of Being, we have meaningfulness. I would add that Being could be thought as the dialectical unity of Actuality (the whole world, both inner world and outer world) and its opposite, Possibility. Maybe it's even more than that, idk what that would be. Being is like "everything -ness" except you have to be careful not to think that in any limiting way. So in a sense, it is not Intuitable; trying to think it leads to nothing. But in Nothing, there Being is

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 18:34:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I've been trying to say this. This is why formalization has it's limits, it's always of the understanding. Any formal truth, taken too far becomes untruth; that's where you come to the negation of it. When I said that concepts change in dialectical logic, Alex acknowledged this historically only. What I'm trying to convey with the whole point about holding thoughts as the object of ones consciousness is that they necessarily need to change, not only historically, but in our individual minds. Every time I re-read a previous part of the book having read further, I understand that part much more clearly. I may have understood it formally or literally the first time, but I didn't understand the content of the thought. Hegel definitely does criticize formalism. He does so precisely on the basis that Logic, to be metaphysical, must base its movement on the *content* of thoughts, not just their forms. How do we get beyond the form to the content? If we understand a definition, we merely understand the form. It's by holding it in our mind that we can come to the content. This is not intuition-ism, because one does not uncritically accept the result uncritically, but explicates it again in formalized thought and checks it logically

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 20:49:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 You said "I think you have it backwards in your first sentence; when something is sublated it moves out of immediacy and becomes a mediated moment in the new thought-object " Im not sure I have it backwards, maybe I worded it wrong or maybe we don't agree what is the final point of the sublation. I think Determinate Being is the final point of the sublation not Becoming, Becoming is only partially sublated. Becoming is mediated but Determinate Being is immediate as Hegel says in the quote I made above:- ‚ÄúFrom becoming there issues determinate being, which is the simple oneness of being and nothing. Because of this oneness it has the form of immediacy. Its mediation, becoming, lies behind it; it has sublated itself and determinate being appears, therefore, as a first, as a starting-point for the ensuing development.‚Äù

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 20:53:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Its interesting actually how he says Determinate Being has the 'form' of immediacy. Does that mean it can have merely the form of immediacy but actually contain mediation which lies "behind it"?

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 20:57:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I realise my understanding of the word 'form' here is pretty colloquial though and I don't actually understand exactly what Hegel is referring to when he talks about form and content though.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 20:59:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    but it seems like hes saying Determinate Being is immediate, in form, but otherwise has mediation behind it.

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 21:28:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "the mind makes general images of objects, long before it makes notions of them" The key word here being long before, which does not necessarily mean immediate. But I actually feel like we are getting further away from our disagreement, because I don't necessarily disagree with this: "What Hegel does is different in that he uses language to construct a mental image or intuition and then clarifies it bit by bit with the Remarks and the rest of the text. These are ways of developing a Notion (admittedly not entirely clear what that means), which is beyond language and at best conveyed, not defined, by it." But it is by no means a difference from mathematics, at all! In fact, since you mentioned formalism, your explanation might as well be one of intuitionism, which holds that all mathematics is based in intuition which is geometric in nature and which is only conveyed through mathematical symbolism (it goes a bit deeper than that, in fact it's interesting to go back to what Brouwer actually thought, who was actually deeply engaged in mysticism (compare Hegel (Enc¬ß82d):

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 21:29:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "It should also be mentioned here that the meaning of the speculative is to be understood as being the same as what used in earlier times to be called ‚Äúmystical‚Äù, especially with regard to the religious consciousness and its content. When we speak of the ‚Äúmystical‚Äù nowadays, it is taken as a rule to be synonymous with what is mysterious and incomprehensible; and, depending on the ways their culture and mentality vary in other respects, some people treat the mysterious and in¬≠comprehensible as what is authentic and genuine, whilst others regard it as belong¬≠ing to the domain of superstition and deception. About this we must remark first that ‚Äúthe mystical‚Äù is certainly something mysterious, but only for the understand¬≠ing, and then only because abstract identity is the principle of the understanding. But when it is regarded as synonymous with the speculative, the mystical is the concrete unity of just those determinations that count as true for the understanding only in their separation and opposition. So if those who recognise the mystical as what is genuine say that it is something utterly mysterious, and just leave it at that, they are only declaring that for them, too, thinking has only the Significance of an abstract positing of identity, and that in order to attain the truth we must renounce thinking, or, as they frequently put it, that we must ‚Äútake reason captive.‚Äù As we have seen, however, the abstract thinking of the understanding is so far from being something firm and ultimate that it proves itself, on the contrary, to be a constant sublating of itself and an overturning into its opposite, whereas the rational as such is rational precisely because it contains both of the opposites as ideal moments within itself. Thus, everything rational can equally be called ‚Äúmystical‚Äù; but this only amounts to saying that it transcends the understanding. It does not at all imply that what is so spoken of must be considered inaccessible to thinking and incomprehensible."

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 21:31:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ) But even if I grant you everything you just wrote, that doesn't change the importance of formalization one bit. Brouwer might have thought that all formalism only consists of instructions to reconstruct an inner truth but that doesn't mean he abstained from using it! So why souldn't we apply the same to Hegel?

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 21:33:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Of course, the danger of premature identification exists, as does that of losing something in the formalization, but it's not like any formalization erases the original text, it is still there to be contemplated and re-evaluated at any point.

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 21:40:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "Any formal truth, taken too far becomes untruth; that's where you come to the negation of it." I don't think that's true. "Every time I re-read a previous part of the book having read further, I understand that part much more clearly. I may have understood it formally or literally the first time, but I didn't understand the content of the thought." Again, mathematics evolves constantly, but its prior truths remain unchanged, only recontextualized, similar to re-reading a book. "Hegel definitely does criticize formalism. He does so precisely on the basis that Logic, to be metaphysical, must base its movement on the content of thoughts, not just their forms." Yes, he applies logic to logic, as had stressed from my first participation in the reading group. "How do we get beyond the form to the content? If we understand a definition, we merely understand the form. It's by holding it in our mind that we can come to the content." If all you understand about a definition are that words are written on a page, you haven't understood the definition at all. Again, that's no real difference.

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 21:40:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "This is not intuition-ism, because one does not uncritically accept the result uncritically, but explicates it again in formalized thought and checks it logically" Which intuitionists do as well.

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 21:46:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I truly hate when people act like mathematics is understanding some manipulation rules and applying them to sentences in order to derive other sentences. It's such a cliche! And I get that people have no idea about mathematics because they've never been exposed to it, but still, not even Hilbert believed that. The life and blood of mathematics consists of understanding the essence of definitions as conveyed through symbols and using that understanding to make explicit what is already clear.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 22:14:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 I'm not so willing as Andru to discredit Maths here, I know hardly anything about Theoretical Maths. I see the whole process of Logic so far as kind of going back and forth between formalism, or understanding, on the one hand and speculation/Reason on the other. Also the whole development of Maths is surely dialectical as well like anything else, not the formal method of Maths obviously but the history and metaphysics of Maths perhaps, for want of a better phrase.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 22:16:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I do feel like Alex and Thomas you are approaching the reading tho maybe more to validate what you already know rather than getting into the details of what is actually said sometimes.

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 22:26:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I distinctly try not to do that. In fact I'm constantly highlighting what that we not do that. Furthermore, if asked, I could already count down a litany of instances where I don't think what is written completely aligns with the interpretations given by Lawvere and/or Schreiber. I don't, because nobody except me knows those interpretations, but it's not like I simply overlay them on top of what is written. In fact, when other people give premature identifications, like that of oppositions with contradictions or of contradiction with everything, I go out of my way to correct that. With that said, there are clear instances where what Hegel writes just obviously corresponds to mathematical notions, which I'm not going to forfeit just because I don't want to distort the text. And that's not even about Lawvere's interpretation, it's about basic concepts that come up all the time. Like in the section about the boundary, it was just obvious to me what he was talking about because it corresponded to stuff I am literally doing research on. It is just obviously in the text, which I'm honestly surprised about. I'm not going to pretend it's not there when Hegel is literally making arguments about Newton's treatment of differentiation!

    @minimaltom#0 No, that's actually fairly fitting: " ¬ß174 The foregoing dialectic is the same, too, as that which understanding employs the notion of infinitesimal magnitudes, given by higher analysis. A more detailed treatment of this notion will be given later. These magnitudes have been defined as such that they are in their vanishing, not before their vanishing, for then they are finite magnitudes, or after their vanishing, for then they are nothing." But check out the first annotation of "The infinity of the Quantum", that's where he really gets into it!

    @minimaltom#0 Is it? I don't think I mentioned anything math related for instance in my summary on the last chapter. With that said, math is metaphysical, and lots of what he talks about are logical or mathematical notions: contradiction, finitude, infinity, boundary, das eins, all of these are mathematical in nature. And it shouldn't be surprising, really, that mathematics would heavily feature in a metaphysical text.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 22:46:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 22:54:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I guess part of why I do that is to keep the mathematical notions clean. I actually hate it when people make haphazard connections, like between, say, set theory and the French revolution, because it diminishes both of those concepts. But Hegel brings in these concepts like contradiction on his own, and this was exactly what the analytics charged him with: using unclear concepts, like continuity (Russell) to introduce metaphysical muddles and hide formal incoherence. But then you have Lawvere, who made real, current-day mathematics out of it (which is more than can be said about analytic philosophy). So part of why I started to actually read it was to see for myself if there is substance to it, if Hegel is a charlatan or a genius, or if he couldn't handle the ghosts he summoned. And there clearly is, even if I'm not sure I'd go with everything he wrote! And that makes me happy. I actually feel joy when reading the book, just to see how what he does and where he goes with it. It is so unforseeable, he always throws a curveball at you! So I do want to convey what I can see he does (and when I can see it because sometimes I'm really not sure how he gets from one thing to the other). But I don't want to diminish anyone else's enjoyment. So I'll try to keep everything approachable, it is actually usually in the negative, when I'm explaining why someone else's formalization falls short, that I actually get into the technicalities.

  • nameiwillforgetThu Feb 08 2024 22:54:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Why, thank you!

" Re: the mind makes images: Once the mind creates a notion from the images, that notion can be be immediate, held in conscious experience. This is what he means by immediacy. This IS the contention of our disagreement, so I am confused by you moving away from it.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 23:23:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Again, mathematics evolves constantly, but its prior truths remain unchanged" Exactly, that is how it is different from philosophy. In philosophy, the prior truths have changed.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 23:24:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Regards intuitionism: you are using the term in the philosophy of mathematics sense. Not in the Schelling or Romantics sense or Mystical sense

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 23:24:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel explains exactly what intuitionists do not do, that is apply logic to the results of intuition, in your quoted passage on Mystical>

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 23:25:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I only bring that up to clariy, as it seems people dismiss what I am saying as though it is mysticism

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 23:30:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I am not implying math is "manipulation rules and applying them to sentences in order to derive other sentences". Not at all. But I do not think that their content can be regarded as metaphysical. Hegel uses some concepts from math, as logic always has, but there are important differences, especially with finite and infinite. The chapter on Quantity definitely is full of maths, again, I think it needs to be taken in its metaphysical significance, as grounding mathematical concepts from outside. The outside-of-math-ness of metaphysics which I refer to is capture in the meaning of Being, and why its formalization looses its point. I already explained a great deal about that without a response to I'll stop for now.

    But basically, that we can know Being and Nothing immediately

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 23:39:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomThu Feb 08 2024 23:40:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 23:41:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Yea: the rest of that sentence/paragraph gets into determinate vs pure being.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 23:41:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Being is the notion implicit only: its special forms have the predicate ‚Äòis‚Äô; when they are distinguished they are each of them an ‚Äòother‚Äô: and the shape which dialectic takes in them, i.e. their further specialisation, is passing over into another. This further determination, or specialisation, is at once a forth-putting and in that way a disengaging of the notion implicit in being; and at the same time the withdrawing of being inwards, its sinking deeper into itself. Thus the explication of the notion in the sphere of being does two things: it brings out the totality of being, and it *abolishes the immediacy of being, or the form of being as such.*"

  • andru0358Thu Feb 08 2024 23:43:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Heidegger writes about Being as the "is-ness" (may he is wrong, or different form Hegel); but anything that *is* has its "is-ness" lost in *what* it is

It is a systematic whole, in which each of its constituent functions is the very total which the notion is, and is put as indissolubly one with it. Thus in its self-identity it has original and complete determinateness.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:17:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I agree with the first part in the sense that thinking constantly evolves, and that a primary way in which it evolves is through restriction and therefore exclusion, which creates a parallel opportunity to study the excluded, which has been a pattern in thought for a long time, I don't think that this invalidates or changes prior results though, only places them into proper context. I am fascinated with the connection to the mystical and how it was in the background of so many great scientists, and I'm definitely willing to go with Hegel in the weaker sense of, basically, intuition, but as to his actual method, which he is hinting at, I think it's interesting but I haven't completely made up my mind about it. There clearly is a logic to it, but it is precisely because it's not rigorously formalized that it has to be approached with caution, because it could err at any moment.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:21:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Well, but if it is held in conscious experience, isn't it experienced, which was what I said? Regardless, I don't see how that's the contention of our disagreement at all, which isn't about whether an image in the mind is immediate but on whether it is valuable to try to formalize Hegel

But same idea i think. What I was saying before about formalization following after; I think ideas like Being and Nothing escape formalization; I have been looking more at that website, but mostly just out of curiosity, I remain skeptical of it. More to the point, the truth has to actually be established independent of formalization if it has to be established *prior to it*, right?

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 00:25:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So if Logic is more than merely formal, it has to be able to establish its own premises

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:26:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I also definitely disagree with that. I don't think prior truths in philosophy change in a sense that isn't simple recontextualization. They might have been false from the beginning or concerned, say, social relations that changed over time, but insofar as we are talking about actual metaphysical truths, I don't think they change at all.

  • minimaltomFri Feb 09 2024 00:27:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 what do you mean it has been a pattern in thought for a long time?

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 00:27:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:28:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 00:28:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:30:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I see

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 00:30:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)
