  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:31:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Well, I'm not against that method (Hegel's). But the point is that afterwards he does apply logic to it.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:39:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Again I'll underline that I'm not saying we should from the outset assume the existence of mathematics. What he's doing is deriving the existence of mathematics from a supposedly more basic metaphysical reasoning using the abstract unity and concrete difference of being and nothing in becoming as a basis. I've never disagreed with that. That's still metaphysical though as it is literally beyond the physical. In other words, the laws of the physical universe could vary in a way that mathematical laws can't, which though still can vary in a way that logical laws can't, which can still vary though! And, and here is the fun part, this variation can be described using category, of course assuming a meta-framework within our normal thinking, but can still at least to a limited extent trace out the results of variations in logic! And this is actually done in current mathematical research! However, it does depend on a prior framework that is always implicitly assumed, but I still maintain that Hegel does that too, as he is again using at least human intuition, and, let's be honest, also logical laws before he has them derived.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:43:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    However, and that is actually what I consider a controversial thought of mine, I think geometry might vary less than logic. As in, we can vary logic but the basic geometric shapes stay the same. But I'm not completely sure about that.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:45:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Well, but that's concepts already, that's not conscious experience anymore

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:53:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "What I was saying before about formalization following after; I think ideas like Being and Nothing escape formalization" I don't. I think their experience cannot be formalized, but the role they are playing in the overall system can. "More to the point, the truth has to actually be established independent of formalization if it has to be established prior to it, right?" I don't think so. I think it has to be *grasped* prior to it but is only fully established afterwards. In fact, you can even apply that directly to Hegel without any recourses to mathematics, as he is using notions he is only fully defining later.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 00:54:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yes, but through its own development

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 01:12:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Well, it has. On a very concrete level, one usually starts with a nice structure to then note the necessity of going outside that structure, to discover the initial structure is only one of a great many of such structures, but is particularly well-behaved, which makes it all the more special. You can make this a lot more abstract, and Hegel does, but that happened again and again in human history.

  • minimaltomFri Feb 09 2024 01:35:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 ok I getcha

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 06:33:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 So there is a lot going on here but to go back to the first bit after I spoke --- Contradictions are easy to define: its ‚àÉ a (a and not a). He doesn't say that the contradiction of the finite is subjective in the paragraph I shared, he seems to distinguish them --- I think his point there seems to be that in the first appearance of nothing we have a subjective contradiction (i.e. we've thought something contradictory) whereas in the second contradiction it appears he's talking about the finite as a determinate object (which is a something because it contains something as one of its moments). I.e. an objective contradiction. The reason nothing, for me reading this, has constituent elements is because we are *diving into* these objects --- i.e. becoming is internal to nothing and determinate being is internal of becoming. So when we come to a further determination along in the process of the writing, the determination curls back and impacts every object that was previously discussed. So nothing *at the start* (before the elements 'are posited in it') doesn't have constituent elements --- sure, because nothing *at the start* is only observed from the outside and is the stupidest possible nothing, an incredibly boring object which gives us basically no understanding of what is going on. Its like a perfect sphere or point or symbolic token (i.e. merely the word nothing or as Hegel puts it 'not', negation). And Hegel warns us not to pause there in the introduction. The problem is that the moment you take that token seriously as an object and *really* have negation or not (really the moment you say that there is any kind of *actual* negation, not mere token '-' --- you are off to the races in terms of turning that not against itself because you can then go '--' and get a positive object, which you can name 'a' and you can negate that again into a negative object '-a' and that tells you ‚àÉa (-a and a) --- i.e. you get a contradiction which lets everything else appear).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 06:37:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "The idea of "reading" it a certain way is contrary to the very point of the book" Actually, my point is that reading it in a Zizekian way is just reading it: i.e. there are defenses for what I am saying all throughout the book, I keep seeing them (for example at the very beginning Hegel mentions that the beginning is the end and that everything loops back on itself: so I'm saying 'hey, maybe Hegel is limited by form here, maybe, we gotta read the whole thing in a single splat to understand it, because to read it linearly is actually to misunderstand it, in part because the infinite --- which Hegel calls reason itself --- is a circle'). The fact that we like to yell at each other and that you don't want to read me charitably doesn't negate that.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 06:50:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "If there's any representation thought of contradiction, it seems like it would be the unity of opposites; the dialectic of opposition as not rigidly separate but also not identical, united and different. And in this unity, a becoming of a third. The unity of Being and Nothing become existence; and similarly in repitition, we the Something and Other are united in Being-for-itself. In the shorter logic, he says "Being-for-itself ... As the relation of the negative to itself it is a being that is for itself, the One"; he goes on to discuss it as "the One", "it does not relate as something does to other but instead, as the unity of something and an other". This unity creates contradiction for the understanding because looking at the opposition as such, their unity seems impossible. But their opposition is sublated in the unity, it's still there, but not visible." I think the problem here might be the word 'impossible': contradictions are impossible but all of their effects are possible and as a result it is possible for a contradiction to be partially possible (i.e. for a part of the contradiction to be possible --- both in terms of either half without the other half but also in terms of a partial object which can adhere to either half but which is not bound to either half --- i.e. petit objet a which is the contradiction of contradiction: i.e. both a contradiction and not a contradiction, the part which 'exists' is not a contradiction and the fact that it can adhere to either possible state is the contradiction). This is the difficulty that I have is that the contradiction *is in the object itself* not just in the understanding of the object and the way to resolve it is to create petit objet a (which is precisely what happens in the move from becoming to determinate being: becoming is the grand movement of everything, determinate beings are always missing something, always partial, always without, always lacking: that's the point of quality).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 06:54:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "I think to translate it into set theory or something is not only to mediate it from outside; it also, to me seems to be trying to flatten it in a single understanding. To use a spacial metaphor; I think the understanding is like a 2 dimensional snapshot, and dialectics is trying to understand things in 3 dimensions. So we see a couple 2-d images and see things which appear contradictory and have to Reason into the depth, the third dimension, to see how the contradiction is only apparent, ie resolves" I half agree with this: my position is that if you reduce it to set theory you have to do so by speaking about the contradictions in set theory (such as Russell's paradox).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 06:55:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "To me, formalism is always in the realm of Understanding. Reason has left the picture, however necessary it was to develop the formalism; it is now a static system The Immediacy of any of these ideas is lost; and for Being and Nothing, that's pretty crucial" I think you should rethink this: I don't think reason escapes formalism, rather reason is formalism taken to the end.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 06:58:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 So I would like to juxtapose the unity of opposites in the number line against another possibility: a mere amalgamation. I could give you all the numbers in the world as like [-124593.23452, 9384, 3.1467, 27...] like as a set without order and this, I think, is what hegel calls 'simple unity'. The reason the number-line begins to take on contradictory nature is precisely its orderedness: i.e. its possible to move smoothly from one side of point to the other and back again and have all that make sense (and this is a folding in of the contradiction into the object).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:02:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Also, nothing does exist too: its just that this doesn't mean what people think it means... Because we are dealing with linear logic we cannot produce every outcome in every timeline and thus the specific contradictions, the specific 'nothing' matters. At least that is my reading... However, I do think... that there was a conflation I was making which you were right to call me out on. When Hegel is speaking of simple unity he's speaking about simple amalgamation I think and there is a contradiction in it, it just isn't a contradiction of the objects concerned (i.e. the object form 'amalgamation' has a contradiction/boundary of its own between it and other concepts, but that doesn't mean the things in the list are in contradiction with each other until the amalgamation is developed into something that brings them into contact, like a number line which does contain a contradiction in the form of the possibilities of motion about a single point it implies).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:13:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 So I disagree with you about formalism but its for a different reason --- I think that all formalisms already contain their failure, their contradiction inside themselves (a fact which is constantly demonstrated within mathematics) and for that reason formalism already contains the failed object, you don't have to reach 'beyond' formalism to acquire immediacy (or to put it another way, there is already immediacy in formalism in the form of the token/symbol which always has an immediate embodiment in the formalism before it begins to signify anything). Immediacy exists imeddiately within formalism, immediacy is a moment of the mediated (contained within the mediated). That's why railing against formalism is not a useful or interesting project from my perspective (because the only reason to rail against it is to claim there is an outside to it, there is no outside).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:16:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 The problem with 'definitions' to my reading is that Spinoza isn't developing his results out of the immediacy of the formalism itself. I.e. when I give definitions really I'm making assumptions. Hegel is assuming something (the basic fact of formalism, which is negation) but its just the single thing, which is the single thing we need to be able to actually proceed with any thought anyway...

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:19:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Formalism does not guarantee truth, but there is no truth without formalism. This is not a contradictory statement.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:32:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think there is a misreading here: specifically the idea seems to be that what is reaquired is for us to negate formalism in an undirected way. Any such negation will either just provide confusion or a different formalism (Alex is choosing 'different formalism' and Andru, I think are choosing confusion). Rather we need to do an 'x of x' and read this as we need to formalize formalism itself which is what Hegel is doing in the science of logic (i.e. notice that formalism itself is a contradictory negation --- becuause it is a determinate being and all determinate beings are contradictory negations of some other thing through their qualities). The formalization of formalism itself reduces down to a single token... negation (Hegel goes for 'being' but I continue to deeply suspect this, but the basic move of going for a single token/symbol is correct). I get your point that he's not defining it in chapter 1 but he is developing it throughout the whole book (i.e. he's constantly applying the negatory token back onto itself at every step and aquiring a new token 'nothing is the being of being' --- 'becoming is the nothing of nothing' --- 'determinate being is the becoming of becoming' --- 'quality is the determinate being of determinate being' --- 'something is the quality of quality' etc. He doesn't state these moves in exactly these terms, but that's how I read what he's doing) and each of these moves is purely formal starting from a purely formal base: i.e the 'philosophical' move he's taking here is to reject formalism through its total embrace (i.e. embrace it to the point of contradiction). However, I think he's actually both defining and developing because both have to be done due to the nature of the object defined (i.e. due to the nature of quality as a necessary moment of being). That's the difficulty that I'm having with this yelling about formalism: the immediate doesn't lie beyond the formal but rather is its internal contradiction.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:37:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Also, I think you shoud consider that Hegel... doesn't know what he's talking about here in modern terms. Symbolic logic didn't even exist when Hegel is writing (and there is a lot of this section on infinity which is annoying to read as a modern mathematician because its like 10 lines of code to describe what he wants but he has to repeat himself 50 different ways because he doesn't have the words for it). Like here he's still stuck on the infinite as a circle, he doesn't even know (likely) that there are more than one order of infinity --- aleph null vs aleph 1 (though he'd probably think that's an interesting result and he certainly is approaching that point and failing over and over again).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:38:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yeah, that's because you aren't a mathematician.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:42:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 I would be careful with this one... I think Hegel thinks there is an infinite (and the infinite is reason... i.e. the necessary exclusion of contradiction which also necessitates the near existence of contradiction). I would say that what Hegel is stumbling over but not really expressing well, I think, is self-similarity (i.e. he would look at a Mandelbrot set and say 'there, there is the infinite').

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:49:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Hegel does both, he defines *and* develops --- the development occurs as a necessary moment of the definition. The starting point is sufficient to entail the whole logic (i.e. the definition is 'complete') but that starting point is a self-contradictory token s.t. the development is required because there are many possible missteps where one-sidedness might cause one to fail to take necessary steps because they are only necessary in abstract at the highest level, across the whole logic, not in a particular reality (and we exist in particular realities --- and this failure is like the fifth step in... its just after quality where he points out that realities are determinate beings).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 07:58:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 No, its just that I 'already know' a lot --- but I am very interested both in a filling out of knowledge (i.e. the ways the text develops something that I didn't previously understand, the bit about self-similarity is something I've only really considered after reading this section on the infinite for example) and as an opposition to what I believe (for example, I've said multiple times that I think Hegel erred in starting with being rather than nothing... but that should be taken not as me reading for what I know but rather drawing out an important distinction between what I believe to be true and what Hegel is doing). However, I don't let that flipped value discount the rest of his arguments for me.

    @nameiwillforget#0 Prematue doesn't mean wrong :b

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 08:43:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Also I should address this because its been bothering me: I think that when I say 'I'm doing a Zizekian reading of Hegel' People might think I'm like a grad student whose advisor really loves Foucault and I really like St. Thomas Aquinis and so I go to my advisor and say 'My thesis is a Foucaultian reading of Aquinis' --- as if the world ever needed such a thing. What I'm actually saying is that I think that the reader Hegel himself wants (or rather the spirit of Hegel if we like: i.e. where the understanding of Hegel is) in the modern world today, is Zizek. This isn't a postmodernist pastiche I'm doing here.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 14:00:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I don't think anyone thinks its like this. It's more like a very dogmatic protestant Sect distorting the Bible to fit their own weird sectarian dogma and claiming it confirms what they already believed. And not offering any substantive arguments, but just dismissing what other people have to say. When you say you are reading this such is "because we are *diving into* these objects" There is literally no textual evidence that Hegel suggests this and it seems to be like a very arbitrary misunderstanding you have clinged very strongly, I don't know why.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 14:40:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It's amusing that you say I'm choosing confusion: It's actually important to let yourself feel confused if you ever want to learn anything. Confusion is how your mind recognizes that you don't understand. You have to sit with that in order to understand something as difficult as Hegels text. If you run away or suppress your confusion, you'll end up w a lot of false confidence that you "already know things" but aren't actually so. I think I actually understand the first part of the text quite well and am clear in my explanations. So I'm not sure what you think I'm confused about. Moving beyond formalism is not a sea of confusion. It's Thinking in thoughts rather than definitions. Formalization is helpful to be precise in our thinking and to hold out thinking outside of us so we can check it. This "checking" is precisely what is done by Hegel with his method of making the thoughts the Object of immediate awareness. (Alex, I don't know why you persistent in claiming concepts cannot be immediate; can you explain why you claim this?) Formalism is a check on knowledge. But it requires reducing thoughts to other thoughts. This cannot be done for basic premises, as we have all agreed. So if formalization is "necessary" for truth, but the premises cannot be formalized, and as we all agree, formalism only provides truth on the bases of its premises, than formalism proves the impossibility of truth. It's simply absurd to say "there is no truth without formalism". Formalism depends on premises, truths outside itself. Something 'true' outside formalism is always needed to establish the truth of formalism. Formalism itself cannot acquire truth. This is why a method for checking ones thoughts *other* than formalism is necessary.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 14:45:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    If formalism is a way of representing thoughts mediated by simpler thought, than we need a different way of representing thoughts for the simplest thoughts. That is in our own mind. The method described w quotes. We can discuss it's validity or pitfalls. But Hegel is definitely not in "total embrace" of formalism, unless you mean it in a very weird sense, more like Platonic forms than what we are talking about.

    @andru0358#0 If that is what Alex said, that concepts cannot be immediate thats easy to falsify by looking at the first few lines of Determinate Being as such: ¬ß 191 "From becoming there issues determinate being, which is the simple oneness of being and nothing. Because of this oneness it has the form of immediacy."

  • minimaltomFri Feb 09 2024 16:39:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 17:38:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Regards both "form" and the immediacy of thought/concepts: I found this quote address the confusion. Regards Alex's claim that Hegel presupposes/assumes "human intuition" and "logical laws before he has them derived". Here is Hegel's explanation of what he is doing: "Logic is usually said to be concerned with forms only and to derive the material for them from elsewhere. But this ‚Äòonly‚Äô, which assumes that the logical thoughts are nothing in comparison with the rest of the contents, is not the word to use about *forms which are the absolutely real ground of everything*. Everything else rather is an ‚Äòonly‚Äô compared with these thoughts. To make such abstract forms a problem presupposes in the inquirer a higher level of culture than ordinary; and to study them in themselves and for their own sake signifies in addition that these thought-types *must be deduced out of thought itself*, and their truth or reality examined by the light of their own laws. We do not assume them as data from without, and then define them or exhibit their value and authority by comparing them with the shape they take in our minds. If we thus acted, we should proceed from observation and experience, and should, for instance, say we habitually employ the term ‚Äòforce‚Äô in such a case, and such a meaning. A definition like that would be called correct, if it agreed with the conception of its object present in our ordinary state of mind. The defect of this empirical method is that a notion is not defined as it is in and for itself, but in terms of something assumed, which is then used as a criterion and standard of correctness. No such test need be applied: *we have merely to let the thought-forms follow the impulse of their own organic life.*"

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 17:40:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    paragrph 24n of EoL

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 17:41:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Here is the following sentences which are probably important: "To ask if a category is true or not, must sound strange to the ordinary mind: for a category apparently becomes true only when it is applied to a given object, and apart from this application it would seem meaningless to inquire into the truth. But this is the very question on which every thing turns. We must however in the first place understand clearly what we mean by Truth. In common life truth means the agreement of an object with our conception of it. We thus presuppose an object to which our conception must conform. In the philosophical sense of the word, on the other hand, truth may be described, in general abstract terms, as the agreement of a thought-content with itself. "

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 17:44:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So perhaps this criteria itself is presupposed and not proven. Maybe; but what I would like to insist is that before we can claim that, we have to read him carefully enough to see if he develops it anywhere. In my opinion, we have to learn how he gets from A to B, to ask whether he is smuggling in assumptions in the *how* he gets there. I am actually super interested in digging into enough to see if there is content which is not derived or justified. I have thought I have found them, and then kept reading and reflecting and only later realized it is justified

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 17:48:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But "form" here is different than formalism of symbolic logic. And why it has to be primary; we are talking about the most basic possible structures of thought: Being and Nothing/Emptiness. There are no thoughts without "is-ness" implicit in them; and for Hegel, negation is the basis of Reason, and negation is predicated on Nothing. But the only way we can know if these are the "impulse of their own organic life" of the Thought of Being and Nothing, is to attempt to *think* them, to hold them in our mind and allow them move, and not bring in our preconcieved understandings about them.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 18:04:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I mean, do a ctrl-f on 'outside' of the chapter on determinate being: section 222 "Being and nothing in their unity, which is determinate being are no longer being and nothing ‚Äî these they are only *outside their unity* ‚Äî thus in their unstable unity, in becoming, they are coming-to-be and ceasing-to-be." (their unity here being the determinate being which is inside of these objects... i.e. you can't have determinate being not be inside of being, it isn't other from from being, so the unit is inside of the joint object of being-nothing, i.e. becoming). Yes there is, when developing the logic of determinate being he literally says that the limitation is *inside* of the object, that being-for-other is *inside* of the object, (there's this whole paragraph where he talks about how the normal parlance treats these things as 'outside' and that's fine and all, but it isn't the direction he's going with it --- section 244: "Now in so far as something in its limit both is and is not, and these moments are an immediate, qualitative difference, the negative determinate being and the determinate being of the something fall outside each other. Something has its determinate being outside (or, as it is also put, on the inside) of its limit; similarly, the other, too, because it is a something, is outside it. Limit is the middle between the two of them in which they cease. They have their determinate being beyond each other and beyond their limit; the limit as the non-being of each is the other of both." i.e. the actual being of the object lies outside the limit (or as it is also put 'inside' --- here hegel is saying that the whole orientation of common parlance around 'limit' is incorrect, but he'll repeat it to make it clear what he means: he means that we are talking about the stuff 'inside' the limit at a spatial level and 'outside' the limit conceptually).

  • angelus888Fri Feb 09 2024 18:35:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I've always assumed the point of philosophy itself is to assess the direction or orientation of any systematisation of facts.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 18:35:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What he is saying is Being/Nothing "as such" / "Pure" Being/"Pure" nothing, the thoughts in themselves, only exist outside their unity. Ie, Determinate being is not inside Pure Being. It is the unity of Being and Nothing, and therefore, not their purity, or their "as such", not inside them

  • angelus888Fri Feb 09 2024 18:35:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    That is to say, it is formal, it is the shape of the container in which any amount of facts may be placed.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 18:35:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Inside only existss with limits

  • angelus888Fri Feb 09 2024 18:36:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And it is the container by which, through it's alteration, one may arrive at new conceptualisations of any given amount of facts.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 18:36:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Pure being and Pure nothing do not have limits

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 18:36:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    they have not inside or outside

  • angelus888Fri Feb 09 2024 18:37:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    There's more than that I'd say, because through the systematising and formal practice one can possibly arrive at new theorised outcomes that may outrun the mere collection of data.

  • angelus888Fri Feb 09 2024 18:37:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This is how you get situations like Ancient Greeks and Romans figuring out atoms or Buddhist monks theorizing about extremely large numbers that they could not possibly scientifically prove.

  • angelus888Fri Feb 09 2024 18:37:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Or zero, I suppose, another one.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:18:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Read your own quote carefully: How is Determinate being "inside" being *if* "in their unity ... [they] are no longer being and nothing"? How can x be in y, if y is *only* outside x? He explicitly says in that passage right there, Being and Nothing *only* exist in Determinate being in their unity *as* "coming-to-be and ceasing-to-be". You are right, "Det-begin it isn't other from from being"; Det being precedes the other; Neither Being nor Determinate Being are "somethings"; you seem to be treating them as "somethings" by suggesting they have insides and outsides. Being is in Determinate as sublated; as a moment of both moments. This is why thinking about inside/outside, subset/superset are all WRONG. It just is not like that. You have to let go of these ways of thinking and think about it in the way Hegel describes. Being is in every single concept; if its meaningful, it has Being. Outside of Being: there isn't even nothing, because Nothing has being. When he says "Pure Being" or "Being as such", He is talking about holding the *thought of Being in your mind*; it passes into the *thought of Nothing* and back; the Being of Nothingness, to my mind, is the best way to understand Pure Being. These passings give the bases for new thoughts; coming-to-be and ceasing-to-be; these both contain Being and Nothing, but not *as such* but as sublated - as moments, but their "as such" has disappeared. Determinate Being then contains them in this same way; but it is neither contained "inside" Being, nor vise versa; Being is inside Det Being, but not Being "as such". Being "as such" exists only outside of all determinateness. We simply *must* think of these thoughts *as the thoughts they are*, not translated into any other system of thought. Their basicness requires this; thats the same reason formalization of them misses the point. They *have* to be grasped in their "immediacy", or in their "immanent meaning"

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 19:32:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Or, for example we start with the section on finitude like this: "This contradiction is, indeed, abstractly present simply in the circumstance that the something is finite, or that the finite is. But something or being is no longer abstractly posited but reflected *into itself* and developed as *being-within-self* which possesses a determination and a constitution, and, still more specifically, a *limit* which, as *immanent in the something* and constituting the quality of its *being-within-self*, is finitude. It is to be seen what moment are contained in this Notion of the finite something."

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 19:32:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Or there's this gem: "This infinite, as the consummated return into self, the relation of itself to itself, is being-but not indeterminate, abstract being, for it is posited as negating the negation; it is, therefore, also determinate being for it contains negation in general and hence determinateness. It is and is there, present before us. It is only the spurious infinite which is the beyond, because it is only the negation of the finite posited as real ‚Äî as such it is the abstract, first negation; determined only as negative, the affirmation of determinate being is lacking in it; the spurious infinite, held fast as only negative, is even supposed to be not there, is supposed to be unattainable. However, to be thus unattainable is not its grandeur but its defect, which is at bottom the result of holding fast to the finite as such as a merely affirmative being. It is what is untrue that is unattainable, and such an infinite must be seen as a falsity. The image of the progress to infinity is the straight line, at the two limits of which alone the infinite is, and always only is where the line ‚Äî which is determinate being ‚Äî is not, and which goes out beyond to this negation of its determinate being, that is, to the indeterminate; the image of true infinity, bent back into itself, becomes the circle, the line which has reached itself, which is closed and wholly present, without beginning and end."

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 19:38:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Sorry, I haven't agreed that thoughts can't be reduced to other thoughts for basic premises. Formalism can acquire truth --- it can aquire the truth of formalism itself (i.e. it is immediate to itself, i.e. that is the science of logic, that's the whole point of the introduction as I read it). I think the term 'simpler' here is the problem for the simplest thoughts they are their own 'simpler' thoughts (i.e. once we get down to the level of contradiction it represets itself as a pure token).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 19:39:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 Is this andru? If so then whose the one doing weird sect stuff...

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:40:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He's joking that I'm taking this too seriously bcs of party discipline. Dave and I are in the same weird sect

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:41:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 So are you saying that contradiction cannot be reduced to simpler thoughts?

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:45:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Contradiction as "is & is not" Is a dialectical unity of Being and Nothing, or contains "is" and "not"

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 19:45:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think there is an assumption here (on your part) that formalism entails assumption beyond the object of the formal itself and I think that needs to be disentangled: What I read Hegel saying here is not that we need to reach beyond formalism but rather that we need to turn formalism against itself at its base (i.e. for me the more interesting line is *their truth or reality examined by the light of their own laws* --- i.e. we need to peer into them or the end is also important *we have merely to let the thought-forms follow the impulse of their own organic life* --- i.e. peer into them).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 19:47:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 *as the agreement of a thought-content with itself.* (i.e. we have to peer into the object to determine its truth, we are diving in, not building out).

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:48:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I agree that Hegel is interestes in "forms", absolutely. But Alex and I were disagreeing about the value in formalizing the thoughts of Being and Nothing in symbolic logic of Category theory.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 19:48:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I mean there definitely is, the first step is not justified really --- his choice of being over nothing which is the starting step of idealism vs. materialism in my opinion, and I'm sure there are other semi-broken steps throughout

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:48:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I am open to it having *some* value. But I think the value these ideas hold in SoL is lost

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:49:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I don't think either Being nor Nothing precede each other *logically*

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:49:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think he acknowledges either could come first

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:54:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 No you cannot use the quotes of "peering into them" to say that the movement of the logic is doing that. Every single moment requires the individual thought to be "peered into" in its Immediacy to establish its Truth before moving on. It's not that the movement of the Logic is peering more and more "into" or "inside" The language of "in" and "into" are not the same as "inside". The Doctrine of Essence discusses outer appearance versus inner essence. Even here, its more of a linguistic thing than insideness as spacial; at least usually. Sometimes it happens to be spacially inside. But even in our current chapter, limit and inside are *not* spacial. All that visual imagery can be helpful to develop the thoughts, but we ultimately have to let it go and understand these thoughts as "pure abstraction", as thoughts simply as they are derived

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 19:56:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "building" is a problematic metaphor too, except we are accumulating thoughts; some are connects in complex structures, some aren't. But any metaphor, spacial or otherwise is ultimately not reliable

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 19:57:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yes and being and nothing become determinate once we establish determinate being occurs within them (i.e. the determinate being curls back and impacts them and their meaning by being contained within them).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 19:58:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Not at first, but once you get to determinate being they do.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:02:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Are you saying Determinate being is contained in Pure being?

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:04:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:06:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:08:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    That's always how nothing is a moment, in determinating the Not

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:11:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Sorry read the text even more closely --- he's saying that there is a thing which is being and nothing and when we're looking at the portion of the thing that is outside of determinate being that is when its this 'pure nothing' and 'pure being' but when we consider the unified portion of this thing we get determinate being. Its like how I'm Mr. Jones if I meet a cop, Dr. Jones if I'm at a conference, Thomas to my friends, and Tom to people who don't know me very well in professional settings. Its a naming convention over a partial object. I.e. now that the contradiction of being and nothing has moved into determinate being it isn't a pure abstract contradiction but becomes filled in with specificity.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:12:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Determinate being contains their unity in that *a* determinate being: "is this & is not that"

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:12:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yeah but this thought is linguistic its already formalized. I'm treating them like somethings because determinate being is a moment of being just as being is a moment of determinate being.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:13:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Any example requires somethings, right?

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:13:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:14:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Having moments would make it determinate

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:15:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But my point is that this what they are 'as such' --- being is a contradiction of somethings 'as such' in its own essence *because* determinate being is a necessary consequence of it --- to say otherwise is to say that determinate being is not a consequence, its to move from being-nothing-becoming to determinate being in a metaphysical manner.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:16:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But a consequence means Being determines Det Being, not the other way aruond

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:18:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    If you think about the "What Is", ie of everthing - actual and potential and otherwise. "What Is" is Da-Sein, Det Being. The "what" of "what is" is distinct for the "is". Normal science / physics / empirical science pays attention to the "what" to the loss of the "is". Being is not a container of "what is", but the is-ness of it

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:19:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:22:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:23:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:26:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yeah, I know that they aren't spatial (in a materialist way) I'm saying that they are conceptually inside, that the further developments are necessary from the previous ones (i.e. that there is an if-then relation). We aren't going 'outside' because we aren't just assuming determinate being into existence, the claim is that its a necessary development that results from being. If you start saying 'oh well this next thing is outside this previous thing' then to me that means 'oh this next thing is something extra from this previous thing, not a necessary development from it but just some crap I pulled out of my ass'.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:28:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yeah, I mean something formal by 'inside' and 'outside' and I use those words advisedly because I think that this is what people tend to think when we say something is 'outside' or 'building': they tend to think that they are doing actual work with the development of determinate being and such wheras the point is that, no, that is all just a necessary consequence. Its work for us as thinkers (because the consequence is not always immediately visible in the consequent) but it is internal to the consequent, a part of it that you can't just chop off.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:32:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I understand better what you mean: the movment is immanent and logically necessary, from the "peering into", the thoughts, we see their truth, and the movement is a result of their truth. What I have been reacting to is the "container" language, set-theoretical or otherwise. I also agree absolutely "its work for us as thinkers"; and not external from our conscious thought; the goal is to clear ones mind sufficiently that the thoughts themselves determine their own movment, not that they are moved by our mind.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 20:33:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "if then" structure would have to be developed though, and obv its a later historical development. The structure of the movement is logical precisely in the sense of coming-to-be and ceasing-to-be and other internal ideas

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:35:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Are you saying that there is no being in determinate being? that seems like a crazy position (i.e. that being doesn't apply to determinate being). Ah, I think I see now... when I say 'x is not y' you are still treating this as if y is exactly equal to the territory that perfectly excludes x. How about this line: the state of Washington is not the United States. I.e. having being as a negative moment of determinate being doesn't say anything about its containment. Or to put even better --- the mind is not the brain (even though in some sense they perfectly overlap).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:40:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 No, that's not how consequences work --- its the consequence which determines the consequent at the level of qualities (the consequent merely determines the 'truth' of the consequence --- at the level of everything but truth the consequence determines the consequent in a back propagatory manner).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:41:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 As determinate being, being has moments.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:44:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 No, being isn't even the 'is' (that's actuality). Being is the very capacity for having a word at all... which applies to all the words and it picks up whatever the words are able to understand about themselves in the process.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:46:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yes but being and nothing require 'is and is not' as moments as well: they both require each other.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 20:49:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:11:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yeah, but Andru's point is precisely that these are not to be taken as concepts but as immediate experience for which instructions are conveyed through text. The question is about the justification of "being is" because "is" already contains being. But is is a concept. You can't ground immediate experience on a concept.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:12:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 23:14:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I am not claiming they are *not concepts*. But their concept is derived not from other concepts, only a description of a mental state taken to be the referent of the concept. Even concepts grounded in other concepts can be held *immediately* in ones mind. You have an *experience* of various concepts in your mind when you do your logic research

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 23:19:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:20:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I will be interested to read it

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:22:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 What i mean here is that if I say 'if a then b' yes the typical reading is that a implies b, i.e. the truth of a garuntees the truth of b. But reverse this and the other way of writing it is '-b -> -a'. And the problem is that things like 'quality' 'determination', etc... these are all negations, so what that means is that their negatory aspect back propagates into a through the necessesity.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 23:25:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I don't think you can import contraposition here. This is preciesly the importnace of understing Hegel's logic *in its own terms*. The movements are of Being, Nothing, Becoming, Negation, Determination. They are different logical operators than If-Then

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 23:25:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    its just *not* that form of logical implication

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:27:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think by being Hegel means something like 'that which everything has in common'

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:29:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I don't think hegel is doing anything useful or comprehensable without contraposition

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:30:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I thought his definition made sense: being, pure being, as in, something defined and with no other qualities except that it exists, without a particular spatial extension or the like and also without an internal speration, which would be a distinction that is no longer pure being. The thought of this isn't particularly strange to me because I know such a structure from homotopy type theory, wherein it can also be described as the result of, basically, collapsing or suspending any particular structure by making all of its parts equal to itself, which is why it also made sense that he would say it is simple equality with itself. This goes into how a better treatment of equality can be as a structure instead of a property, an equality between two things or even of a thing to itself either existing or not instead of two things either being equal or not. This goes into how equality also can be not simple. I've seen all of this before, so it makes a lot of sense to me to see it again. Now, as to whether we can experience pure being, we clearly can experience our existence, but that is much more specific, but does the notion or image or even complex of images I hold in my mind count as experience even if it is fairly precise and detailed? Or is it better approached through meditation, which would be in some ways more immediate and is also something Hegel mentions as an approach? It really depends on what you count as experience.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:32:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 How do we get to nothing from here (mathematically)?

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 23:33:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:36:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I suppose the sense is that through meditation particularities of our consciousness can be stripped away, even to the point that spatial and temporal thinking as well as any other particularities are suspended

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 23:40:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I agree that stripping away is necessary. Otherwise it would be something, would be spatial or temporal, etc. That's why I have compared it (clumsily) to Meditation. He does discuss "empty consciousness". And in a sense, its mediated by the process to get to it. But *logically* it depends on no other thoughts or concepts

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 23:41:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "what the Indian calls Brahma, when for years on end, physically motionless and equally unmoved in sensation, conception, fantasy, desire and so on, looking only at the tip of his nose, he says inwardly only Om, Om, Om, or else nothing at all. *This dull, empty consciousness, understood as consciousness, is ‚Äî being*."

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 23:41:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Its an ancient religious idea that by clearing ones mind, one just "is being", one experiences "being"

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:43:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 But then he points out that this space isn't completely clear because immediately things pop up into it. My difficulty is that I think of immediate as being literally im-mediate --- i.e. a double mediation (double negation since mediation is a negation and immediate is the negation of negation).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:44:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And in this sense the immediate is a form of mediation itself.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 09 2024 23:44:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Mediation is not necessarily negation though.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:45:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It is because mediation always demands a second or third term (If I'm mediated I need some kind of vouchsafe to mediate me, I am not complete)

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:45:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Nothing is the initial object/the empty set, containing nothing and being contained in everything in a precise mathematical sense. Now, the interesting thing is that for any particular background (mathematical) universe, every object is between the being and nothing of that universe, and in this precise sense these notions are even more basic than that of any other objects, which are between the two. But, for any particular universe we can step outside of it and treat the objects of this universe as in turn induced through structure outside of that universe. I'm using the term universe illustratively here, but it has a precise meaning, and one of its fundamental features is that every such universe is contained within another generalized universe, and in this background universe every object of the initial universe is an instantiation of being, basically, and thus abstractly the same thing, namely being. So being and nothing in our initial universe are both instantiations of being in our background universe and thus abstractly the same thing, though their role in the concrete initial universe is precisely opposing. I'm explaining a lot of theory fairly roughly here, so I'm sorry if it sounds a little confusing.

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:46:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Containing nothing is a bit of a clumsy description, actually, it's better to say consisting of nothing

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:48:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    One can also say that "every such universe generates another generalized universe out of it that then contains it". Both perspectives can be used as a starting point

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:49:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So being and nothing are kind of universal in an even more fundamental way than even mathematical universes

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:49:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So every universe can mediate some other --- but how do we mediate mediation itself?

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:50:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Category theory. That's what it's all about. Or at least a good part of it.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 09 2024 23:53:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But then, I think you're claiming that category theory is immediate, that it's being üòÑ

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:53:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Category theory arises precisely when we zoom out of particular structures and instead look at their relations. But these relations in turn form a structure themselves, and structures of this kind can be compared between each other, forming a higher network of relations and therefore a structure, and so on‚Ä¶ but, interestingly, this process has a limit: the ‚àû-category of ‚àû-categories, which contains itself, up to size issues that stem from Russell's paradox (therefore, strictly speaking, it doesn't exist, what exists is a "tower" of ‚àû-categories of "small" ‚àû-categories that never ends. I know you'll love this).

  • nameiwillforgetFri Feb 09 2024 23:55:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 No, I'm saying it's the most "mediated" thing, at least in the sense that it considers and is composed of all relations between everything in a giant and extremely complex network, basically. Not at all like pure being though, which has no further structure. This has lots of very complex structure.

  • andru0358Sat Feb 10 2024 00:08:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Negation also not the same as nothing ,it's ceasing-to-be or not-being. Negation requires being

  • firedog235Sat Feb 10 2024 00:18:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 But I think this is my point, the most mediated thing is the most immediate.

  • firedog235Sat Feb 10 2024 00:18:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Because its contradiction

  • firedog235Sat Feb 10 2024 00:25:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I didn't say that negation is the same as nothing, but nothing is a negation (¬ß 135 --- nothing is immediate negation).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 10 2024 00:25:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I personally would even say that nothing is immediacy itself.

  • nameiwillforgetSat Feb 10 2024 00:29:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Yeah, but it's not though

  • nameiwillforgetSat Feb 10 2024 00:31:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It sounds intuitive from a yin-yang-balance kind of intuition, but once one applies formalism to it, it shows itself that the chain of higher structures never goes back into lower ones

  • firedog235.Sat Feb 10 2024 00:53:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Well the structures inside the chain don't, but the chain itself is infinite (and as hegel says, that means it has a self similarity and as he'll develop that self similarity is actually non- relation, which I've airways read as contradiction).

  • andru0358Sat Feb 10 2024 01:02:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 What is the most mediated thing?

  • andru0358Sat Feb 10 2024 03:08:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Is being a container then? Maybe it is

  • minimaltomSat Feb 10 2024 04:29:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 This may be too wishywashy but maybe Being is just nothing, you can't hold it in mind because when you try you just get nothing. All I get when I try to think of Being is something that is, but I don't think thats pure Being so I try to think of whats even more fundamental than what 'is' and theres nothing, I fail to think pure Being so I just end up with Nothing.

  • firedog235.Sat Feb 10 2024 04:29:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The most mediated thing is contradiction-nothing --- though I think here I'm thinking new thoughts. I'm not completely certain on this question of mediation and immediate objects: it feels correct to me to say that contradiction is simultaneously the most mediated thing (because it's not every other thing) and also its totally immediate/immediacy itself (both at the level of thought---om, of, om, but also because I think contradictions are the sort of hard nodal points of non-exisrence that structure everything else: what we also call 'material').

  • minimaltomSat Feb 10 2024 04:30:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Trying to define what Being is is maybe to not follow the rules Hegel sets out because he says its not got any determination.

  • firedog235.Sat Feb 10 2024 04:31:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And also its got all the determinations, he does state the beginning is the end

  • minimaltomSat Feb 10 2024 04:32:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Yes but we're percieving or taking it as if it hasn't.

  • minimaltomSat Feb 10 2024 04:33:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Sat Feb 10 2024 15:43:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0@firedog235#0 I'm curious what you mean "I've read every other thing"? Also, I don't think the contrapositive will apply retro-acticely back on these chapters because their logical structure is Not syllogistic. I could be wrong about that; truly. He describes things syllogistically sometimes; idk how contrapositive quite works with them. But all his movements, every single one of them is a Negation already. By my understanding; even the Becoming of Existence is the negation of indeterminacy. What becomes? Just the negation of the *form* of Being prior. This is why I think really understanding Being and Nothing is so important, however slippery. They really are the bases for the logical movements from there. With any of these moments, we think about: what it *is* - our understanding. Move from it by negation to it's opposite, but a new opposite, ie Existence -> Quality -> Something. All these movements are concretizing by negation. Which is to say, contra <@589918821729566721> , I don't think any of this is arbitrary at all. The terms might be, but the thoughts they signify are not.

  • andru0358Sat Feb 10 2024 15:43:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The beginning is even logically grounded: His whole purpose it to get from "pure thought" which is the basis of Being/Nothing, pure in the sense of Immediacy and not needing any other thoughts to know them. We can know is -ness, I think, from *our is -ness, our being*, as long as you separate it from the all the determinate content of your being. Pure Knowing is the conceptual basis to know the truth of something. My understanding is basically he is working towards a rigorous concept of Truth. Not a concrete truth, but the truth of 'what truth is', the immanent being of Truth. In this sense, we cannot necessarily know if we have the ideas of Being, nothing, becoming, etc. *in their truth* until we know *how to know the truth of any thought/object*. Which is the whole point of the book. And why it circles back. I don't think that makes it *logically* circular, but it might. We will have to see as we go.

  • andru0358Sat Feb 10 2024 15:46:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    How do you ever know if you have the *true* understanding of Truth?

  • dve.h_37844Sat Feb 10 2024 16:42:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Excellent articulation comrade. I completely agree.

  • firedog235Sat Feb 10 2024 17:43:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 If determinate being is to be taken as a consequence of being, then whether or not Hegel knew he was doing a syllogism, he was doing a syllogism (however I think that he did know and they are meant to follow as syllogisms: he keeps saying, 'this is not yet posited in this' 'now this is posited by that' which all mean that a syllogism is being followed). However the contrapositive is perfectly happy working through a -> -b ::: b -> -a and we have to remember that if we want positive b, we can just grab it as the next sublation (i.e. if quality is negative, something will be the positive of quality, if something is negative, its limit will be positive, etc.) . When you pair this with the fact that we fall through a contradiction just about every other step (becoming, the finite, the infinite, etc.) then -a also flips back and forth in its meanings as well (i.e. being is its own opposite in becoming, limit is ought and ought is limit in the finite, the finite is the infinite and the infinite is the finite in 'the one,' etc). I agree it isn't arbitrary: but it isn't just negation --- its concretizing through contradiction-resolution. My point is that 'is'-ness if it is to be immediate it is so only because it is the most mediated thing ever (this is my materialism speaking here: even if we meditate on this stuff that is only possible through the movement of history to make us capable of such meditation). I don't think immediate is prior to mediation, but rather the turning back of mediation against itself (its the self contradiction of mediation) You asked about a and -a being more or less simple than contradiction. The 'is' is not more simple but the '-' is the most simple thing of all: its immediacy itself --- however, it is also the most mediated object since it is also negation itself... I don't think it can be defined in any terms but itself, however it is also totally defined by itself (totally mediates itself because its totally mediated by 'everything').

  • firedog235Sat Feb 10 2024 19:00:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Every other thing means being around in Marxist spaces for 10 years, reading pieces of Hegel here and there, reading Zizek, my training as a computer science (which has a large dose of logic in it), reading Kant in school, Reading the grundrisse and other texts from Marx, Reading Mao, etc. Like just reading a lot of philosphically and political-economically oriented stuff which all has encounters with Hegel but isn't Hegel (except of course the pieces of Hegel which is Hegel). And my point isn't that these are all 'correct' but you encounter a lot of the arguments.

  • nameiwillforgetSat Feb 10 2024 20:45:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235.#0 I'd like a citation for that Hegel quote. Regardless, you should know that there are several kinds of infinity, and not just ‚Ñµ-s (which also don't return to their beginning). The inifiny in question here is basically infinite-dimensionality. And there is some truth to the idea that these structures are similar: they are similar in that a higher one contains the lower one (and not just as an object but also as a subset, to describe it in a set-theoretic analogy).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 10 2024 20:54:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 So this one is half a new thought --- Hegel keeps mentioning 'self-relation' when talking about infinity and further on he definitely mentions non-relation (on the chapter on the one where he brings in the void) but I think that what he means by this 'self' relation is fractal self-similarity.... i.e. the infinite as a Mandelbrot set. I'm not saying that he's saying that explicitly (i.e. these things are not officially described until the 1960s) but I think he's stumbling around this concept in the section on infinity and he keeps talking about the line of infinite progress but this is just to make the infinite finite and so its spurious and how we also have to make finite infinite and so I'm like 'what does it mean to make the finite infinite' and to me that's fractal self similarity). ‚Ñµ-0 returns in that everything in it is a number, we can rebase anywhere we want (we can make any number zero when we reframe), We usually base the list of numbers themselves off a finite program or set of assumptions, etc. etc. (and this is the infinite finite I'm talking about: if there is any kind of relation, including non-relation --- which is a relation turned against itself --- then we are able to make the infinite finite and the finite infinite).

  • andru0358Sat Feb 10 2024 22:41:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Two points: Re: it's not just negation: My understanding of contradiction-resolution is negation of negation. Every movement seems to involved discussing a lack in the previous moment; Quality is folded back into existence even, meaning Being is being becoming concrete. Only with Something is it *a* being, an existent proper. And that is also the first Negation of the Negation, he says. I'm trying to re-read the chapter slowly & carefully having profitted a lot from discussing the immanent connection of the forms and the movements. Trying to comb out the structure of the movements. I still don't think they are syllogistic. Also: positing comes from the realm of essence, he notes this somewhere and it's explicit in that book. Syllogism comes from the book on concept: only after Universal, particular, singular, which syllogisms depend on. Syllogism is one version of if-then structure; it seems like you mean it in a more modern, broader if-then structure. If you says that consequences implies such a structure; doesn't that assume a specific *type* of consequentiality? Is it possible that if-then is one form but there could be others? Are you suggesting that thought requires the structure you have in mind? Or perhaps you're projecting how you think onto it? Maybe there's a good argument for what you are suggesting; but I do not feel convinced

  • nameiwillforgetSat Feb 10 2024 22:59:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 You can actually explain this a lot easier: infinity, as in, say, the infinite numbers from ‚Ñµ_0 onwards, arises at the limit of the finite, just in the classical way in which a limit sequence works, or the axiom of infinity, therefore is defined by the finite and furthermore is bounded by the finite, as in, if you imagine the infinite numbers as an interval, then it is half-closed with ‚Ñµ_0 its boundary. Therefore it is not truly infinite, (note that the German word "unendlich" literally means without end or boundary) as it has an end. Similarly, the finite numbers are only defined as finite by not being infinite, and furthermore, tend towards infinity. Therefore, both of these notions are intertwined and one goes into the other through negation, meaning complementation: the complement of the infinite numbers are the finite ones and the other way around. Hegel now says that this going into each other should be understood sequentially and forms "true infinity" as infinity going into finitude and then back into infinity infinitely often. I'll write it up more closely if I have the time.

  • nameiwillforgetSat Feb 10 2024 23:07:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Side note: did you see the Legacy of Lenin panel with Studebaker? I thought that one was really good

  • dve.h_37844Sun Feb 11 2024 12:38:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I put this on and re-read the section on negative being and it made sense. https://youtu.be/0PcIFk2t2ns?si=2fv_CGdoPyEsuVGM

  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 19:32:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Re: infinite: <@638122715668152320> my understanding is that infinite of limits of a sequence, ie the way real numbers tend towards infinity but are always themselves finite, that's a math version of what Hegel calls 'bad infinity', right? I can get a reference in a bit if you want. In The passage I read closely on the infinite within the finite, the argument goes like this: That finitude is *internally* determined to be finite; that it is intrinsic to finitude to be finite. Therefore, the finitude of finitude is not contingent on any*external* determinations. Therefore, nothing outside of it can lead it to cease-to-be. Finitude is the intrinsic nature towards ceasing-to-be (established in the prior section). By self-determining this ceasing-to-be, finitude will *always* contain this end. It's this "always", which Hegel takes as it's infinity; infinity as eternality. Eternality in classical philosophy (Engles gets this wrong in Anti-Duhring), is not persistent through time, but established outside of time. Of course Hegel doesn't mean anything temporal in the context. Eternal means outside of the changes within movement of Logic. Because it's self-determining, no other movements can change the nature of the finitude to be finite. But this self-determining means that finitude never "ceases to be" finite. And therefore this aspect of it is infinite. I know it's weird because finitude is thought as a quality of a something; but here it's both the quality and the something. The question is finitude as a concept itself finite? And it's the weird Hegelian way of thinking that forces the answer to be "yes! It must be, immanently!" That's immanence is based in Hegels method of finding the content in the form, and the truth of the content, and re-establishing our understanding of the form based on this immanent truth. Idk if I'm making sense; I honestly am not quite sure why the concept of finitude would have to be finite. He concludes it doesn't, and that seems right

  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 19:32:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But I think that helps makes sense of what he means as infinite in terms of self-relation and eternality. Although I of course might be wrong and welcome your critiques

  • nameiwillforgetSun Feb 11 2024 19:58:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "my understanding is that infinite of limits of a sequence, ie the way real numbers tend towards infinity but are always themselves finite, that's a math version of what Hegel calls 'bad infinity', right?" Yes

  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 20:00:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235.#0 I'm also coming to be more sympathetic to both ideas of contra-position and mediation of immediacy. The more he establishes about Existence in chapter two, the more we know what Pure Being is Not. He said "something is, and therefore also is an existent". So Is-ness is actually Existence (being, but determinate being). I am thinking the best way to approach the two primordials is: Nothing is that which has Being but not Existence, is not something. But this approach is mediated. It's basically the contra-position which Thomas was talking about; back propagating negation. Or maybe I'm stretching that too much.

  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 20:00:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hope I'm not dumping too much in here. Always open to feedback

  • nameiwillforgetSun Feb 11 2024 20:03:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This infinity excludes and is therefore bounded by the finite and therefore not in the literal German sense infinite. Its negation, meaning complement, is the finite, and and similarly the complement of the finite is the infinite and the two are co-determined (at least according to Hegel). Hegel then says that this process of negation as he described it should be taken to actually happen sequentiall, and that the "infinity of reason" is this finitude going into infinity and vice versa.

  • nameiwillforgetSun Feb 11 2024 20:13:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "That finitude is internally determined to be finite; that it is intrinsic to finitude to be finite." The more important point is that it is in the finite to become infinite. The infinite is what Hegel calls finitude's "Ansichsein". "Therefore, the finitude of finitude is not contingent on anyexternal determinations." Well, no, finitude already contains the concept of infinity and its "Ansichsein" is already in (bad) infinity, and similarly the conepto of bad infinity is finite in that it has a boundary. Therefore these two concepts are co-determinate and that is what makes the movement of one into the other possible that constitutes the infinity of reason.

  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 20:18:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    You're taking a comment out of context where I am explaining *how* the infinite is contained in the concept of finitude.......

  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 20:47:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I admit I might have explained it poorly. I think he is more clear that his talking about 'finite things', not finitude as finite. But then he moves into then he moves into the *Being of finitude* in the finite: "But the point is, whether in thinking of the finite one holds fast to the being of finitude and lets the transitoriness continue to be, or whether the transitoriness and the ceasing-to-be cease to be. But it is precisely in that view of the finite which makes ceasing-to-be the final determination of the finite, that this does not happen. **It is the express assertion that the finite is irreconcilable with the infinite and cannot be united with it, that the finite is utterly opposed to the infinite.** Being, absolute being, is ascribed to the infinite; confronting it, the finite thus remains held fast as its negative; incapable of union with the infinite, it remains absolute on its own side; from the affirmative, from the infinite, it would receive affirmation, and would thus cease to be; but a union with the infinite is just what is declared to be impossible."

  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 20:48:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Paragraph 251

  • nameiwillforgetSun Feb 11 2024 21:04:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yeah, but that's the bad perspective of understanding that Hegel is speaking against

  • nameiwillforgetSun Feb 11 2024 21:12:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Because it doesn't recognize that finitude becomes infinity and vice versa

  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 21:46:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I agree. But as Thomas mentioned, that bad perspective is intrinsic to immediate understanding of the finite. It's a great example of the necessity for immanent critique of that understanding; not to take the ideas merely as given. That was the whole point of my explanation. So it's entirely pointless to disagree with me on a technicality which as yet to be established. This is precisely the problem of formalism: that it fails to see the kernel of truth in what does not match up to our pre-conecieved understanding. I wasn't even saying that infinity is excluded from finitude. You're imposing that; a concept can contain both infinity and finitude. My language is actually pretty careful about that. Your "already" is precisely the mistake. This is all part of establishing the infinity of finitude. It cannot be brought in from outside: precisely the meaning of the section is the "immediacy of finitude" One has to pass through this contradiction within the Being of Finitude, the holding the idea of finitude in one's mind, in order to find the infinite united in it. To simply assert it misses the *movement*, misses the Reason, Vernuft of the logic. If we don't follow the movement of how each moment comes-to-be, then we can't understand it from the logic itself, but are left importing our pre-conecieved ideas, wrongly.

  • nameiwillforgetSun Feb 11 2024 22:05:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 We are still talking about when you said that "the finitude of finitude is not dependent on any external determinations", right? Because I still think that Hegel doesn't think this is true: "In jedem liegt hiermit die Bestimmtheit des Anderen, die nach der Meinung des unendlichen Progresses voneinander ausgeschlossen sein sollen und nur abwechselnd aufeinander folgen; es kann keines gesetzt und gefa√üt werden ohne das andere, das Unendliche nicht ohne das Endliche, dieses nicht ohne das Unendliche. "In each lies therefore the determination of the other, which, according to the opinion of the infinite progress are excluded from each other and can only follow each other sequentially.: one cannot be determined and captured without the other, the infinite without the finite and tha not without the infinite".

  • nameiwillforgetSun Feb 11 2024 22:10:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think that's a lot more decisive on this than a paragraph that doesn't say the same thing and actually argues against what it is supposedly saying.
