  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 22:29:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I should have said "the finitude of finite things", I was conflating those to terms, but it's precisely their connection from which the contradiction arises. "When we say of things that they are finite, we understand thereby that they not only have a determinateness, ... but ...non-being constitutes their nature and being. Finite things are, but their relation to themselves is that they are negatively self-related and in this they are negatively self-related and in this very self-relation send themselves away beyond themselves, beyond their being. They are, but the truth of this being is their end." Paragraph 249

  • andru0358Sun Feb 11 2024 22:33:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    You're claiming "Hegel doesnt think thats true" as though Hegel claims they can't both be true. In your passage I think he's saying neither can be "entirely" captured without the other. But the finite comes first, and the infinite out of it, and turns back and determines the finite further

  • nameiwillforgetSun Feb 11 2024 22:46:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "You're claiming "Hegel doesnt think thats true" as though Hegel claims they can't both be true. In your passage I think he's saying neither can be "entirely" captured without the other. " No, you are right in that the difference is between finitude and finite things: a particular finite thing is determined by having an end, meaning excluding something. But in this determination is already contained the notion of the bad infinite as the negative, meaning complement: the complement of a finite thing is infinite. But the finite is only characterized by not being infinite but becoming infinite and the infinite by not being finite. "Nach ihrer n√§chsten, nur unmittelbaren Bestimmung genommen, so ist das Unendliche nur als das Hinausgehen √ºber das Endliche; es ist seiner Bestimmung nach die Negation des Endlichen; so ist das Endliche nur als das, wor√ºber hinausgegangen werden mu√ü, die Negation seiner an ihm selbst, welche die Unendlichkeit ist." "According to this next, only immediate determination is the infinite only the transcendence of the finite, it is in its determination the negation of the finite, as is the finite only that which has to be transcended, the negation at itself, wich is the infinity." Same paragraph

  • andru0358Mon Feb 12 2024 03:19:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    My understanding: the bad infinity is not mere bad in that it's negatively defined; but in being negatively defined as separate from finitude, finitude becomes it's other. The infinite cannot have an other: an other implies a limit. He's says that would be a finitized infinite. The true infinity is the the sublation of the finite and bad infinite, both are its moments.

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 12 2024 11:24:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Well, sure

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 16:34:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Re: it's not just negation: Yes, its negation of negation (contradiction, '-' -> '--' -> '- and --' -> '- and +') If positing comes from the realm of essence and positing is something we can do 'inside' and object in the chapter on being (he, does say things like 'now this is posited in this') then that means that at least some part of my loops-back-on-itself theory is correct (and of course it isn't my theory, its Zizek's theory of Hegel that you don't really know what is going on until the end of things 'the owl of Minerva alights at dusk'). So if-then (necessity) is the modern form of syllogism (syllogism was more limited than general necessity). However, we could say 'over-determined' which is a concept that means, at least in my reading, both determined by multiple things *and* determined as a contradiction (because if you are determined by multiple things, then the multiple things can determine in opposite directions which generates a contradiction). Over-determined is, of course, composed out of many possibly conflicting 'if-then' all competing with each other (thus it isn't separable from 'if-then' but begins to transcend it by way of generalization to a multiplicity of necessities).

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 16:41:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 I don't think this quite captures it --- everything you're saying is true until I notice that this sequential movement back and forth between finite and infinite *can also* be sold as a 'progressive' (spurious) infinite (i.e. *this* movement from infinite to finite is the 367th movement between infinite and finite, the next one will be the 368th, etc.) Instead you have to reduce it to the level of a time crystal and ask what is simultaneously not a movement and movement or what is simultaneously infinite and finite and to me that would be an object like the Mandelbrot set (which is finite in that it can be written as something like a closed form infinitely self-recursed).

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 16:46:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Does he conclude that the concept itself is finite or infinite --- I think that he concludes the concept of the finite itself is infinite (it *always* 'ceases-to-be' thus the infinite is found in the finite)?

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 17:03:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 That's why I say its fractal self-similarity: a finite thing which is also infinite (or rather, going on the difference between finite things and the spurious infinite, I would say that fractal self-similarity as a concept is the true infinite, and a particular self-similar fractal is one of the finite images of this whole concept which includes all such objects).

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 17:05:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I like the Mandelbrot set particularly because at some point we're going to get into non-relation which I believe is not exactly chaos but is deeply inter-related to chaos (I would say that in a 21st century 'Logic of Science' treatise that chaos, in the precise mathematical sense of sensitivity to initial conditions, would be a required moment of non-relation).

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 12 2024 17:31:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 No, because if you read carefully he never says that anything is "simultaneously infinite and finite" (he talks about finite infinity but that's slightly different and not about self-similarily but about the fact that this infinity has a boundary). He is careful in always saying that finitude is becoming infinity and vice versa, so this is clearly a sequential development, not a temporal one. Wtf is a "time crystal"? Sounds like something from Bravest Warriors.

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 12 2024 17:33:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 Where exactly does he say that?

  • dve.h_37844Mon Feb 12 2024 17:35:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 > The ought as such contains limitation, and limitation contains the ought. Their relation to each other is the finite itself which contains them both in its being-within-self. These moments of its determination are qualitatively opposed; limitation is determined as the negative of the ought and the ought likewise as the negative of limitation. The finite is thus inwardly self-contradictory; it sublates itself, ceases to be. But this its result, the negative as such, is [a] its very determination; for it is the negative of the negative. Thus, in ceasing to be, the finite has not ceased to be; it has become in the first instance only another finite which, however, is equally a ceasing-to-be as transition into another finite, and so on to infinity.

  • dve.h_37844Mon Feb 12 2024 17:35:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    269 on Marxists.org

  • dve.h_37844Mon Feb 12 2024 17:38:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He goes on > But [b] closer consideration of this result shows that the finite in its ceasing-to-be, in this negation of itself has attained its being-in-itself, is united with itself. Each of its moments contains precisely this result; the ought transcends the limitation, that is, transcends itself; but beyond itself or its other, is only the limitation itself. The limitation, however, points directly beyond itself to its other, which is the ought; but this latter is the same duality of being-in-itself and determinate being as the limitation; it is the same thing; in going beyond itself, therefore, it equally only unites with itself. This identity with itself, the negation of negation, is affirmative being and thus the other of the finite, of the finite which is supposed to have the first negation for its determinateness; this other is the infinite.

  • dve.h_37844Mon Feb 12 2024 17:38:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (these two sections are part of the same paragraph from start to finish - the final paragraph before the section on infinity begins)

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 17:53:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 Yes and no --- there must be a parallax object (something which is a single object but flips back and forth in an unstable manner, like the image of the two faces/vase). So when you say 'one thing made up of tiny versions of itself' the two perspectives are 'one thing' and 'tiny versions of itself' that aren't the same because the tiny versions aren't at the same level as the whole thing.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 17:57:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 12 2024 17:58:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 12 2024 18:08:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 No, see, it's the other way around, he criticizes the idea of a unity: "Diese Bestimmung des wahrhaft Unendlichen kann nicht in die schon ger√ºgte Formel einer Einheit des Endlichen und Unendlichen gefa√üt werden; die Einheit ist abstrakte bewegungslose[163] Sichselbstgleichheit, und die Momente sind ebenso als unbewegte Seiende. Das Unendliche aber ist, wie seine beiden Momente, vielmehr wesentlich nur als Werden, aber das nun in seinen Momenten weiter bestimmte Werden. Dieses hat zun√§chst das abstrakte Sein und Nichts zu seinen Bestimmungen; als Ver√§nderung Daseiende, Etwas und Anderes; nun als Unendliches, Endliches und Unendliches, selbst als Werdende." "¬ß 301 This determination of the true infinite cannot be expressed in the formula, already criticised, of a unity of the finite and infinite; unity is abstract, inert self-sameness, and the moments are similarly only in the form of inert, simply affirmative being. The infinite, however, like its two moments, is essentially only as a becoming, but a becoming now further determined in its moments. Becoming, in the first instance, has abstract being and nothing for its determinations; as alteration, its moments possess determinate being, something and other; now, as the infinite, they are the finite and the infinite, which are themselves in process of becoming."

  • dve.h_37844Mon Feb 12 2024 18:30:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

But I don't think he means "before us" as in for us, this group, because I don't think any of us have quite got it üò¨ Let me know if I'm wrong and you have it before you in your thought

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 12 2024 19:05:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Can you give me a paragraph where it occurs?

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 20:29:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 So this is related to section 290: This yields the decried unity of the finite and the infinite ‚Äî the unity which is itself the infinite which embraces both itself and finitude ‚Äî and is therefore the infinite in a different sense from that in which the finite is regarded as separated and set apart from the infinite. Since now they must also be distinguished, each is, as has just been shown, in its own self the unity of both; thus we have two such unities. The common element, the unity of the two determinatenesses, as unity, posits them in the first place as negated, since each is supposed to be what it is in its distinction from the other; in their unity, therefore, they lose their qualitative nature-an important reflection for rebutting that idea of the unity which insists on holding fast to the infinite and finite in the quality they are supposed to have when taken in their separation from each other, a view which therefore sees in that unity only contradiction, **but not also resolution of the contradiction through the negation of the qualitative determinateness of both**; thus the unity of the infinite and finite, simple and general in the first instance, is falsified.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 20:29:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Then 293: The falsification of the finite and infinite by the understanding which holds fast to a qualitatively distinct relation between them and asserts that each in its own nature is separate, in fact absolutely separate from the other, comes from forgetting what the Notion of these moments is for the understanding itself. According to this, the unity of the finite and infinite is not an external bringing together of them, nor an incongruous combination alien to their own nature in which there would be joined together determinations inherently separate and opposed, each having a simple affirmative being independent of the other and incompatible with it; but each is in its own self this unity, and this only as a sublating of its own self in which neither would have the advantage over the other of having an in-itself and an affirmative determinate being. As has already been shown, finitude is only as a transcending of itself; it therefore contains infinity, the other of itself. ¬Æ Similarly, infinity is only as a transcending of the finite; it therefore essentially contains its other and is, consequently, in its own self the other of itself. The finite is not sublated by the infinite as by a power existing outside it; on the contrary, its infinity consists in sublating its own self.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 21:00:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He isn't criticizing unity to say that there is no unity of opposites: he's criticizing it as a point contradiction (i.e. thinking that the unity of opposites is simply just nullity: nonsense, incomprehensible and unparseable). The important line for me is just at the end of section 300: "The infinite, therefore, as now before us is, in fact, the process in which it is deposed to being only one of its determinations, the opposite of the finite, and so to **being itself only one of the finites**, and then raising this its difference from itself into the affirmation of itself and through this mediation becoming the true infinite. That what escapes the typcial story of the infinite is the way that the infinite contains itself as a finitized infinite. This does lead to the various alephs (after all, in some sense the distinction between ◊ê-0 and ◊ê-1 is that 1-◊ê is a reptition of the infinite within the infinite. A kind of infinite squared, its 'what if you have an infinite list of infinitely sized objects'). In that sense he's also talking about this division. But more importantly what he's saying is that in order for the infinite to be the *true infinite* it has to subordinate itself as a finite moment --- infinitely. And my point is that this is what a self-similar fractal accomplishes (or really I don't want to fall to far down this example path, what I mean is this is what self-similarity in general accomplishes: not just the fractals, but also the self-similarity held in the ◊ê-0 and ◊ê-1 distinction which is the self-similar fractal taken to a very high level: of course there are further determinations but the trick is that we have that the two step from 'infinite as another finite' to 'infinite as the infinite of the finitude of the infinite').

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 21:08:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Or to put it another way 'infinite as the infinite *failure* of the infinite' --- which I would say is self-similarity (i.e. the self-similar is never really self-similar).

  • firedog235Mon Feb 12 2024 21:10:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And also as we get further --- the self-similarity of self-similarity itself is non-relation (which is this failure) because the only thing which the set of all self-similar objects has in common is the fact that they don't relate to other objects in the set (because if they did, then they would be the same object, because each object is self-similar) and this is held in common with the set as a whole not just between all the objects in the set which then means that the set as a whole is self similar only on this one kind of relation: non-relation.

  • andru0358Tue Feb 13 2024 00:43:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Yea: paragraph 276 - second paragraph in Alternating Progression- it occurs 6 times. It does to be syllogistic. He uses to say "As ___ it is posited to be ___" where the latter is a determination or quality of the former. Although idk how consistent that is

  • nameiwillforgetTue Feb 13 2024 00:49:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "Gesetzt", which as a standalone word mainly means "typed" as in typing letters into a printing press, but is also kind of the adjective related to "Gesetz", meaning "law".

  • andru0358Tue Feb 13 2024 00:49:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Thank you!

  • andru0358Tue Feb 13 2024 00:50:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Idk what to make of that but okay

  • nameiwillforgetTue Feb 13 2024 00:50:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Yeah, it's not exactly an often used word

  • nameiwillforgetTue Feb 13 2024 01:53:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Oh, I forgot, it's also the past form of "to sit". In fact, that might be how it's most often used colloquially. However, Hegel mainly uses it in the passive present, not the active perfect, so "es ist gesetzt", meaning "it is typed", not "es hat sich gesetzt", meaning "it sat down".

  • nameiwillforgetTue Feb 13 2024 02:15:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It is sometimes used in the passive, I suppose, as in "ich habe das kind ins auto gesetzt", "I sat the child into the car", but "es ist gesetzt" in this meaning, as in "it is sat" is unusual. But actually thinking about it I'd say the closest translation would actually be "set", as in "we can set this variable to zero".

  • firedog235Tue Feb 13 2024 05:05:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Apparently the english word 'posit' has roughly the same origin and meaning but from the Latin --- it means to place. So 'to posit in' something means 'to place in something' or 'to set in something.' But in English it has the further meaning of 'to assume' as in 'set a variable to zero' could also be written 'lets assume the variable is zero' or another way to think about it might be 'lets find zero in this variable' (i.e. yes the variable can vary over all of a space, but lets just limit it to this space --- zero). Of course, in order to so posit something as zero it must be *possible* to posit it that way (to set it that way) so there is still a relation of necessity --- the necessity of possibility. (or the ought --- I ought to be able to set this to zero... so I will and consider what happens then). That's the kind of necessity I think we're dealing with in Hegel, speculative necessity.

  • dve.h_37844Tue Feb 13 2024 14:28:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What time are we meeting on the 17th?

  • andru0358Wed Feb 14 2024 02:37:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    From my investigations: "set" and "put" feel simplest; the connection to law, laws are "set" and "put" "in place". The word he uses for opposite = entgegengesetzt From Google translate: entgegen = in contrast to gesetzt = set Two opposites are "set in contrast to", posited in their contrast. -- herabgesetzt - "reduced" herab - down gesetzt - set --- herausgesetzt = exposed Her = here Ausgesetzt= exposed Aus = out out of Heraus = out of here Exposed = Set out, set out of here Set = exposed - out --- Festgesetzt = fixed Fest = firmly Fixed = firmly set Set = fixed - firmness --- vorausgesetzten = prerequisites vorausgesetzt = provided Voraus = in advance Vor = before --- zusammengesetzt = composed, compound zusammen = together, collectively, jointly Composed = set together, put together Idk if this is helpful, but it was fun. Alex can probably tell me I am off w some of these words. It seems to have a very basic grammatical operation, like how in"set in relation to" or "put in relation to" the word "set" and "put" mean very little. --- In the chapter in Essence where he discusses Posit*ing*(not posit*ed*), it is as "Positing Reflection" -"Die setzende Reflexion" Setzende = setting (according to Google translate). It's not clear what here is different simply being in Essence: Reflection: Shine, versus realm of Being: Existence. But he defines "positedness": "self-sublating immediacy" and "immediacy purely as *determinateness* or self-reflecting". I think something about immediate determination seems relevant. He seems to use in relation to determinations of concept in discussion

  • andru0358Wed Feb 14 2024 02:42:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/hegel/works/hl/hl399.htm#HL2_400 Paragraph 840 "The self-relation of the negative is, therefore, its return into itself; it is immediacy as the sublating of the negative; but immediacy simply and solely as this relation or as return from a negative, and hence a self-sublating immediacy. This is posited being or positedness, immediacy purely and simply as determinateness or as self-reflecting. "

  • andru0358Wed Feb 14 2024 02:43:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Back to infinity

  • andru0358Wed Feb 14 2024 02:48:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Finally reading the remarks at the end - super helpful: ¬ß 308 Thus the progress can be put in the following more characteristic form. The assertion is made: the finite and infinite are a single unity; this false assertion must be corrected by the opposite: they are absolutely different and opposed to each other; this must be corrected again by declaring that they are inseparable, that the determination of each lies in the other, by the assertion of their unity, and so on to infinity. What is required in order to see into the nature of the infinite is nothing difficult: it is to be aware that the infinite progress, the developed infinite of the understanding, is so constituted as to be the alternation of the two determinations, of the unity and the separation of both moments and also to be aware that this unity and this separation are themselves inseparable.

  • firedog235Wed Feb 14 2024 21:30:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Or to put it another way --- the infinite is the infinite failure of the infinite to be the infinite.

  • firedog235Wed Feb 14 2024 21:31:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 This does seem to claim that immediacy is post mediation (i.e. the negative has to return to itself before it can become immediate?)

  • andru0358Wed Feb 14 2024 22:45:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 In a sense. I believe so: I think what he's developing rigorously here he says elsewhere, which is everything is as much mediated as immediate in different ways. Like Being and Nothing only need to be immediate logically for their role in the beginning. Babies are not born with the *concepts* of Being and Nothing; but the idea of empty consciousness is often related to (inferred) baby consciousness. It requires no concept; and in that sense it's difficult to attain, mediated by discipline of the mind. But also, I have come to think, you don't have to *experience* emptiness to conceive of it. Holding part of your mind empty is enough to get the Idea. But they're still abract in the sense of abstracting from all determinations. And I think that's what he is developing on Essence: Reflection. That we have to reflect on the way we meditate thoughts to "turn back" to immediacy. Or something. Notice it's not immediacy as indeterminacy, like being, it's immediacy as determinateness. Excited to get there together.

  • andru0358Wed Feb 14 2024 23:09:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I think the True Infinity is the transcendence of the failure. The failure points to a beyond. You can't stop with the failure; idk if you're referring to the bad or true infinite. It kind of bothers me he doesn't develop a term for the bad infinity, ie the Beyond. I realize then the true infinity would then not have itself as a moment. And that maybe a concept as Beyond, would not fit some standard for it to be a stand alone concept. I'm curious if any of y'all have a sense of what those standards seem to be?

  • minimaltomWed Feb 14 2024 23:20:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    not up to infinity yet üòÑ really trying to understand the beggining, gonna hardcore it next few days and hopefully get there

  • minimaltomWed Feb 14 2024 23:23:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    up to finitude now

  • andru0358Wed Feb 14 2024 23:33:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I need to re-read the earlier parts myself!

  • firedog235Thu Feb 15 2024 08:42:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So actually as I was looking at this I think that the key to what he means by the infinite, and how it is distinguished from spurious infinity is in the beginning of the next chapter when he talks about 'the one' as being-for-self which is both its own being-in-itself and its own being-for-other: the point being that any self-similar loop is immediately infinite because it implies the possibility of infinity (i.e. that being-for-self relates to the infinite as determinate being relates to becoming: determinate being is the inner contradiction or internal movement to becoming's outer contradiction or outer movement). I think the infinite, Hegel's true infinite, is any finite that has two points that tie back to each other --- he says circle (and this is where the right Hegelians have a field day --- so many metaphors about God and circles come to mind along with demands for romantic return). And that structure and all those metaphors 'count' (i.e. they're very 'whatever') --- but as we'll see in the next section it also includes the constant return to a place from which no return to the past can occur or to retreat a bit the constant haunting of the possibility that the point of return on that finite space will fall into *any other infinite than the one we were previously dealing with:* i.e. the acknowledgement that this point of return in the junction of the finite-infinite is an instability that can orient towards any other infinite-finite. To me this is what is means by 'there is no beyond' --- we can always find ourselves jumping into some other infinite (in fact I would say statements that prove incompleteness are these kinds of jumping off points for new infinities because they return you to the place where you have something true that can be proven axiomatically, showing that the axioms have to grow, and even if more powerful axioms cause the number to shrink again --- unless you have a poweful paraconsisstent base you have to grow axioms again).

  • firedog235Thu Feb 15 2024 08:51:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 But doesn't he give us the term 'spurious (fake) infinite'? So to me the standard of a spurious infinite would be something like the movement of an engine subject to the consumption of some fuel --- i.e. its going to run out at some point and then it will do nothing forever (but as a result it will be subject to whatever forces move beyond it to effect it). That's why its a fake infinite. And the only true infinite would be an infinite that sets up, perfectly, the conditions of its own continuation --- i.e. that would have 'no beyond' because its perfectly established all the conditions for it to repeat itself. And then looking into the next chapter on the one (and throwing in some Zizek and cliff notes reading) it appears that the only thing which does this is the void (i.e. the perfect non-relation, i.e. the only thing which always sets itself up to occur again is the *possibility* --- not certainty --- of the *failure* to relate perfectly to the next future step in the chain of causality --- which is a consequence of contradiction, because if you have anything other than the *possibility* of such failure as such a relation then you have being which is something other than nothing).

  • dve.h_37844Thu Feb 15 2024 15:11:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Just realized I can‚Äôt make it to the group on the 17th. Was looking forward to it since there‚Äôs been so much good discussion. I‚Äôll watch the video and post my blasphemies next week!

  • minimaltomSat Feb 17 2024 14:45:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "because its perfectly established all the conditions for it to repeat itself." sounds to me like further spurious infinity.

  • minimaltomSat Feb 17 2024 15:28:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    spurious infinity will never run out of fuel, you can always add another zero to a number.

  • minimaltomSat Feb 17 2024 15:30:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    the whole point of spurious infinity is that you can always imagine another finite beyond it, it never runs out of further finitude, it never runs out of fuel.

  • minimaltomSat Feb 17 2024 15:50:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    only the finite runs out of fuel

    non jargon filled refutations to the above only please

  • firedog235Sat Feb 17 2024 22:28:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 What make the spurious infinite spurious isn't the repitition of it but rather the failure of repetition --- I'f I'm counting 1,2,3,4... --- 4 *is different* from 3 *is different* from 2, etc. I.e. I *failed* to repeat the previous number. When Hegel says the infinite is like a circle he means its a perfect reptition, not a partial repetition --- or rather that 'whatever the infinite is, its that which repeats perfectly' --- *not* that which repeats partially so that there is some way to measure how many repititions have occured. There should be no way to measure how many repetitions (and on the number line there is such a way, we just look at the number).

  • minimaltomSun Feb 18 2024 01:17:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 thats interesting but I don't think that means it ever runs out of fuel like an engine, it never ends, it is infinite, albeit 'bad/spurious' infinity. Saying all this though actually perhaps were both missing the point here because bad infinity is infact qualitative at this point not quantitative which appears later in the SL and is considered a true infinity I believe by Hegel. Also spurious/bad infinity is infact endless repetition, at least according to David Gray Carlsons 'Comentary to Hegels Science of Logic" "It is spurious because it names only the endless autistic alternation between being and non-being. It is not to be confused with quantitative infinity, which will be a true, not a spurious, infinite."

  • andru0358Sun Feb 18 2024 15:38:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I don't think repitition is a sufficient criteria. "Om, Om, Om..." Could be the infinite by that definition. It's not thag the alternating progression is problematic in it's not being repetitive. I don't remember him saying much about repitition at all. When he says a circle, my understanding is that it's like spurious infinity and negativity spurious infinity joining. Not like a circle you can draw. The true infinity sublates finitude and the beyond. It includes it's opposite and its own failure. Any description of infinite which involves an opposition would be false; the true infinite as much includes sequential progression as repitition. The problem of the spurious infinite is that it is *the other* of the finite. Even in a progression, it's a sense that the progression "to infinity"; but does not really say anything about what it is to, what is infinity, except it being beyond finite. This beyond-ness, tho, makes infinite limited to the beyond, that is the beyond is separate from finitude. But infinite cannot be limited. That's the key to this whole section, Hegel returns to it many times. The infinite cannot be thought as a beyond of finite because that would be a restriction on infinite. There's nothing the infinite is excluded from. But it's also not just Being; it is being, but not abstract or pure being. The image of the circle represents not repitition, but self reference. But it's not merely self reference; it's the self reference of everything - material and ideal. He says the infinity is the basis of Ideality. I think this is connected to what we were saying before: that finite things are connected to the infinite through the eternal nature of finitude. That distinction between finite things and finitude has something to do w ideality and the way the infinite is in all things

  • firedog235Sun Feb 18 2024 20:21:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "I don't think repetition is a sufficient criteria." It is necessary and that's why I said perfect repetition --- i.e. repetition without any possibility of a counter. "The problem of the spurious infinite is that it is the other of the finite." Its not that its the other of the finite I think, rather its that its otherness is externalized from the infinite rather than internalized. Its the *wrong* other of the finite. The circle is finite (i.e. its just a stupid object out it the world) but its infinite character is internalized as opposed to an unrolled oscillation on the number line. "This beyond-ness, tho, makes infinite limited to the beyond, that is the beyond is separate from finitude." --- I think he takes a stronger position here: not that it limits it to the beyond but rather that *there is no* beyond (i.e. the beyond is a contradiction, any time you encounter 'there is no' --- that means contradiction. There is no god: god is a contradiction, there is no subject: the subject is a contradiction, there is no woman: 'woman' is a contradiction, there is no proletariat: the proletariat is a contradiction). "There's nothing the infinite is excluded from" (Because the beyond is nothing, the infinite is excluded only from the beyond, because everything is excluded from the beyond or rather founded upon the contradiction of the beyond) What I'm thinking of is self-similar fractals and recursive functions where the infinite object (the recursive function) is *representable* as a finite object (a function that calls itself) and in this sense as a pure function that calls itself --- sets itself up to be called again perfectly --- it is the true infinite. The circle would also be a true infinite --- any point flows into all other points on the circle perfectly (at least if it is a perfect circle). Its just that the circle isn't *all* that the infinite is. Its both repetition and self-reference (self-reference require repetition).

  • firedog235Sun Feb 18 2024 20:24:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 thats interesting but I don't think that means it ever runs out of fuel like an engine, it never ends, it is infinite, albeit 'bad/spurious' infinity. --- well, I don't think so, the fact that it's the spurious infinity actually means its not an infinity.

  • firedog235Sun Feb 18 2024 20:27:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Saying all this though actually perhaps were both missing the point here because bad infinity is infact qualitative at this point not quantitative which appears later in the SL and is considered a true infinity I believe by Hegel. Also spurious/bad infinity is infact endless repetition, at least according to David Gray Carlsons 'Comentary to Hegels Science of Logic" I think you're missing the word 'perfect' in what I said. That modifier is doing a lot of work. An endless repitition (like on the number line) isn't perfect. If you have an actual perfect repetition then you can represent it as a finite recursive function: e.g. def f(x): return f(x) This would be a 'true infinity' (except of course it depends upon the drive of the computer and builds up stack, but if that is all abstracted away then it would be a true infinity: Hegel will go on further to develop that there is only the void as a true infinity I think in the next section but for now this suffices).

  • firedog235Sun Feb 18 2024 20:28:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 When are we meeting again? <@386755556817240065>

  • andru0358Sun Feb 18 2024 20:39:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The "internalized" other is correct, more precise than what I was saying. Where does he say "there is no beyond" that seems wrong to me. He says the true infinity has the bad infinity/the beyond as one of its moments. The beyond is nothing in the sense that Pure Being is nothing; nothing has being here tho. This is why this section and how we interpret it depends on and turns back to clarify the first chapter. I don't think fractals, circles or anything can be but an analogy for the true infinity. I think he literally means all that exists and the beyond are encapsulated on the true infinity. So maybe the true infinite has the form of something like a fractal. There does seem a recursiveness here. I don't know if it's necessarily "perfect repitition" tho. That would be static, not a becoming. He says the true infinity is a becoming. Like when you say "a perfect infinity" I don't think there can be *a* perfect infinity. That would suggest it is an existent, a something, and thereby finite.

  • firedog235Sun Feb 18 2024 21:31:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I'm saying it in that formula... Hegel gets close with $302 --- where he says "It is *only* the spurious infinite which is the beyond, because it is only the negation of the finite posited as real ‚Äî as such it is the abstract, first negation; determined only as negative, the affirmation of determinate being is lacking in it; the spurious infinite, held fast as only negative, is even supposed to be not there, is supposed to be unattainable." And I hold him also to be saying that the spurious infinite is a pure contradiction (i.e. in other places where he speaks about the contradictory unity of finite and infinite, its in the context of the spurious infinite). Further in that bit he says that the beyond is also the 'indeterminate' which I always take to be structured as a contradiction (undefined is always undefined becuase there are no answers and a multiplicity of answers which fit its structure lim x -> infinity 1/x is undefined --- indetermninate --- because its both positive and negative infinite). So I keep saying recursive fractals (and just to be clear, thought is structured as a recursive fractal, so I'm also talking about subjects here) because that is the most advanced object I can think of that meets his definition and it also sets us up for the next section where, I want to always formalize things as 'the x of x' --- i.e. the negation of negation, the determination of determination, the quality of quality, the something of something, the limit of limit, the finite of the finite, the infinite of the infinite, etc. And specifically if we really want to understand the void I'm saying 'oh yeah, that's the self-similarity of self-similarity (i.e. the infinite of the infinite). And I do think he means self-similarity, period, when he talks about the infinite (the fractals are an example).

  • firedog235Sun Feb 18 2024 21:35:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "That would be static, not a becoming. He says the true infinity is a becoming." What makes it into a becoming is the fact that the self-similarity of self-similarity is non-relation: i.e. the only thing which *actually* perfectly repeats itself like this is non-relation or failure or... contradiction. That's why the infinite is a becoming, but he hasn't clarified that in this section. Its an untied reference (i.e. becoming itself, the movement between various states, contradiction, is infinite, is eternal, is transcendental, etc. --- there is a transcendental object, it just the transcendental object is the contradiction of the statement 'the only thing that doesn't change is demand for change itself' --- which is a nothing as well or to put it another way *there is no* transcendental object --- because the transcendtal object is contradiction itself).

  • andru0358Sun Feb 18 2024 21:53:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Do you consider emptiness to be a contradiction?

  • andru0358Sun Feb 18 2024 22:12:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0@firedog235#0 You also didn't reply to my point about the singularity of *the* true infinity. I'm curious what you think, if you disagree. I think this is a moment which clarifies the metaphysical nature of the text. It's not *just* a logic; the abstractions are not separated from physical world or actuality. It's about Being. <@638122715668152320> referred to metaphysics as outside the physical world. I don't think that is what it means for Hegel or Aristotle. What Hegel is saying here about Ideality and Reality is what I understand metaphysics to be about. He seems to be basically saying with the infinite, ideality enters as affirmative content. Ideality unites finite things to the infinite, the ideal. Does this passage make yall uncomfortable? ""¬ß 316 The proposition that the finite is ideal [ideell] constitutes idealism. The idealism of philosophy consists in nothing else than in recognising that the finite has no veritable being. Every philosophy is essentially an idealism or at least has idealism for its principle, and the question then is only how far this principle is actually carried out. This is as true of philosophy as of religion; for religion equally does not recognise finitude as a veritable being, as something ultimate and absolute or as something underived, uncreated, eternal. Consequently the opposition of idealistic and realistic philosophy has no significance.""

  • andru0358Sun Feb 18 2024 22:22:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 By transcendental here do you mean something like this beyondness or ideality?

    @firedog235#0 Your code is exactly spurious infinity, it‚Äôs no different than a number line, in fact you could count the recursions, again you‚Äôre muddying the water with jargon

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 00:02:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    In fact maybe that‚Äôs not spurious infinity, spurious infinity isn‚Äôt about number lines or recursion or anything. That can be used as an analogy sure and they are of course related but we‚Äôre pre quantity here.

    Just saying, ah that‚Äôs the same as something else like a numerical infinity therefore I‚Äôve explained it is not to understand it.

    It‚Äôs like you understand maths/logic and something you see is comparable so you say ah! I‚Äôve understood one so I understand the other, that‚Äôs not how it works

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 00:14:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Where do quality, something, something/other, being-in-itself/for-other, limit, constitution and so on come into your understanding of infinity? You‚Äôve just jumped straight into the sexy glamorous section of infinity and fuddled it together from other things you know.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 02:06:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think this is the common understanding of contradiction (i.e. when I was learning symbolic logic this was what my brain spontaneously snapped to for contradiction --- what is the rational square root of 2? It just a 404 error.) This is not *all* of what a contradiction is, but its certainly the first order of what a contradiction is (before it *also* appears as a positive object that doesn't fit the context --- i.e. exception , or a movement between two possibilities within the context, or a single object that creates such a movement --- i.e. universal, and finally the it reappears as the need for such an object in all contexts). The last thing is emptiness as such but before you can get there you have move through a specific emptiness, and not every step is an emptiness. The singularity of the true infinite is its multiplicity (he'll get into that in the whole point about the one vs. the many I think --- i.e. the true infinite is the very fractured nature of all other infinities). I.e. the true infinite is contradiction because contradiction is, under some context, able to produce any particular object. That's what I meant when I was talking about infinite being failure and contradiction --- that its a singular object that fails to be a singular object.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 02:18:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 On $316 It doesn't make me uncomfortable... but with the huge caveat that I've been pretty certain most Marxists have an idealist notion of materialism for a long time (a lot of which is the fault of Stalinism impacting even the non-Stalinist strains of Marxism). When Marxists are like 'materialism is... the idea that the universe is made out of atoms (super bad) or even that production is primary in the relation of structure and superstructure (bad, but better) they're not really boiling materialism down into its primary idealist principle (i.e. they are not recognizing both how materialism must not only stand in opposition to idealism, but must also stand as an idealism --- i.e. must be a sublation of idealism --- and thus in what sense there is something eternal in materialism. For me, however, the key to materialism is the reduction of all possible eternal principles down to a single self-contradictory principle of contradiction). Thus, the problem with 'idealism' isn't that there isn't a 'one' but that people are constantly appealing to the wrong one, an inflated one, that is other than 'the void'.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 02:28:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Its not the spurious infinity --- I explicitly said to abstract away the stack and any other mechanism to count the recursions. Its not useless Jargon and I'm not just going 'aha maths = infinity' either. The reason I keep saying self-similar fractals (or rather, the reason I keep saying self-similarity itself which is the whole category of all such fractals) is because I've read ahead a bit and seen that Hegel is going to start talking about 'the one' and the 'the many' and 'the void' and 'non-relation'. And what I think is interesting is that the self-similarity of self-similarity itself (i.e. the way that the set of all self-similar objects is similar to each of the objects it contains) is that none of them relate to each other because if they did they would, definition-ally, contain each other (because if they relate to each other then you only need one of them to represent all of them --- i.e. if one of these objects contains another of these objects, then they are the same object because each of them is self-similar). And that means that non-relation is the self-similarity of self-similarity (just as the infinite is the finitude of the finite, the finite is the limitation of limitation, limitation is the something of something, something is the quality of quality, quality is the determination of determination, determination is the becoming of becoming, becoming is the nothing of nothing, and nothing is the negation of the negation). That's my understanding of how each of these things relates to the previous order of things --- that they're all negations and specifically they're all negations of negation so they call be turned against themselves.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 02:36:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (though I think that last one is bit confused because, once again, he starts with being but should start with nothing making being into negation of negation with nothing as pure negation).

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 05:21:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    it is "unnecessary" jargon. What you described there is still spurious/bad infinity despite the slight of hand trick by "abstracting away" the stack. It is infinity of the understanding or common use, not the infinity of Reason. It is debated whether the term should be bad or spurious anyway. Bad would imply that it is infinity only of a bad kind wheras spurious would imply its fake, not real infinity. The German terms Hegel uses are slecht(bad) and echt(true or really??). I'd still like to hear you convincingly describe how Determinate Being progresses through Something/Other, Ought, Limit, finitude, Infinity and so on. Or part of it at least.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 06:13:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Its spurious (Hegel says explicitely at some point that its not a true infinity, i.e. fake --- I think the debate would be whether is *also* bad). That's not a 'slight hand trick' --- what I'm abstracting away is precisely all the bits that would make it spurious (i.e. I agree that yes, with a stack it would be spurious, yes, with a counter it would be spurious --- but if you abstract, i.e. strip out, all that stuff and leave it only as a pure recursion then its no longer spurious). Its like we're talking about cats and I'm saying 'a house cat like a lion except its smaller, friendlier to humans, poops in a box, descends from a different branch of the feline tree, etc. etc.' and then you're like 'no that's still a lion' even though my whole point is that I'm going strip out all the important differences between lion and a house cat.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 06:25:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Okay we start with determinate being (being with difference) and then we ask, what is the determinate being of determinate being itself --- i.e. how does it differ from just pure being (i.e. determine itself as separate from) and the answer is quality; the determinate being of determinate being is quality (i.e. determinate being is seperate from being because it has qualities). And then we say okay, how does quality qualify itself (i.e. what quality does quality itself have to have to be a quality) and the answer is it has to be the quality of a something (that is, when I say there is 'blue' the quality of 'blue' is what kind of thing its attached to --- I can have a car blue, or a sky blue, or an ocean blue, or etc. i.e. the quality of the quality blue is what particular object its attached to out in the world). So that means we now have 'something' as an object (a qualities that other qualities adhere to) each of whose qualities is a determination (i.e. difference from something else). Now what is the something of something? This is where the whole discussion about objects for themselves and objects for other come in but the point is that now the something is relation to another thing in the same way a quality was in a relation to something and the answer, according to hegel, is that the something of something, its in-itselfness (what it is) is its limitation: the boundaries which say 'this is this and that is that'. This is some other object that the something relates to both as its opposite and as its definition (it is defined as *not* that other thing, i.e. by its limit) and which it also includes (i.e. a line is not a point, but it is all the points between two points). This all eventually piles up in the *ought* which is the limitation of limitation and which is also the finite. The ought is the overcoming of limitation, and since every limitation comes paired with an ought (i.e. the limitation is itself limited) the finite produces the infinite.

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 09:41:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Except for one important detail, cats exist, computers without a stack don‚Äôt. You can‚Äôt just abstract away the parts of something that don‚Äôt fit your argument. Not that it‚Äôs an argument anyway I don‚Äôt really see the point of your analogy, I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs true infinity at all. As for fake infinity or not I‚Äôd like to see the page reference. I‚Äôm not saying there may not be good arguments for it being spurious as a posed to bad

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 10:05:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What are you trying to say by that analogy? That this hypothetical computer would be able to compute infinity instantaneously? That would mean it‚Äôs reached the end and its not infinite. Or do you mean the computation would just go on indefinitely for ever? Then it‚Äôs just the same as spurious infinity. Giving a real world example of infinity is to explain it from the understandings perspective which Hegel says is bad infinity.

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 10:20:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 In the second paragraph your explanation is EXTREMELY bare bones and you gloss over things like being-for-other/in-itself, which are crucial to understand finitude. You don‚Äôt even mention constitution or determination. Just saying this concept is a limitation of the previous comment, the next concept is the limit of that one is just to very loosely define dialectical progress in general. You could say that about every concept in the book and say there we go, nailed it!

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 19 2024 12:10:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "referred to metaphysics as outside the physical world." Yes, outside, but not separated, at least in the strong sense you're proposing. Rather, the ideas are "incarnated" in (among other things) the physical world. This is pretty certainly true for Aristotle, and I'd say also for Hegel (compare also David Corfield's comment that to Hegel not Plato but Aristotle was the true father of idealism, as he provided a concept for how those ideas are instantiated. Sadly, I can't find that comment right now though). In fact, that is already inherent in Hegel's comment on the Platonic ideas in the introduction:

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 19 2024 12:11:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Um dies in die Vorstellung wenigstens aufzunehmen, ist die Meinung auf die Seite zu legen, als ob die Wahrheit etwas Handgreifliches sein m√ºsse. Solche Handgreiflichkeit wird zum Beispiel selbst noch in die Platonischen Ideen, die in dem Denken Gottes sind, hineingetragen, als ob sie gleichsam existierende Dinge, aber in einer anderen Welt oder Region seien, au√üerhalb welcher die Welt der Wirklichkeit sich befinde und eine von jenen Ideen verschiedene, erst durch diese Verschiedenheit reale Substantialit√§t habe. Die Platonische Idee ist nichts anderes als das Allgemeine oder bestimmter der Begriff des Gegenstandes; nur in seinem Begriffe hat etwas Wirklichkeit; insofern es von seinem Begriffe verschieden ist, h√∂rt es auf, wirklich zu sein, und ist ein Nichtiges; die Seite der Handgreiflichkeit und des sinnlichen[44] Au√üersichseins geh√∂rt dieser nichtigen Seite an."

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 19 2024 12:13:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "To get some idea of this one must discard the prejudice that truth must be something tangible. Such tangibility is, for example, imported even into the Platonic Ideas which are in God's thinking, as if they are, as it were, existing things but in another world or region; while the world of actuality exists outside that region and has a substantial existence distinct from those Ideas and only through this distinction is a substantial reality. The Platonic Idea is the universal, or more definitely the Notion of an object; only in its Notion does something possess actuality and to the extent that it is distinct from its Notion it ceases to be actual and is a non-entity; the side of tangibility and sensuous self-externality belongs to this null aspect. "

  • nameiwillforgetMon Feb 19 2024 12:25:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "Does this passage make yall uncomfortable?" Not at all, as noted in the passage I quoted Hegel seems to assume that the Notion is the only thing that is true about an object, this is just an attack on anti-idealism, which I don't subscribe to.

  • andru0358Mon Feb 19 2024 14:52:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ""just as the infinite is the finitude of the finite, the finite is the limitation of limitation, limitation is the something of something, something is the quality of quality, quality is the determination of determination, determination is the becoming of becoming, becoming is the nothing of nothing, and nothing is the negation of the negation"" Every single one of these is wrong üòî

    Like Quality is close, it's existent determinateness. But nothing definitely not negation of negation. Nothing precedes negation. Negation is ceasing-to-be

  • andru0358Mon Feb 19 2024 15:14:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 15:24:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Computer's without stacks exist, stacks were a thing that was invented, they aren't magical things that always existed. And there are programming languages that don't operate with the stack. For example, scheme (which is not a language I tend to use, but never the less it exists) can reuse the current functions frame if it uses tail optimization. There's also such a thing as stackless python. As for why spurious definitely means 'false' and (and may only incidentally mean 'bad'): see $302: "It is only the spurious infinite which is the beyond, because it is only the negation of the finite posited as real ‚Äî as such it is the abstract, first negation; determined only as negative, the affirmation of determinate being is lacking in it; the spurious infinite, held fast as only negative, is even supposed to be not there, is supposed to be unattainable. However, to be thus unattainable is not its grandeur but its defect, which is at bottom the result of holding fast to the finite as such as a merely affirmative being. It is what is untrue that is unattainable, **and such an infinite must be seen as a falsity**. "

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 15:52:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 What I'm trying to say with that analogy is that the very fact that we can symbolize the infinite with a finite object (a name, a function, a fractal, etc.) that *always returns to itself perfectly* that we git the true infinite. In section $302 again: "This infinite, as the consummated return into self, the relation of itself to itself, is being-but not indeterminate, abstract being, for it is posited as negating the negation; it is, therefore, also determinate being for it contains negation in general and hence determinateness. It is and is there, present before us. " i.e. the infinite is 1) a relation of itself to itself that is 'consumated' 2) its not indeterminate (undefined --- or 'beyond') 3) it is and is there, present before us (i.e. we can see the whole damn thing). And to me the only things like that are, perfectly self relating objects like: circles, recursive functions, fractals, etc. (i.e. the set of self-similar objects). I think the real problem here is when Hegel says that he doesn't like the 'finitized infinite' and its easy to over-read. The finitized infinite he's talking about there is an *externally* finitized infinite (i.e. an infinite which the finite is trying to 'count' or 'run' in relation to some finite measure). What he wants is an *internally* finitized infinite which is the same as the *internally* infinitised finite -- I.e. an infinite in which some limit of an otherwise finite object is totally looped back on itself in a manner that removes it as a limit. Comparing a circle to a line is useful if we remember he already discussed lines in the section on the finite and how they are limited by a point --- but in a circle there is no such limitation to work with (a circle is not bound by two points).

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 16:03:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Also let me deal with these more precisely: That this hypothetical computer would be able to compute infinity instantaneously? --- no, that's not what I'm saying. Or do you mean the computation would just go on indefinitely for ever? --- it would do that, but that *perspective* is the spurious infinite. Internally it will always be either just entering or just exiting itself in a way that can not be counted and has nothing to do with 'forever time' because it only has a time space where it can be in one of two states (just entering or just leaving itself). Yes it 'goes on forever' from an external perspective, it is externally finitized as a spurious infinite by the finite. But it does more than that: internally, it is *always* (eternally) present in a finite number of states: which is the true infinite (when a finite object overcomes its limitation through a total separation from other finite objects --- which also means the total elimination of of the limit those other finite objects represent, in this case the function 'f' has become totally separated from other functions by virtue of the fact that there is no way to reach those function from inside 'f').

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 16:45:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 All I was trying to do was nail the process loosely (I'm not trying to nail every detail down to the finest point, partially because Hegel is also wrong about some things and mostly because not every detail is equally important). I feel like you're either just trying to put me through my paces or asking me to spoon feed the section on finitude to you, considering it doesn't have much to do with the finite outside the sections on limit and ought.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 16:51:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0@minimaltom#0 I'm not convinced that's all it is: I think there is an idealism to materialism (I think materialism is a proper sublation of idealism which means its an idealism of idealism: it basically turns towards idealism itself and says 'this is finite' and then does the same trick idealism here performs but against idealism itself). However, the only way it can strip idealism down to finitude is by taking a small portion of it and maintaining that portion: the portion which allows the finite to also be infinite. I also realized what all the stuff about division was about in conversation with <@589918821729566721> --- its that the true infinite strips out limitations from finite objects by permanently separating them *from other finite objects* in the same way that a circle is permanently separated from a pair of points as its limits (and the only important point about it that becomes its limit, the center of the circle, is permanently separated from the circle itself --- i.e. not in contact with the circle).

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 17:17:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Well you‚Äôve just let the cat out of the bag, you have to concentrate on every detail or you won‚Äôt understand the following in what he‚Äôs saying, That‚Äôs why you don‚Äôt understand the concepts and your conclusions make no sense. So much of what you‚Äôve just said is flat wrong.

  • andru0358Mon Feb 19 2024 17:22:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Yea I think there are many mistakes in here. The whole move of "how does quality qualify itself" and "what is the something of the something" is wrong and just made up. I think the rest of us are trying to really understand the text, especially *how it moves* from on moment to the other. Are you interested in this, Thomas? Or just sharing random thoughts that feel related to you? Bcs that's fine, I just think we should just understand that's what you are offering

  • andru0358Mon Feb 19 2024 17:37:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "it is and is there, present before us (i.e. we can see the whole damn thing)." This is only true if you follow the logic step by step, holding the thoughts in your mind, meaning starting with empty consciousness, emergence of becoming, etc.. I think what Hegel would assume is that to actually hold infinite in your mind in this passage would be a truly sublime, awe inspiring experience. Talking about it in terms of programs or computers externalizes it from our own thoughts. The fact that "to me the only things like that are..." Only speaks to your refusal to consider new thoughts, precisely what is necessary for this book

  • andru0358Mon Feb 19 2024 17:46:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel is very explicit that it is precisely problematic to bring outside thoughts into this. This is attempting fundamental truths on their own terms. To say he is wrong about things, especially without really understanding what he is saying, is to presuppose you already have a better method. I'd go so far to say there is no point to reading this book of you are unwilling to question your prior beliefs. Personally, I would give up materialism and become religious if the book convinced me the Truth of God. It's not just a matter of Hegel's argument making sense on its own terms, but that I understand his terms and come to agree with them. Unlike any other logic I have seen, he is at least attempting to fully develop the terms internally. So I think to claim he is wrong necessitates where his mistake in reasoning is, which requires understanding his reasoning, how me moves from step to step. And since you can't do that, i just don't take seriously claims he is wrong. I'm sure he is wrong somewhere. But can't merely compare his to our pre-conecieved thoughts. His will be the more rigorous until we can sublated his method

  • andru0358Mon Feb 19 2024 18:30:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This is very important passage from Something and Other, paragraph 228, regards both positing and the relation of finite and infinite: "In the sphere of being, determinate being only proceeds from becoming, or, with the something an other is posited, with the finite, the infinite; but the finite does not bring forth the infinite, does not posit it. In the sphere of being, the self-determining even of the Notion is at first only in itself or implicit ‚Äî as such it is called a transition; and the reflected determinations of being such as something and other, or finite and infinite, although they essentially refer to each other or are as a being-for-other, they too count as qualitative, as existing on their own account; the other is, the finite ranks equally with the infinite as an immediate, affirmative being, standing fast on its own account; the meaning of each appears to be complete even without its other. On the other hand positive and negative, cause and effect, however much they may be taken as isolated from each other, are at the same time meaningless one without the other. "

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 19:02:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think here how something is 'posited' is equated with being-for-other, how something is explicitly determined by its opposite or 'reflected' in it, as apposed to being-in-itself which is merely implicitly determined. From what i've read the 'for' in being-for-other is to be taken more like 'with', like being-with-other.

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 19:07:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    the way something is inwardly determined in-itself is really interesting tho. From what I've read in Houlgates book It is internally determined by ceasing to be itself but still retaining what it is in the process. if it didnt cease to be yet retain its essense (maybe wrong term) it wouldn't be determined. Ill try and find the section Houlgates refering to.

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 19:12:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    also in the paragraph before that, 227 Hegel equates being-in-itself with the Kantian thing-in-itself in which we have only empirical knowledge but lack access to the thing, we know nothing about it. He says that Kants definition of thing-in-itself is only the case if you take a things being-in-itself in isolation from its being-for-other. The truth is that something is internally and externally determined at the same time removing the seperation between the thing and our perception of the thing.

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 19:14:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think this has huge repercussions for his take on idealism, that its not just all in our minds, reality and ideality aren't apposed to each other

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 19:17:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Here his concept of ideality is radically different from Kants. I think its called objective idealism as apposed to Kants subjective ideaslism.

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 19:28:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    although reading further, although he contrasts positedness with being-in-itself as he does with being-for-other it seems there is a subtle difference. "This expression (positedness), it is true, includes also being-for-other, but it specifically contains the already accomplished bending back of that which is not in itself into that which is its being-in-itself" (228)

  • andru0358Mon Feb 19 2024 19:57:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 The passage on constitution is hard to parse but if you slow down enough to follow his difficult language, it is developing this internal vs external determination. Constitution is external determination, the way the other determines something. He then sublates them together in something: since something is internally determined to be determined by other, the constitution (external) is implicit in the (internal) determination. Posited is this external determination, I think, the very nature of something posits an other; the other is constituted by this external positing of the something This is how he is moving from in-itself, to for-other, to more concrete in-itself, to the explicit unity of the two. Then "the negation is now immanent" "something behaves in this in relation to it's other *through itself*" (These are from Cambridge translation) "Now has its affirmative existence through its intermediary alone"

  • andru0358Mon Feb 19 2024 19:58:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He's moving to for-itself step by step: affirmative self determination. But runs up to problems out which the infinite has to transcend. More later.

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 20:10:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 This seems to be consistent with what I've gathered constitution to mean more generally, that its the way something is altered by something else (re-constituted maybe? or just constituted) while simultaneously retaining its identity. Im foggy on this tho so id have to reread the section.

  • minimaltomMon Feb 19 2024 20:15:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 it seems to me from what youve said more like were doing the reading for you.

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 23:47:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I literally said that the level of 'nothing' is confused because I think Hegel reverses it from an actual science of logic (for reasons that have to do with the social context of German Idealism --- I also think this explains why he calls something 'the first negation of negation', because all his movements are just negation of negation applied recursively to the previous steps... but he wants to avoid that position for reasons having to do with ideology). So I think that the definition of quality that Hegel gives in $196 is --- Determinateness thus **isolated by itself** in the form of being is quality. Okay so let's first compare that to what I've said... 'the determinate being of determinate being'--- i.e. the definitely limited being of definitely limited being --- i.e. the way in which the entire order of being that is determinate being is separated or limited out from other orders of being, objects, categories, etc.? OMG, that looks like what Hegel calls quality, i.e. Determinateness is thus **isolated by itself** in the form of being, and I call that quality (and Hegel calls that quality). As far as it being 'existent determinateness' (existing predictability --- citation needed, btw) --- isn't the thing which seperates determinate being from other forms of being its existence? I.e. isn't the definitely limited being of definitely limited being found in how it demands consistency (existence in Hegel's terms, not actuality) as opposed to indeterminate being (undefined, contradictory) being that its stands within and is merely a piece of?

  • firedog235Mon Feb 19 2024 23:58:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 First of all, I do go through every detail in the first pass. However, the only time every single detail is important is when you're running an argument like a computer and you want to know if it crashes. At that level, Hegel's argument has already crashed as far as I'm concerned (it crashed when he said we should focus on being rather than nothing). So now I'm playing in the space of arguments like Hegel's, the ways to make what is already a broken and bad program function so that I can figure out *what he meant by it* and *what I can get from it* which means that bits and pieces are going to be thrown out in trying different similar arguments to try and find what is important and structural vs. what is incidental vs. what is nonsense. But also like, not every detail passes through to every part of the argument? There are conceptual barriers here (limit and ought act as barriers between the finite and infinite for example --- like you don't need a really deep articulated understanding of quality to understand the finite if you have a pretty good understanding of what is going on in limit and ought). I.e. not every step is important for establishing every other step of the argument --- the structure of the argument can remain sound even while the individual steps are crap. For example I'll make this argument: The sky is blue All men are mortal All mortal men die Socrates is a man :::Socrates will die The fact that the sky is blue is incidental. Like your claim that we need to get super hung up on every detail all the time forever in every context from now until the end of the world *feels* principled and it *feels* like its correct... but actually its crap. You can't see the forest for the trees --- that's why you don't understand the concepts and you have no conclusion whatsoever.

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 00:05:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 youre saying "Determinateness isolated by itself in the form of being" means "the determinate being of determinate being"?

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 00:39:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yeah, this is my interpretation of what Hegel is doing, its my cliff notes of how it moves from one moment to another. So far every time you've tested me in this context (i.e. when I have time to actually go through the pile of receipts, not when there is time pressure) what has happened? I've always gone to the text and been like 'I'm saying this because the text says that and look, aren't they not that dissimilar?' Of course I'm interested in it. The bit on infinite is some of the most interesting writing I've encountered in the past couple years. If I wasn't interested in it I wouldn't write to you about it here... I'd just chuckle at you and go about my day. As far as quality qualifies itself --- see $206 where Hegel says that quality is *especially* a property: i.e. it is the quality of qualities as a category to be the quality (property) of something --- or to flip it around reading that same section: "The more stable determinatenesses, on the other hand, such as figure, shape, are not called properties, nor even qualities perhaps, because they are conceived as alterable, as not identical with the being [of the object]." That is, things which are 'stable determinateness' (apply to many objects), such as figure and shape, are not considered to be qualities (perhaps) of the object, for Hegel (and in his tradition) because they can be changed and the object remains the kind of object it is. Specifically something is *something* because it has a particular set of properties, or rather, a particular set of qualities. It is the quality of quality that it be the quality of *something*. Quality qualifies itself (because if I say quality of quality I can also say qualified quality and strip out the 'of' and have the meaning remain the same) as *something*. (Or to put it yet another way, if quality is defined as the *definitional difference* of a thing, then the definitional difference of quality from other determinations is the way it applies to *something*).

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 00:55:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yes, --- i.e. the definitely limited being of definitely limited being --- i.e. the way in which the entire order of being that is determinate being is limited out from other orders of being, objects, categories, etc. In hegels statement: Determinateness is thus isolated by itself in the form of being --- there are two limitation going on. The first is determinateness itself (which is the first limitation) and the second is the limit placed on the first limitation (and he adds 'in the form of being' transforming determinateness into determinate being). So we get Determinate (determinate being) thus isolated by itself (determinate being) in the form of being, is quality. We can even go to the very first sentence of the remark: "In determinate being (a) as such, its determinateness is first of all (b) to be **distinguished** as quality." --- i.e. the thing about determinate being that makes it determinate being, its determinateness, is also its quality because quality is just determination applied to determination.

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 01:08:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Yeah, that's because you don't yet think of your own mind as a program running on a computer, whereas I do. So I'm not externalizing. Just because its squishy and made of organic chemicals doesn't make your mind into 'not a computer'. It seems to me you really want to bring mysticism into this discussion. You want the soul to be made of something other than 'millions of tiny robots'. Sorry, its not. The sublime is the unkowable (i.e. its so vast and complicated and *beyond* that we don't know what it is)... so if that's what Hegel wants (for us to not understand what he's saying, for it to be impossible for us to understand) then we should rebel against him. The other side of the sublime is the obscene (the totally known) and I think that's our primary disagreement. I want an obscene Hegel, I don't care about making him sublime, I want to know him so totally that I know exactly what is shit and what isn't (i.e. I want to cut him open and see all his guts splayed out on the ground). What I want is the sublimity of the obscene (i.e. the you don't know just how much you know). You seem to want the obscenity of the sublime (i.e. you know that you will never know) and I'm just not here for that.
