  • andru0358Tue Feb 20 2024 02:47:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "So far every time you've tested me in this context (i.e. when I have time to actually go through the pile of receipts, not when there is time pressure) what has happened? I've always gone to the text and been like 'I'm saying this because the text says that and look, aren't they not that dissimilar?'" My experience is they have been dissimilar more times than not. Thats fine; it's just very hard to have a conversation when you refuse to acknowledge you're wrong. I'm not saying you're wrong about everything, but when you are wrong, instead of being open to it being pointed out, it becomes a rabbit hole of falsifications of the text. Quality: you are clearly twisting the words: by "in the form of being" , he means "in immediacy". If you slowed down to understand the terms you would understand why. "Determinateness thus isolated by itself in the form of being is quality ‚Äî which is wholly simple and immediate." "quality as a determinateness which is only immediate or only in the form of being." "In the form of being" is not a "limit" by which I hope you mean negation, limit is derived from something and other, so premature. The form of being is immediacy. This is important for understanding the book. The for of "determinate being" is not immediacy, it's mediated. Hence why "determinate being of determinate being" is wrong. It's almost the opposite. Re: property: He actually says: "Quality is especially a property only where, in an external relation, it manifests itself as an immanent determination" The "only" is pretty important thing to cut out. We don't have any immanent determinations yet, so it's irrelevant. This is taken out of context from a remark discussing Spinoza's proposition that determinateness is negation. More to the point: your claim "Something is *something* because it has a particular set of properties" Is entirely wrong and shows you have spent much time with the something, or something and other.

  • andru0358Tue Feb 20 2024 02:47:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    P210: " In our ordinary way of thinking, something is rightly credited with reality. However, something is still a very superficial determination; just as reality and negation, determinate being and its determinateness, although no longer blank being and nothing, are still quite abstract determinations.

  • andru0358Tue Feb 20 2024 02:53:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 You can arbitrarily define my words however you want, but that doesn't mean that sublime was meant to mean unknowable, that's boring formalism. Cells are not robots, the brain might be *like* a computer, but I don't know any evidence that it *is* a computer. Do you *experience* your mind as a computer? What the realm of Being is about is thoughts immediately in the mind. So translating it to computer terms is externalizing it, or at least mediating it by another intellectual system

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 06:19:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 Capitalism is a mad god that needs to be put down (or at least tied down).

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 06:37:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ""In the form of being" is not a "limit" by which I hope you mean negation, limit is derived from something and other, so premature." No, my use of 'in form of being' is not meant to mean 'negation' --- I point it out to say that quality and determinatess are still in the realm of being (i.e. its not just 'determinateness' that Hegel is talking about but rather 'determinate being'). The negation is in the determinateness and then a second time in the isolation of (determination of) that determinateness, not in being in my interpretation. Also --- because determination is difference, it's possible for it to have immediate access to difference within itself 'as such'. That is, it's possible for me to say this sentence: what determines determination against all other objects is its immediate access to determination which other objects have to always import from determination as a mediation --- i.e. its possible to have immediate access to mediation and to mediate immediacy --- to define something as being different though its immediacy (or to return to the immediate from the mediation of determinate being, to double mediate back into immediacy). I'm not claiming that determinate being is immediacy, I'm claiming that its determination is its immediate access to determination (i.e. there is an immediate mediation/mediated immediacy in determination) --- there's an important distinction there.

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 06:38:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "The "only" is pretty important thing to cut out." Its only important if its a distinction that makes a difference. Do you mean its important because qualities are also 'immanent' --- (because it can't be because you think that this weakens the argument that the quality of quality is something: because it only strengthens that argument). But I don't have a problem with the idea that qualities are immanent. That isn't a point of contention. See above.

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 06:40:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúYou can arbitrarily define my words however you want, but that doesn't mean that sublime was meant to mean unknowable, that's boring formalism.‚Äù It's not defined as unknowable and I‚Äôm not saying it arbitrarily --- it just is unknowable, as part of its bigness and grandeur --- If it's knowable then it‚Äôs as small as the human mind and thus *not* sublime. Its unknowability is just a consequence of its bigness. You can mean whatever you want and if it turns out you don‚Äôt want the downside of the sublime with its upside you should pick a different word (though secretly at the Zizekian level I would whisper to myself that you‚Äôre just doing petit-bourgeois ideology because you want the upside without the downside, you don‚Äôt want to pay for your advancement, you want ‚Äòx without x‚Äô i.e. ‚Äòthe sublime without the sublime‚Äô).

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 06:40:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúCells are not robots, the brain might be like a computer, but I don't know any evidence that it is a computer.‚Äù Only in the sense that robots are not robots: but in the sense that cells perform specific enumerable tasks, cells are subject to discipline by (and programmed by) an overwhelming force (the body), cells are fully automated in their operation, they‚Äôre robots.

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 06:41:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúDo you experience your mind as a computer?‚Äù Yes, I‚Äôve had the experience of having a thought and having it just... flash out of existence. Like it would if a chip burned out in a computer. Or noticing that the waves in an acid trip seem to follow my heartbeat (i.e. it feels, a lot, like what I assume it would feel like to be in a biological computer).

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 06:43:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúWhat the realm of Being is about is thoughts immediately in the mind. So translating it to computer terms is externalizing it, or at least mediating it by another intellectual system‚Äù Why are thoughts immediately in the mind not programs running in a computer? And you can call it ‚Äòmediation by another intellectual system‚Äô but it could just as easily be called ‚Äòthe attempt to internalize another intellectual system into Hegel‚Äôs system.‚Äô And also I‚Äôm deeply suspicious of this notion that has popped up that we shouldn‚Äôt be appealing to these other ideas: I don‚Äôt think you really understand something (or to put in hegeleze, can really rationalize it --- because I‚Äôm talking about the rational here, not the understanding) until you can restate it in another context. It doesn‚Äôt really become itself until it returns to itself in an alien form. Otherwise you‚Äôre just parroting it.

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 06:44:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ‚ÄúMysticism as the intention to understand consciousness through experience, sure. I mean, it's called phenomonology now This book assumes the results of Phenomonology of Spirit‚Äù No, I mean mysticism as an appeal to the sublime, to the beyond. Super-naturalism. The idea that whatever is going on doesn't rest on a material foundation. For example the idea that what is going on the mind is fundamentally different from computation rather than, for example, just a hyper specific form of computation.

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 06:58:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "I see you're interested in the text. But it doesn't seem like you're interested in taking it step by step, understanding each term in its own derivation. Ie not bringing limit into understanding of quality." I do this every time I read a chapter, I go through each step. Using the term limit was an attempt to clarify what I meant for you --- well really for Tom (i.e. not just repeat 'quality of quality' at you until I'm blue in the face --- to try and aid your intuition to understand what I mean by quality of quality but... like you want to do this the hard way so okay let's do it the hard way). What I want is for us to first proceed as if the other person is an intelligent human who is trying to understand things (i.e. to first attempt to understand what I'm saying and see how the text, I don't know, might support it, rather than saying 'oh yeah, I didn't immediately get that so it must be bullshit and you're a bullshitter'... which is very annoying and of course if people are going to be an asshole to me then I'll be an asshole back).

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 07:56:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ¬ß 191 From becoming there issues determinate being, which is the simple oneness of being and nothing. Because of this oneness it has the form of immediacy. Its mediation, becoming, **lies behind it**; it has sublated itself and determinate being appears, therefore, as a first, as a starting-point for the ensuing development. It is first of all in the one-sided determination of being; the other determination, nothing, will likewise display itself and in contrast to it.

  • andru0358Tue Feb 20 2024 19:00:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I think the whole thing hinges on Hegel's conceptions of thought in immanent movement; how he sees thoughts moving immanently. The way he conceives the whole project. I think that probably is wrong to some extent, to what extent? It seems remarkably undetectable to me so far. Which would say small; but even so, the whole thing might collapse if so. But I think we could only say, imo, by understanding it fully and being able to step outside of it. When we think we have found a mistake, I believe we really ought to question ourselves; what are our prior beliefs on which our critique is grounded, are they able to be justified in such rigor? I think learning it has helped me a ton to slow down and notice my own assumptions and modes of thought. If I could find something I think is wrong in Hegel, and develop it as rigorously as SoL, I would certainly not feel depressed that Hegel was wrong. That would be a very important contribution to humanity, imo. Even Marx did not attempt to develop his own Logic; so it is of course exceedingly ambitious. Many critics have been shown to be smuggling in unwarranted assumptions, ie lacking self awareness and rigor. But to me, the value in all this is developing that self-awareness and sense of rigor. Not the conclusions themselves; although if they seem true, one must take them seriously as well

    @minimaltom#0 So 'not mediated' --- i.e. a negation of mediation? To me what is important isn't 'categories, objects' the reason I listed that out is because there is a word-I-don't-know-what, but what is important is that to isolate something is to negate its connection to something else. So even if you say 'isolated in its immediate-ness' --- you are still negating its potential connections to other things in this moment of analysis (i.e. you're mediating it down to its immediacy).

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 20:14:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 What is non-non-being?

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 20:52:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 21:13:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0@minimaltom#0 Okay so let's go with 'being' --- i.e. mediated mediation might just be immediacy. The reason why I quoted ¬ß 191 is because Hegel seems in that section to be placing immediacy *after* mediation (i.e. determinate being is first this mediated becoming and *then* it has the form of immediacy, it seems we need to negate from mediation into immediacy: however I admit that may 'the form of' is a modifier that means 'is not really' so I'm not certain. Actually, looking it up it seems to mean 'what it is without differentiation'... however this notion of what determinate being is without differentiation is coming *after* its mediated moment in becoming... so there's that). And my understanding is that when <@476561351167311872> is saying 'it can't be the determinate being of determinate being' he's objecting based on the question of immediacy: that determinate being is a mediation. But Hegel seems to have a more complicated relationship in mind between determinate being and immediacy/mediation as well as a more complicated relationship between mediation and immediacy themselves.

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 21:14:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 And as a materialist --- if being is just what 'immediately appears in the mind' and is in that sense 'immediate': then I gotta say, from the perspective of material reality, this immediacy is the most mediated thing imaginable (i.e. in order to have any kind of immediate thought or idea it actually has to be totally indexed, discovered, related to, explored, understood, rationalized, transported from sensory organs, imagined, etc. in the mind before it can be just a stupid immediate thought). In this sense I have difficulty treating the distinction between immediacy and mediation as an *easy* primary distinction where you can just say 'quality is immediate and so it can't be the determinate being of determinate being because that's a mediation'. Like, maybe the mediation of mediation is immediacy? Maybe determinate being is in some way immediate as well (section 191 seems to indicate that) So given all that if determinate being is mediated, and quality is immediate, then the determinate being of determinate being would be the mediation of mediation which I don't think has be determinatively ruled out as immediacy?

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 21:27:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 yes I think the relationship between them is very complicated. ¬ß 191 "From becoming there issues determinate being, which is the simple oneness of being and nothing. Because of this oneness it has the form of immediacy. Its mediation, becoming, lies behind it" so determinate Being has the form of immediacy but its mediation lies behind it. I brought this up before because I wanted to know what the difference was between having something and having the form of something was.

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 21:28:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I do know that understanding sees things only as immediate tho

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 21:28:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    its like it disregards what is mediated in something

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 21:29:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think its like how we see ourselves as being just what we are in ourselves because were seeing it from the perspective of understanding, we dont see the way we are mediated externally. Add to that we are only seeing ourselves in terms of being-in-itself without being-for-other.

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 21:32:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    this is my own interperatation tho, it could be wrong, especially the last bit

  • andru0358Tue Feb 20 2024 22:53:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "... I don't think you understand the text until you restate in a radically different way and context that continues to be true to the text. Until that happens your just parroting it (i.e. you 'understand' it in the Hegelian since but haven't 'rationalized' it --- the english language is getting dumb here)." Why do you suppose this is the case? Don't you first need to understand it on Hegel's terms in order to restate it? Otherwise you won't know what is being lost in your transformation. This is why we push back on you bringing in outside stuff or trying to twist it; we want to know that you understand it on its terms first. Once we understand it, we should be able to explain it, and get on the same page. Then we can debate its shortcomings and how to sublate it into a 'better' system.

  • andru0358Tue Feb 20 2024 23:04:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Immediate in SoL is logically immediate. Empty thought is both immediate and indeterminate because it is does not depend on any other thoughts to be derived logically, that is to appear clearly in our mind. Each other moment can be derived from only the thoughts before it and their immanent movement (something we should discuss further). But then each moment has its own Being, can be thought directly, held in the mind, *immediately*. its from this that its inner contradictions/deficiencies come out and it moves dialectically, eg developing other concepts to define it stably. I am open to all your critiques as how this method may be flawed. I have thought a lot about whether this holds up with what we now know about the brain. Hegel of course believed in the divine soul, spirit. But ultimately, what we are talking about is simply self-awareness of thought; its like formalism of math without the symbols, instead, it has to be held clearly in your mind to check it. It is *not* supposed to depend on the nature of that mind, just on its capacity of three operations: Being, Negation, Becoming - Understanding, Doubt/Skepticism, and Speculation/Reason. I am still curious if you would elaborate why you hold so firm on the primacy of negation or contradction, rather than the simultaneous identity of being and negation.

  • andru0358Tue Feb 20 2024 23:08:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    On each moment in this section being thinkable on its own: p228: "In the sphere of being, the self-determining even of the Notion is at first only in itself or implicit ‚Äî as such it is called a transition; and the reflected determinations of being such as something and other, or finite and infinite, although they essentially refer to each other or are as a being-for-other, they too count as qualitative, as existing on their own account; the other is, the finite ranks equally with the infinite as an immediate, affirmative being, standing fast on its own account; the meaning of each appears to be complete even without its other"

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 23:35:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 23:36:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 No, you first need to restate Hegel's statement to understand it. The way you know what is lost in the transformation is when someone says 'hey you lost this in your transformation'. * Maybe the problem is that I don't post **THOMAS IS A FUCKUP** every time someone makes a good point that changes my mind (such as when Tom said that determinate being is different from becoming and I thought they weren't and then we read the chapter and I was like, oh yeah --- becoming is the externaml movement of the contradiction and determinate being is the internal point around which that movement occurs).

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 23:44:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 no I insist you say that everytime üòÑ

  • minimaltomTue Feb 20 2024 23:48:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    here we go

  • firedog235Tue Feb 20 2024 23:49:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "Immediate in SoL is logically immediate. Empty thought is both immediate and indeterminate because it is does not depend on any other thoughts to be derived logically, that is to appear clearly in our mind. " Or course, empty thought is incredibly difficult to maintain meaning that in fact you have to mediate away other thoughts to get to empty thought. This doesn't really answer the original question about quality as mediated mediation (and seems to work against it --- i.e. it seems to imply that every mediation is also an immediate in some way and thus saying something is immediate and thus not a mediation doesn't work as an argument). What I'm saying about restatement is (edit: *not*) contradicting this statement about notions being thinkable on their own: what's 'thinkable on its own' about the notion is the *structure* of the notion --- but to get to that structure (and to get it into your head) you have to give it the acid test of trying to apply it in multiple places: even if multiple places simply means in multiple places *within itself* --- and while Hegel has done some of that, he hasn't done all of that exploration because how could he? Also I would say that this isn't a pedagogical position that Hegel is taking I think... I think he's just saying here that these things are separable into themselves (like a separability clause in a contract, just because the judge throws out one clause doesn't mean the others all collapse).

  • dve.h_37844Wed Feb 21 2024 00:00:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Joining the zoom now

  • dve.h_37844Wed Feb 21 2024 02:32:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Good chat guys. For anyone who wants to finish up *the infinite*, starting at 288 and reading until the end of the section was helpful for me.

  • minimaltomWed Feb 21 2024 02:43:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôm hyped

  • andru0358Wed Feb 21 2024 02:52:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Yea I think I misspoke to some extent, immediate only takes it's logical not-mediated meaning for the first two, being/nothing, which I was responding to. They are mediated by mental mechanisms, but not conceptually defined by them; they're empty, without definition or content; mediated by the mental mechanism of clearing away only. Other thoughts are logically mediated in that we come to them through their derivation. Their immediacy is holding them in our minds. Hegel uses this as the "acid test", ie, it's the *immediacy* of the finitude which spells it's contradiction and leads to the infinite. It's taking a magnifying class to the concept to find any problems. I think Hegel even implies somewhere that if it's incoherent, ie contradictory, it can't have being, its negated. Hegel's logical method has to be internal. Pedagogically, examples are helpful. But they can't determine whether the concepts are True without a method, and that's what he is developing. We might simply misunderstand the examples. We may be misinterpreting the science bcs of our own background assumptions. Especially if we are trying to evaluate the Truth of the book, we have to understand it in conceptual fully and in its own terms first.

  • firedog235Wed Feb 21 2024 05:00:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 No, examples can't determine truth. but in the end the method is also an example itself (in the sense that is the sui generis self-example). I'm okay with contradictory things not having being, contradictions also have consequences beyond their immediacy that give them being (i.e. there are non-contradictory aspects of contradictions, partial object which are partially contradictory and don't exist and partially consistent and do exist).

  • firedog235Wed Feb 21 2024 05:32:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I am unhappy with my explanation of ought = limitation of limitation in the chat. There is a straightforward way to look at it which is that limitation is like a chasm and ought is like a bridge across the chasm and a bridge negates a chasm (by providing a path across it ---- the bridge being made out of 'not chasm stuff' that must be available in order for the chasm to act as a limitation to either side of the chasm: this necessarily available material is the contradiction of the limitation, the fact that the limitation say 'though shall not pass' and the rocks on either side of the chasm say 'build a bridge and pass anyway': thus there is a limit on limitation in the ought --- limitation cannot be a total limit, it must implicitly point to a beyond --- It is only in the infinite that this beyond will be turned back against itself and we will find 'there is no beyond' --- the beyond is a contradiction --- but for now...). However, this is not *enough* because it only speaks to the *limit* of limitation. The limitation should also expand through an ought in the same way that the object negated in a particular limitation is expanded (i.e. the territory you can explore is expanded through the ought of the bridge) --- i.e. the fulfilling of the ought, ought to expand limitation if ought is to be the limitation of limitation.

  • firedog235Wed Feb 21 2024 05:38:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Right now I think of it this way in exemplar form: we have a line that is between two points (say 0 and 1) and the limitation is contradictory because the very fact that we say 'this line is only between 0 and 1' implies that there are lines that could be longer or shorter: the limitation is a fake limit, a mere prohibition (whose truth is that its can be contradicted: i.e. you're blocked from going further and you are not so blocked). So we get the first ought which I feel is a kind of spurious ought where we just swap out one limitation for another --- now the line is between 0 and 2. Okay but in reality, the limitation is actually saying that a line is defined as opposed to a point (its not a point) and there ought to be some point which isn't on *any* line. This means it ought not be in any of the limits we might choose along this number line. That means it *has to be* (necessity) orthogonal to the number line (possibility, because there are many such points, not just one) --- creating a plane. This is the true ought. But what happens here? We don't overcome the original limits --- in fact our line might still only be between 0 and 1 or 0 and 2, but instead in this true ought, we actually create a whole new type of object (the plane) and what's more we also introduce *more* limitations --- because now the line can't just be between two points, but instead it needs to be *the shortest distance between any two points* --- we've added a limitation, i.e. following this ought not only expanded the space of objects, it also expanded the space of limits. Thus this true ought is the limitation of limitation itself (i.e. there is a coincidental moment where the overcoming of the ought of a single object also overcomes the limitation of limitation itself, by, ironically, expanding limitation). But then the infinite comes in and starts tying these limitations off by self-relating the limitations (i.e. the line becomes its own terminal points in the circle).

  • dve.h_37844Wed Feb 21 2024 12:31:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The way I keep the system in my head is by focusing on the finite. I don‚Äôt really need to think about the infinite as anything other than the opposite of the finite. Once I understand how the finite ceases to be from moment to moment, I go back and examine its unity with the infinite. It‚Äôs very hard for me to imagine two *concepts* at once, unless I use mental pictures or math. And Hegel does talk about this issue in the text. He actually has a term for the infinite-that-we-don‚Äôt-really-care-about-yet, and that‚Äôs very helpful for me. When he started the system with pure being, it was necessary for him to invent pure nothing so that he could have something to compare pure being with. That necessary comparing of concepts *is* the system. At least that‚Äôs how I understand it.

  • douglainWed Feb 21 2024 13:33:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Given that Hegel starts with pure being, it seems to me that the infinite is intrinsic to the project. The book begins with Substance, that is the stuff that the whole of reality consists. Starting with the infinite or with the finite will set up the same dynamic I think, but it is the case that the finite emerges from deteriminate being first. That is because determiniate being is differentiated and thereby includes the negative. By being determined it is necessarily limited. I do not think Hegel invents pure nothing. Rather the negative has been a concern since the earliest days of Greek philosophy. It's certainly a problem presented in parmenides. Without a negative concept there cannot be multiplicity, movement, change, etc... And this is why Parmenides, who claimed that the negative was not, argued that the truth was one thing and that it was undifferentiated. In a Louis CK bit from years ago Louis CK's kid asks him "why?" until Louis is forced to answer the question on the most abstract basis possible. He's pushed into philosophy: "Why?" "Because some things are and some things are not!" "Why?" "Well, because things that are not can't be!" "Why?" "Well, because then nothing wouldn't be. You can't have fucking 'nothing isn't. everything is.'" <---Parmenides "Why?" "Because if nothing wasn't there would be all kinds of shit that we don't want, like giant ants with top hats on dancing around." "Why?" "Oh, fuck you! Eat your french fries you little shit!" https://youtu.be/Tf17rFDjMZw?si=Sp3jWOPRuKFu3pL9

  • douglainWed Feb 21 2024 13:40:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    As for the ought as the negative of the limitation: Hegel says: "With respect to the form of the limitation and the ought, two prejudices can be criticised in more detail. First of all, great stress is laid on the limitations of thought, of reason, and so on, and it is asserted that the limitation cannot be transcended. To make such as assertion is to be unaware that the very fact that something is determined as a limitation implies that the limitation is already transcended. For a determinateness, a limit, is determined as a limitation only in opposition to its other in general, that is, in opposition to that which is free from the limitation; the other of a limitation is precisely the being beyond it. Stone and metal do not transcend their limitation because this is not a limitation for them." Because the stone does not think, does not even feel, its limitedness is not a limitation for it, that is, is not a negation in it for sensation, imagination, thought, etc., which it does not possess. But even the stone, as a something, contains the distinction of its determination or in-itself and its determinate being, and to that extent it, too, transcends its limitation; the Notion which is implicit in it contains the identity of the stone with its other. If it is a base capable of being acted on by an acid, then it can be oxidised, and neutralised, and so on. In oxidation, neutralisation and so on, it overcomes its limitation of existing only as a base; it transcends it, and similarly the acid overcomes its limitation of being an acid. This ought, the obligation to transcend limitations, is present in both acid and caustic base in such a degree that it is only by force that they can be kept fixed as (waterless, that is, purely non-neutral) acid and caustic base."

  • douglainWed Feb 21 2024 13:43:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But it is reason, thought, which is supposed to be unable to transcend limitation ‚Äî reason, which is the universal explicitly beyond particularity as such (that is, all particularity), which is nothing but the overcoming of limitation! Granted, not every instance of transcending and being beyond limitation is a genuine liberation from it, a veritable affirmation; even the ought itself, and abstraction in general, is in imperfect transcending. However, the reference to the wholly abstract universal is a sufficient reply to the equally abstract assertion that limitation cannot be transcended, or, again, even the reference to the infinite in general is a sufficient refutation of the assertion that the finite cannot be transcended. So it is through thought and reason that the finite can fully sublate its own limitations and transform into the infinite without creating a beyond that is its other and that maintains the finite. This creation of the beyond and the holding onto the finite, the creation of an infinity of the finite, is a spurioius infinity as it is not a self-realized infinity where the unity of the finite and the infinite is apprehend in the notion.

  • douglainWed Feb 21 2024 13:43:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It is worth noting that here, in the section of the ought, that Hegel critiques Kant or the NeoKantians.

  • andru0358Wed Feb 21 2024 17:17:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Louis CK *ought* to have read the Science of Logic üòÖ I feel like this is good training to be a parent in that specific respect. Re-reading the development of the infinite last night, the key turn which stood out to me is this: "¬ß 300 If, at first, the return into self was considered to be just as much a return of the finite to itself as return of the infinite to itself, this very result reveals an error which is connected with the one-sidedness just criticised: first the finite and then the infinite is taken as the starting point and it is only this that gives rise to two results. It is, however, a matter of complete indifference which is taken as the beginning; and thus the difference which occasioned the *double* result disappears of itself. ... it is quite immaterial what point is fixed on or which of the two is taken as the beginning. ... Since both the finite and the infinite itself are moments of the progress they are *jointly or in common the finite*, and since they are equally together negated in it and in the result, **this result as negation of the finitude of both is called with truth the infinite.** Their difference is thus the double meaning which both have. The finite has the double meaning of being first, only the finite *over against the* infinite which stands opposed to it, and secondly, of being the finite and at the same time the infinite opposed to it. The infinite, too, has the double meaning of being one of these two moments ‚Äî as such it is the spurious infinite ‚Äî and also the infinite in which both, the infinite and its other, are only moments. **The infinite**, therefore, as now before us **is**, in fact, **the process in which it is deposed to being only one of its determinations, the opposite of the finite,** and so to being itself only *one* of the finites, and **then raising this its difference from itself into the affirmation of itself and through this mediation becoming the true infinite.**""

  • andru0358Wed Feb 21 2024 17:18:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    -- I added the spaces and bolding to help lay emphasis, the italics are from the original

  • andru0358Wed Feb 21 2024 17:23:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 -- The significance of this being a *Becoming* only now really sank in for me. What <@1144442476145426592> said about the necessity of comparing concepts for them to be stably defined: that Being and Nothing require each other for their meaning, and in the same way, now, Infinite and Finite taken separately only pass into each other. But this passing into each other thereby forms the means to define them each, but only in reference. This inter-determination is what makes it a Becoming, and not a self-stable existence. Something is also a Becoming. I only now really understand this myself. Something has two determinations, abstract existence and negative reference to the Other.

  • dve.h_37844Wed Feb 21 2024 17:51:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0@douglain#0 I think you and <@386755556817240065> are right. There are clearly levels of understanding to this system that you gain by simply attempting to use the system.

  • dve.h_37844Wed Feb 21 2024 17:51:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Doug is clearly a Dark Sith Lord and can wield it, in its entirety, with ease.

  • andru0358Wed Feb 21 2024 18:05:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Initially Something has no qualities to define it by except existence and distinction from the other. But it is itself an other, equally. So something is merely the idea of a something distinct from an other; there's nothing distinguishing it. By developing the being of Limit, the something and other are the define by that limit; and that definition is implied by their existence, so is intrinsic. Finitude is the explicit quality of being determined by a limit. So only now in Finitude, Something has an intrinsic Quality. When the Limit becomes intrinsic to the Something, it's then called a Limitation. The Ought is *not really* the limitation of limitation; only by taking the first loosely to mean 'negation' and then specifying precisely what is being negated in it. The Ought is: "The in-itself ... As negative reference to itself as limitation" What does that mean? The Limit was that which Something (and Other) were determined by; it took the place of each other as the negative self-reference. Instead of "I am other of other" they became "I am what is not outside the limit". With finitude, the limit is internalized: "I am what is not outside*my* limitation". Here, limitation becomes the determination. Quality was the existent determinateness / being of determinateness. Limit was an in-itself, determination as an in-itself. Here, Limitation is the determination of the finite; but no longer external determination. It is *internal* negative self reference. But "internal" and "negative self reference" don't sit easily. Something is now internally determined and therefore no longer a something, it *transcends itself*. I think*ought* is the in-itself of the internal determination The negative self reference is negated

  • firedog235Wed Feb 21 2024 21:30:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 So I think that my point was that the view of ought as mere negation of limitation is not sufficient, but actually you have to take **limitation** of limitation seriously to get a true ought as not only the overcoming of a specific object but as the overcoming of limitation itself that is then back propagated to specific objects: the problem is that you can have a spurious ought to go with the spurious infinity (i.e. I ought to be able to extend the length of this line a line little bit more) as opposed to a true ought that would create actual objects. The first ought is a mere 'negation of limitation' --- it is an 'ought' in the same way that spurious infinite is 'an infinite' but it isn't the true ought. The line you're refrencing is from $254 I think? the full sentence is "This in-itself, therefore, as the negative relation to its limit (which is also distinguished from it), to itself as limitation, is the ought." The difficulty I have is that by the time we reach this sentence, limit and also limitation is already included in 'in-itself as negatively related to x' as one of its necessary moments I think (that is, a limitation is *also* an in-itself negatively related to something and to properly have an in-itself you must *also* include a limitation). So one way to read this would be 'This *limitation*, therefore, as the negative relation to its limit (which is also distinguished from it), to itself as limitation, is the ought.' Which can also be restated as 'This limitation, as the negative relation to itself as limitation is the ought' which I think can also be read as just 'the ought is the limitation of the limitation'.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 00:28:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The problem with all that is that limitation is not an in-itself anymore, I don't think

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 02:13:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think he just establishes that limitation is an in-itself in that paragraph (he kind of rushes the establishment because I think one of his points is that you have to immediately specify further that the limitation is more specifically an ought and he doesn't want to leave us in the realm of limitation, but I think section 254 is where he does the double movement). But beyond that, my understanding is that once established as the in-itself its always the in-itself, now we're haggling over deeper specifications within limitation (if there are in-itself which are *not* limitation they would have to come before and be either determination or constitution as separate guys from each other within the 'in-itself').

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 02:18:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Its certainly a 'something' of limitation (something here is not a Hegelian something), it has a limitation (section 258) and therefore must have a something of limitation.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 05:50:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Re-reading the section on limit, it's never developed to be an in-itself. Re-reading the part on limitation, he never establishes that. They are qualities; limit is called "otherness" and non-being-for-other. In-itself comes from something; he uses the term in-itself here bcs it's not really a something, because it's not determined by an external other or external limit. He explains in the next paragraph something transcends itself because bcs the limit is sublated to be internal. That's why, in the paragraph developing Limitation and Ought, he call it an in-itself; it's basically a something, but technically transcending that form. Limitation cannot have a limitation because it would require 1) it to be an in-itself, but it's a quality, it exist in the thing it is a limitation of. 2) it would have to be finite, ie have an immanent limit. But an immanent limit requires immanent determinations; limitation is determined as for that which it a limitation of. I mean, again, it just seems like you're clinging on to this "limitation of limitation" because you like the sound of it, without any attention to the text. Idek what you're talking about with "overcoming specific objects" and "back propagation". I really think it's important we try to understand the text in its own terms and try to understand the specific meanings of each one. How they are used in the text is extremely precise and based on their derivation. Pulling in our own associations of the words doesn't have a good track record so far

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 06:57:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    P268 "the ought is the transcending, but still only finite transcending, of the limitation. Therefore, it has its place and its validity in the sphere of finitude where it holds fast to being-in-itself in opposition to limitedness, declaring the former to be the regulative and essential factor relatively to what is null."

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 07:31:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "Re-reading the section on limit, it's never developed to be an in-itself." Here we're talking about limitation (not limit, right?) --- I'm not talking about limit, I'm talking about what happens when non-being-for-other (limit) further becomes determinative of a particular object, not just an externality. "In-itself comes from something; he uses the term in-itself here bcs it's not really a something, because it's not determined by an external other or external limit. " I don't think this is correct at this point --- in multiple places he seems to indicate that the in-itself which is the meeting point (at this point) of constitution and determination has already taken on the property of being externally limited. "Determination and constitution showed themselves as sides for external reflection; but the former already contained otherness as belonging to the something's in-itself; the externality of the otherness is on the one hand in the something's own inwardness, on the other hand it remains, as externality, distinguished from it, it is still externality as such, but present in the something." I don't see why a limitation isn't *also* a something (i.e. why the limitation isn't the in-itself of in-itself which is the something of something). Certainly by the time we start discussing limitation we have access to something --- it *could* be a something, there are somethings at this point (I'm not saying that means it is something for sure, just that we aren't here restricted from having these things).

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 07:31:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I also notice that 'something' is the first negation of the negation while limit is outright defined as a negation of negation in 254 --- for me this isn't a problem (I think its negation of negation all the way down) but for Hegel this would seem to indicate that a limit is at least a something, so I don't know where that leaves limitation... Overall, my feeling is still that in 254 he doesn't like outright say 'the limitation is the in-itself of x' but I think that's heavily implied throughout the entire paragraph (and before that) --- really that the limit is the in-itself seen from outside (the meeting point of constitution and Determination) while the limitation is the in-itself posited as such.

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 07:32:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "He explains in the next paragraph something transcends itself because bcs the limit is sublated to be internal." I think the next paragraph is just a reiteration and shortening of 254 --- I don't think this is a forward moving paragraph. It was already sublated to be internal in 254. "That's why, in the paragraph developing Limitation and Ought, he call it an in-itself; it's basically a something, but technically transcending that form." I mean I would agree that ought is an in-itself, but also limitation (and also a something, ought is also a something --- an over-specified something). But that's because I think each of these things is conceptually contained in the other so that somethings are a kind quality, in-itself is a kind of something, limitation is a kind of in-itself, ought is a kind of limitation.

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 07:33:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Limitation cannot have a limitation because it would require 1) it to be an in-itself, but it's a quality, it exist in the thing it is a limitation of." Okay I think he're we're getting into an interesting argument but I don't buy it: qualities can also be somethings --- its not the case that *all* qualities are something (because quality comes first, something is specified on quality) but I do think it is the case that all somethings are *also* qualities (of something else --- which I think is one of the points of the movements of limit and limitation, but also they are qualities of reality). So saying 'well its a quality' --- Are you saying limitation is a *pure* quality --- because that doesn't seem correct. This is an even more interesting argument: "2) it would have to be finite, ie have an immanent limit. But an immanent limit requires immanent determinations; limitation is determined as for that which it a limitation of." Hegel definitely says that the infinite starts with the ought (which comes ever so slightly after limitation) so I'm not convinced that its not finite immediately on that basis. But you have a deeper idea of finite in mind. So 'immanent determination' means the limitation has to have qualities --- which I'm okay with, I think its also a something so it has qualities.

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 07:34:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 So I think the claim here is that limitation *doesn't* have qualities (or that a specific limitation doesn't have any quality to it, it is a quality but doesn't have a quality, unlike a something which I read as the quality of quality and thus flips around and becomes a quality with qualities). And the reason why is that what would be called its 'qualities' are just the object its attached which it is a quality of, not which is a quality of it. Okay... Except that it does have a quality of its own which is the ought: that is, it has these mediated determination in the object its a limitation of, sure, but it also has this immediate determination in the ought, in the fact that it can be overcome: this is not a quality of *the object* that the limitation is attached to but rather its a quality *of the limitation*. The fact that there is a place beyond the points at the end of the line is not a quality of the line but of the points as the limitation of the line (the argument for this being that *anything* could be in that space beyond, but that *anything* doesn't affect the line --- just the the fact that it only goes up to its limiting points affects the line: but the 'anything' does affect the points, if the anything touches them perfectly and brushes up against the line, then the points are not a limitation any longer because actually its the edge of this other thing which becomes the lines limitation --- or to put it another way, the immanent determination --- quality --- of a limitation is that it can be replaced by another limitation).

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 07:36:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "I mean, again, it just seems like you're clinging on to this "limitation of limitation" because you like the sound of it, without any attention to the text." Yes it can *sound* like that to you, it is poetic but that's not why I'm advancing this. I'm advancing this because I read the text, and this was the thought I got out of it. It may be wrong thought, I may not have read it correctly (I don't think so), but it is the thought I immanently felt while reading it. ‚ÄúIdek what you're talking about with "overcoming specific objects" and "back propagation".‚Äù By ‚Äòovercoming specific objects‚Äô I mean to juxtapose the limitation of a single object vs. the category of all limitations. By ‚Äòback propagation‚Äô I mean that once you‚Äôve determined something is true for a category it becomes true for everything in that category (it back propagates from the category to the specific objects).

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 07:45:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ‚ÄúI really think it's important we try to understand the text in its own terms and try to understand the specific meanings of each one.‚Äù I agree ‚ÄúHow they are used in the text is extremely precise and based on their derivation.‚Äù That‚Äôs fine. ‚ÄúPulling in our own associations of the words doesn't have a good track record so far‚Äù I strongly disagree, I think I‚Äôve learned more from pulling in associations of the words than I ever possibly could have just nodding my head in agreement and not really understanding but pretending I do so as to save myself the risk of not looking like a fool. The associations are going to be there regardless. That is not really negotiable. It is changeable, but only by stating them and dealing with them, but stating them and dealing with them is not *negotiable* if we are to actually be having a conversation. What we‚Äôre actually arguing over is whether I will state the associations or remain effectively silent (i.e. whether we will have a real conversation about this vs. me occasionally parroting you to not annoy you and otherwise shutting the fuck up). And I don‚Äôt do that, I may moderate tone but If I disagree the choice between ‚Äòah yes that‚Äôs very interesting but are we aware that...‚Äô on one end of the spectrum and ‚Äòthat not true you idiot‚Äô on the other (and silence as the third), but the choice isn‚Äôt ‚Äòoh yeah, you‚Äôre right, definitely‚Äô when I definitely don‚Äôt agree. You have to make me agree with you. (I also think there is a strange desire not to deal with the human side of learning here: like the text should be understood on its own terms, but it has to be understood by a concrete human being, you're only going to get them to understand the text on its own terms *in their own terms* simultaneously --- how's that for a unity of opposites).

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 07:46:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúThe ought is the transcending...‚Äù This isn‚Äôt a problem for me because to transcend an object is also to be the object (really to complete it) so It doesn‚Äôt really create a firm separation between ought and limitation. So unless Hegel says means the opposite by transcendence somewhere...

  • minimaltomThu Feb 22 2024 20:32:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    sorry not read all of everyones comments yet but just had the thought while i was reading (253) that there is a contradiction in **something** being **finite**, and conversly "that the finite is". (253) How can something be finite if it *is*? the definition of finite would imply that it should end but it carries on being, it exists infinitly right before our eyes, it doesnt end. If something is then it just is theres no end, otherwise instead of saying something **is** you'd always say it **is but will not be**. (this is but will not be a pencil) Like I can look at this pencil and say if it is finite then let me see it end, when is it going to end its supposed to dissapear but it just carries on being and you cant sit there and watch a pencil til it just ceases to be. So its like youre supposed to be finite but you just keep staying there... and on and on üòÑ

  • minimaltomThu Feb 22 2024 20:36:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    is this the contradiction hes talking about? ("This contradiction is, indeed, abstractly present simply in the circumstance that the something is finite, or that the finite is.")

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 20:51:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I don't disagree *pedagogically* with bringing in our associations; that feels like a slight of hand. You were claiming "actually you have to take the ..." As though speaking *logically*. I am claiming that you cannot *rely* on understanding of terms by associations. Our Intuitive sense of the terms *has to yield* to the technical determinations. That's pretty explicit in Hegels introductions. Rational critique has to form and shape our intuitions, not the other way around. This only works if you are willing to experience the falsity of your intuitions and continue to in letting it attempt to try to grasp the meaning; being cut to size by critical reason, and continuing to try to grasp it more. If you cling to your intuitions despite critical falsifications, you're not really learning anything. For example, to say "really that the limit is the in-itself seen from the outside" is just to say you don't know what in-itself is. I'm just asking you to consider that. "Seen from the outside" is for-other. In-itself is contrasted to the for-other. The in-itself is there merely implicit, explicitly, it's only know as 'not other', negative self reference. Limit becomes this "other" which something is *external* defined against, ie it's that which Something (and the other something ) are defined in negative self reference, their being-for-other determination. Limit never develops an independent existence; it only exists as a moment for the something and other (which is a something). I'm not saying it couldnt have become a something; idk, I previously thought it did. But Hegel doesn't say it does. It *only* exists *for somethings*, hence, not an in-itself. If the somethings cease to exist, so would it. That's part of what it means to be a quality, it does not stand on its own. So the passage on Ought, we *really do* have to dig through all the previous developments to understand what he means by *in-itself* in that context. To know what is being negated and why

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 20:53:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm definitely not advocating for thinking like a robot and cutting off associations and intuitions. First I'm a mystic and now I am robot without humanity üòÖ I'm saying we *ought* to refine our intuitions down to the precision of the text. Or at least, that is what I think is the best way to approach this.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 22 2024 21:19:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 <@805731746384445460>, is there a connection between the super ego and the ought in Lacan? Because through Zizek I've gotten that the super ego is all about what you 'ought' to do and to the extent where the ought becomes an impossible demmand. I came to this by thinking about how sometime the ought is impossible, you ought not to have broken that and so on, sometimes the ought is fulfilled and sometimes it isnt, and it seems like the super ego is the ultimate nuerotic instance of this as its always telling you what you ought to do even when you can't. Could very well be a superficial similarity but thought id throw it out there. (¬ß 263) ""'You can, because you ought' ‚Äî this expression, which is supposed to mean a great deal, is implied in the notion of ought. For the ought implies that one is superior to the limitation; in it the limit is sublated and the in-itself of the ought is thus an identical self-relation, and hence the abstraction of 'can'. But conversely, it is equally correct that: 'you cannot, just because you ought.' For in the ought, the limitation as limitation is equally implied; the said formalism of possibility has, in the limitation, a reality, a qualitative otherness opposed to it and the relation of each to the other is a contradiction, and thus a 'cannot', or rather an impossibility.""

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 22:14:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 In Freud and most classical psychoanalysis the Super Ego is the 'ought' or 'should' as opposed to the want or desire or drive of the Id

    Fromm's book Man For Himself is truly remarkable! Clear Hegelian reference, and is basically about developing a healthy super ego, or conscience. One which is internalized, and refined by self reflection, not external pressures. Because the super ego begins in childhood as internalization of parents voices; and many people never uproot it to question it but live by the implicit values they grew up with. So he shows how to develop a real Ethic from a materialist understanding of our sense of ethics

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 22:43:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "This only works if you are willing to experience the falsity of your intuitions and continue to in letting it attempt to try to grasp the meaning; being cut to size by critical reason, and continuing to try to grasp it more." I'm trying to get there, not yet there --- I mean I do allow this to happen: I just have a very high bar for its occurrence (you really have to convince me that I'm plain wrong as opposed to 'well I didn't have that feeling when I read it' Which is very like 'cool, whatever'). (there isn't really a disagreement on the primacy of the text, rather the disagreement is on whether the text says what you think it says vs. it saying what I think it says vs. and this is a radical possibility --- it being ambiguous between the two of us). "Seen from the outside" is for-other. In-itself is contrasted to the for-other." I've considered it and that was not my reading (and I don‚Äôt think this is ambiguous, but you can consider my evidence and see if you agree). Its contrasted *and* unified with the for-other. The something splits into the for-other and the in-itself *and then* the in-itself is further determined into the determination (the for-other of the in-itself) while the for-other is further determined into constitution (the in-itself of the for-other). This means that the in-itself obtains an aspect of the for-other in its determination (this is in section ¬ß 231). (which isn't *just* for-other, it's specifically the for-other of the in-itself).

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 22:44:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think the most interesting argument you've made here is: "Limit never develops an independent existence; it only exists as a moment for the something and other (which is a something)." First I want to insist again: we aren't talking about limit but limitations, because I think it may be an important difference. But I also think I did specifically say it seems very likely that limit is something so this is a fair question. But is a limit something then using this criteria? I actually think that is: because the limit is determined outside both something and its other it has to be something itself independent of both of them (the mountains between eastern and western washington are mountains whether or not eastern and western washington are the territories on either side). This could be extended by thinking of a situation where the limit is instead a desert or a river (i.e. it obtains an independent existence because it matters *how* something and other make contact with each other through the limit for us to decide which limit, exactly, we‚Äôre talking about). I think this reasoning is enough to defeat the question for the purposes of *my argument* (i.e. I think a limit does exist independently as a third in the formula of something and other --- its the ‚Äòand‚Äô which has its own substantive existence). The fact that he says a point is a limit in section 246 (and we know he thinks a point is also a something --- actually he calls lots of ‚Äòsomethings‚Äô ‚Äòlimits in that section) makes me think that a limit is also a something in this way.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 22 2024 22:44:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I totally think it can and is exploited terribly

  • minimaltomThu Feb 22 2024 22:44:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    the position of the one who knows

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 22:45:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 But then the question would become --- okay maybe a limit is a something, even a something necessarily... but it isn‚Äôt a *limit* without both something and the other. This is where I would move to *limitation* as the in-itself of the in-itself as opposed to limit because limit may always be a something but may not carry the valence of something into its quality as a limit while limitation may not be burdened with that deficiency: by this I mean precisely in the move of internalizing the limit into the object through limitation the direction of causality flips --- its not that limitation doesn‚Äôt exist without the something its assigned to, but rather the something its assigned to doesn‚Äôt exist without the limitation (my evidence is this sentence from 254: Something's own limit thus posited by it as a negative *which is at the same time essential*, is not merely limit as such, but limitation) This essentialness would seem to flip the direction of necessity on its head in terms of what requires what to exist.

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 22:45:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "So the passage on Ought, we really do have to dig through all the previous developments to understand what he means by in-itself in that context." I don't disagree (If you remember, the conceptual break I was talking about was between the infinite and the finite --- I was annoyed at tom for stepping into the middle of a conversation about the infinite with a demand that I explain the whole of the finite in a single go to him to prove to him that I'm not an asshole and bullshitter. Even in the form of **our** disagreement --- ought = limitation of limitation, limitation = in-itself of in-itself, etc. each step I propose still relies upon all the previous steps. To really get the ought in my understanding you would need to dig through all the aspects of limitation which would entail all the aspects of in-itself which would entail... etc. which is why this statement has triggered such a total exploration of the text which is why it's a good question: if it was a bad question it would be very easy to answer).

  • minimaltomThu Feb 22 2024 22:46:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 22:51:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    You say "because the limit is determined outside both something and it's other" And this is precisely false, I think. It's *only* determined by something and other It exists outside them (as the idea of outside of them), but has no determinations outside them

  • minimaltomThu Feb 22 2024 22:54:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    not within its limit "the very fact that something is determined as a limitation implies that the limitation is already transcended" ¬ß 265

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:00:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ¬ß 243 "Limit is the mediation through which something and other each as well is, as is not." ¬ß 244 Limit is the middle between the two of them in which they cease. They have their determinate being beyond each other and beyond their limit; the limit as the non-being of each is the other of both." ¬ß 246 "These limits are the principle of that which they limit; just as one, for example as hundredth, is the limit, but also the element, of the whole hundred."

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:02:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    All these give a strong sense that limit is merely a quality of the somethign and other; could not exist indepent of them. If there's anything to suggest otherwise, I'd consider it, but i've re-read it many times now and find no indication. I have no clue how the limit becoming "immantment" would change that. The limitation is simply "Something's own limit thus posited by it as a negative which is at the same time essential"

  • minimaltomThu Feb 22 2024 23:05:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I have to go, got to go spend some time with my girlfriend. Been doing too much reading

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:06:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 But abstractions are also examples, they're just examples paired down to the essential thing (at least in my understanding). An example is good for establishing some things --- its good for establishing existence (so there are definitely limits that exist that are also somethings --- that is clear). And its good for establishing negation of existence (if you could provide me with an example of a limit which is *not* a something that would counter my position by establishing that limits aren't contained in the category of something). But if we really want to start with the beginning of limit~~ation~~ as a substantive object --- we should perhaps look at 239 where Hegel says: "There is a single determinateness of both, which on the one hand is **identical with the being-within-self of the somethings** (thomas here: identical with their somethingness as far as I can tell --- that is from section ¬ß 209) as negation of the negation, and on the other hand, since these negations are opposed to one another as other somethings, conjoins and equally disjoins them through their own nature, each negating the other: this determinateness is limit."

  • minimaltomThu Feb 22 2024 23:07:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I have read Hegel say a few times about limit being itself a limit but i have no idea what hes talking about as of yet

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:08:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "Its contrasted *and* unified with the for-other. The something splits into the for-other and the in-itself *and then* the in-itself is further determined into the determination (the for-other of the in-itself) while the for-other is further determined into constitution (the in-itself of the for-other). This means that the in-itself obtains an aspect of the for-other in its determination (this is in section ¬ß 231). (which isn't *just* for-other, it's specifically the for-other of the in-itself)." The something is *both* in-itself and for-other; they are the two determinations of it; the 'in-itself' is the unique one, the determination that comes to exist only with the concept of the something: "¬ß 220 Determinate being as such is immediate, without relation to an other; or, it is in the determination of being; but as including within itself non-being, it is determinate being, being negated within itself, and then in the first instance an other-but since at the same time it also preserves itself in its negation, it is only a being-for-other. ¬ß 221 It preserves itself in the negative of its determinate being and is being, but not being in general, but as self-related in opposition to its relation to other, as self-equal in opposition to its inequality. Such a being is being-in-itself."

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:08:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think that limit is a quality of something and other (but also *I* think that a something is also a quality so, that doesn't cause a difficulty) --- but I think 239 shuts the door.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:11:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    239 shuts the door?

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:11:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    idk how you are reading that

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:12:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "The something is both in-itself and for-other; they are the two determinations of it; the 'in-itself' is the unique one, the determination that comes to exist only with the concept of the something:" --- that's fine, I'm just saying that the in-itself, as a something, also so splits. and the in-itself's for-other is what we call the determination.

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:14:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 That Hegel says 'this determinateness which is identical with the being-within-self of the something (this determinateness which is identical with the somethingness of the somethings) ...: this determinateness is the limit. That's how I'm reading it (the stuff about negation of negation is interesting but it reinforces the point since something is the first negation of negation, the each negating each other is also interesting but I think its to the side of our current argument).

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:15:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think that's the abstract statement that you want

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:16:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He is saying it is a "determinateness" which is a quality, not a something

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:16:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    its the determinateness *through which* something has "being-within-self"

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:16:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    becaues its the negative self reference

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:17:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:17:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:17:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    We're in determinate being

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:17:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    -ness is always a quality

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:17:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:17:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:18:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ¬ß 190

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:18:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:18:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:18:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Sorry you're right about that but its besides the point --- **THOMAS IS A FUCKUP** --- it can be a quality and a something

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:19:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (I'm a fuckup because I got to into beating you, not because I'm wrong) it doesn't matter that -ness is a quality

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:19:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    he is relativising the something and other, and saying their determinations can be the same, they don't have to be defined against each other, they can be defined by the "middle" between them

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:19:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    That's fine

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:19:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    but thats all the limit is, the thing which they are defined against. It says "I am not what is beyond that - my limit"

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:20:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    so the limit *only* exists for the purpose of defining them

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:20:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    it has not independent existence

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:20:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The thing, one dares say the something

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:20:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    but allows them do be defined by their own quality, not by another something

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:20:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Or, the limit is a something whose quality *as a limit* only exists for the purposes defining the two others

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:20:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:25:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:38:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Thu Feb 22 2024 23:38:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:46:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think what is negated in the second negation can't be described by that formula. Its negating the "one-sideness" of mere quality. The Quality of Quality, is that quality is simply some aspect *of* quality, perhaps its abstractness, its "deficiency". That it is "only immediate". Something is "negation of the negation"; negation is defined in the section on quality: "Nothing, as thus the determinate element of a determinateness, is equally something reflected, a negation." Negation is a "determinate element" of quality/determinateness. So that suggests to my, only if you squint and conflate Quality with an element of it, can you say Something is Quality of Quality. Quality, perhaps is negation 'in the form of being'; conent is negation, form is being. For something, the *content* is being; thats what I take to be have "in itelf"; But it is only outwardly distinguished as not other; its form is negation

  • andru0358Thu Feb 22 2024 23:46:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)
