  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 00:10:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 So here we're making progress and I can see how I could have shortened this whole argument up and was wrong myself (I kept thinking of *negation* as being synonymous with *nothing*) So we both get to be a little wrong here (your wrong because the squinting is a valid move). Insomuch as negation is a quality (and hegel says that negation is quality burdened with nothing) then something --- which is defined as negation of negation, necessarily is also a quality of quality. But I like this because it makes me have thoughts which may develop into new concepts rather than running around in a circles through the text. I don't think however that they are siblings --- maybe quality is the *grandparent* or *great grandparent* or *aunt* of something (i.e. negation is the quality of quality or negation is the quality of nothing), but I definitely don't buy the sibling (or we could even say cousin) hypothesis: I think this step actually shows that something must flow from quality through negation which is a quality. My suspicion is that my original point about Hegel starting with being may continue to hold here --- that effectively quality burdened with nothing would be just quality (negation would be just quality) if Hegel wasn't an idealist and that in fact Hegel is adding steps to suit his idealism. But this is my spontaneous thought --- I'm not convinced by it yet (the other possibility I would hold out is that it goes quality of quality -> reality of reality -> negation of negation -> something, but this is also spontaneous and not a firm thought).

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 00:50:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I am hesitant to say Negation is a Quality, as though negation does not precede it. He does use 'negation' in moments of becoming, but as "abstract, immediate negation". Also, v interesting at the end of the section on Quality: "Negation taken as mere deficiency would be equivalent to nothing; but it is a determinate being, a quality, only determined with a non-being." I think negation *becomes* a quality. So in that sense maybe Something derives from Quality. Tbh, I don't have a good intuition of *how* something is a negotiation of negotiation, like which negation is being negated? The emptiness of pure being? Or of Quality? But coming back to limit, do you see why he calls it a "non-being-for-other"?

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 00:50:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This is quite fruitful and interesting now

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 00:52:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Oh yea, since Quality has two moments, would those be its qualities? Reality and negation?

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 00:54:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I still think: Quality is Negation in form of Being Something is Being in form of non-being/negation. But he says something interesting about Something in Relation to Quality we could parse together:

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 00:55:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ¬ß 208 In determinate being its determinateness has been distinguished as quality; in quality as determinately present, **there is distinction ‚Äî of reality and negation.** Now although these distinctions are present in determinate being, they are no less equally void and sublated. Reality itself contains negation, is determinate being, not indeterminate, abstract being. Similarly, negation is determinate being, not the supposedly abstract nothing but posited here as it is in itself, as affirmatively present [als seiend], belonging to the sphere of determinate being. Thus quality is completely unseparated from determinate being, which is simply determinate, qualitative being. ¬ß 209 This sublating of **the distinction** is more than a mere taking back and external omission of it again, or than a simple return to the simple beginning, to determinate being as such. The distinction cannot be omitted, for it is. What is, therefore, in fact present is determinate being in general, distinction in it, and sublation of this distinction; determinate being, not as devoid of distinction as at first, but as again equal to itself through sublation of the distinction, the simple oneness of determinate being resulting from this sublation. This sublatedness of the distinction is determinate being's own determinateness; it is thus being-within-self: determinate being is a determinate being, a something.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 01:02:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What do you think Being of Being is?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:06:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Well, I think determinate being here is marked as a something --- and what is more the phrase negation of negation is truth of Hegel in some sense because I actually doesn't fit exactly what he says here: by which I mean that one way to look at this would be: quality splits into reality and negation, however the two come back together (as in becoming) and this co-equal coming back together of reality and negation produces a new determinate being that is both simply the token 'determinate being' but now also because it sublates two sub components (negation and reality) there is something for it to determine *against* and as a result it is also a something (the whole category of determinate being is a something now).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:08:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So my naive answer for 'being of being' would be becoming

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:08:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But I don't think that's Hegel's answer (I would think his answer would be nothing)

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:10:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But I also want to get back to the move from something being the sublation of reality and negation to the negation of negation --- because for me that's a really interesting move: I think it indicates that reality and negation are *not* co-equal branches of quality.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:11:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (i.e. that reality is just 'x with some y' while negation is just 'y with some x' or even that reality is just 'x with some -x' and negation is just '-x with some x')

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:33:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm thinking quality->reality->negation->somthing is more likely true (i.e. that the reality of reality is negation: I know this is a poetry, but there definitely is a bias against reality if you really read this last sentence of 197 very closely: "Quality, taken in the distinct character of being, is reality; as burdened with a negative it is negation in general, likewise a quality but one which counts as a deficiency, and which further on is determined as limit, limitation." --- it's not quality 'in general' which moves onto limit and limitation but specifically negation in general which moves on to limit and limitation --- passing by way of something. To me, I think Hegel is starting to smuggle materialism into his idealism here. Must still consider however.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:34:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    If the above is true then negation is not merely 'a quality' but rather the essence of quality by the time we reach negation.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:35:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (insofar as I know anything about essence, all caveats apply, this may or may not be a Hegelian essence, etc. etc.)

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 01:35:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Why is it important that it's a repitition of the same term? Why not Quality is being of nothing Reality is being of being Negation the nothing of quality Becoming the coming-to-be (being passing to nothing) ?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:41:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Because I think what is going on here is we're moving from the most abstract concept to the most abstract concept as a series of necessary steps and the most abstract concept at each stage is the jumping off point for developing anything new so the only thing left to it is for it to apply itself to itself to generate something new (i.e. to sublate itself) --- I'm treating all of these steps as being prototyped on sublation (at least I think this what happens when its time for us to see a true new concept --- as opposed to something which is just an assemblage). This has to do with my understanding of contradiction, that you don't get anything interesting until you have a contradiction (which is always a self-contradiction eventually).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:46:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm not *completely* opposed to the idea that there could be an equal splitting in one of these objects --- especially because of non-relation (maybe the contradiction is such that it has to appear in multiplicity of distinct non-reducible paths)... but that wouldn't get us out of the x of x problem --- it would just say that there are two or more distinct 'x of x' that aren't equal to each other: which I'm not opposed. However, tbh I was originally reading reality and negation as coequal but looking at them now I don't think they are and I actually think that since we haven't yet hit non-relation that its like everything up til the one has this singular deterministic path for the moment.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 01:47:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (we have to remember that every object after negation... is a negation: so that's why they can all be negations of negations by being x of x --- because they are all inherently negations in my reading).

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 03:07:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I don't think every moment is a negation. There's an alternation of Beings and Negations, with becomings thrown in. Ought, I'm not sure what it is, may Ought is both a quality and a Being? He does say it *is* and *is not*. But Quality is a negation; something is a being, limit a negation, finite thing (being), limitation (neg), finitude (neg), infinite (being) I am curious why you believe that only contradictions are interesting?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 04:40:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I would say that for Hegel clearly the moments before negation are not negation (or at least we can quibble over that and I don't particularly want to) --- however almost all of them (except being itself) have a flavor of negation since they all contain nothing somehow (and I believe that being without nothing doesn't exist, its not a concept, thing, idea, possibility, etc. in fact it is a contradiction). However after negation I think he gets into a groove where everything that is coming up is some kind of negation from that point forward (even the whole category of determinate being is a negation because it is a negation of negation because it is a something). To me 'being' is just 'not not' and becoming is 'not and not not' So even if there are becomings and beings thrown in... they're nothings first (this is not hegel's position). But even ignoring what I think, ought is definitely a something so even if its a quality its a quality which has negated itself into something. This is why I claim Hegel should start with nothing --- because the 'not' is what is doing all the work. "something is a being, limit a negation, finite thing (being), limitation (neg), finitude (neg), infinite (being)" --- I mean the opposition isn't between being and negation but between being and nothing, but they're all determinate being so they're all nothing as well as being and they are all (except quality perhaps) negations (because he doesn't build something out of reality without negation, he shoves negation into reality right quick). I think that only contradictions are 'interesting' because a system without contradictions is an automation. Its basically just pure being (the being without nothing that doesn't exist: i.e. its not really possible to not have a system without contradictions, but an automation is as close as we could imagine) --- Its death without death. Boring. The only point where there is choice, let alone freedom, is once there is a contradiction.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 05:51:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    My retelling of chapter 1 would be: Nothing (false) -> being (true or false --- because false false is true so we have either true or false available to us) -> becoming (true --- because tautology allows us to start swapping things out for other things, so tautology applied to tautology can swap tautology out for mere truth of becoming) -> determinate being (T and F) because the truth of truth is that it is *not* equal to tautology, is other than tautology, and as a result we get T != (T or F), the move from being to becoming can not be reverse stepped, we get a contradiction -> determinateness (F again, higher level) contradiction of contradiction: that which is both a contradiction and not a contradiction --- determinatenesses are contradictions because they establish difference (this and that cannot be the same) but they are not contradictions because they exist (are determinate *being*).

  • minimaltomFri Feb 23 2024 17:13:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I thought this was an interesting line ¬ß215 "a determinate being is determined as other only through being compared by a Third" I was wondering if this **third** is us the audience, as in this observation is only true 'for us' and isnt therefore posited or or immanent developement at this stage.

  • minimaltomFri Feb 23 2024 17:15:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    just before that he says "Otherness thus appears as a determination alien to the determinate being thus characterised, or as the other outside the one determinate being" so the other doesn't percieve itself as the other.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 17:48:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 Maybe this is unfair and I just got lost on the argument: but basically every starts with contradiction because otherwise it'd be boring? Basically pure being is too boring bcs it's pure? I think there's both beauty and the sublime (which does not mean unknowable) in the unity of Pure Being and Nothing. They're not even really opposed on their purity. Idk if it is a contradiction or not. But I don't find any aesthetic problem with it. I agree with every movement is centered on a negation. But what is being negated? There has to be being to negating. Being is doing all the work of there being anything to work with, to be negated. I think that's why Nothing is not quite negation; pure negation wouldn't even be negation, it'd return to nothing. Negation requires a being to negate. Negation requires being, and one negation makes contact with it, it becomes det being, DaSein. So negation isn't a stand alone thing; and I think the same is for contradiction. Contradiction requires beings in contradiction.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 17:50:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Idk about being as 'not not'. Do you not think that 'not' has being? So with a 'not' or a nothing, being is already there

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 17:57:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Well I think the development coming out of something/other doesn't depend on which one is which. So the development is immanent. He's emphasizing precisely the abstractness of both, only having that they both exist and are distinct from each other. That's all we know about them. He could write it as "the two somethings, mutually each's other" but he does need to analyze one at a time, to move through their individual determinations. But everything that applies to one, does also to the other, bcs they're only distinct . He trying to emphasize the relativeness of "other"-ness. Other -ness is *not* immanent

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 17:58:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    *Y'all* we gotta move on to Infinity and Being-for-itself

  • minimaltomFri Feb 23 2024 18:01:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I see your point but why is he referring to a third point of view, who or what is that?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 18:25:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "Maybe this is unfair and I just got lost on the argument: but basically every starts with contradiction because otherwise it'd be boring? Basically pure being is too boring bcs it's pure?" No. You asked why contradictions are 'interesting' not why they're 'true': They're 'true' because they're generative and you only need the single concept (the only nothing which demands the existence of something is a contradiction) to bootstrap yourself. Hegel needs two concepts to bootstrap himself (being *and* nothing). This is because of his idealism. The materialist response (by way of Occam's razor) is that this is one concept too many ("one becomes two"). "I agree with every movement is centered on a negation. But what is being negated? There has to be being to negating." This is the disagreement between idealism and materialism at a deep level --- for materialism **there is no** being (and it doesn't have to be negated, the deepest concept is nothing negating itself --- or really nothing nothinging itself --- which is being which is contradiction --- its still nothing/not which is doing all the work: being is only doing like 99% of the work, in so much as it is 'not nothing' --- its really the 'not' which is doing the work). Contradiction doesn't require 'beings in contradiction' --- that's just what the appearance of contradiction must be within being --- actual contradiction is before everything else including being (its also after everything else -> its the mediated immediate). I don't think the pure 'not' has being, however I think it may not actually be nothing because its actually less than nothing (Here I'm bringing in Zizek). I.e. really it should be Nothing (contradiction)-> less than nothing (F) -> Being (T or F) -> Becoming (T) -> Determinate Being (contradiction again).

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 22:56:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What does 'Being' mean to you such that to claim: "the pure 'not' has [doesn't] have being?" What is it that it doesn't have? Pure not is, but does not have being?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:30:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0@dve.h_37844#0 Pure not is, but does not have being? Actually the pure not is not (both at the level of 'haha language is fun' but like really it doesn't have being, its not --- there is a name for that 'not,' the token/symbol --- but that also isn't the pure not, that's many contradictory twists and turns through being in by the time we get to the token). The pure not inside of every 'not' is the way in which something doesn't exist (at least once we're talking about objects). This is why its also the carrier of possibility: because possibility is first a non-being (pure possibility is first a non-being, it is only when it turns against itself that we start to get actual possibilities, after we've already stepped into being --- so determinateness or quality maybe is the first place where actual as opposed to pure possibility enters). Like the base note of the contradiction the pure nothing that ex-sists (here ex-sists means, something like 'fails to exist') before the pure not, is all that stuff which is actually impossible in the purest sense and couldn't ever happen: these things do not have being (or to put it another way, nothing == contradiction and contradiction == nothing: it's not just that contradictions don't exist but rather everything that isn't a contradiction exists and that's why I brought up the many world's hypothesis of quantum mechanics: here I'm not really stepping away from Hegel (except for the quantum mechanics bit): he also thinks things 'exist' if they are consistent --- Zizek's point about Hegel is that Marxists don't understand that Hegel is *almost* materialist in his idealism, and so most of what he says holds, that might be my disagreement with <@1144442476145426592>, not certain: there is more materialism to the Infinite that appears at first, it isn't all just fluff and stuff about God).

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:33:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think I'm developing this in real time so mistakes will be made (I haven't until now really tried to directly map these onto Hegel's direct categories) But I suspect that Being is just what I've said it is: its tautology. Its 'not contradiction'.

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:33:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But what is "Being" that pure not does not have?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:33:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It doesn't have tautology, at all

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:34:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Its not equivalent to anything else

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:34:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I am asking about Being

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:34:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm not asking about pure not.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:35:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Yes but the answers answers both questions

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:35:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Being is tautology?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:35:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think, and this is spontaneous, new, undeveloped but I think being is tautology, equivalence

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:35:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Is pure not, then, not equivalent with itself?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:36:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    No

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:37:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So it's a multiplicity?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:38:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Once you have being you do play this game of a = not not a... but that's not from the perspective of being. Before that a != not not a (this was the difficulty I had with Alex when he was mad at me for saying that an orange is not not an apple: this is true because a cat is not an apple and an orange is not a cat: this kind of sophistic logic is the pure not working itself out in being).

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:39:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think the word *sophistic* is key

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:39:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Its both key and 'ha ha' overread --- the point is that sophistry is the *begining* of logic. You can't have logic without sophistry

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:39:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I don't agree

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:39:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Then what is sophistry?

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:42:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I should be clear --- my point isn't that we end there. But that its the basic core component of reality, of existence, being, and logic and the eternal and even that before being --- that first it decieves, first it fails.

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:43:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And that is the materialist position

  • firedog235Fri Feb 23 2024 23:46:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (actually I should be a bit more precise --- I say we don't end there. The way we don't end there is the failure to fail --- so failure is eternal in that sense and that's the idealism of materialism --- the essential unity of the two which I why I'm not so afraid of Hegel's 'inflammatory' statement about idealism)

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:49:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    To me, Logic requires a desire for Truth, what I name Integrity. Sophistry is a disregard for Truth, dishonesty, opportunitism, manipulation, deceit. Its why you have lost credibility with many in the group; you *seem* more interested in looking clever than getting to the truth of the matter. When you have an interest other than truth, but pretend to seem interested in the truth instrumentally for that other purpose, that's sophistry, imo. Logic exists for the purpose of overcoming our self-deceptions, over coming our sophistry. Do you have any basis to claim this nonsense is prior to being?

  • andru0358Fri Feb 23 2024 23:53:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Zizek is also a sophist, and not a materialist.

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 00:38:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "Do you have any basis to claim this nonsense is prior to being?" Not from Hegel, From Zizek yes but my personal basis rather is just that contradictions don't exist, they ex-sist (can't exist), and as a result they are not part of being. And I think its interesting that physics seems to indicate that everything that can exist does. So... they aren't a beyond, but rather they're the foundation upon which being exists (actually exists). The "true is a moment of the false." --- I think you're avoiding saying that Sophistry is *not* logic because you know what the implication of that is (therefore sophistry is the limit of logic, sophistry is a limitation on logic, logic ought to be sophistry). What I would say is that logic is the sophistry of sophistry --- the deception of the deceiver, and since the highest form of deception is self-deception it is specifically the deception of self-deception (i.e. its playing with meaningless symbols in their abstract movements --- deception, what you've called 'formalism' --- in the attempt to break ourselves of our self-deceptions because we can't *directly* escape our self-deception --- or to put it another way, Hegel is very careful in section $175 about saying that dialectic is *not* sophistry and my point is that 'yes its *not* sophistry, because its the negation of sophistry, its the sophistry of sophistry'. The reason *why* he feels the need to say this, though, is because that is the prime accusation against Hegel --- that what he's doing is *merely* nonsense and I'm saying I agree with Hegel I agree with Hegel that isn't *merely* doing nonsense, that like most adverbs that word is doing more work in that sentence that it should and that in reality Hegel is exploring the *implication of nonsense* for everything --- i.e. how do we *actually* escape sophistry).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 00:38:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think that the use of the word desire is very important in what you said because one of the basic self-deceptions is the fantasy that *we* are the one serving truth. I should be clear, fantasies are sometime true so I'm not saying that anyone who thinks this is definitely wrong (or definitely wrong all the time), but rather that the fantasmic energy around this desire of truth leads us into error. The desire for truth is not, and cannot be the way to the truth (after all desire is the desire of desire --- desire desires nothing so much but to continue to be desire, i.e. to remain unfulfilled).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 00:42:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I would not define the desire for truth as integrity --- I think these are different things (specifically I think integrity is the drive towards truth which is not a desire in the sense that drive transcends desire). "Its why you have lost credibility with many in the group; you seem more interested in looking clever than getting to the truth of the matter." Yeah this is like the 'socialism is just equality' petit-bourgois type socialism that thinks that looking clever or achieving something great is just useless nonsense of the intelligentsia and not the inner core of the greatness of the intelligentsia which would have to be a part of any communism worth having. Even if *all* I care about is looking clever (and its not all I care about: what I care about if you really want to know is not suffering horrible death and I think that lies are a good way to suffer horrible death, and I also care about us getting these ideas right, not just repeating old stupid cliches and nostrums which have gotten us into this bad state to begin with, but that's neither here nor there) looking clever is still productive *by itself* --- it isn't something to be squashed except in the most extreme case (extreme here meaning like, putting peoples lives in immanent direct harm during an emergency and even then, I suspect the tendency). It has forced all of you to be on your best game and not treat this as just another reading group. "Zizek is also a sophist, and not a materialist." As to the last point, why not both? The best logician of materialism will be the best sophist because they will be the best at deceiving us out of our self-deception. If the accusation is that Zizek is *merely* a sophist --- then yeah *that's* some nonsense.

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 00:49:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (and I can give you an example for why desire for truth doesn't function: I go to the doctor and I say 'doc do I have cancer?' and the doctor replies, out of an abundent desire for truth, to only tell the truth 'you either have cancer or you don't have cancer' and sends me on my way. This doctor has told the truth, even desires not to lie, but nevertheless this doctor has no integrity and no drive towards truth: to me this is the problem of being).

  • minimaltomSat Feb 24 2024 00:51:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 As far as I understand a sophist is someone who is concerned with rhetorical argument over truth or integrity but has come to mean a charlatan, do you think zizeks a charlatan or the former?

  • andru0358Sat Feb 24 2024 02:36:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think Zizek is sincerely interested in philosophy, although I don't think he's that great; his politics are very compromised imo. I don't think there were many good philosophers in his whole generation; I think he and Willam Jameson are closest to what I wish was there. But the conviction of philosophy is historically not so big since WW2, imo. But declining since Hegel's time. In part for good reasons. But also, imo, a lot of technologism & scientism. I think truth has to be humanistic, not formal. I think that's the rational kernal of idealism; the truth is in always at least partly subjective, in the sense of my/our relation to it. Pure subjective truths like philosophy, in some sense are more able to step outside History. Whereas any practical truth is contextualized by historically specific human practices, programming, engineering, therapy, politics, pedagogy, publishing, etc.. But philosophy is still a human practice. And what desires take us to it affect how we interact with it. Isn't that what Zizek means about the master signifier as the 4th moment? The subjective, orienting, driving force? Hegel says little things about overcoming finite desires, implying desiring ideals instead. This is really a difficult task, psychoanalysis has shown. I think religions have taken it seriously forever; and Hegel knew much more about all that than anyone since. It's simply the default now to be in self deception. Quite an achievement of inner work to overcome. Maybe not historically even possible. Maybe it never was and all this is naive. But it requires self knowledge, ultimately, and Reason to unwind it all. A constant self questioning; Kierkegaard and Nietzsche are v good on this. As is Freud. idk Lacan but I understand he's taken to be doing that type of analysis. Zizek understands it, to play the game. But he's also much more influenced by post structuralism and all that sophistry. Philosophy became a celebrity thing, and he is definitely into that.

  • andru0358Sat Feb 24 2024 02:36:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And making things complicated became a technique of sounding smart. Foucault admitted this to John Searle.

  • andru0358Sat Feb 24 2024 02:37:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And I just don't take him as an authority on anything. Maybe he's good at making it fun to get into these topics..he's done his hw for sure.

Engels thought Marxism was much more scientific than Zizek‚Ä¶not sure where he got that idea from.

  • andru0358Sat Feb 24 2024 03:33:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "The chief defect of all hitherto existing materialism ‚Äì that of Feuerbach included ‚Äì is that the thing, reality, sensuousness, is conceived only in the form of the object or of contemplation, but not as sensuous human activity, practice, not subjectively. Hence, in contradistinction to materialism, the active side was developed abstractly by idealism ‚Äì which, of course, does not know real, sensuous activity as such."

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 03:49:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "I think Zizek is sincerely interested in philosophy, although I don't think he's that great; his politics are very compromised imo. " I think that Zizek is a very good philosopher though not the most careful scholar (the two are not exactly the same thing). I would agree that his politics are not completely my own but I always pay careful attention to the reasons why he says something, not just the headline (because usually the headline is a provocation).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 03:52:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "I think truth has to be humanistic, not formal." No. The truth is the formalism of formalism (in that sense it is ‚Äònot formal‚Äô since formal is also a negation, but this ‚Äònot‚Äô doesn‚Äôt take us to ‚Äòmore human‚Äô --- if anything it takes us towards something more like ‚Äòmore alien‚Äô). To me that is the whole point of this book we're reading. The truth *can't* be simply humanistic (i.e. you can't oppose humanism to the formalism of the truth). The truth may not be *merely* formal (in fact it isn‚Äôt) but it is formally formal (i.e. it must be formal or it doesn‚Äôt work, if it isn‚Äôt formal it isn‚Äôt truth). You don‚Äôt get to just free yourself of formalism arbitrarily (which I don't think you think, but you haven't given me a good rubric for when to drop formalism), but also the formality of it demands you work through contradictions if you are really driving towards truth and at some point your system will ‚Äòbreak‚Äô on those contradictions at which point the formalism breaks down and you have reinvent it anew with new assumptions. Assumptions are okay for first passes but the assumption is always founded on a contradiction: the contradiction that everything must be justified and the assumption doesn‚Äôt have to be justified --- that‚Äôs how I take Hegel‚Äôs specific statement in $175 --- i.e. ‚ÄúFor sophistry is an argument proceeding from a baseless presupposition which is *uncritically* and *unthinkingly* adopted‚Äù (aside, this is also speculative reason without the return to reason that occurs in finding out your speculation was either right or wrong) --- the problem isn‚Äôt that you adopted an argument or even that you adopted it baselessly but rather that you did so unthinkingly and uncritically, i.e. without the ability to consider your assumption as an assumption (which means as a contradiction). This is the whole critique of formalism and Spinoza which I don‚Äôt read as a pure ‚Äòformalism bad‚Äô (which you seem to read it as) but rather ‚Äòinformal formalism bad‚Äô.

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 03:52:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "I think that's the rational kernel of idealism; the truth is in always at least partly subjective, in the sense of my/our relation to it." To make this the rational kernel of idealism is to make it materialist but to make it materialist isn‚Äôt to say something like ‚Äòmy relation to the truth is the story I tell myself about it, your relation to the truth is your story about it, we all have our separate stories and they don‚Äôt have to be made consistent with each other‚Äô --- that may be true but it isn‚Äôt The Truth. However, if I read this as an actually materialist claim then what you're saying here is a basic naive materialism (i.e. one way to put it would that materialism is the speed of light --- causality/truth is not predetermined but moves only at the speed of light, only at the speed of time --- the truth is that you don't know the truth until you encounter it, etc.) But this is not a *human* thing (its not epistemological but rather ontological). You don't know the truth until you encounter it because the atoms in your body literally don't ‚Äòknow‚Äô their truth's until they encounter them. This is an aspect of the truth itself (it's in things themselves). Which is why I mention the speed of light/atoms. However, you would need to pick a side on this for me to know what you mean.

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 03:54:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúPure subjective truths like philosophy, in some sense are more able to step outside History. Whereas any practical truth is contextualized by historically specific human practices, programming, engineering, therapy, politics, pedagogy, publishing, etc..‚Äù There is a use of the word ‚Äòsubjective‚Äô here that I think is both understandable but strange: I feel like if philosophy can step outside history then that would make it actually objective while if these others are bound to human history then they‚Äôre actually subjective, but I also know that there is likely a flipping of meaning (drawn from German idealism) that is occurring here between idealism and materialism. But this is suspect to me (especially since I suspect that German idealist subjectivism may be conflated with more modern uses of the term).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 03:56:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúBut philosophy is still a human practice.‚Äù Maybe, maybe not (it may be the movement of spirit above humanity --- spirit here translating into ‚Äòthe symbolic‚Äô in materialist terms) ‚ÄúAnd what desires take us to it affect how we interact with it.‚Äù Sure. ‚ÄúIsn't that what Zizek means about the master signifier as the 4th moment? The subjective, orienting, driving force?‚Äù I‚Äôm not certain which work that is in but if you send it to me I‚Äôd like to read it. However, when it comes to the master signifier --- my understanding is that the truth of the drive is not the master signifier, but rather petit objet a (the unbearable gap of possibility which remains even if the master signifier is overwritten).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 04:00:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúHegel says little things about overcoming finite desires, implying desiring ideals instead. This is really a difficult task, psychoanalysis has shown. I think religions have taken it seriously forever; and Hegel knew much more about all that than anyone since.‚Äù Maybe, but I think Lacan gives us some nicer formalisms that have the possibility to make it more comprehensible (in the mathemes). ‚ÄúIt's simply the default now to be in self deception. Quite an achievement of inner work to overcome. Maybe not historically even possible. Maybe it never was and all this is naive. But it requires self knowledge, ultimately, and Reason to unwind it all.‚Äù I agree that it requires reason, I think that was my point. But the overcoming of it --- here I will be an atheist christian and say that it isn‚Äôt about ‚Äòinner‚Äô work, though that may help...

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 04:07:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    A constant self questioning; Kierkegaard and Nietzsche are v good on this. As is Freud. idk Lacan but I understand he's taken to be doing that type of analysis. Zizek understands it, to play the game. But he's also much more influenced by post structuralism and all that sophistry.‚Äù Good! People who aren‚Äôt influenced by it, have no response to it and don‚Äôt have any idea why they‚Äôre failing. They‚Äôre tribes people trying to fight off the foreign legion. ‚ÄùPhilosophy became a celebrity thing, and he is definitely into that. And making things complicated became a technique of sounding smart. Foucault admitted this to John Searle.‚Äù I agree, I‚Äôm not trying to make it complicated, but also complicated isn‚Äôt clever, and it's not what I‚Äôve been trying to do. I‚Äôve been pretty straightforward about thinking this is all about a single, really rather simple, concept (contradiction).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 04:09:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄùThat's just a formalistic understanding of Truth‚Äù That‚Äôs kind of my point --- that what you call formalism *is* desire for truth: so we have to get even more specific about the interconnection between sophistry and logic than simply relying on this spontaneous naive response. Its not *bad* as a spontaneous naive response (i.e. there are far worse) but its not anywhere near complete and it definitely isn‚Äôt up to the task of understanding Hegel.

  • andru0358Sat Feb 24 2024 04:11:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "" to make it materialist isn‚Äôt to say something like ‚Äòmy relation to the truth is the story I tell myself about it, your relation to the truth is your story about it, we all have our separate stories and they don‚Äôt have to be made consistent with each other‚Äô --- that may be true but it isn‚Äôt The Truth. "" I mean here you making truth a passive, contemplative truth. Marx's quote above, the whole thing on These on Feuerbach is that truth is a human practice. Even Ontology and Epistemology, we have to realize we are human engaged in intellectual practices, with a history, often in textual medium, etc.. That these truths only have a human significance. That's the materialist meaning of subjectivity, not arbitrary idiosyncrasies, like "story I tell myself" The rational kernal of idealism is to have our own psyche/mind in order, that their are truths in our heads; we may come to know them through communication and practical experience, but they're not *about* the outer world, they're inner. Ie logic. But still, the standard we hold them too has to be a reference to our practical existence, not mere formal rules. That's the problem w the Doctor example. The truth is about whether he actually *has cancer*, not an answer which technically avoids being incorrect. That's the difference of formal/abstract truth vs contet/concrete truth

  • andru0358Sat Feb 24 2024 04:12:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Formalism is an obstacle to truth. It's a an illusion. Desire is physiological

  • andru0358Sat Feb 24 2024 04:12:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Desire is in our bodies

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 04:28:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 I'm not completely certain which part of this statement you're responding to: but if you mean that the infinite interpreted as material is just dialectical materialism I would agree? But you seemed somewhat hostile to the idea of the infinite in the live-stream. Zizek also has the various absurdities of the Soviet Union as part of his life history (and his understanding of what Marxism has actually been), and his critique of the Trotskyist understanding of the soviet union is that even if all the usual Trotskyist points hold about it being a counter revolution due to the failure of global world revolution the *nature* of the failure is *still* not well understood by Trotskyism because Trotskyism doesn't understand its *own* relation to this counter-revolution (this fact is an attempt to reject or repress something of our own fantasy by rejecting the counter revolution as a consequence of our revolution). Its still *our* counter revolution, i.e. an always-existing inherent potential consequence of *our* project including also the anti-scientific nonsense of the soviet union necessitated due to its self-justification through scientism (i.e. the fact that bureaucrats were formally justified to be in power due to their superior understanding of the scientific needs of the proletarian revolution --- the constant need for a 'correct line' for example --- however this very scientism lead to the need for the bureacratic chaos, the purges, the paranoia, the show trials, etc. as the *form* of counter revolution --- as opposed to a fascist counter revolution which takes the form of a civil war and death squads and death camps with no need for a trial where those killed simply do not participate in the symbolic order in the way they not only *do* participate in Stalinism, but where what's more the symbolic order turns against everyone --- specifically the bureacratic paranoia is an important symptom here).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 05:12:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "I mean here you making truth a passive, contemplative truth." I don't think the contradiction is contemplative. I do think that contemplation is fairly human so when I say its something more 'alien' I'm actually saying its not contemplative insomuch as the contemplative is human. All the 'we have to realize we are human engaged in intellectual practices, with a history, often in textual medium, etc.' --- that's fine but the moment you say 'That these truths only have a human significance.' --- the word *only* is doing a lot of work, way too much work, in fact it needs to go on strike... And if we *carefully* read Thesis 1 and thesis 2 --- Marx's claim here isn't 'there is only sensuous human activity and contemplation is nonsense' --- just that you can't stop at the contemplative or rather that the sensuous and human is a *necessary* (but there is no claim of *sufficiency*) aspect of materialism (i.e. you can't prove truth by thinking it into place: and btw, even with contradiction as I've proposed it this not something I've just theoried into place, its a constant rough encounter with contradiction through what is hopefully no more than half a natural lifetime --- empirical encounter in the realms of math, logic, philosophy, politics, biology, physics, etc. --- that has lead me to this point where the end becomes the beginning in contradiction. When I give you the reason for why contradictions are 'true': that's claim is meant to be read as a dialectical union of the empirical and tautological --- not just tautological). For the truth to be a humanism --- humanism would have to be sufficient for truth (and of course then the question would be 'what's the point of theory or Marx's whole project at all, he could just write the first thesis and be done with it: practice alone will save us). And what's more if we continue to read thesis 2 if anything that isn't about humanity, that's about the alien character of the truth from humanity.

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 05:14:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "The rational kernal of idealism is to have our own psyche/mind in order, that their are truths in our heads; we may come to know them through communication and practical experience, but they're not about the outer world, they're inner.‚Äù If here you‚Äôre saying that there is no necessary relation between what is in my head and the outside world (other, perhaps, than than the obvious naive one that the thoughts in my head are somehow encoded as actual material neural networks) then this is fine. Sure. ‚ÄúIe logic.‚Äù No necessary relation also means no necessary lack of relation. But I hold contradiction as the base due to the happy coincidence of self-reflective empirical reasons and tautological beauty, as stated --- not just merely tautological beauty.

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 05:15:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúBut still, the standard we hold them too has to be a reference to our practical existence, not mere formal rules.‚Äù Sure. But you‚Äôre forgetting the formalism of formalism which is the very manner in which the practical existence gets pulled into the formal rules (I think I pointed out that the formal recognition of assumptions as mere assumptions is part of the formalism of formalism and of course the inputs to a model act as assumptive input to the model --- they aren‚Äôt justified in anyway other than that they *are* the input --- this would include the inputs of practical experience into the models of our minds --- i.e. practical experience also goes into that building up and falling down of the assumptions of a system based off what I‚Äôve said?).

  • firedog235Sat Feb 24 2024 05:16:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 ‚ÄúThat's the problem w the Doctor example. The truth is about whether he actually has cancer, not an answer which technically avoids being incorrect.‚Äù I.e. its a formalism without formalism: the formalism that protects against this non-answer is the formalism that tautologies are not results, a tautology doesn‚Äôt pay the bills. I.e. the very claim that formalism is bad *is* a formalism (i.e. is the start, but not the end, of the formalism of formalism). ‚ÄúDesire is in our bodies‚Äù Desire gets projected into our bodies in the form of the symptom, but desire is not *just* in our bodies. But yeah, the truth of the desire is the symptom in our bodies.

  • minimaltomSat Feb 24 2024 15:40:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think I‚Äôve just had a minor breakthrough with being-for-self. ‚ÄúSomething‚Äù is determined by its ‚Äúother‚Äù which is external to it. It is being-for-other. being-for-self is is also determined by its other but that other is now internal to itself as it‚Äôs own moment.

Just because some of them are disgruntled about losing doesn‚Äôt mean the project of Marxism wasn‚Äôt worth the risk, or still is. I think critiquing Marxism in the abstract is just silly.

If Marx's Poverty of Philosophy overcomes the objections from Zizek and Pinkard tell us how. Judging them as silly and insisting they have been dispatched is to throw truth aside and replace truth with your own will.

  • minimaltomSat Feb 24 2024 16:23:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Being-for-itself is also ‚Äúabsolute‚Äù determination. one definition of absolute is something which depends on nothing else as it‚Äôs ground, it‚Äôs not dependent on something else for its definition. ‚ÄúSomething‚Äùis affected and determined by the ‚Äúother‚Äù through its ‚Äúconstitution‚Äù. Being-for-self is self sufficient and independently grounded, impervious to change by an other external to it.

It‚Äôs my own take, I could be wrong but I think it‚Äôs right

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 16:27:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 If someone makes the argument that Trotskyists don't understand the whole and then point out what they don't see, makes an argument that Trotskyists don't see something and thereby don't see the whole, countering that they do see the whole without addressing the argument offered to the contrary is, again, merely a willful insistence. The truth is something we work out through argumentation and reason and not through insistence.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 16:28:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 I don't know what you mean when you say we are done with abstractions as political tools. Seems to me that we rely upon abstractions all the time. We can no more do without abstractions than we can do without sensuous particulars.

  • dve.h_37844Sat Feb 24 2024 16:51:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 That doesn‚Äôt make *sense* a tool though. The tool is Marxism, which begins with materialism. Like when you interviewed Cutrone on philosophy and he said something like ‚Äúwhen you show up to the scene of a crime, you first have to determine if a crime has been committed‚Äù. What I don‚Äôt want to do is treat materialism as a philosophy. Dialectics, as I understand it, is actually a physical process of nature. We need only look to Engels, or Darwin for proof of this.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 16:57:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 Whether or not you want to treat materialism as a philosophy doesn't determine whether or not materialism is an ontological philosophical position. When you say you don't want to treat it as a philosophy you are saying that you don't want to question your assumptions but accept what amounts to a received opinion as fact. You say, "beyond this point I refuse to think." Treating reason as a tool requires that you have put aside trying to discover things and want to work upon a problem in a prescribed way. If I pick up a screwdriver and want to use it as a tool I will have to find screws. But, what if what I'm working on doesn't have screws?

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 17:00:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 You say we only need to look to Engels or Darwin for proof of this, but that's profoundly authoritarian. That's saying, "Darwin and Engels already told us what to think." If Engels or Darwin demonstrated that dialectics is a physical process then we should be able to understand their arguments and their arguments should be able to hold up to our scrutiny.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 17:01:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Reading Hegel our task is two fold: First, understand what he said and his arguments. Second, scrutinize what he said and see if we find it convincing. Do Hegel's arguments hold up? What we aren't doing is figuring out what the doxa is, the simple slogan that we can memorize and repeat.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 17:07:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 I hope this is true.

  • dve.h_37844Sat Feb 24 2024 17:08:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 It‚Äôs the dictatorship of the proletariat. I‚Äôm happy to discuss Hegel in a more philosophical way, but where Marx is concerned that is hardly the point. We haven‚Äôt seen science disprove what Engels asserted in the Dialectics of Nature. It still holds. So, I‚Äôm not sure where to go from here?

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 17:09:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 17:11:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 Here's what you do first, stop merely asserting what you think has been established and try, in your own words, to repeat the arguments you learned. How did Engels demonstrate that dialectics are in nature (for instance in a stone) and then tell us how this refutes Hegel's idealism (if you think it does.) None of what I've said in this morning has anything to do with Darwin, Marx, Hegel or Engels. What I've been responding to is merely your refusal to engage beyond the level of assertion and insistence.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 17:16:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I mean materialism is a philosophy. Of course it is. It just seems to be the one that's operative in the world. Fred Hampton wrote about it in terms of Marxism. You have to claim things exist, I exist, I can do things, they seem to affect other things. This isn't a dream or delusion, etc.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 17:16:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 17:18:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It's a philosophical claim, but seems to be one that carries evidence. And if you discard this claim, action in the world itself becomes a slideshow of meaningless, disconnected, images and perceptions with no relation between them. And there's no motive to do anything, ever, much less anything notable. Aristotle in Nichomachean ethics seems to be arguing with proto-Buddhism when he states that those who don't desire anything, or who champion the death of desires, are removing the motivation to all greatness and all things terrible as well.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 17:18:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He's not arguing along an axis of class conflict or material change like Marxists would understand, but at a basic level, he's saying, well no motivation, no *achievement*.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 17:19:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • dve.h_37844Sat Feb 24 2024 17:33:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 I‚Äôm not sure what you want me to do here? I just don‚Äôt agree with the assertion from Thomas that Marx didn‚Äôt understand Hegel. We all know what Zizek said. I think it‚Äôs an absurd thing to say. Why? Well why not grant Marx an in depth understanding of Hegel since he was German and a member of the young Hegelians. I just don‚Äôt care to get into a 30 paragraph dialogue about it. Sorry to disappoint.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 17:36:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What was the reason Thomas gave for his claim that Marx didn't understand Hegel? In general, the rule of thumb should be to read charitably. That is, do not interpret Hegel or Marx as if they are stupid people who say stupid things, but work to see if you can read them so that they are smart and make sense. If, after a charitable reading, you find a mistake then point out the mistake. The question is not whether Marx understood Hegel but rather do we understand Marx's understanding of Hegel. The question is not whether Hegel was overturned by Marx, but do we understand Hegel well enough to know what that would mean if true.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 17:38:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @dve.h_37844#0 If you are not interested in deepening your understanding on a topic that is being discussed recognize that attempting to merely assert your opinion and shut down the conversation is not a great way to proceed. You don't have to discuss anything you don't want to discuss.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 17:40:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Also, another good rule of thumb is when someone has refuted something you've claimed don't just repeat your argument again, even if you don't quite accept their refutation. Instead take the time to think about it and then, if you feel they have refuted what you've said, try to take that in. If they haven't then offer a counter that takes their coutner claim into account.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 17:48:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 Well, essentially the whole world becomes a sort of sophistry. I can call you a woke Robin DiAngelo Cultural Marxist because someone credibly claimed that in the past, and some number of people agreed with it. Therefore you've been effectively linked, you can argue based on facts or history, or descriptions of objects in the world, or the past, but I can reply that the object itself has changed and now you are doomed to be renamed at will. So my mistruth has become reality because I can claim the underlying substance of the words themselves have changed.

    I could do a political example too. In 100 BC I could say "I am for the Republic" and mean - the senate, the Popular assembly, elections. And say the same sentence in 10 AD and mean "I am for Augustus," but the meaning of the phrase, "I am for the Republic" can still be logically linked to the former, not the latter, and discarding the latter. But a dialectician, like yourself, would argue that the second, somewhat propagandistic and false, definition, is acutally real now due to changes in the terms of the utterance itself, and now it is impossible to lie. It is impoossible both to be for the republic, and against it, and no amount of pointing to people who meant one thing or another actually matters anymore. No facts matter.   • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 17:58:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The meaning of words change over time. It happens. Also, a word will mean one thing in one context and another in another context. In fact, sophists often use confusion about that, treating words as if they only have one meaning, in order to make their specious arguments.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 17:59:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'll give you an example, If you will answer my questions, said Dionysodorus, I will soon extract the same admissions from you, Ctesippus. You say that you have a dog. Yes, a villain of a one, said Ctesippus. And he has puppies? Yes, and they are very like himself. And the dog is the father of them? Yes, he said, I certainly saw him and the mother of the puppies come together. And is he not yours? To be sure he is. Then he is a father, and he is yours; ergo, he is your father, and the puppies are your brothers. Let me ask you one little question more, said Dionysodorus, quickly interposing, in order that Ctesippus might not get in his word: You beat this dog? Ctesippus said, laughing, Indeed I do; and I only wish that I could beat you instead of him. Then you beat your father, he said.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 17:59:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 Has the irony ever struck you, that I am fluent in multiple languages and translate them, but of all the people I listen to, I place the **LEAST** stock in the linguistic constructivist models?

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 18:00:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 18:01:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think through the polyphany of human languages, each culture attempts to construct a description about our shared, material world. Our style of communication, verbal and written, are approximations of this external reality, but that dosen't mean there aren't particular things to describe and delimit.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 18:01:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What do you think about my example of sophistry and how recognizing that a word changes meaning in different contexts is the solution to the absurdity?

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 18:02:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Even a word like "blue" I could say to you, and you might imagine light blue,and me, dark blue, it is an apporximation, but both of us are aware of blue. In very ancient times, in both seemingly Ancient Greek and classical Chinese, there was no "blue" there was "qing" (greenish blue, etc) and "wine dark sea" but no true word for blue. Did human brains perceive blue? of course they did, but they did not verbally quantify it.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 18:02:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    What do you think of the example I gave?

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 18:03:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 18:03:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    One thing then I go back - this process, in history, is often explicit: Herodotus invents words and says so, Aristotle is even more funny about it, he will say "the intermediate term between (two extremes) for which no word exists." I find this so impressive. Pure attempt at material description without even bothering too much about the verbal formula. It's quite a beautiful thing in a way.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 18:04:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 18:13:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So just the word "GRASS" has no truth value. Nature may be said to natively have: mud, tree, grass, water, sound, wind. But to narrate these into a statement "the wind was blowing in the trees" at least in Aristotle's experience, was a thing only another person could say, in language, gramatically, with some sort of action.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 18:13:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

I think that when leftists say they're queer they aren't calling themselves a bad name. You think they are. That isn't about the dictionary it's about the attitudes and social reality that actually exists on the left.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 18:26:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 We're kinda getting into aristophanes territory. I think this is maybe the bottom line, the truthful description of one thing will only have so many avenues to it's justification in terms of multiple arguments or really, explanations, but in terms of non-facts, untrue arguments, unreal assertions - these are actually infinite.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 18:26:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So even as you hold the chocolate in your hand, the amount of it is actually hugely increasing and hugely decreasing at all times.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 18:26:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    If we look at it PURELY through verbal conceptions.

  • angelus888Sat Feb 24 2024 18:26:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Only a material test stops this endless insane vertigo.

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 18:27:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Sat Feb 24 2024 22:09:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 I am truly needing to reflect on the point about solipsism and the need of an other to recognize the existential isolation of our self. In family therapy theory, the theory of differentiation (by Murray Bowen) says that we only have a sense of Self insofar as we are able to become close to another. We only realize the particularities of who we are by knowing another person and realizing ourself, how we think and feel, as particular. But that moment alone only shows us who we are as who we are *not*. In a sense it shows us, if we let it, the contingenctness of who we are; and in that, we can ask ourselves if want to or *ought to* stay this way or not: we can ask *how to be,* or *what to become*; we experience freedom through the self-awareness which came from knowing another as different, and thereby seeing the possibility of difference, where we assumed the necessity of our being. We experience oneness as external, and faced with multiplicity of Being in possibility, back to indeterminacy. But a relative indeterminacy, a limit. In being limited, we recognize our commonality. The other person, presumably, also experienced their radical difference in the interaction and was confronted with their contingency, non-universality. It's the non-universality then, we have in common, and is universal. A negative Universal, we are all not The One. We join in the Oneness by recognizing our mutual not-One-ness. The impossibility of knowing solipsism except through knowing other persons, which falsifies these hypothesis of solipsism; we experience other persons as simply different. To question their "reality" as persons implies also a question about our reality: what is it about myself that I am claiming these other persons to not have? What is it about me that is "Real"?? I think it is precisely the capacity to recognize our relative non-Reality, our finitude, that makes us self-aware, being-for-self, free.

  • andru0358Sat Feb 24 2024 22:10:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So I object to immortality. Only through contemplating our morality, our immanent death, finitude do we realize our own Ought

  • douglainSat Feb 24 2024 22:11:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I object to immortality on principle, but if somebody offered me a pill so I'd be as healthy as I was when I was 20 and could remain that way forever I'd take the pill.

    @andru0358#0 "'Anyone who does not partake of society is either an animal or a god" Aristotle

  • minimaltomSat Feb 24 2024 23:00:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 This is the passage from a section in the book called 'Seperation from the analyst' that I got it from "I am always a bit puzzled when I hear talk of analysands ending their analysis in a peaceful and friendly manner, and then hear of them befriending their analysts afterward‚Äîas if the choice of their former analyst as a friend were an indifferent choice, as if there were not enough other people in the world to befriend. Friendship is not, in and of itself, out of the question, assuming one has surpassed the stage of blaming the Other for one's problems or one's fate.* But it suggests that a certain demand toward the Other‚Äîa demand for recognition and approval, in short, for love‚Äîmay well remain unresolved Peaceful "termination" hardly seems consonant with the reversal of position regarding the onerous renunciation that is required to go beyond castration."

  • minimaltomSun Feb 25 2024 18:12:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The "sadness of the finite" paragraph is ¬ß250 in a) the immediacy of finitude. Its quite a dense one actually and I'm not sure it was saying what I claimed actually.

  • minimaltomSun Feb 25 2024 18:14:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think I said it was qualitative being brought to its end but it was actually "qualitative negation pushed to its extreme"

  • douglainSun Feb 25 2024 18:20:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The thought of the finitude of things brings this sadness with it because it is qualitative negation pushed to its extreme, and in the singleness of such determination there is no longer left to things an affirmative being distinct from their destiny to perish. Because of this qualitative singleness of the negation, which has gone back to the abstract opposition of nothing and ceasing-to-be as opposed to being, finitude is the most stubborn category of the understanding; negation in general, constitution and limit, reconcile themselves with their other, with determinate being; and even nothing, taken abstractly as such, is given up as an abstraction; but finitude is the negation as fixed in itself, and it therefore stands in abrupt contrast to its affirmative. The finite, it is true, lest itself be brought into flux, it is itself this, to be determined or destined to its end, but only to its end ‚Äî or rather, it is the refusal to let itself be brought affirmatively to its affirmative, to the infinite, and to let itself be united with it; it is therefore posited as inseparable from its nothing, and is thereby cut off from all reconciliation with its other, the affirmative. The determination or destiny of finite things takes them no further than their end. The understanding persists in this sadness of finitude by making non-being the determination of things and at the same time making it imperishable and absolute. Their transitoriness could only pass away or perish in their other, in the affirmative; their finitude would then be parted from them; but it is their unalterable quality, that is, their quality which does not pass over into its other, that is, into its affirmative; it is thus eternal

  • douglainSun Feb 25 2024 18:23:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think that this line--The finite...is itself this, to be determined or destined to its end, but only to its end--or rather, it is the refusal to let itself be brought affirmatively to its affirmative, to the infinite, and to let itself be united with it; it is therefore posited and as inseprerable from its nothing--is roughly the same thing as saying that qualitative being is brought to its end.

  • minimaltomSun Feb 25 2024 18:27:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 I think its also saying that if it wanted to the finite could join with its affirmative, the infinite but it stubbornly refuses to so as to maintain itself as what it is rather than just be an amorphous indeteminate thing??

  • douglainSun Feb 25 2024 18:29:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I remember that when I was struggling with religion in my 20s, trying to figure out if I believed in God, I decided that the problem of death wouldn't really be resolved by what was promised by certain Christian faiths. The promise was that after death I would be reunited with God or the Godhead. What I realized was that my own self would clearly be absorbed and destroyed by such a thing. So death either meant becoming nothing or becoming everything and, from my point of view, there wasn't much of a difference.

  • minimaltomSun Feb 25 2024 18:31:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 yeah this is what i hate about that reassuring saying that we decompose when we die and become soil and so on, so we carry on in a way in the circle of life. Yeah but thats just not you!

  • minimaltomSun Feb 25 2024 18:31:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    youre still gone!

  • andru0358Sun Feb 25 2024 18:31:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I think the ambiguity is connected to something quite complicated in Doctrine of Essence, where essence is taken to be distinct from being or immediacy; Immediacy becomes appearance, shine, illusory being, I think. But he also shows it's not really seperable from being, I think. Thats where it gets complicated; Even in something, which Quality is not yet, there is an in-itself which is only implicit, not immediately known. So that being-in-itself becomes an abstract, mediated by its determinateness, it's not-other. But that's not what it is in-itself. Immediacy and Being become separate. But the whole development of Something and Other is still based on the ground of the unity of being and nothing, as the whole book is, even Essence, etc..

  • minimaltomSun Feb 25 2024 18:37:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • andru0358Sun Feb 25 2024 18:54:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    There does seem something avoiding our real existential isolation and immanent mortality in this mind if ego-death, unity with everything and everyone. I think that unity has truth equally as our fragile unique individuality born of our freedom.

  • angelus888Sun Feb 25 2024 18:54:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 We are at a point in the dominance-to-collapse curve of postmodernism that we 1) read everything through the lens of postmodernism but 2) postmodernism is already a fatally ill with the pathologies arising from it's own contradictions that will eventually negate it. Example: I recently started reading R.J.B. Bosworth's *Mussolini's Italy: Life Under the Fascist Dictatorship, 1915-1945* (2004? 2007?). In the introduction I was immediately struck by the ideological frame of this huge book being an healthier, more productive, more interesting, and more vibrant school of postmodernism that we have discarded. Here's a quote, from literally the start of the preface: ‚ÄúThe recovery of the voices lost within the totalizing narratives of modernization and nationalization is one of the most challenging tasks facing historians today, but before we can even begin to identify and listen to these voices, we must first understand the mechanisms by which they have been (and continue to be) silenced.‚Äù So this is healthier postmodernism - examining the information lost through empashsis on grand narrative structures like Italian Fasicsm, that could end up blotting out the granularity of the thing in real life. This is not the postmodernism of today which essentially has settled for equating all utterances as equal from an evidentiary perspective, where claims can't really even be made about things, where nothing can be said to be better or worse than anything else, where nothing causes anything, etc., history is reduced to a child's mobile of entertaining textures, sights, sounds, and tinklings. My fear is that this perspective has essentially penetrated all dominions of human knowledge and practice, from philosophy to history to business to Human Resources planning to, of course, politics. EDIT: So that's why I don't think either of us WANT to be postmodern sophists, per se, but we are trapped in the gravity of this thing that is quite omnipresent.

    @andru0358#0 I was just targeting he and our discussion very narrowly. I know I was reading Aristotle that way, Plato that way, but I have to work hard to throw away that frame and say Plato **IS** making a claim or Cicero **IS** attempting to assert something here. Not allow the inner Lyotard in my brain to win. EDIT: I can't determine to what extent it's postmodern Hegel here as I'm not versed enough to say.

  • angelus888Sun Feb 25 2024 21:01:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But I guess the thing also to note is that postmodernism was useful at some point, as that quote shows. But it experienced decay, now it's just sophistry, equating nothings, etc.

  • angelus888Sun Feb 25 2024 21:02:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I'm more exploring a position that us as readers at this time are investing an entire assumed postmodern outlook on these texts that do not exist within them. They are seeing their claims-making in a way that is nearly alien to us, and we must be able to sieze our framework, shatter it, and try to figure out what they are saying on their own terms.

  • angelus888Sun Feb 25 2024 21:04:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'm not sure I have defined this observation and watched the move in time of that postmodernist window well enough - which is explicit in the historical text I just mentioned - to be able to formulate a hypothesis on approaching this issue.

  • andru0358Sun Feb 25 2024 21:07:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I listened to a panel w Spivak from the 80s and she was basically saying that same thing: not letting grand narratives exclude marginal truths or whatever. I just don't understand why not do that dialectically to fold it into the "grand narrative"?

  • angelus888Sun Feb 25 2024 21:12:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 If I were to make a (somewhat parodic, and morbid) Postmodernist claim it would be something like: "Actually reading postmodernism into Hegel is good because it's more appopsite to our times and there is no truth contained within any text, it is always a linguistic performance that can be re-interpreted at any time, with all interpretations being equally valid."

  • andru0358Sun Feb 25 2024 21:18:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Right. I think that's the claim in question: is there truth within the text? What does truth mean in this sense? Thankfully, that's what Hegels book is about and he develops all his terms immanently, so it's well suited to reading on its own terms

  • angelus888Sun Feb 25 2024 21:20:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think there are a range of interpretations that come close to whatever is in the original of a non-random text, which are intended. Since a person speaking, at any point, must have some idea in their head as to what they are speaking about. That said, misreadings can also be very valuable and interesting, and provide room for creativity where a set of known elements is broken, and new elements are invented or related.

  • angelus888Sun Feb 25 2024 21:22:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But from a didactic perspective yes, you'd want an accurate view, but what I am saying is this is challeneged by some very deep preconcepts in the reader. It's like trying to read classical lit without Christianity leering at you, it's very hard, and even harder to reconstruct the pagan audience of these things in your brain, which was the major audience.

I do think Dasein is kind of the foundation for existense tho. Existence in general as apposed to something that exists.

  • andru0358Mon Feb 26 2024 18:06:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Determinate Being is the sublated unity of Pure being and nothing; Is-ness and not -ness. Quality is this determinate-ness; it's not yet 'a being' but it is, it exists, only immediate; I think of it like; a baby coming out of empty undifferentiated mind, would notice a thing first by noticing the quality of the thing. If they first saw a red ball, they'd see redness and ballness before they saw it as a ball. It's immediate in that sense, of not even yet a thing but the aspects which would make a thing a thing

  • minimaltomMon Feb 26 2024 19:10:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)
