  • andru0358Tue Feb 27 2024 00:00:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Yea Form is one of those words that's so flexible and general it's hard define.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 29 2024 17:15:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Re Form: I think it's like shape except for the spacial aspect of shape. It's also often thought in contrast to content. Form, in that, is akin to appearance (content akin to essence). Like Quality as such is a form, but particular qualities have content; but like, red ball is more a ball than it is red; it's a ball in a red *form*. But also, concepts are 'forms' in a way; the ancient Greek word for form is 'Eidos', and 'idea' was the feminine form of the word. Ironically it also means essence. Platonic Forms are essences of ideas that are the most real, to him. Aristotle juxtaposed form with matter, in saying everything is a mixture of both. For example, body and soul, or brain and mind, are supposed to be examples. A knife is made of metal, but what make it a knife is having a blade and handle, the form the metal is shaped into; not just the shape, but also the implicit purpose of cutting, etc. Here they're very contentful. The form is the interesting part. Hegel seems to be distinguishing form and ideality; ideality seems to be closer to Plato's and Aristotle's ideas of form. Hence, form and content almost reverses form and matter in which is interesting. For example a "something" is more a form without content. It's just like the idea of something. Is the idea of a something a something? The rational kernal of formalism, imo. Is that we cannot think without forms; Heidegger tries to do so, I'm still trying to to sort through it. Poetry does it. But poetry is the opposite of rigour; it's trying to do something entirely different. Poets are trying to say more than they intend. Philosophy needs forms of thought which are clear, so that we know exactly what we are saying. Hegel's emphasis on immanent development is precisely this; that if a terms is brought from outside, it becomes one-sided, and smuggles in assumptions unexamined; but his critique of understanding, to me, is also a critique of over reliance on forms which I have been calling formalism.

  • andru0358Thu Feb 29 2024 17:16:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I did look up the German and Hegel uses the specific word, even with a capital F. He definitely means it there in some philosophically significant way which we may not have access to. But that's why I tried to give my philosophical understanding of it.

  • old_doeThu Feb 29 2024 17:56:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 You mean "die Form"? I dont speak German but Im pretty sure it is just capitalized there naturally

  • minimaltomThu Feb 29 2024 23:42:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

I think he also talked a bit in the intro/prefaces about the unity of form and content in the same way he might talk about the unity of subject and object, about the unity of opposites. I was wondering if we might have an example of that here in form of limit which can‚Äôt be thought of apart from what it‚Äôs limiting.

  • andru0358Sat Mar 02 2024 02:26:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I'm sad chat has died down. Was I too argumentative or is the Being-for-itself chapter too Idealist? A friend mentioned to me the introduction to Philosophy of Right is about self-determination, freedom. So I stared checking it out to see if it's connected. He says animals are not free because they cannot "place before it's mind what it desires" So freedom requires this reflection of desire. It's the ability of thought to negate the desire. He then goes into Negative Freedom as one-sided, using the familiar example of "Hindus" in meditation. He again calls this "pure intuition", "abstraction from all definite character". Sounds a lot like Being. <@805731746384445460> but he adds that "this indefiniteness [Being?] is itself only a negation."

  • minimaltomSat Mar 02 2024 11:56:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • nameiwillforgetTue Mar 05 2024 15:51:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 "he rational kernal of formalism, imo. Is that we cannot think without forms; Heidegger tries to do so, I'm still trying to to sort through it. Poetry does it. But poetry is the opposite of rigour; it's trying to do something entirely different. Poets are trying to say more than they intend." Where do you get that idea from? I'd say it is precisely what distinguishes poetry from prose that it treats form as a structural factor, not just an ornamental one.

  • firedog235Tue Mar 05 2024 16:18:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 lol, you and me both

  • firedog235Tue Mar 05 2024 16:20:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Being-for-self is infinity which has collapsed into simple being? I'm not sure why you want me to say it

  • firedog235Tue Mar 05 2024 16:41:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 Its not too argumentative in the sense that we didn't need to argue, but arguing takes something out of me and I have a 9 to 5 these days. I'm not certain about this line on being being only a negation (i.e. I'm not certain if this sentence is a bridging sentence or a defining sentence, one that bridges being into something like its being for other, or if he's saying 'well being is really nothing' here: either way I still think that what gives being this feeling of emptiness is the way that it is associated with pure identity and formality and that what is negative within it is 'truth' --- i.e. it is 'true' but only tautologically true). My way of resolving all this is simply to notice that 'not' can produce truth because it can 'not' itself ('not not') while with being if you want to get back to 'not' you have to play tricks (specifically, you have to get someone to buy that the thing which everything has in common is nothing, which a metaphysical idealist is unlikely to just buy: once again, to me this is why Hegel spends so much time talking about being in the first chapter's remarks and justifying his starting there: because its not the appropriate place to start really and I think it is this 'starting' which is the problem for Hegel's idealism, he starts with tautology and then has to kind of bootstrap himself out of it).

  • firedog235Tue Mar 05 2024 16:51:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 The other thing is that on fomalism vs informalism: I think that my problem is that when people say that something is 'just a formalism' they think what is being demanded is 'informalism' as something before form. Whereas what I'm demanding is dialectics which is after form in the sense that its the infinite of form (form turned back into and against itself, or form taken as the one becoming the many). I also have this other strange thought when considering Hegel: in Engels (and maybe Marx) the difference between materialism and idealism is often given as being on of practicality vs. theory and how theory has to flow from practice... but it seems that Hegel doesn't exactly disagree with this in the following sense: he starts with the most practical categories to hand (not the most 'correct' I think, but the most practical) --- what is and what isn't --- and then develops off into the more theoretical realms (his theory follows his more basic practice). So I don't think this base and superstructure argument is actually the real disagreement between Marx-Engels and Hegel (or that its the *real* division between idealism and materialism). I know that <@476561351167311872> was talking about how there is some kind of universality in being non-universal. I would relate this to the division between the masculine (there is a universal, but there is an exception) and the feminine (there is no universal, no exceptions) in Lacan. Both are contradictions but they are subtly different ways of handling the contradiction (masculine is a contradiction because it claims a universal but then wishes to except it, feminine is a contradiction because the fact that there is no exception to the statement that there is no universal means the statment that there is no universal is itself a universal).

  • angelus888Tue Mar 05 2024 16:54:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 Eh I think immortality's cool. I'm not afraid of that one so much.

  • firedog235Tue Mar 05 2024 21:20:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 This is exactly it I think --- there are times when hegel is talking about the becoming of a particular thing and times when he's like 'okay lets discuss how this thing is static'.

  • andru0358Tue Mar 05 2024 21:28:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Oh i see what you are saying. that's very interesting. That poetry takes form seriously and unites it with the content. I meant, not so much the poetic form, but the use of imagery in poetry. So like, epic poems, which use iambic pentameter obviously take form seriously. But most contemporary poetry does not use a standard form, but plays with it, and stretches it, in that sense uses it in artistic unity of the whole. but the artistic whole, is for poetry, rather outside the forms; its not the literal meaning, the structure, the rhymes. To me, poetry is the epitome of non-literalism (in words). A lot of modern poetry is conveying imagery, and only in the image, with the tone and feel of the language, does the real content of the poem come through. That's what I mean by poetry going beyond form. It's not just prose written with an intentional structure asform; that form is also only gesturing beyond itself

  • minimaltomWed Mar 06 2024 21:48:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I found the last remark from Infinity to be very helpful in understanding Ideality which is essential to Being-for-itself. Ideality has felt like a key concept in understanding the conceptual turns of the whole chapter. He defines Being-for-itself as sublating otherness; he gives the example of consciousness because we can represent external objects, or even the idea of an external world, in our mind. So such the ideation is a way we sublate our other in ourselves.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 08 2024 13:51:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think you're right being-in-itself is how something exists in isolation, as opposed to existing in relation to an other (being-for-other) but everything has to be determined negatively, how do you think something can be determined when it is on its own? It is determined by the negation in itself, so I think I'm right that something is determined internally. It is also the negation of negation: In Quality you have Reality which is then negated and something is the negation of that negation, whereby being is reaffirmed again. I'm still trying to work out what the significance of Negation of Negation is though, not something I grasp totally.

  • andru0358Fri Mar 08 2024 13:56:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • firedog235Sat Mar 09 2024 09:32:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 The significance of negation of negation is two fold --- one the thing double negated isn't the original thing (this is the old cliche of dialectics that most sects will teach if they concern themselves with this question at all) second that a thing negates *itself* so we're back to negation of negation, quality of quality, something of something, etc. --- i.e. you have apply the concept to itself to finally see how it breaks out of itself.

  • firedog235Sat Mar 09 2024 09:32:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (you have to remember that every one of these concepts is a negation of some kind once you're above 'negation' (i.e. once you're at or above 'something').

  • firedog235Sat Mar 09 2024 09:33:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But I'm not certain where you guys are reading this specific negation of negation I'm not following closely

  • firedog235Sat Mar 09 2024 09:34:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    (and really they are all negative above 'nothing' but tbh I think nothing is the base of this whole structure and sublation --- negation of negation --- is the 2-level analytic move par excellence of the dialectical process that hegel is describing).

  • minimaltomSat Mar 09 2024 11:29:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I‚Äôm referring to something, the original negation of negation, being that it literally negates the concept of negation which previously negated reality.

  • minimaltomSat Mar 09 2024 11:37:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôm trying to figure out at the moment if negativity(neg of neg) is the same as ‚Äúchange‚Äù which is the endless othering of the other that happens in something and other. I thought they were before because their structure seems so similar to me but I‚Äôm not sure now. There‚Äôs at least 3 things going on in something. 1. Change and 2. negativity which both determine how something has selfhood in isolation and 3. simple negation against the other which lead to its being limited. I assumed the first 2 were totally related but now I‚Äôm not sure.

  • minimaltomSat Mar 09 2024 14:29:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Just read mctaggarts commentary on being-for-self, all three pages of it! üòÑ he basically goes through each saying this is invalid, this is unnecessary, this next part is irrelevant etc etc üòÑ

  • minimaltomSat Mar 09 2024 14:49:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    To sum it up: being-for-self is being but now determined completely internally, it‚Äôs determining limit is within itself now so it‚Äôs self sufficient, requires nothing apart from itself for its definition. being-for-self is ‚Äúone‚Äù it is for-one since it is not for-other (other relatedness which has been sublated). One implies many of the same, the one and many repulse and attract each other like particles in physics so that they are ‚Äúequipoised‚Äù and one doesn‚Äôt get entangled with the other or reconstitute the other in any way, thus we arrive at a multiplicity of self-contained alike things and this is quantity.

  • minimaltomSat Mar 09 2024 14:57:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think there is a lot more to it than this but its a fairly good summarisation

  • andru0358Mon Mar 11 2024 01:03:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Thank you!!!

  • firedog235.Mon Mar 11 2024 17:34:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think if I did my own logic of science it would start: 'Nothing --- total lack of self identity --- contradiction. Thus the answer to any question about it must be 'No.' While easy inmmediate contradictions pose themselves, such as the question "is the nothing that to which every question concerning it must be 'No'?", these questions are no problem for the nothing from its own perspective as, being a contradiction, it easily grounds any such further contradiction. However, while the nothing itself easily presents us with contradiction, there is something beyond the nothing implicit in its concept. 'No,' a necessary consequence of nothing is not burdened with the same necessity to respond 'no' to every question concerning its nature. This mere falsity --- less than nothing --- allows for alternative responses: in fact any possible response. To the question "Is 'no' a word?", the answer may be yes while to the question "is no true for all questions concerning our existing concepts" the answer may still be 'no.' Thus we have introduced the further concept of tautology: the answers to all questions concerning 'no' are 'yes or no'.

  • firedog235.Mon Mar 11 2024 17:34:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This tautology, however, is being itself which assigns a truth to every existing object: that is, both to 'no' a falsity which is less than nothing, and to 'yes or no' i.e. tautology. This generates 'yes' alone and it is here that we might fail by simply falling back into tautology or alternatively 'no': noticing that yes applied to any previous concept simply returns that concept: oscillating in its answers depending upon its other. When we say 'yes, the answer is no' we mean that the answer is no whereas when we say 'yes the answer is yes' we mean it remains yes. In this way 'yes' or 'truth' acts as a becoming... except: when we apply this yes-identity as an affirmation of contradiction-nothing something interesting happens. Rather than returning back to us the contradiction which always returns 'no' to every question we instead get back a contradiction which always returns 'yes'. This is opposed also to tautology, which always returns yes by way of a pivot: tautology follows the formula 'yes, it either is or isn't' -- 'however this new contradiction responds merely 'yes' or to make it clearer 'yes, it both is and is not.' It is this *positive* contradiction which is named by hegel 'determinate being.' The being in which each positive determination or concept must be equally burdened by distinction from another which it is *not*. In this way the ground is laid anew for a reconsideration of four (but really five) logical concepts.

  • firedog235.Mon Mar 11 2024 17:49:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Otherwise, there isn't really a justification for the move from becoming to determinate being: at least not in the text --- if I remember correctly hegel just asserts it as a new jumping off point and while I observed that there does seem to be a distinction between the two (outer contradiction in becoming --- the yes needs the preexisting no to oscillate between itself and not itself, inner contradiction in determinate being) --- but the need for this move is not obvious in that section I think and I was doing a lot of lifting to draw out this distinction for <@589918821729566721> (who seemed to notice the distinction but didn't know what it was exactly).

  • firedog235.Mon Mar 11 2024 17:55:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But it does play nicely into a new thought I've had about cynicism: which is in the mode of truth as pure truth (becoming, the 'yes'). That the reason cynicism follows the formula 'i know very well but I know' is that its acting as if the nuerotic obsessive rule (I must know, yes or no) continues to operate as a protection against falsehood even as it takes steps that go against the obsessive tautology: specifically because cynicism affirms everything in its truth, it risks also affirming a negative contradiction in its truth and thus generating a positive contradiction.

  • firedog235.Mon Mar 11 2024 18:05:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So while the obsessive maintains a separation of concerns between true and false (is rejecting contradiction) through their constant updating of action according to knowledge (new knowledge causes them to radically adjust behavior to maintain the distinction between yes or no so that the tautology always remains true) the cynic behaves *as if* their new knowledge will lead to this outcome *automatically* even though it doesn't. Thus 'they know very well but they know' --- they know what they're doing is perverse but because they know they think that things should automatically change to protect them *because* that's what happens in the case of the (tautological) nuerotic obsessive. But they forget, or rather merely perversely 'know' that this happened for the obsessive because the obsessive is moving specifically to constantly maintain the tautological stance even while the cynic is merely oscillating between positive and negative haphazardly without being careful to *not* oscillate into a contradiction: something an obsessive is horrified by. Thank God (nothing) there is a position beyond cynicism and nuerotic obsession.

  • firedog235.Mon Mar 11 2024 18:05:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 <@386755556817240065> ^

  • angelus888Tue Mar 12 2024 13:41:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 This conversation between you and I, whether the chocolate ration is increasing or decreasing in 1984, whether you can get away with redefining all homosexuality as "queer" then making us a minority in our own movement to spicy hets, and then as a result if I can then also redefine you as a "woke cultural DEI marxist" and do the exact same operation to you, has been incredibly, incredibly intellectually fruitful to me. I've had multiple inspirations from it. I think in short it shows the trouble that dialecticians have with the truth, the tendency to invert truth and lie, and to slide into situations where professions, people, things - end up doing the opposite of what their (Platonic) form would suggest they do. We get doctors who kill, as in Nazi germany, firemen who set fires - as in Ray Bradbury's *Fahrenheit 451*, agricultural scientists who create starvation (Trofim Lysenko), and now "LGB"TQ+ orgs who are more aggressively chemically and surgically converting LGB youngsters than any Christian group has, ever. I also seeming now see arguments for the vitiation // elimination of both "informed consent" and "do no harm" in medicine. Medicine against medicine, in the name of (Hegelian concepts of? ethics?), perhaps.

  • angelus888Tue Mar 12 2024 13:43:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I'd also say it caused me to think about "truth" from a dialectical perspective and that was a whole other inspiration it gave me. If we think about Chocolate as points on a graph (0 grams - or unknown), then 100 grams, then 75 grams, then 40 grams - we can determine 75 was decreased to 40. The statement "The chocolate ration was decreased" is true materially, and also not deceptive, and also temporally most relevant - which may be why it is not deceptive. Changing the frame, we can say 0 was INCREASED to 40 - but this is deception. There is an extra element here - telling something that may be factually true, but which is deceptive (maybe because it's untrue IN TIME) and omits or deletes data that shows its deception - mainly that there was an even higher point (100g) that we are failing to mention.

  • angelus888Tue Mar 12 2024 13:43:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This to me is similar to the catholic concept of "mental reserve."

  • angelus888Tue Mar 12 2024 13:44:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This second point regarding a dialectical approach to "truthful" but perhaps better put low-quality truthful statements or truthful-but-deceptive statements, or manipulative statements, I've only started to explore, but it is fascinating. Time may be part of the key here.

  • angelus888Tue Mar 12 2024 13:44:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0 All in all, our little argument was incredibly illuminating to me <@386755556817240065>

  • angelus888Tue Mar 12 2024 13:45:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think Materialism provides a torch for illiminating these deceptions, attaching specific utterances to specific meanings, and exiting the hall of mirrors that one can otherwise get trapped in with regards to flexible and deceptive definitions.

  • andru0358Mon Mar 18 2024 01:36:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I guess Doug said he wasn't going to share the recording, so idk how y'all left off. When I left, <@805731746384445460> 's objection to the lack of "method" brings up the important questions I think. In the Preliminary Notion of Encyclopedia Logic, Hegel has some interesting quotes: "The necessity of understanding Logic in a deeper sense than as the science of the mere form of thought is enforced by the interests of religion and politics, of law and morality. ...... The Greek philosophers, for example, became antagonists of the old religion, and destroyed its beliefs. Philosophers were accordingly banished or put to death, as revolutionists who had subverted religion and the state, two things which were inseparable. Thought, in short, made itself a power in the real world, and exercised enormous influence. The matter ended by drawing attention to the influence of thought, and its claims were submitted to a more rigorous scrutiny, by which the world professed to find that thought arrogated too much and was unable to perform what it had undertaken It had not ‚Äî people said ‚Äî learned the real being of God, of Nature and Mind. It had not learned what the truth was. What it had done was to overthrow religion and the state It became urgent therefore to justify thought, with reference to the results it had produced: and it is this examination into the nature of thought and this justification which in recent times has constituted one of the main problems of philosophy."

  • andru0358Mon Mar 18 2024 01:40:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Also this passage on his relationship to ancient religion: "It may be well at the commencement of logic to examine the story which treats of the origin and the bearings of the very knowledge which logic has to discuss. For, though philosophy must not allow herself to be overawed by religion, or accept the position of existence on sufferance, she cannot afford to neglect these popular conceptions. The tales and allegories of religion, which have enjoyed for thousands of years the veneration of nations, are not to be set aside as antiquated even now." With that I want to share something else

  • andru0358Mon Mar 18 2024 01:41:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    When Svetaketu was twelve years old he was sent to a teacher, with whom he studied until he was twenty-four. After learning all the Vedas, he returned home full of conceit in the belief that he was consummately well educated, and very censorious. His father said to him, 'Svetaketu, my child, you who are so full of your learning and so censorious, have you asked for that knowledge by which we hear the unbearable, by which we perceive what cannot be perceived and know what cannot be known?' 'What is that knowledge, sir?' asked Svetaketu. His father replied, 'As by knowing one lump of clay all that is made of clay is known, the difference being only in name, but the truth being that all is clay so, my child, is that knowledge, knowing which we know all.' 'But surely these venerable teachers of mine are ignorant of this knowledge; for if they possessed it they would have imparted it to me. Do you, sir, therefore give me that knowledge.' 'So be it,' said the father. . . . And he said, 'Bring me a fruit of the nyagrodha tree.' 'Here is one, sir.' 'Break it.' 'It is broken, sir.' 'What do you see there?' 'Some seeds, sir, exceedingly small.' 'Break one of these.' 'It is broken, sir.' 'What do you see there?' 'Nothing at all.' The father said, 'My son, that subtle essence which you do not perceive there in that very essence stands the being of the huge nyagrodha tree. In that which is the subtle essence all that exists has its self. That is the True, that is the Self, and thou, Svetaketu, art That.' 'Pray, sir' said the son, 'tell me more' 'Be it so, my child,' the father replied; and he said, 'Place this salt in water, and come to me tomorrow morning.' The son did as he was told. Next morning the father said, 'Bring me the salt which you put in the water.'

  • andru0358Mon Mar 18 2024 01:41:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The son looked for it, but could not find it; for the salt, of course, had dissolved. The father said, 'Taste some of the water from the surface of the vessel. How is it?' 'Salty.' 'Taste some from the middle. How is it?' 'Salty.' 'Taste some from the bottom. How is it?' 'Salty.' The father said, 'Throw the water away and then come back to me again'. The son did so ; but the salt was not lost, for salt exists for ever. Then the father said, 'Here likewise in this body of yours, my son, you do not perceive the True; but there in fact it is. In that which is the subtle essence, all that exists has its self. That is the True, that is the Self, and thou, Svetaketu, art That" From the Chandogya Upanishad

  • firedog235Tue Mar 19 2024 00:21:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I agree that probably that is very important for understanding Hegel's idealism ^ (the one is), my only difficulty is that I'm not an idealist but rather a dialectical materialist (there is no one). What is neither immediate nor mediated?

  • firedog235Tue Mar 19 2024 00:23:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think my strongest objection is when people say 'you don't understand hegel'... I'm like --- yeah I understand Hegel. I just really don't agree with him at this very deep level.

  • andru0358Tue Mar 19 2024 00:25:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Have you sublated it tho?

  • firedog235Tue Mar 19 2024 00:37:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think there is no one that is neither immediate nor mediated (or to put it another way, I think there is nothing which is neither immediate nor mediated) --- and I don't think this nothing is completely equivalent to Hegel's being, in so much as Hegel's being is this immediate emptiness which unites all reality under a single banner: there are still positive responses possible for this being (we can say its self-identical for example). I think that there is no such thing that unites everything, there is nothing that provides this unity(in both a common sensical way of using the word 'nothing' *and* in the 'that to which all answers are no' way of using the word 'nothing' --- i.e. negative contradiction, 'for all x, not x'). This is important because I want nullity to both impact reality (i.e. I want its consequences to *not* be stripped out as a nothing, all these contradictory movements which we clearly observe) but *I* also don't want people to treat contradiction as if it doesn't have any importance at all as an impossibility (i.e. I want it to actually be nothing). *And* I also don't want people to say that things which actually are possible are impossible. *And* I want a single starting point, and Hegel's being... it isn't really a single starting point: yes he says that the being is nothing (and I agree, but only because I think everything is a sublation of this nothing, starting with the first object to 'be', the less than nothing 'no' --- so because being is a sublation of nothing it is *also* nothing) but while it is *a* nothing I don't think its the nothing which is actually forced to generate something: rather I think that this comes about because Hegel smuggles nothing into it. I also *bring* nothing into it, but the nothing I bring in is not smuggled in would be my difference.

  • firedog235Tue Mar 19 2024 00:37:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think a good attack against my position would be the assertation that my nothing exists in-itself, or as-such: not the 'no' which does exist, but rather 'that which all questions about it are answered no'. That would have to exist: but it can't because it isn't even consistent.

  • firedog235Tue Mar 19 2024 00:39:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Have I transcended my disagreement with Hegel? Or is it have I transcended Hegel in general? I think there is a transcendence to be found in drive...

  • andru0358Tue Mar 19 2024 21:48:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 If I understand you correctly, you're rejecting Hegel's doctrine of 'The One's? And the idea that there "such a thing that unites everything", ie Being (which is of course, not a thing, but I get you)? What I am understanding is that you are rejecting the *unity* of everything. Is that right? Like there is an important dualism between *what is* and *what is not* or contradiction?

  • firedog235.Tue Mar 19 2024 22:20:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Yes: there is no universal, no exceptions

  • firedog235.Fri Mar 22 2024 05:26:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 For all x, x exists (x is consistent), x is not a universal --- i.e. "there is no" (trigger phrase for inconsistency) universal. The argument is that it's the only position from which nothing is assumed (both in a negative --- I'm not assuming anything --- and in the positive sense: the no-thing is assumed) its this unity of opposites at the level of occams razor is the point of it.

  • firedog235.Fri Mar 22 2024 05:31:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @andru0358#0 No more the opposite: will to power is invested with all this meaning (even if it is personal) the point of the actual drive is that it's meaningless, its the space which registers some random cruff or noise that you have to repeat simply to keep the space of desire open. At least that's (one of) my understandings of drive.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 14:11:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Here is a section from the book "A Commentary To Hegels Science Of Logic" by David Gray Carlson which explains where Hegel derives the Begining of the Logic from and why it is immediacy and Being. """With What Must Science Begin? Here is a good place to regress and discuss the essay that precedes Pure Being. Hegel's goal is to develop a presupposition-free philosophy that provides its own foundations. Starting with an unproved "given" is precisely a surrender to superstition. Ever the enemy of philosophy, stipulation is "stupid." Every other science distinguishes its subject matter and scientific method. The subordinate sciences are permitted premises that are taken for granted. But Logic may not presuppose any forms, "for these constitute part of its own content and have first to be established within the science." (43) Yet Hegel begins - with Pure Being. Isn't choosing to begin a contingency and a presupposition? Hegel admits this. "All that is present is simply the resolve, which can be regarded as arbitrary, to consider thought as such." (70) Hegel remarks: "What philosophy begins with must be either mediated or immediate." (67) But which beginning shall we stipulate? He chooses immediacy, but on what basis? Hegel justifies the choice because what is here presupposed is (much later) proven. By "proven" he means that the very last step of the Logic (Absolute Idea, which is the same as Absolute Knowledge)** mediates the first step. His philosophy will take us in a circle. If the beginning is also the end, then the beginning is justified. At this point, the end and the beginning will be a "mediated cognition," which is what Hegel...

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 14:11:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ...says proof is, (481) Absolute Knowing (or Method) is the unity of mediation - all the mediations there are - and pure immediacy. It is the final step in the Logic. At that point, the absolutely immediate is also the absolutely mediated. The ultimate step, Hegel says, "is the immediate, but the immediate resulting from sublation of mediation . . . This result is therefore the truth. It is equally immediacy and mediation." (837) Pure Being, then, is merely a one-sided view of Absolute Knowing - the side of immediacy. In order to begin, Absolute Knowing breaks itself apart in a gesture of abstraction (since Pure Being will not suffer being merely a "part" in a greater whole). Absolute Knowing, "in its absolute self-assurance and inner poise," (843) stands back from its content, "allowing it to have free play." (73) The first move belongs to the Understanding. Hegel warns that it is essential to start in this one-sided way. Any other start provides a result, not a beginning. (72) "[T]he immediate of the beginning must be in its own self deficient and endowed with the urge to carry itself further." (829) Hegel's "famous and irritating beginning" is therefore a failure - an attempt to conceive of an unmediated self-identity. Immediacy and mediation are "unseparated and inseparable and the...

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 14:12:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ...opposition between them . . . a nullity." (68) And because the beginning is a failure, "advance is not a kind of superfluity; this it would be if that which the beginning is made were in truth already the absolute." (829) As Hegel emphasizes throughout the SL, the fate of a self-identical (or "diverse") entity is to disappear and render itself into nothing. This The Beginning is already foretold in Figure 1(b). Pure Being is the first diversity to show its own nothingness. It is often said that Hegel intends the last step of the Logic to be the first. This needs refinement. The first step comprehends immediacy as such - Pure Being. It may be said that Pure Being is the antepenultimate step - the third from last. In effect, the Understanding falls back two steps and produces an abstraction. From this retrogressive move, progress is necessitated."""

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 14:13:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    this is the accompanying diagram

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 14:25:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think the reason that immediacy is conflated with being here is still not clarified but I think if we read the final part of the Logic we would see that immediacy in this final triad of IMMEDIACY-MEDIATION-PURE KNOWLEDGE may be derived from the standpoint of Being

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 14:49:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    As Hegel puts it "This pure Being is the unity into which pure knowing withdraws" ¬ß107 So the way I see it Thomas debating whether Being or Nothing is the most fundamental element is missing the point of why Hegel is starting from Being. He's starting with Being because thats what pure Knowing withdraws into at the end of the development.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 14:56:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    pure immediacy is pure Being and the begining is to be pure immediacy. Pure Nothing isnt pure immediacy.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 15:10:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Also Hegel says that positive and negative are more developed determinations of Being and Nothing so when you liken Being to 'yes' and Nothing to 'no' which you do in your argument you're not refering to the pure Being and Nothing that Hegel is, youre using them in their more developed forms of yes and no that only appear later. "Of course, since we are speaking here of a particular actual something, those determinations are no longer present in it in the complete untruth in which they are as being and nothing; they are in a more developed determination, and are grasped, for example, as positive and negative, the former being posited, reflected being, the latter posited, reflected nothing; the positive contains as its abstract basis being, and the negative, nothing." ¬ß138 ---

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 15:14:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    so positive and negative (yes and no) are "posited, reflective" being and nothing, further developments of Being and Nothing and not Being and Nothing in their purity as we are working with at the begining.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 17:46:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Im just going to repost here what I posted on the Sublation website group incase people didnt see it there. I‚Äôve got a couple of suggestions I think would to help the meetings be more focused. I would like to suggest that every session we focus on a smaller particular selection of the text like 20-25 (or however many) paragraphs so that the group is more focused. For me particularly the smaller the better but I know that might not be popular with everyone who might want to go faster but what are peoples thoughts on that? That workload would be much more manageable for me than half a chapter at a time or whatever. Also Doug if you are going to bring up particular sections in the group I would find it helpful if you could make it known which paragraphs they will be, if not a day before then at least a few hours before the meeting, so we could make sure we‚Äôve read them. Whatever we decide I would find it helpful to have a more clear view of what exactly we will read and talk about rather than flicking from one thing to the other all the time and never zooming in on specifics. Not to say there isnt a place for that kind of wide scope of course but I did find it interesting when whe focused on that one paragraph last session even though the atmosphere was pretty tense after me throwing a tantrum.

    However, I remembered why I didn't do that earlier: since my version is German you won't get much out of it. But if you open the main file (called Wissenschaft der Logik.org) with Emacs you can look at how it works, and you can create your own along the same lines using Emacs and Org-Roam.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 25 2024 21:51:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    has anyone come across this guy on youtube before? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RTJTS2I-6RY

  • firedog235Wed Mar 27 2024 17:38:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 No I'm not missing the point, I'm disagreeing with it --- because part of my claim is that pure knowing is not primarily being, but rather primarily nothing: the pure knowing will consist primarily in the knowledge of the tenuousness of knowledge itself: maybe not for Hegel, Hegel may think that pure knowing *is* more than I do (i.e. he's stepping through everything as if its being, whereas I would take all his steps and point out that they are various nothings), but I'm saying that the materialist position lies in the failure of pure knowing, and so I'm ending at nothing as well... so I don't misunderstand Hegel. I disagree with Hegel. So, I take that 'no' is more developed than 'nothing-contradiction' --- that's always a part of my argument (and also that 'yes' is more developed than being-tautology). But I *disagree* with Hegel that being is prior to 'no': I think first there is nothing and then 'no' develops out of this nothing (i.e. no is more developed than nothing) before being in its purity can appear, and the being is extracted from this 'no' (because I think that being simply isn't immediate for materialism. I agree that Hegel thinks it is, but for materialism what is immediate is nothing). This being *for me* is tautology from which we can then extract 'yes' (so it goes general object (nothing-contradiction) -> particular (no) -> general object (being-tautology) -> particular (yes)). In this precise sense, that I hold no and yes as being more developed versions of nothing and being: I keep with Hegel.

  • firedog235Wed Mar 27 2024 17:39:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @douglain#0@minimaltom#0 I would also find it helpful to see what sections we are going to discuss and on what basis. <@386755556817240065>

  • nameiwillforgetWed Mar 27 2024 18:58:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 That reminds me, you mentioned last time that your argument was Occam's Razor, "the simplest possible explanation is usually correct". But applying OR in a metaphysical context is tricky to say the least because very complex statements can be the simplest possible. The natural numbers are the simplest they could possibly be, which means they are very, very complex. This ties into my general point that, if you're assuming everything possible comes out of contradiction, then you have some rule determining what is possible, and that is a thing.

  • firedog235Wed Mar 27 2024 23:26:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Well, yes, the 'no' that is simultaneously distinct from and the same as nothing-contradiction is this rule (or rather its beginning). The 'no' which is a response to every question concerning nothing-contradiction, is the beginning of 'possibility'. However, this no is *also* a requirement of the nothing, its total aspect and response, and so its simultaneously nothing (the heart of what assuming nothing is) and less than nothing (because actual nothing returns this no matter what, but what is returned, the 'no', sometimes returns something other than no which we only find out, after the tautological step, is 'yes'), it bridges the gap between nothing and being. The fact that this 'no' is also another nothing (a less than nothing) is what makes the nothing-contradiction into the simplest possible explanation. I agree that it blows up eventually (even into something as complicated as the ideological horizon of being), but as an internal consequence of its own logic moving through various oughts... in the same way that the natural numbers are a consequence of '0' moving through various oughts (if I have zero, then I have 1 because I have 1 object: i.e. zero. But if I have one and zero then I have '+1' because 1 is '+1' from zero, but if I have '+1' then I have all the natural numbers through repetitive applications of '+1', etc.)

  • nameiwillforgetThu Mar 28 2024 09:59:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 "Well, yes, the 'no' that is simultaneously distinct from and the same as nothing-contradiction is this rule (or rather its beginning). The 'no' which is a response to every question concerning nothing-contradiction, is the beginning of 'possibility'." In what way does this set up what is possible?

  • firedog235Sat Mar 30 2024 07:49:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 So when it comes to 'possibility' there's something important that I might not have fully grasped when I first mentioned it. It seems you might want to limit what is possible to specific definitions, like saying 'possibility is a sentence in this language,' 'a category,' or 'a theory and a model.' However, I'm emphasizing, particularly through my use of the word 'no,' (which can also be interpreted as 'not') a critique against confining 'possibility' within such a tautological boundary. This critique is aimed at the notion that 'what is possible' encompasses everything that is 'not impossible' and what is more, that everything possible is first impossible/contradiction --- it then moves out of that through this fleck of non-contradiction in its own kind of 'no' or 'negation' (which will have more and more advanced interpretations as the possible develops) but precisely because it has such a no or negation it must, necessarily end up back in a contradiction out of which a new kind of 'no' develops as a kind of piece of dangling being that is less than nothing left over as everything negates everything else down to nothing-contradiction. So that's what I mean by 'no' setting up what is possible: its precisely that each contradiction has a proceeding realm of possibility which establishes the contradiction, but the contradiction, being 'for all x, x' also can be interpreted as 'for all x, not x' and this new 'not x' in the context of the new contradiction creates a new 'not' that can then act to establish a new realm of the possible (but doesn't necessarily do so, it has to somehow lock against itself to really build up a new realm of possibility against the old realm of possibility or what is sometimes termed an 'order of being'). The not of 'for all x, not x' either points back to the current contradiction *or* it points to a domain beyond the current contradiction, depending upon its material historical movement.

  • firedog235Sat Mar 30 2024 08:39:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So for example if I hit this contradiction 'not an apple and not not an apple': there are many ways 'not' can be read here to produce new possibilities. There are of course all the semi-contradictions that aren't contradictions (possibility vs. actuality for example --- an apple seed is actually not an apple but possibly not not an apple) or partiality vs. totality (the skin of the apple is not an apple but its also not not an apple) or brand domain vs biological domain (an apple computer is not an apple but its also not not an apple): these are all negations that could come out of this contradiction of 'not an apple and not not an apple' (i.e. they are all --- *not* 'not an apple and not not an apple' --- in some way that makes plausible sense but they all are different ways of make this plausible negation occur, they do not evoke the same object). But what you really want is a 'not' that actually points beyond the apple, non-apple dichotomy as a concept. So one that points internal and which is probably the embodiment of the contradiction to its fullest is the life-cycle of the apple (the movement from apple to seed to tree to cutting to tree to apple to seed to tree to.... etc.): that really is both an apple and not an apple in some very deep sense (i.e. it sublates an apple. Its not an apple, and apple is a concrete object and this is a lifecycle. However an apple is part of it, one of its steps, however it is an apple, in the sense that the commodity of a particular kind of apple can be tied to this entire life-cycle as a process through money/labor time and the interactions of the market, and it also completes an apple, in that you don't really understand what an apple is until you have at least some basic idea of what this process, but finally it also transcends the apple by providing the conditions for evolution of the apple into something else --- some other fruit or plant).

  • firedog235Sat Mar 30 2024 09:01:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Its this last step which points out of the apple, i.e. which poses the question of the negative dialectic of the apple. Of course, apples transcend apples in that its always possible to evolve a better apple: a sweeter apple, an apple that keeps better, an apple that is more resistant to worms or fungus, etc. These are the internal transcendence of an apple (its 'desire' --- structural/object not subjective desire --- to evolve into another apple. This is a positive *attractor* that pulls the apple back into itself and it is this *attractor* which is the positive contradiction of the apple: not any concrete existing object but the negative space of a strange attractor), the way it points back to itself. But this very object 'evolution' is also (and primarily) a 'no' to what already exists in the realm of life: and in the specific realm of the apple, it would include all the things that aren't apples that evolve from an apple: i.e. it first cycles back into itself, but then it generalizes from 'apple evolution to apple' (self-referential or 'positive' contradiction) to 'apple evolution into non-apple' i.e. apple speciation (like what has started to happen to the brassicas). Next we get the general 'no' which is speciation split off from its specific origin (i.e. having nothing to do with apples, speciation as a pure speciation) and then generalization to the whole realm of life (i.e. back down the tree of life to life forms that came before apples and into the future and along all the branches). And at this point we hit a concrete ecology that *is* (i.e. what actually evolved) --- but this ecology has its own positive and negative contradiction (positive I think I can say: All the possible ecologies that could come out of the actually existing ecology through natural selection would be the positive contradiction: i.e. this *attractor* which pulls it back to the same kind of ecology, maybe one based on carbon life and water chemistries for example).

  • nameiwillforgetSat Mar 30 2024 12:01:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 I think you're misundestanding my point: I'm not saying you need a criterion for what is possible *vis a vis* what is impossible, I'm saying you need something establishing the possibility of something else *at all*. In your example, I'm not saying you need something to determine whether or not an apple is possible, I'm saying you need the idea of an apple for an apple to be possibly possible. If all you have is contradiction and nothing, then there is not just no way to distinguish between what is possible and what is impossible, there is more fundamentally no way something that could be possible could emerge.

  • firedog235Sat Mar 30 2024 19:57:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 If I have nothing then I have 'no' which is not nothing and which is what is possible (its not nothing because the answer to the question 'is no nothing' is 'no'). 'no' is the first 'thing' --- less than nothing (in many senses, the most fun and sophistic one of course being that 'no' is literally fewer letters than 'nothing' --- zizek prefers 'othing' as this primordial 'no' however).

  • firedog235Sat Mar 30 2024 19:58:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But outside of this loose reasoning (the letter argument) 'no' is actually the first positive object, nothing reflected back into itself

  • firedog235Sat Mar 30 2024 20:00:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And its also a requirement of nothing, a consequence (i.e. if you don't have 'no' you don't have nothing because nothing is that to which the answer to all questions about it is no --- including also the question 'is nothing that to which the answer to all questions is no?': i.e. nothing requires a no at its root at its base, for there to be nothing, there must be less than nothing).

  • andru0358Sun Mar 31 2024 19:59:18 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    You say "nothing is that to which the answer to all questions about it is no" You keep saying this, and now you explain it's the basis for why "no" is primary. But I'm sorry, that concept of nothing is just a meaningless formalism. It has nothing to do with dialectics or Hegel.

  • andru0358Sun Mar 31 2024 20:00:42 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Nothing cannot be captured by a formula like that. Hegel is precisely try to develop a logic beyond formalism, ie formulas and arbitrary definitions. You can just translate it into a formula and then use your own bad translation to refute it

  • andru0358Sun Mar 31 2024 20:05:17 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    For example, you could as, "does nothing have a meaning?" Yes it does! Hegel states this, it's also immediately clear. When we say the word, it holds meaning. You might not get the meaning. But that's on you

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 00:59:40 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @andru0358#0 Actually nothing (as far as I can tell) is meaninglessness itself: that is its meaning. Its contradiction, its nothing, it gives no meaning and it receives no meaning. Meaning has to be found elsewhere, in something lesser. Hegel may or may not be reaching beyond formalism but my point is that there is only the formalism of formalism 'beyond' (though not really beyond) formalism: i.e. the very acknowledgement that you can be completely formally correct and still be wrong because of something that isn't accounted for in the formula and the reduction of formula itself to an empty point. But this acknowledgement doesn't 'defeat' formalism, it merely proposes a replacement formalism (i.e. one that does account for this new thing, whatever it is in the case of an outside thing, and one that is based on this empty point in the case of the empty point).

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 01:04:10 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    (when I say as far as I can tell, I'm not saying as far as I can tell in Hegel --- I mean as far as I can tell as a person: if Hegel's claim is that I should just spontaneously and immediately recognize meaning in nothing then my refutation is as simple as his demonstration --- I don't).

  • andru0358Mon Apr 01 2024 01:05:02 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Saying it's "meaninglessness itself" is a meaning

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 01:05:58 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @andru0358#0 Not really, I don't actually know that that means so I don't know how its a meaning

  • andru0358Mon Apr 01 2024 01:06:12 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    That's your problem

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 01:07:08 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @andru0358#0 I think its a more general problem --- I think a lot of people have demanded to fill that void with a false meaning and its caused a lot of grief for humanity throughout the ages

  • andru0358Mon Apr 01 2024 01:10:06 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Please just stop trolling

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 01:13:00 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @andru0358#0 I am actually literally not trolling. This isn't a joke. I'm literally saying that I think Nothing can *only* be captured by a formula, that there is *nothing* beyond formalism (i.e. there is no in-formalism, truly) and I think that people should never fill in nothing with false meaning because that's how you get religious nonsense. Ultimately, my joke is always that I'm not joking.

  • andru0358Mon Apr 01 2024 01:13:38 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Like you can think that. I just don't know why you'd stay in a Hegel reading group and troll people about it

  • andru0358Mon Apr 01 2024 01:17:16 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It's like a libertarian in a Capital reading group who just won't give up on "actually labor doesn't create value, if I dig a whole and fill it up, no value is produced"

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 01:24:30 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @andru0358#0 Because the only reason most people read Hegel is because of Marx (and it really is the only reason for sublation to be reading Hegel) --- without Marx he's just another dead German Philosopher and the liberals love Kant more so Kant's the one whose going to get read more. I'm the one here to draw the distinction between the materialism of Marx and the Idealism of Hegel (and also the idealism of Marx and the materialism of Hegel since this division isn't completely consistent in either direction) to see how either is flawed. It's not a trolling, its the hermanuetic of suspicion to balance out a hermaneutic of faith (which I also have, most moves Hegel makes I'm fine not quibbling with). As for the libertarian objection, I would say no that's not what I'm doing. Because the libertarian is just ignoring something which Marx actually addresses (Marx, after all says that value is *socially necessary* labor). Like the libertarian's objection is also Marx's own objection *to other socialists* so the libertarian isn't even reading Marx. My objection, at least according to you, is not Hegel's objection. Hegel claims being and nothing are co-equal. I'll buy that Hegel says that, I'm just saying Hegel is wrong because of something he actually said (not something he didn't say in the case of the libertarian objecting to Marx --- that's bad faith).

  • andru0358Mon Apr 01 2024 01:34:57 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Defending formalism is taking up Bertrand Russell's objection to Hegel

  • andru0358Mon Apr 01 2024 01:36:03 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Saying its proposing a different formalism is just wrong. You just don't get it

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 01:38:26 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @andru0358#0 Or it may mean that what Bertrand Russell and I mean by 'formalism' is different --- that's possible.

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 01:38:39 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I would have to look into that

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 01:55:18 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 So I think that we got to an interesting point before (like months ago) and I think that you were proposing empty model/empty theory for nothing. I think I would like to propose this, first I don't think we can go with separate model and theory for nothing: I think we would need something more like a model-theory which is something that is translated both as a model and theory which either accepts or doesn't accept itself as its own model. So for example the model-theory: {'for all x, x is a statement in first order predicate logic'} would be self-accepting while the model-theor: {‚Äòfor all x, x is an elephant} wouldn‚Äôt be self accepting. So then let's say that nothing is the model theory {} or even better I‚Äôll give it a symbol: ‚óª. So that‚Äôs the first step away from category theory I‚Äôd maybe take and I would call a theory model pair maybe a ‚Äòsystem‚Äô (unless there‚Äôs some better or standard name for it, I can‚Äôt find one) and I‚Äôd call this a self-referencing system.

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 01:55:35 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 Now this seems to work for nothing in a way that doesn‚Äôt require any kind of ‚Äògrowth‚Äô or ‚Äòexistence‚Äô of the nothing (i.e. its just an empty model-theory, or we could even say its just emptiness itself). But I think there is a problem, certainly at least if we are looking at this from the perspective of category theory. The problem is that if a statement is not in a model in category theory that doesn‚Äôt mean the statement is either true or false but rather its undefined, which means in fact that the absence of the statement from a model is not a statement about its absence but rather a statement about its undefined character within the model. The model is unable to give meaning to the statement: it in fact has all possible values as possible values: or rather it has *none* of the possible values as values. It is the case that an undefined statement is both is not true and not not true --a contradiction. Or to put it another way, this emptiness is not actually an emptiness, but a gentleman‚Äôs agreement not to put a definition to things we aren‚Äôt considering and the development of a traditional classical logic actually pulls its non-assumptive determinations from this ‚Äòsea of incoherence‚Äô (i.e. nothing) that exists beyond (or rather, within) the emptiness. However, we may not want to violate this gentleman‚Äôs agreement right away and instead ask, what takes part of absolutely *every* statement in this sea of decoherence. And what I‚Äôm saying is that they all have a negation in front of them (even if they don‚Äôt because, of course not not x is also x). I.e. all statements of an undefined object are *not* true (i.e. the undefined statement is *not* true but its also *not not true* and thus, like how you can always find a room at the infinite hotel, you can always find a not in the sea of decoherence).

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 03:27:46 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @nameiwillforget#0 But then I realized that there was one last problem with the undefined. The final objection which is the one you're making perhaps, is that 'okay' but there isn't anything that exists for the undefined to 'undefine'. But then the response is that the undefined is greedy --- it grabs everything 'outside' the model and undefines it. This would include the empty model-theory itself which is undefined in the empty model theory. Thus the not that is pulled out of the undefined is standing on top of nothing (the empty theory-model which is not true *in* the empty theory model and also not not true *in* the empty theory model).

  • andru0358Mon Apr 01 2024 03:28:50 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Nothing, pure nothing: it is simply equality with itself, complete emptiness, absence of all determination and content ‚Äî undifferentiatedness in itself. In so far as intuiting or thinking can be mentioned here, it counts as a distinction whether something or nothing is intuited or thought. To intuit or think nothing has, therefore, a meaning; both are distinguished and thus nothing is (exists) in our intuiting or thinking; or rather it is empty intuition and thought itself, and the same empty intuition or thought as pure being. Nothing is, therefore, the same determination, or rather absence of determination, and thus altogether the same as, pure being.

  • nameiwillforgetMon Apr 01 2024 05:14:13 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @firedog235#0 I'm a bit ill, so this is maybe too galaxy-brained for me, but if it grabs everything 'outside' the model, that implies something outside the model exists, and thus something exists, right?

  • firedog235Mon Apr 01 2024 06:53:17 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I'm sorry you feel sick üò¶ No, because the only thing it grabs is the empty model-theory itself which is also, because it is empty, totally undefined (i.e. its nothing but undefined). However the undefined doesn't exist because its a kind of contradiction (it doesn't exist, but it also doesn't not exist)... but it definitely *doesn't exist* first. The undefined here is grabbing a hold of something that doesn't exist --- i.e. itself --- 'the undefined' under the name of the empty model-theory ‚óª (which it can do because it is itself a contradiction so it doesn't care if it has internal contradictions). However a *consequence* of this undefined character is simply the less than nothing, ('not' or 'no'), which is not immediately contradictory and thus can exist (or rather ex-sist, stand out from nothing/contradiction). When this 'not' is combined internally with the undefined as 'not x and not not x' (or not undefined and not not undefined) it doesn't exist (because that whole statement points to something that doesn't exist --- that whole statement is also, itself, undefined), but when its pulled out as 'not (x or not x)' we end up with just 'not (T)' which is just 'not'. This is how nothing generates something (specifically the something of 'not').

  • minimaltomFri Apr 05 2024 20:06:01 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • minimaltomWed Jul 24 2024 16:11:01 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @andru0358#0@douglain#0@firedog235#0@nameiwillforget#0 <@638122715668152320> <@476561351167311872> <@805731746384445460> <@386755556817240065> , what are we going to be talking about this weekend?

  • minimaltomWed Jul 24 2024 17:08:01 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I have found out something interesting in the Houlgate book me and Doug are reading about the difference between ~~empirical~~ sensible intuition and intelectual intuition in Kant and Hegel and I think it is very important bearing on reading Hegel (especially in ¬ß120 in the intro which Alex was talking about on the Patreon thread.) Sensible intuition for Kant is intuition of empirical/material reality and is merely correpondent or reflective as in you cant just think something and it appears in front of you. Intelectual intuition on the other hand is not dependent on reality, (it is therefore a priori/idealist and internal.) So what you think and what there is has no distinction as it does in sensible intuition, you think something and it appears there right before you. Kant believes that Humans are only capable of sensible inuition and not intelectual intuition, they can't think something and it materialises infront of them, only God is capable of this intelectual intuition. Hegel on the other hand believes intelectual intuition is possible for Humans and infact this is exactly what he means by pure knowing. This is shown for example when he says in ¬ß120: ".....although the ego could be characterised as *pure knowing or as intelectual intuition*" So everything Hegel is talking about here is in the realm of intelectual intuition, something Kant doesnt even believe is possible for mortals. I beleive this is why Hegel refers to it as being the mind of god before he creates anything because he is claiming to be able to perform intelectual intuition, something Kant says only God capable of doing.

  • minimaltomWed Jul 24 2024 17:14:26 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I know the quote above is also talking about the Ego so it is a bit confusing but he says also a bit later: "But what, at the beginning of the science, is actually present of intellectual intuition ‚Äì or of the eternal, the divine, the absolute, if its object be so named ‚Äì cannot be anything else than a first, immediate, simple determination. " Still not totally clear but I believe he means that the begining contains *intellectual intuition* in its most minimal form, Being. I will look if there are more occurences of the phrase 'intelectual intuition'.

    @douglain#0@firedog235#0 I‚Äôm ok with that, <@386755556817240065> ?

  • minimaltomTue Jul 30 2024 20:13:09 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Been reading about Ficthe on Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy and came across this about his use and developement of the term "intelectual intuition": > This same ‚Äúidentity in difference‚Äù of original self-consciousness might also be described as an ‚Äúintellectual intuition,‚Äù inasmuch as it involves the immediate presence of the I to itself, prior to and independently of any sensory content. To be sure, such an ‚Äúintellectual intuition‚Äù never occurs, as such, within empirical consciousness; instead, it must simply be presupposed (that is, ‚Äúposited‚Äù) in order to explain the possibility of actual consciousness, within which subject and object are always already distinguished. The occurrence of such an original intellectual intuition is itself inferred, not intuited. > > Unfortunately, Fichte confuses matters by sometimes using the term ‚Äúinner‚Äù or ‚Äúintellectual intuition‚Äù to designate something else entirely: namely, the act of philosophical reflection or purified self-observation through which the philosopher becomes conscious of the transcendental conditions for the possibility of ordinary experience‚Äîamong which, of course, is the occurrence of the ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù intellectual intuition as a Tathandlung. On other occasions, he employs the term ‚Äúintellectual intuition‚Äù in yet another sense: namely, to designate our direct, practical awareness within everyday life of our moral obligations (categorical imperative qua ‚Äúreal intellectual intuition‚Äù). Given the subsequent abuse of this term by Schelling and the romantics, as well as the confusion that one sometimes finds among expositors of Fichte on this issue, it is crucial to recognize systematic ambiguity of the term ‚Äúintellectual intuition‚Äù in Fichte‚Äôs own writings.

  • minimaltomTue Jul 30 2024 20:15:44 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    So not sure if Hegels use of the term is affected by this "abuse" of the term by Schelling etc or not but already Fichte added to the obscurity of the term himself using it in 3 different ways it seems.

  • minimaltomTue Jul 30 2024 20:19:40 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Started to read about Fichte because I came to the realisation that in 'With What Should The Science Begin' when he starts talking about the Ego in ¬ß117 he's actually talking about Fichte I think and not Descartes. This is aparent from the fact that he describes it as having "recently become famous" and at this point Descartes was already over 100 years ago and also it is Fichte and not Descartes who tried to derive the Categories from the I or the Ego. Well deriving the categories like Hegel is doing might not be exactly what Fichte is trying to do but something similar.

  • minimaltomTue Jul 30 2024 20:23:39 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I'm really amazed how similar Fichtes project seems to be as Hegels and how much they have in common such as how fichte believed that starting the philosophy with the principle of the 'I' could only be justified by the conclusion of the philosophy, very reminisent of Hegels idea of philosophy as a circle that is self grounding.

  • minimaltomTue Jul 30 2024 20:38:41 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It kind of seems to me though that Fichte is working in reverse to Hegel, that he works back from his initial principle (and Hegel rejects having a principle) to find the conditions for its possibility. This is also from Stanford: > After establishing the first principle and conceiving the act expressed therein, the philosophical task is then to discover what other acts must necessarily occur as conditions for the possibility of the original, ‚Äúsimply posited,‚Äù first act and then to do the same for each of these successively discovered acts (or the theorems in which they are formulated). By continuing in this manner, one will, according to Fichte, finally arrive at a complete deduction of the a priori structure of ordinary experience or, what amount to the same thing, a complete inventory of the ‚Äúoriginal acts of the mind.‚Äù This is precisely the task of the first or ‚Äúfoundational‚Äù portion of the Jena system.

  • minimaltomSat Aug 17 2024 14:47:00 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • dve.h_37844Mon Jan 27 2025 14:17:54 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I spent an hour reading the 18 introductory sections of Hegels shorter Logic this morning and I found it much easier to read than the prefaces to the SOL. I then went back and re-read the prefaces and found them much more digestible than I did when I just took a nose dive into them last year. I think the shorter logic‚Äôs introduction acts as a good counter balance to the debates surrounding Hegels philosophical relationship to religion and the actual existing world - a debate that could last months - and it shows how one could easily be on either side of it. Just putting that out there as a way for people to straightforwardly see where Hegel is coming from, and help them move passed sections of the SOL that read like they‚Äôre hieroglyphics. https://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/hegel/works/sl/slintro.htm#SL1

  • headphon3jackMon Jan 27 2025 15:01:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôm almost through the second preface and my favorite part so far are those passages about how people try to use the categories (either through abbreviation or determining objective relationships). But really the categories possess us! We wouldn‚Äôt say we use our feelings or impulses. We wouldn‚Äôt say they are at our disposal! Another point I find curious is when he remarks on language. He says if you split mind and body than logic is sort of a supernatural force. Yet, later on, he says forget the objective notion of things because it‚Äôs actually subjective. So why even have that part about the supernatural logic?

  • headphon3jackMon Jan 27 2025 16:59:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Thinking about it more I guess he answers my question when he uses the example of force and polarity. That an advance beyond abstraction and beyond identity (A = A) is important. That force acquired independent self-subsistence. Yet it‚Äôs still not enough because the further step is abstracting from the opposition to a generality.

  • dve.h_37844Mon Jan 27 2025 18:13:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel is essentially asserting that there is no empiricism that could be more important than man‚Äôs free will and his conscious reasoning. Many Marxists have trouble threading this needle, because they don‚Äôt allow themselves to think like this - for them it‚Äôs progress with no regress.

  • headphon3jackMon Jan 27 2025 18:20:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It‚Äôs that being and the Notion are the same and they relate to each through pure essentialities which are also the same. It‚Äôs like in Rousseau that the sovereign and the people are the same and relate through the government. Or that between subject and object is language, except he explicitly rejects this, and says that thought brings us further away from the object, and language seeps inward into man and contains categories sometimes even snuck in.

  • headphon3jackTue Jan 28 2025 14:48:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Well I‚Äôm thinking it‚Äôs sort of what you already said about implicit and explicit. Like on the explicit level would be the an analytic judgement A = A and on the implicit level the synthetic judgement A = B.

  • minimaltomTue Jan 28 2025 23:59:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 not sure I get what youre saying there. why is implicit analytic a explicit synthetic?

  • headphon3jackWed Jan 29 2025 00:06:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I‚Äôm interpreting it as the explicit or analytic would be in the realm of appearances whereas the opposition contained within would have an implicit, more obscure part

  • headphon3jackWed Jan 29 2025 00:06:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    and saying that the explicit is the explicit is analytical whereas saying the explicit is the implicit is synthetic

  • minimaltomWed Jan 29 2025 00:16:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 could be could be. What have you read of Kant or Hegel so far? I'm guessing youre using appearance in the Hegelian sense rather than the Kantian sense??

  • minimaltomWed Jan 29 2025 00:17:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    i have to go to bed right now tho, catch up tomorrow

  • headphon3jackWed Jan 29 2025 00:19:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I read like half of Kant‚Äôs critique of pure reason (I got through the transcendental deduction but it fried my brain). For Hegel I‚Äôve read the master-slave dialectic but nothing beyond that and I don‚Äôt know his sense of appearance. I was using it in a loose way that I think can be traced back to the Greeks.

  • headphon3jackWed Jan 29 2025 00:19:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Like the allegory of the cave way where we don‚Äôt trust our senses

  • minimaltomWed Jan 29 2025 10:15:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 Well I can't say I know enough to say if youre right or wrong but its interesting to speculate and I did a google search of Hegelian appearance and implicit expicit and just read the stupid AI explaination but it has some paralels to what youre saying. There is a whole section in the logic called appearance so I think Hegel definately develops it a lot further than the common understanding of the word but Im sure its connected in some way to the usual sense of the word like you are thinking. Kant actually just uses the word appearance to mean how things are presented to us through the senses I think and I think hegel will probably develop it from there in someway.

  • minimaltomWed Jan 29 2025 10:16:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    heres google AIs result on appearance In the philosophy of Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, appearance is the relationship between form and content, and the idea that the content of something is only accessible through its form. Explanation Form and content Appearance is the recognition of the difference between form and content, and the idea that these two things are not always identical. Essence Appearance is the second grade of essence, and is the concrete existence of essence. Transient and unstable Appearance is a modification of being, but it is transient and unstable because it is still partial or abstract. Dialectical process Appearance develops through a dialectical process, where a multiplicity of forms build up and stand in contradictory relationship to their content. Higher than being Appearance is higher than being because it combines reflection-into-self and reflection-into-other. Hegel's ideas about appearance are discussed in his works Logic, Outline of Logic, and Shorter Logic.

  • minimaltomWed Jan 29 2025 10:19:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    my knowledge of Hegel is fairly limited tho, I only know what ive gathered from listening to zizek talks and reding the first few chapters of this book, and Ive read an introduction on kant

  • minimaltomWed Jan 29 2025 10:20:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    oh and reading Houlgates books on the logic

    Anyone read anymore of the preferances or anything? I actually started reading the intro to the phenomenology (the preferance is too long and difficult and is supposedly a kind of summary of the whole thing or almost a sort of afterword) and my god its less arduous than the Logic, much more colourful and kind of alive.

  • minimaltomTue Feb 04 2025 18:22:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)
