  • headphon3jackSun Feb 16 2025 00:01:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    https://youtu.be/32mRSahoA7o?si=Dxxe7_pVgUrEfNOr

  • headphon3jackSun Feb 16 2025 00:02:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I found this useful. It explains how the understanding unifies sense intuitions.

  • headphon3jackSat Feb 22 2025 15:13:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Kant says sensuous intuitive experience begins the cognitive process. The cognitive faculties of understanding, judgement, and reason. He believes he can separate out sensuous intuition from necessary, universal, formal, a priori knowledge. His goal is to give the ground for the possibility of synthetic a priori knowledge. He contrasts synthetic judgement that add or augment (A=B) from analytic or identity judgements (A=A). He wants to deal with the a priori or pure forms of these judgements. He points out that math and physics have synthetic a priori judgements as principles and we don‚Äôt even know how they are possible. What if we can‚Äôt separate the immediate from the mediate? Then we have no practical interaction with the thing in itself and can not know it except discursively not sensuously. Kant had written that the faculty of reason was the part of cognition that dealt with concepts that had no object (freedom of will, god, the soul) but now it seemed like they were distanced from all being. Being-in-itself is noumenal. I think this is the point where Hegel comes in.

  • headphon3jackSat Feb 22 2025 15:15:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôd say also what if there is no grounds for synthetic a priori judgements? Based on the preface from the science of logic it at least seems like he‚Äôs making an analytic judgement that being and the notion are identical.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:29:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 in the first chapter of the Houlgate book were reading he says that Kant only believes that a statement like the straight line between 2 points, is synthetic only because he doesn't see the categories as inherent in each other but wholy seperate. I think Hegel does actually believe this is synthetic or even mathematics afterall, at least some kinds of maths.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:31:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 why do you say this means we can't have practical interaction with the thing in itself?

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:32:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 what in particular in the preface do you think says that synthetic apriori is impossible? genuinely interested

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:32:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    not denying your right or anything, think its important

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:32:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I was participating in what Hegel would call natural or unconscious reason rather than philosophical reason. Hegel would criticize me for focusing too much on getting to immediacy because it‚Äôs only a moment held separately without that first part of connecting.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:35:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    just had a thought, what if we dont need apriori judgements if we can have intelectual intuition instead?

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:35:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    and if understanding isnt just judgement as ant claims

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:35:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 now mulling this over

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:35:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 It‚Äôs the part about the Notion being separated into two moments of its totality: 1. *the* substantial Notion as one 2. It‚Äôs determinateness or particular content that is generated by bringing brought before consciousness and evaluated as self-independent and external. If it‚Äôs all one substantial, fundamental Notion then it seems to me nothing is synthetic or augmentative. Instead we are only overcoming the limits of reason by gaining insight into the contradiction.

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:36:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I think an intellectual intuition or discursive intuition is just an a prior judgement made of an a priori judgment

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:37:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 but i think he says judgement is discursive. intelectual intuition isn't judgement

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:37:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    at least houlgate says thats what hegel means

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:37:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Oh like sensuous intuition

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:38:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    yes perhaps, thats not judgmental afterall

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:38:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    That would be immediate if it was pre judgement. The undetermined thing-in-itself.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:38:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    thats right!

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:38:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But the categories are nodes in the infinite material ‚Äî- self knowing of the Notion

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:38:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    not saying i grasp exactly how but ...

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:39:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 whats that from?

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:39:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 First preface

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:39:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ok, ill have a look, the preface is full of advanced stuff!

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:41:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Wait it‚Äôs the second preface actually

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:45:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It‚Äôs after he discusses the way the categories are used wrong (as abbreviations for a multitude of particulars and as objective relations). He mentions that viewing the categories as having external form goes along with that. Then he says that really it‚Äôs not just about the relationship between the thing-in-itself and its actuality, but between the thing and it‚Äôs knowledge of itself. The categories becomes the essence of the Notion that are seen as self-independent and the Notion knowing itself. Hegel put it something like things-in-themselves are an infinitely varied (undetermined) material that has firm knots or nodes (the categories) in it.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:45:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 I believe Hegel has big problems with the thing in itself at least in the way Kant understands it. He does however have a Category of being-in-itself in the second chapter 'Determinate Being'

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:49:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 you got the paragraph number?

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:50:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yeah the kantian picture is that our thoughts don‚Äôt bring our subjectivity closer to the object or a thing-in-itself but cuts us off from it. Hegel wants to embrace knowing the infinite because the truth is infinite. If we can grasp totality of being, or the infinite truth, then that‚Äôs against Kant‚Äôs picture and also against the idea that we can only know totality it by its limitation.

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:51:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Roughly 20-26 will cover what I‚Äôve been talking about

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:54:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 i dont take this as the same as saying he wants to know everything tho. Hegel has a very specific derivation of the category infinite

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 16:55:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think Hegel would say theres no logical reason for there being a thing in itself in the kantian manner

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:56:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Right I think that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm trying to say. That it requires an objective notion of the thing that we can deny.

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:56:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But this puts truth on one side because we can‚Äôt get to the object with our subjectivity so we need to unite form and content.

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:57:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And we can do that because the form has an inner determination that serves as its content

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 16:59:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    When that inner determination serves as its particular content then the negation isn‚Äôt an absolute negation into nothingness, but the negation itself has a positive aspect. It‚Äôs the positive aspect of the negation that can give us insight into the contradictions. That‚Äôs how we raise reason beyond limitation.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 17:01:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 I dont think it puts truth to one side but it redefines what truth is. Truth wouldnt be knowing what the thing in itself is if there was one, not in the Hegelian meaning

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 17:01:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    truth for hegel doesn't depend on objects or the senses

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 17:02:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 this is interesting tho

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 17:02:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Hegel was saying that ordinary, common sense had adopted the objective notion of things and rejected logic and thus out truth to one side by seeing form as only attached to content and not included in determining it.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 17:03:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 ah right, i thought you meant hegel was leaving truth to one side

  • headphon3jackThu Feb 27 2025 17:04:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    No this is hegel‚Äôs criticism of ordinary common sense and how they didn‚Äôt appreciate the categories that appeared to mind as fragments. They didn‚Äôt take time to clarify those fragments with logic because logic appeared empty of content to them.

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 17:09:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    interesting stuff im now reading those paragraphs

  • minimaltomThu Feb 27 2025 20:39:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Got Hegel fatigue but read most of it, really good stuff

  • minimaltomSat Mar 01 2025 16:05:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yeah this is what i think hes saying

  • minimaltomSat Mar 01 2025 16:05:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Im still reading these paragraphs as theres some quite hard parts

  • minimaltomSat Mar 01 2025 16:07:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    we never really got to grips with this stuff in the reading group so far I think

  • minimaltomSat Mar 01 2025 16:07:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    it is hard

  • minimaltomSat Mar 01 2025 16:07:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    but i really think we need to

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 01 2025 16:34:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yeah it‚Äôs difficult and Hegel adds another difficulty which is his critique of ‚Äòthoroughness‚Äô. You know, to be thorough would be to examine the beginning and firmly establish it before moving on. But those that fundamentally misunderstand the first Notions of Logic (being, nothing, and becoming ‚Äîbecoming containing the first two as moments) will reject the beginning, and therefore all the rest, as not firmly established in the name of thoroughness (but really it‚Äôs laziness and reducing mental labor). Thoroughness tends to do the opposite of itself and brings in categories and propositions that lie beyond the initial principles eg. That content is different than form, infinity different than finitude, mediation is no immediacy, etc. even though it is unjustified to presuppose such propositions. In fact it‚Äôs the business of logic to enquire into the truth of those propositions.

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 01 2025 16:37:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel wrote that the education and discipline of thinking, by which it acquires plasticity and overcomes the impatience of casual reflection, is procured solely by going forward with the study of the science of logic, (he referred to it as skeptical philosophy or metaphysics proper) and carrying the entire development out to its conclusions.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 05 2025 18:51:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 thougoughness sounds to me kind of like polishing a turd üòÇ

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:41:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 <@1275846548932132864> One thing interesting in these passages is Hegel saying that freedom can be obtained through thinking in this refined way. In usual activities we find that we arent in control of what were doing at all, were driven by desires which we cant control and can hardly then call our own or that we master them.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:41:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    just going though them again

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:43:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think Kant thinks alternatively that we all have some kind of freedom simply by being having one foot in the noumenal realm. Or thats what Ive gathered from reading an intro

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:43:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    the noumenal realm for Kant is completely free and its the inner phenoumenal world which is deterministic. Again just what I remember reading

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:45:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    wheras hegel says we can be totally free by thinking dialectically. "When we give ourselves up to a sensation, a purpose, an interest, and in it feel ourselves confined and unfree, the place into which we can withdraw ourselves back into freedom is this region of self-certainty, of pure abstraction, of thought."

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 20:47:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 There‚Äôs a tricky part there in regards to what is more universal and what is more particular between the categories (when used as abbreviations or objective relations) and the finite nature of an individual human. I‚Äôd say Hegel‚Äôs claim is we have to withdraw back to logic (ie. Thought as thought) in order to find freedom from being used by the categories.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 20:47:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It‚Äôs part of rejecting the objective notion of things

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:47:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Ah yeah!!! He says we dont control the categories either

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:48:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    just like our feelings or drives

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 20:50:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    In Kant‚Äôs schema the universal particular and individual fall under the logical determinations of quantity. The pure categories (the determinations acting in themselves) of quantity are unity plurality and totality. Totality is of key importance.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:50:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    our thinking should mould itself to the categories not the other way round

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 20:50:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel says we can know totality in its affirmation and not just by its limits or finitude

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:51:53 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    right ok, when he talks about true infinity in the second chapter he talks about how it is completely unlimited.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 20:55:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    you have finitude vs infinity as a dialectic but that infinity turns out to be only a bad infinity in his words because if it is up against finitude as its limit it can't be truly infinite because it stops where finitude begins. Infinity can only be true when it is completely self detemined and this happens because finitude and (bad/spurious)infinity become sublated into being just moments (aspects) of the higher concept of true infinity.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 20:55:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Its also in the introduction when he discusses the beginning of the science being the notion. But then in the next section, about with what science must begin, he says philosophy must begin with either mediation or immediacy which is what Doug was talking about in the last session.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 20:59:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yeah I think you‚Äôve said it here about as well as I could describe it

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:00:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 this is what ive gathered up mostly through reading Houlgates comentary

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:00:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:02:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yeah but he then says each way, immediate or mediate, can be shown to both be inadequate or something. Which is weird because because he says about the need being pure immediacy or in other words pure being

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:03:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    "What philosophy begins with must be either mediated or immediate, and it is easy to show that it can be neither the one nor the other; thus either way of beginning is refuted."

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:03:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It‚Äôs like when you determine a side of the contradiction and hold it steady, then it‚Äôs only an empty abstraction. Raising the contradiction to the level of consciousness and following the movement of its moments as particular, concrete content and the one self-infinite Notion.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:03:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    When we can get a glimpse into the nature of the contradiction than we‚Äôve expanded our knowledge of totality

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:04:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I‚Äôm halfway through that part, but I think he wants to start with pure immediacy but not as empty abstraction. It has to develop, just like the methodology and everything else, from the movement of the inner determinations of the Notion itself.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:04:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yes it needs to be both the form (abstraction) and the content at the same time!

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:04:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And he talks about how some parts were presupposed from philosophy of spirit which I‚Äôm still working through the exact argument there

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:05:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The notion of science in particular being presupposed from the philosophy of spirit

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:06:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yeah well he does say being is immediate although it has mediation hidden behind it which i think is to say it is 'implicit' wheras its immediacy is explicit (we can see it)

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:07:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yeah Ive read a bit of how he gets that from another book

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:07:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He wants nothing presupposed in the science. He says philosophy can not borrow its method from math or empirical sciences. It‚Äôs methodology and all it‚Äôs other things must develop in the immanent determination of the Notion itself.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:07:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    the end of phenomenology and the logic actually come to practically the same conclusion i think

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:07:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The method being the positive aspect of the negation I think

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:08:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:09:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:10:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:17:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I think he says the notion of science is presupposed as a starting point from the inner determinations of mind (thought coming to know itself?). Just like how the categories becomes the nodes or knots in the self-infinite material of the thing in itself when they are brought before mind. It is thought recognizing itself as thought through thought.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:21:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 hmm ok, thats a bit difficult to understand completely

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:22:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think tho hes saying those categorical knots are very big in that they are used very casually in natural logic because they are so detemined? Is that right?

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:23:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    those knots being the most universal categories maybe??

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:24:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    and those big knots are the most recognised by science so far

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:24:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    thats why people can casually use them so confidently

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:26:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 The universal, it is being argued here at least, is more real than the particular. Has more substance.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:26:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel questions what foundation the individual has without it

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:27:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 theyre the large knots? The universals?

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:28:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    sorry firm knots, not large

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:29:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel - "Here and there in this mesh there are firm knots ¬Æ which give stability and direction to the life and consciousness of spirit; these knots or nodes owe their fixity and power to the simple fact that having been brought before consciousness, they are independent, self-existent Notions of its essential nature."

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:30:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    so these knots have been brought before conciousness and comprehended logically

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:33:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    just before that he says "whereas when thinking is an instinctive activity, spirit is enmeshed in the bonds of its categories and is broken up into an infinitely varied material."

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:36:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    so when we think instinctively we are so baffeld by the amount of categories in this mesh we dont really know whats going on. But we have these firm knots which have been brought before conciousness before and can be used with confidence in ordinary thinking

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:38:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 The important part, it seems, is that spirit is fundamentally consciousness and this self knowing (the bringing the categories before consciousness ‚Äî- which are universal because the hold many particulars under one unity) is a fundamental determination of its actuality.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:38:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So there‚Äôs the thing itself and the thing in it‚Äôs actually, but the self-knowing of the thing also determines that actuality.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:42:06 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This was part of the argument that rejects viewing the categories (aka the determinations of thought) as external forms that are distinct from the matter of thought and only attached to it. It‚Äôs rejected because it‚Äôs inadequate for truth. It‚Äôs inadequate for truth because a mere form with no content is assumed to be determined as finite and incapable of holding truth in its self-infinite.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:43:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    you refering to this part maybe? "The most important point for the nature of spirit is not only the relation of what it is in itself to what it is actually, but the relation of what it knows itself to be to what it actually is; because spirit is essentially consciousness, this self-knowing is a fundamental determination of its actuality."

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:46:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yeah that‚Äôs part of it

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:46:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    i find that sentence a bit confusing atm

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:49:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I think it‚Äôs only a few paragraphs before where he says the Notion is the universal or indispensable foundation

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:50:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    can you give a paragraph or a quote?

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:52:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I have a weird way of taking notes but I‚Äôm thinking of this part that comes before the part we‚Äôre talking about. Basically if the notion is the indispensable foundation and the categories (which are also notions) relate us to the thing-in-itself by it being a self-knowing and all the same thing in different moments of the Notion.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:53:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Thought is not an indifferent form without a matter, but actively determines the matter

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:53:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So Hegel says at the end of the sentence i quoted "self-knowing is a fundamental determination of its actuality" so it knowing what it is, is a part of what it is to be self concious

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 21:56:40 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I think that it knowing what it is informs how it appears to the mind. I‚Äôm interpreting ‚Äúactuality‚Äù as appearance.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:58:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    yes but it is also what it means for self conciousness to be what it is, its definition.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 21:59:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 so were not interested in "the relation of what it is in itself to what it is actually" becuase the nature of conciousness is to know that already, as in it knows what it itself is just by being self-conciousness

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 22:00:49 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Im not sure actuality is the same as appearance here

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 22:01:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    i think its refering to the truth of the matter

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 22:01:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 No peep the ‚Äúnot only‚Äù

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 22:02:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The most important point is not only what it is in itself (immediate)to what it is actually (mediated appearance) but also this other point about the relation of what it knows itself to be and what it actually is.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 22:02:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Someone who followed Kant might only think of the first relation for example. They might be trying to find truth there.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 22:03:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 ok thats paragraph 23 üëç

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 22:04:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yeah! üëç

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 22:04:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And perhaps that, making that mistake of not taking in the second relation of what it knows itself to be, is the problem of viewing thought as external form that maps onto or accommodates objects.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 22:05:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    That‚Äôs why we can‚Äôt get past the limit or raise the contradiction. Because we‚Äôre viewing the categories as external forms that describe objective relations of matter but have no role in determining them.

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 22:08:03 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    im sure it is, cant say im quite there yet in my understanding üòÑ

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 22:10:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 If it‚Äôs self knowing there is no limit the relation between subject and object because they‚Äôre both aspects of the the same thing related by self knowing or recognizing that it is the same.

  • headphon3jackFri Mar 07 2025 22:11:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    No noumena and phenomena

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 22:14:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 oh thats good üëç

  • minimaltomFri Mar 07 2025 22:14:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    need to take a break

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 11 2025 15:36:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The beginning of philosophy is the foundation which is present and preserved throughout the entire subsequent development, and remains completely immanent in its further determinations. Progress in philosophy is a retrogression, a grounding, or an establishing by means of which we first obtain the result that what we began with is in fact truth (not just arbitrary), and also primary truth. ‚Äî- It is an important consideration that the advance is a retreat into the ground. A retreat into what is primary and true on which what the beginning is made, depends, and originates. The essential requirement for the science of logic is not so much that the beginning be a pure immediacy, but rather that the whole of science be a circle within itself, in which the first is also last and the last also first.

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 11 2025 15:37:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The progress from that which forms the beginning is to be regarded as only a further determination of it, hence that which forms the starting point of the development remains at the base of what follows (doesn‚Äôt vanish from it).

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 11 2025 15:38:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Progress in knowing is not provisional, hypothetical, or problematical because it is the result which appears as the absolute grounds. Progress in knowing must be determined by the nature of the subject matter itself and its content. This beginning is not something neither an arbitrary or provisional assumption, nor something which appears to be arbitrarily or tentatively presupposed, but subsequently shown to be properly made the beginning.

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 11 2025 15:39:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Pure knowing only yields a negative determination that beginning is to be abstract. If pure being is to be the content of pure knowing, then the pure knowing must stand back from its content, and not determine it further. Or, if pure being is to be considered the unity into which knowing has collapsed (at the extreme points of its union with the object), then knowing itself has vanished in that unity, which would leave behind no difference from the unity by which the knowledge itself could determined. Nor is there anything else present, any content, that could make the beginning more determinate.

  • minimaltomSat Mar 15 2025 14:41:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 Pure knowing is what comes at the end of the phenomenology I believe

  • minimaltomSat Mar 15 2025 14:43:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    So he‚Äôs saying how that is the presupposition of the science of logic but pure knowing must stand back from it it and not determine it any further, so in that way pure being is in a way presupositionless like he says although I‚Äôm a bit foggy exactly how

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 15 2025 16:51:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 One thing to key in on is that it‚Äôs not an essential requirement for the science of logic that the beginning be pure being or pure immediacy. It‚Äôs about the circle of scientific advancement that‚Äôs created by the result being the ground. In this way progress in philosophy is a retrogression.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 17:52:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Sent this question to Stephen Houlgate and just got a response. This was my email: > Hi Stephen, > > I just wondered if you could explain what Hegel means when he says in the 2nd Preface to the Science of logic ¬ß 24: > > "The most important point for the nature of spirit is not only the relation of what it is in itself to what it is actually, but the relation of what it knows itself to be to what it actually is; because spirit is essentially consciousness, this self-knowing is a fundamental determination of its actuality." > > Is the first point, 'the relation of what it is in itself to what it is actually' a description of the Kantian perspective of the thing in itself? > > I think i understand the last point, that knowing itself is part of what it is to be self conscious, it is a defining characteristic of self consciousness so spirit doesnt need as in the first point to find out what it really is in comparison to its notion of itself because knowing that is its very determination. > > its the middle bit 'the relation of what it knows itself to be to what it actually is'. I can't fathom what this relation would consist of and what the significance of it would be. > > Thanks

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 17:53:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    here is his response:

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 17:53:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    > Dear Tom, > > This will have to be a quick response, but I hope it helps. > > When Hegel speaks of what spirit is "in itself" (an sich), this has nothing to do with Kant. The comparison is between what spirit is implicitly and what it is explicitly ("actually"). So, in his philosophy of history Hegel argues that all spirit ‚Äî that is, all human self-consciousness ‚Äî is implicitly free, but not all spirit is explicitly free. So, e.g., the Egyptians were implicitly free (as self-conscious) but not explicitly free, since they did not develop the rights and institutions of true freedom. > > The second point is that we need to compare what spirit knows itself to be with what it is explicitly (actually). You are right that self-knowledge belongs to what we are explicitly, but it does not exhaust the latter. Otherwise, we could never misunderstand ourselves ‚Äî or fail to understand fully who we are. > > This is related to the question of the categories of thought. They are "instinctively" at work in who we actually are, but this doesn't mean that we understand them fully ‚Äî that we know fully who and what we are. The task of the Logic, therefore, is to disclose how the categories are properly to be understood, and this understanding may run contrary to how we normally understand them (an understanding that currently governs who we actually are). > > Coming to understand the categories properly, therefore, will transform who we actually are, since, as you say, self-knowledge belongs to who we actually are. So it makes a difference to who we actually are if we have a clear understanding of the categories that inform our lives, or if they are just unconsciously at work within us. In the latter case, we will, or may, suffer the dialectic that they contain without understanding why. > > I hope this sheds some light on this issue. > > Best wishes, > > Stephen Houlgate

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 17:54:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    only just got it so still absorbing it, was suprised to find that the sentence wasnt about Kant!

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 17:59:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    very interesting to think that explicit refers to what something is in actuallity

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 18:01:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    like implicitly, in my inner perception of myself, I may be an alpha chad but explicitly, in reality, Im just a beta cuck

    Synthesize it, flip it, sublate it: Sigma Male

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 18:48:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Made this bit make more sense to me, or made me read it closer > Since, therefore, subjective thought is our very own, innermost, act, and the objective notion of things constitutes their essential import, we cannot go outside this our act, we cannot stand above it, and just as little can we go beyond the nature of things. ¬Æ We can however disregard the latter determination; in so far as it coincides with the first it would yield a relation of our thoughts to the object, but this would be a valueless result because it would imply that the thing, the object, would be set up as a criterion for our notions and yet for us the object can be nothing else but our notions of it.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 18:50:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    hes saying how can the object be the criterion for our notions when all the object is for us 'is' our notions of it. How can our notions be the criterion for our notions, thats just circular logic.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 18:52:17 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    our thoughts and the object are the same because all we have of the object 'are' our thoughts

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 17 2025 19:06:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

He clarified, too, that there is more to what is explicit than self-knowledge, because if there wasn‚Äôt then there would be no misunderstanding about the explicit objects aka who we are. It seems like it will be that the categories of thought, as pure essence recognized as self by self conscious, will be the clear understanding of the categories.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 17 2025 19:09:44 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 17 2025 19:16:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yeah I think that‚Äôs gotta be a stretch. If it‚Äôs all thought it‚Äôs all thought, but then what is explicit? I still believe we have to say that thought is implicit, but the explicit actuality of appearance for the Egyptian slave was not free. Therefore, the outside of subjective thought must appear as an object even if it is ultimately recognized as self-conscious thought.

  • headphon3jackThu Mar 20 2025 17:14:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I read the first two chapters of Houlgate‚Äôs book and found a lot more on it in the second chapter

  • headphon3jackThu Mar 20 2025 17:32:14 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôm starting to think he‚Äôs saying that the truth of self consciousness is immanent or internal to itself, but it must be made explicit. This seems to involve it appearing explicitly as an other to its own self.

  • headphon3jackThu Mar 20 2025 17:35:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But an explicit or implicit criterion of judgement can‚Äôt be the start of philosophy because that presupposes the absolute idea which we‚Äôd judge the beginning by, and it presupposes that the understanding is the faculty of judgement. When we really try to start without any presupposition then we are left with sheer indeterminate being or pure being. We can‚Äôt know it‚Äôs truth by judging it against its further development, because as an indeterminate beginning we can‚Äôt presuppose its further development. It must happen immanently.

  • minimaltomThu Mar 20 2025 17:46:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 what page is that?

  • minimaltomThu Mar 20 2025 17:50:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    what book is that? üòÑ not chapter 2 of the book im reading

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 22 2025 02:11:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôm thinking that for the categories to be clarified, they must first appear as an other before spirit, and then be recognized as self.

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 22 2025 02:12:41 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 It‚Äôs from the first chapter where he warns readers not to bring Kant‚Äôs reduction of the understanding as being the faculty of judgement into Hegel as a presupposition.

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 22 2025 02:13:34 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    That Fichte for example saw it as a presupposition and. Real self critical philosophy wouldn‚Äôt do that

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 22 2025 02:14:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It‚Äôs part of the reason we‚Äôre looking for a ground that can be causal. Rather than a subject which could be swapped with its predicate.

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 22 2025 02:15:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    like in the statement ‚Äúall bodies are divisible‚Äù. the subject bodies could be swapped with the predicate ‚Äúall divisible things are bodies‚Äù. You could say they both indicate something more foundational like substance, but how could it be causal?

  • minimaltomSat Mar 22 2025 02:33:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 I guess hes saying here that the beggining cant be a judgement in some way but what I think he's saying more broadly is that the judgement that an earlier category is deficient in comparison to a later one isnt the driving force for a category to develop into a more sufficient category.

  • minimaltomSat Mar 22 2025 02:37:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    you can't really make a judgement when your dealing with immediacy because judgement is mediation, is this partly what youre saying?

  • minimaltomSat Mar 22 2025 02:43:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think mctaggarts idea is that we have kind of 2 conceptions in our brain, firstly we *implicitly* have the complete truth which is absolute knowing and which is what our our thinking is and secondly we have *explicitly* the category that we are currently contemplating and the first is used as the criterion to judge the second as deficient and drives us on to develop it to a further category.

  • minimaltomSat Mar 22 2025 02:49:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 this is interesting, cna't quite get my head round it tho

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 22 2025 02:50:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Nah man

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 22 2025 02:53:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It‚Äôs that Kant presupposes things about understanding and judgement that are presuppositions insufficient to a critical philosophy. Further, I think even assuming the development that a category undergoes into a higher stage is a presupposition being wanted about. On my reading, that is the presupposition of the immanent criterion for truth if we follow the development.

  • headphon3jackSat Mar 22 2025 02:54:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    We gotta try and stick to the immediacy of the beginning and not stray from it. That‚Äôs the broader point.

  • minimaltomSat Mar 22 2025 02:56:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomMon Mar 24 2025 13:41:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @firedog235#0 <@805731746384445460> Hi Thomas, I put a criticism of your understanding of Zizek on Patreon, here it is again: > I think Thomas you are operating under a misunderstanding of what Zizek is saying when you privilage nothing over being. Here is an explaination of Zizeks theory of less-than-nothing by Cadell Last > > "To push the Idea of ‚Äúwhy is there nothing rather than something‚Äù further ≈Ωi≈æek plays with the idea that in order to achieve ‚Äúpure nothingness‚Äù (like the image of Death) you first have to be ‚Äúsomething‚Äù (i.e. it is only a subject that can conceive of the pure nothingness of Death); and it is then his claim that because of this phenomenological fact we can say that the excessive visions and images of ‚Äúsomething more‚Äù that appear internal to the symbolic order over and above ‚Äúphysical reality‚Äù (like those images offered in religions and many other metaphysical systems); signify that we must propose a third ontological category that breaks the dualism of something and nothing with the triad of something-nothing-less than nothing."

  • minimaltomMon Mar 24 2025 13:42:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    > "In this way the triadic relation between something-nothing-less than nothing structures the symbolic order because the ‚Äúsomething‚Äù of our reality is overdetermined by the paradoxical nature of less than nothing (as in the triadic structure introduced above). Later in the work we will go into greater depth about the nature of this less than nothing. However, for now, we will say that reality as a totality, for ≈Ωi≈æek, is not just ‚Äúsomething‚Äù of material processes and ‚Äúnothing‚Äù of the void; but also the ‚Äúless than nothing‚Äù of virtuality which he claims has not yet been understood properly ontologically." > > So if Cadell is correct Zizek thinks that to have pure nothing you have to have something or being to think nothing from. This is exactly what I was getting at when I said that to concieve of yourself as being nothing this already implys that the is something because you can't have nothing without something to think it from. And then less-than-nothing is even further the case as this is a completely virtual concept.

    @headphon3jack#0 Sound about right. I‚Äôm not going to say I completely understand how he derives being from the end, after all he says only after the whole things been gone through do you get the justification or the logical ground (as apposed to the historical ground as houlgate says) and we‚Äôve barely got started

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:25:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But I‚Äôm pretty sure being is the beggining for a damn good reason. I also believe that nothing can only be thought after you have being which I think zizek believes too

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:31:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 19:32:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Hegel wrote that the beginning must either be immediate or mediated, but either way we go (objective principle or subjective criterion) is refuted. This necessitates joining the form with the content, and finding the beginning in the development of thought itself. In grounding it and not presupposing it. So it is an issue if we can‚Äôt ground immediate being as the beginning.

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:34:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 Yes I understand that. I actually think if we read Hegel and houlgate closely we will find out exactly why

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:34:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But I think the idea we should begin with nothing instead is silly and naive

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:35:01 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And a misreading

  • angelus888Tue Mar 25 2025 19:38:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Exactly, all of these ideas must be utterly mastered in their most accurate form, and then the problems with them can be described. It is a matter of understanding the thing first without agreeing or disagreeing with it, letting it have its hours on the stage. Then the dissection begins.

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 19:39:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I agree, and I‚Äôm trying to do that. It may be a misreading that beginning with pure immediacy of being over nothing is presupposition, and we can just as well begin with nothing. After all, Descartes showed us that even with a method of radical doubt we still have to admit there is something ‚Äî- Hegel only says to drop the ego out of that and say ‚Äúthinking, therefore, is‚Äù

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:39:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • angelus888Tue Mar 25 2025 19:39:33 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Immanent implies reasoning within the same system as the thing itself analysed, to my knowledge. Sometimes this is a bad thing. I don't want to live in the delusional universe of each system. They're not all equal.

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:39:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @angelus888#0 Yeah exactly.

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:41:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    If you start critiquing someone without having understood what they‚Äôre saying that‚Äôs stupid (as Hegel says)

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:41:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 Yeah I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a presupposition, it‚Äôs just what immediacy is

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:42:13 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    At least not the kind of presupposition Hegel is defending against

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 19:42:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He presupposes that we can think

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 19:42:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Now, starting from the determination of pure knowledge, the only thing needed to ensure the beginning remains immanent in its scientific development is to consider what is there before us. Pure knowing, as concentrated into this unity, has sublated all reference to an other and to mediation. It is without distinction, and as distinctionless, ceases itself to be knowledge. It is only simple immediacy. Simple immediacy is itself an expression of reflection and contains a reference to its distinction from what it is mediated. Simple immediacy, in its true expression, is pure being. Just as pure knowing is knowing as such, so too is pure being nothing but being in general (being and nothing else ‚Äî no further specification). ‚Äî- Here the beginning is made with being represented as having come to be through mediation, and this mediation is also sublating itself. There is a presupposed pure knowing as the outcome of finite knowing (of consciousness). But if no presupposition is to be made, and the beginning itself is to be taken in immediately, then it‚Äôs only determination is it ought to be the beginning of logic (of thought as such). All that is present is the resolve to consider thought as such. ‚Äî- Thus the beginning must be an abstract or absolute beginning that is to be itself the ground of the entire science, so it may not be mediated by anything or have a ground (not suppose anything). Consequently, it must be purely and simply an immediacy (merely an immediacy itself). It cannot possess any determination relatively to anything else, and it cannot contain within itself any determination or content, because such determinations would be a distinguishing and interrelationship of distinct moments (consequently a mediation). The beginning therefore is pure being.

  • angelus888Tue Mar 25 2025 19:43:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 PoMo in its attenuated form has something to offer here. We get our notions of the thing, not the thing, we don't have access to the man, only his acolytes and explainers and translators. So we get a tradition, this is the most academic way to approach it. There are *traditions* of Marxism, of Hegel, of whatever. So we are interacting with one seeming on a certain axis. Still, we can do our best about that essence to which we have the most reasonable, wide, and honest access to try to wrestle the thing itself.

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 19:43:16 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    This is rather long but it‚Äôs from my notes. I wrote it up trying to put Hegel in my own words.

  • angelus888Tue Mar 25 2025 19:43:57 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 19:59:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Being is determined in 3 ways 1. As against an other in general 2. As immanently self determining 3. Setting aside the preliminary character of division, it is the abstract indeterminateness and immediacy in which the beginning is made

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:00:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:00:56 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Then we see a division of being and essence which later on in development proves to be in its totality one sphere of the Notion against another sphere

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:01:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    And there are three determinations being posits for itself as a self immanent determination too

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 20:02:48 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 20:06:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 20:06:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:06:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    He notes that he‚Äôs diverging from the usual class of action of the categories with how he‚Äôs using quality and quantity differently. Especially Kant‚Äôs categories.

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:07:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But this calls for ‚Äúno special comment here.‚Äù Lmao

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:07:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:10:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:11:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Kant is updating the medieval transcendental categories of truth, beauty, and the good into quantity as unity, the one, totality.

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 20:15:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:17:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yes, I believe for Kant a function unifies a plurality in the manifold of senses into a unity or totality of that plurality

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 20:17:11 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Oh I see they‚Äôre the sun categories of quantity?

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 20:17:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomTue Mar 25 2025 20:18:55 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think houlgate explains in chapter 1 that the reason he thinks all the categories are separate is because he derives them from the forms of judgement

  • headphon3jackTue Mar 25 2025 20:22:18 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yeah and that‚Äôs what Hegel is explicitly not doing. Kant has 4 quantity, quality, relation, and modality. Hegel is starting with quality, saying quantity is negative quality, and measure is a specific relation but not relation in general. He also says something about magnitude which is that it includes the alterability of Being, but Being itself does not change.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 12:03:28 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôve watched the workshop which is on patreon and Im less kranky about it but we still only talked about a tiny bit of the houlgate chapter

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 12:10:36 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Just put this in the patreon comments: I don‚Äôt think Thomas is right that what is left over is this negation or x is not x or whatever. What is left is just pure immediacy. All mediation has been abstracted away it‚Äôs not there. The only mediation there is implicit, it is implied that it will come later in the development. What implicit means is that all the information is there to know what being will be in the further development when it becomes explicitly posited because the science is completely necessary it can only be one way, what the beggining implies it will be

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 12:33:20 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    this is from hegel glossary by Sebastian Gardner: (as he says Miller translates this as implicit) > IN ITSELF (an sich). Merely potential or implicit (Miller often translates an sich as 'implicit'). Something is 'in > itself' when it is considered separately from other things, and (in the case of a form of consciousness) when it is > unreflective. That is why, for Hegel, the in itself is mere potentiality: actuality requires determination, negation, > relations with other things. Note that a thing may be 'in itself for us' (an sich f√ºr uns), an expression Hegel uses > often: this just means that we are considering it as it is separate from other things. Contrasts with: for itself, and inand-for-itself.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 12:38:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    this part too is interesting as it explains a bit about what explicit means: > ACTUAL, ACTUALITY (wirklich, Wirklichkeit). Fully-developed, matured. Actuality thus incorporates a > reference to (teleological) necessity; for Hegel the contingent and irrational are not actual (they are, rather, > appearance). In the case of spirit or truth, actual means 'for-itself', explicit.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 12:39:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    so: in itself - implicit for itself - explicit

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:22:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I think the ‚ÄúAll X is Not X‚Äù line is a logic puzzle meant to showcase a way to conceive of nothing. I agree with many of your points, but something is wrong when you say ‚ÄúAll mediation has been abstracted away it‚Äôs not there‚Äù. I would instead say that all mediation has been sublated, and therefore annihilated, yes, but also internalized. So mediation is not all gone, but it is indifferent.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:25:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The two determinations, mediation and the immediate, reveal themselves to be unseparated and inseparable. The opposition between them is a nullity.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:27:52 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Btw someone in a different discord gave me this book on German idealism that has been giving me a lot of context. There‚Äôs some stuff about Hegel, of course, but he‚Äôs not the focus. Thought I‚Äôd share it here.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:28:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    üìé Frederick_C._Beiser_-_German_idealism__the_struggle_against_subjectivism_1781-1801_2002_Harvard_University_Press_-_libgen.li.pdf?ex=680e30ef&is=680cdf6f&hm=39e1d3e4838a4e654fad566f434c1725a2c21c6b86238f0c51cff5242f8c0550&

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 13:31:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 I dont think this all x is not x is apllicaple here tho

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 13:31:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 13:32:30 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:35:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Well pure knowing is from the philosophy of spirit

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 13:35:23 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I know this pure knowing is also the ending of the phenomenology as well tho so that puts a spanner in the works

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 13:35:32 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ah yeah what i was about to say

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 13:35:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    they both end at the same thing I think

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 13:36:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    theyre called slightly different things but they mean the same

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:40:29 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Well it may be different aspects of it. If we‚Äôre dropping out the I, the ego, the self-consciousness and trying to ground being in pure immediacy, then they can‚Äôt just be the same thing. The objective idealists, according to that Beiser book, and I agree this is what Hegel has written, makes the following point: the transcendental subject can not be the precondition of the categories and be less universal than the categories.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 13:40:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    im not 100% on this but i have read it in a commentary

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:40:46 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    There‚Äôs a need to give ground to the external world, and not contain the ego in that circle.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:41:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Which is why, I think, being has to start detached from its essence. I think that essence might be its own self consciousness.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:42:08 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But yes, ultimately, I think you‚Äôre right that Hegel is trying to get to absolute being which has knowledge of itself.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:43:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    A quote from the Beiser to support my argument

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:49:50 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 13:50:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Could you just give me a quick idea what they‚Äôre discussing here?

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:50:43 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel explains the task of philosophy as to find the identity of identity and non-identity

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:55:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    They‚Äôre discussing the two types of idealisms they found when studying German Idealism: the subject or formal idealism attributed to Kant and Fichte, and objective idealism attributed to the Romantics, Schelling, and Hegel. That the subject and object must have some identity to explain the possibility of knowledge, but to account for this reality they‚Äôre led to some dualism given that objects appear as independent of our conscious control. So the problem of German Idealism is how to find a principle of subject-object identity that could surmount but also explain external reality.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:56:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hegel has made an argument against this subjective idealism in the prefaces of the SoL

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 13:58:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    When he discusses how we retreat to freedom in thought because the categories seem more universal than us. Although, I‚Äôm not sure if he‚Äôs arguing for a ground or for foundationalism anymore. If Beiser is correct, then he may be arguing for a regulative instead of a principle.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:08:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 right, going by the second page you posted, they need to say that subject and object are the same in order to have any knowledge, but if they are the same how do you account for there being an objective world

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:08:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But really Hegel says to join the form with the content as the beginning instead of going with an objective first principle or subjective criterion.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:09:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Adding what I‚Äôve learned from Beiser it must be because the absolute is neither objective or subjective, and to label it as such would be to limit the unlimited.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:13:19 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    It‚Äôs like Kant‚Äôs transcendental subject is instead just the appearance of the absolute. How we can know it because it does appear to the subject. Which makes it the highest development of nature and reason. But then at some point Hegel puts less emphasis on nature and more on society, the state, and history.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:31:05 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 In subjective idealism the objective conforms to the subjective. In objective idealism the subject conforms to the objective because objectivity is the source of the subject. üëç

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:33:26 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yeah, it‚Äôs like in subjective idealism the subject attaches forms to things in experience, whereas objective idealism views the ideal as the archetypical.

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:34:12 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Hence Hegel talking about not attaching forms to content, but rather that the form is it‚Äôs own content.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:35:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    With the identity of identity and non identity Hegels saying the subject and object are the same (to have any knowledge) and different (to ensure objectivity) at the same time, and what is the identity of these propositions.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:36:04 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    im just putting this in my words

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:36:24 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The identity having to do with our ability to have knowledge of it. The non-identity to account for its external reality without us.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:37:00 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    and they are both moments of a single identity

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:37:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The absolute

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:37:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    why the absolute?

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:38:31 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    Because it is neither subjective or objective, yet we have an appearance of it in the transcendental subject that gives us a clue it exists.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:40:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    what do you mean by the absolute here sorry

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:41:37 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    The way the romantics (objective idealists) at the time seemed to take it was like the absolute was the same as nature and the transcendental subject was the highest point of nature.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:44:10 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ok

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:45:02 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I‚Äôm talking about this from the Beiser

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:48:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 ok but it seems that Hegel moved beyond this and thought of the absolute as spirit rather than nature?

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:49:21 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    so the absolute isnt so much everything there is but rather evrything that can be thought or known perhaps

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:49:39 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    this is problematic probably

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:49:45 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    how i put it

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:51:58 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ‚ÄúSchelling, Hegel, Schlegel, H√∂lderlin, and Novalis all held that the absolute comes to its fullest realization, organization, and development only in the self-awareness of the knowing subject. They were utterly opposed to any view that would permit a dualism between the subject‚Äôs knowing the absolute and the absolute itself.‚Äù

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:52:09 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    what is hegels differenzschrift?

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:52:35 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I tried to google that when I read it

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:52:51 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    I think its a critique of Fichte

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:53:22 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    ah i think its The Difference Between Fichte's and Schelling's System of Philosophy

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 14:53:47 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    this was an early work and before even the phenomenology so i think he moved beyond it

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:55:27 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackWed Mar 26 2025 14:55:38 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    But he breaks with Schelling a few years later

Some things that stand out to me are that Hegel for sure doesn‚Äôt want to begin with the I or absolute ego, and he definitely thinks we can affirm truth behind its limit and negation. You‚Äôre right about developing the idea of deducing the categories from what thought is minimally, but maybe Hegel‚Äôs right that it‚Äôs not the I.

  • minimaltomWed Mar 26 2025 15:25:25 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomThu Mar 27 2025 21:32:59 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • minimaltomThu Mar 27 2025 21:34:15 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

  • headphon3jackThu Mar 27 2025 21:53:07 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Oh I‚Äôm still digesting the chapter and I haven‚Äôt exactly finished it. The thing that incited me to post was that I had been thinking about a relation between being and nothing, but for their to be a relation it must be a determinate being rather than indeterminate. So unity of being and nothing is that they‚Äôre inseparable but also distinct. Their difference is completely empty and doesn‚Äôt exist in themselves but in a third ‚Äîbecoming, in which both pure being and pure nothing subsist. Because even though they are able to be isolated in abstraction that isolation is not true, and they are in fact inseparable but distinct.

  • minimaltomSat Mar 29 2025 12:30:42 GMT+0000 (Greenwich Mean Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yes.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 31 2025 10:10:23 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 <@1275846548932132864> having read that stuff about German idealism you might actually find zizeks book less than nothing quite interesting. I just read the introduction and he talks about all the different German idealists before Hegel and their various attempts to overcome the subject object divide thing. Like holderlin filling the gap with false narrative but Hegel puts this gap holderlin wants to overcome into the thing itselfs own makeup.
