  • minimaltomMon Mar 31 2025 10:14:12 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It‚Äôs amazing too btw how Hegelian holderlin sounds using words like immediacy and mediation, etc. you can see that Hegel wasn‚Äôt writing in a vacuum and there was a real symbiotic relationship with the others and a lot of debt to their work

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 13:43:24 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Funny you bring this up, I was going to suggest to you that what you‚Äôre looking for to refute Thomas may be towards the end of Remark 3 in chapter 1.

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 13:51:22 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 These parts stood out to me as being relevant towards that end

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 14:04:14 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    The difference of being and nothing is not found in themselves, so it must be found in a third, but not a subjective third with an opinion (opinion is outside the logic), and Hegel says becoming is that third in which being and nothing subsist as moments.

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 14:05:28 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    And, I think this part from Remark 4 is also relevant.

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 14:08:29 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    We start with indeterminate pure being, and since indeterminate is logically the negation of determination, then we can arrive at determinate being in an immediate way ‚Äî‚Äî And we don‚Äôt get stuck at the beginning as an end that needs a second beginning, or something external to it.

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 14:10:56 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Being and nothing are indeterminate, but are only moments that subsists in the determinate being of becoming.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 31 2025 14:58:16 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 thanks I will give them a good read

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 15:02:23 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I wanted to say, additionally, that this stuff about becoming, and especially his focus on the Eleatic tradition, which he puts Spinoza and Ficthe in too, is because he‚Äôs refuting the third man argument against an issue those dogmatic idealist have with external reflection. Since they believed there can‚Äôt be an identity between identity and non-identity, then they begin with immediate being, but that beginning can‚Äôt progress and is an end. So, they need a second beginning or something external added in reflection (which is indifferent to the actual objects). Hegel is saying no, there is an identity between identity and non-identity. Being is the same as nothing, but it is still different, and even though that speculative can‚Äôt be proposed in a judgment, we can still follow the vanishing point where the one turns into the other.

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 15:02:48 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    But in the actual and not the possible

  • minimaltomMon Mar 31 2025 15:15:29 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 is the third man god for spinoza? Just occured to me, could be wrong

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 15:24:51 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I‚Äôve not read a word of Spinoza directly, but I‚Äôve read around him and I think God or Nature being equivalent as the One, which Hegel says the Eleatic tradition is correct on being the historically necessary starting point. So maybe. What I‚Äôve read about the third man argument is it leads to an infinite regress.

  • minimaltomMon Mar 31 2025 15:25:24 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 ah that makes it sound like im wrong üòÑ ignore me

  • minimaltomMon Mar 31 2025 15:26:10 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yeah because once you have that third man, you need another man between the thrid man and the original 2 and so on and so on.....

  • headphon3jackMon Mar 31 2025 15:26:50 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    There‚Äôs a funny line, at least I thought so, where Hegel says you can tell they‚Äôre ‚Äòabstract pantheists‚Äô by their ‚Äòsystem of identity‚Äô

  • minimaltomMon Mar 31 2025 15:31:30 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yeah hes got a sense of humour for sure üòÑ

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:31:32 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Find ing 153 very difficult to understand. I get its mainly to say that being and nothing can't be thought as completely seperate from each other and only subsist in becoming as a transition from one into the other but the particulars are quite tricky

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:35:58 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    i get hes saying that becoming is transition although not in the way we usually think of transition as being movement between 2 different static seperate things

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:36:49 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I take the part after that to be saying that becoming has many empirical, concrete shapes that are being set aside by abstraction to hold being and nothing apart in isolation. But actually an isolated concept is itself, too, empirical.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:36:53 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    its this bit where he starts to talk about reflection: > Now wherever and in whatever form being and nothing are in question, this third must be present; for the two terms have no separate subsistence of their own but are only in becoming, in this third. But this third has many empirical shapes, which are set aside or ignored by abstraction in order to hold fast, each by itself, these its products, being and nothing, and to show them protected against transition. Such simple procedure of abstraction can be countered, equally simply, by calling to mind the empirical existence in which that abstraction is itself only a something having a determinate being. Or else it is some other form of reflection which is supposed to effect the separation of what is inseparable. Such determination carries within itself its own opposite, and, without referring back and appealing to the nature of the thing itself, the determination of reflection can be refuted in its own self by taking it just as it presents itself and pointing out in it its own other.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:37:45 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    This simple abstraction that isolates can be countered by calling its empirical, determinate being to mine.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:37:57 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    so the abstraction itself is false?

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:38:13 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Or else it is some other determination or judgement which we know is one-sided and can‚Äôt express speculative truth

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:38:42 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It may not be that the abstraction is false, but that it‚Äôs determinate.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:38:57 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    And therefore not really being and nothing but abstracted, isolated concept.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:39:07 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    oooh

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:42:53 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I think youre right, what about the reflection bit

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:44:11 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I think that‚Äôs referring back to either an inner or external reflection. The first would be like an analysis which separates out the concepts parts and making logical judgements and the latter would be like synthesizing two abstract concepts together in a unity of the understanding with logical judgements.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:48:22 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Imaginatively or synthetically

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:48:52 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 internal or external? üòµ‚Äçüí´

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:50:11 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Im wondering if Hegels using the term reflection as he developes it in the logic or if hes using the coloquial meaning or Kants meaning

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:52:30 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I don‚Äôt think so! I think here is related to another a comment he made in the first remark about how the later metaphysicians (Christians) rejected that nothing comes from nothing, and accepted that the world could be created from nothing. But he said they only understood this imaginatively (an isolated concept which can be analysed by its inner determinations) and synthetically (adding concepts to each other with an external reflection that is indifferent to the objects)

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:53:30 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    the imaginative ends at the beginning in isolation, and the synthetic needs a second beginning for that reason. Now we‚Äôre back to the third man argument.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:55:31 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    ah so its coloquial you think, reflection as in some third person just thinking about it?

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:55:51 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 No

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:56:08 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    The third man argument is not about people it‚Äôs about forms

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:57:43 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    yeah i didnt mean literally

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:58:43 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    The Eleatics and Plato saw all appearances as illusion, and only trusted the truth in reason. They believed in a world of forms that was the universal for all the particulars. The One over many. Plato criticized his own conception of this in Parmenides and came up with argument from a third. In doing research on this I‚Äôve found the phrasing of it as a third man argument comes from Aristotle.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 15:59:53 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 so this term reflection goes all the way back to aristotle you think?

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 15:59:58 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It leads to an infinite regression, and they thought infinity just won‚Äôt possible.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:00:00 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    in this case

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:00:49 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    i meant plato sorry

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:01:46 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    im very pedantic about this thing sorry its a problem

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:02:04 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I wouldn‚Äôt focus too much on that term. I think it just reminds us that inner reflection analyses concepts, and external reflection synthesizes concepts, but those are determinate. Hegel is trying to clarify the categories by not just separating them abstractly, but seeing them beyond the rational limit of the one-sided opposition.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:02:25 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    i like to know in which context Hegels using terms because it means diferent things in different situations

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:02:33 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Hegel is talking about forms though so he is taking the notion of the one over many.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:05:15 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    ok so this use of reflection hes just saying like from a third perspective

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:05:50 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 No try and stick to imaginative and synthetic when considering reflection or internal and external.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:06:21 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    external to the development?

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:06:38 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Indifferent to whether the object is or is not

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:06:40 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    opposite of immanent?

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:09:58 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It‚Äôs the hundred dollars thing, so he does bring up Kant‚Äôs refutation of the ontological proof of God. If being and nothing are the same, then having a hundred dollars and not having a hundred dollars is the same, but that alters the premise and makes being and nothing determinate.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:10:49 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    A determinate, finite being is one that is in relation to an other.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:11:16 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    If it‚Äôs in a relation then it is brought forward as not indifferent to whether it‚Äôs co-relative is or is not.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:13:56 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Kant is saying that we cannot get to the actual existence (he uses the term existence different than Hegel) just from the possibility or concept of a hundred dollars. So the ontological proof is refuted. Because for him the possible does not contain any more being than the actual, since being (Kant has being as equivalent to existence) can‚Äôt be a real predicate to a subject, or a property of an object.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:22:16 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    > Later, especially Christian, metaphysics whilst rejecting the proposition that out of nothing comes nothing, asserted a transition from nothing into being; although it understood this proposition synthetically or merely imaginatively, yet even in the most imperfect union there is contained a point in which being and nothing coincide and their distinguishedness vanishes. whats the significance of synthetically here? My understanding synthetic means the opposite of analytic, analytic knowledge is contained in a definition (like all batchelors are unmarried) and synthetic is new knowledge

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:24:04 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    My understanding of it is that synthetic adds knowledge by adding an isolated analytic concept (perhaps of the imagination) with another isolated concept.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:24:35 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    ok, why does hegel have a problem with that?

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:25:24 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    he says they merely have synthetic knowledge of it

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:26:35 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    o fuck maybe i read that wrongly

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:27:22 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Because they can‚Äôt make progress from that beginning

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:28:30 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    They start with pure being and pure nothing but end up with a determinate being and nothing that have a relation.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:29:15 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    He‚Äôll use Fichte as an example of this ‚Äòprogress‚Äô from external reflection that requires a second beginning, and therefore an infinite regress.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:38:08 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    so hes saying the christians understood the proposition out of nothing comes nothing synthetically, what does that mean??

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 16:39:46 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    sorry for being dumb and lazy, i will be reading into it myself

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:53:11 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 They argued against that. Christians think the world was created, and therefore had a beginning, rather than being eternal. It seems to me that the Christians understood that being comes from nothing, but they synthetically added the concept of determinate being to the concept of determinate nothing. I‚Äôm going outside the text now to speculate, but it seems the Christians did have a third that they symbolically represent in the trinity. Like maybe if we think of God as being, the Holy Spirit as nothing, and therefore both are determinately related in the determinate being Jesus.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:58:18 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Trying to write it out here has been helpful for me ü§ù

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 16:59:17 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It‚Äôs easier for me to develop my thoughts on this stuff when I‚Äôm trying to explain it to someone else

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:23:11 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 thats good üëç

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:24:58 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 but if you see tyhe way hes writen it, he says they understood the proposition synthetically. The only proposition hes mentioned is that nothing comes out of nothing. That being comes out of nothing isnt described as a proposition. I could be being too pedantic what im saying is its not clear from the way its writen which proposition is being refered to although it should probably be intuitively obvious if you understand what hes talking about

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:29:40 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    what youre saying mnakes sense tho

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:31:02 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    like its synthetic because they just added 2 unrelated realms of thought together with no real explaination

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:31:46 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    rather than hegel who considers them the same as each other, therefore analytic?

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:32:23 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    it is an analytic judgement for him to say being is nothing and nothing is being. The knowledge is contained in the definition

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:36:52 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    like nothing is nothing is an analytic proposition in a way, its much more intuitively grasped and seems common sense, wheras saying being comes from nothing with no explaination is merely a synthetic kind of speculation

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:38:07 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    and here when he says > yet even in the most imperfect union there is contained a point in which being and nothing coincide and their distinguishedness vanishes.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:38:39 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    it looks like hes saying even tho their reaqsoning was flawed there was a kernel of truth in it perhaps

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 17:59:22 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 im not sure why your saying imaginative means ending at the beggining in isolation. Isnt Hegel just using the word imagination to mean theyre just kind of vaguely imagining some kind of connection between being and nothing? How did you get this definition of imagination?

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 18:17:38 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I see now however how when he talks of reflection here he could be talking about the reflection of a determination, as in something is determined by reflecting off something else.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 18:19:33 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    since he says earlier "they are in a more developed determination, and are grasped, for example, as positive and negative, the former being posited, reflected being, the latter posited, reflected nothing"

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:12:16 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 No he says they understood it either synthetically or imaginatively. The proposition he mentions they reject is nothing comes from nothing. The proposition they support is that nothing comes from being, and they might synthetically add together those two isolated concepts of the imagination.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:12:40 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Not unrelated realms of thought. Two distinct, isolated concepts of the imagination.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:13:50 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Idk about this but something seems wrong with calling Hegel analytic

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:14:39 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yes, he‚Äôs saying they‚Äôre right about the unity of being and nothing, but don‚Äôt understand it as it‚Äôs actuality. They only understand it conceptually.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:15:11 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 No you still seem to be thinking of objects and thought as such

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:16:05 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 The positive and negative would be the more developed determinations of determinate being and nothing. Not grasped as immediate, undetermined, pure being and nothing.

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:17:14 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Analytic and synthetic judgements are still judgements, and Hegel says they can‚Äôt be used for speculative truths. So that is why I think he‚Äôs not analytic.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 20:18:42 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 im not saying that Hegel is analytic, what im saying is that for Hegel the statement 'being and nothing are the same' is an analytic judgement because it tells you nothing new about either thing

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 20:19:37 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    thats all i meant but could be irrelevant

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 20:20:12 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 how do you mean?

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:26:29 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I mean that the progress Hegel makes is immediate and not in any kind of reflection or judgement. Immediate being is already a ‚Äònot‚Äô. It‚Äôs not determinate being. It‚Äôs immediately there logically or in thought as such.

  • minimaltomTue Apr 01 2025 20:28:02 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 Ok yeah but I was describing the kind of abstraction that Hegel refutes

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:28:37 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I agree with this

  • headphon3jackTue Apr 01 2025 20:32:09 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It‚Äôs one sided because it dues not include the difference but makes being and nothing distinguish, therefore canceling itself and contradicting. Judgements can‚Äôt get to the speculative. The vanishing point between the two one-sided propositions gives us an indication of the becoming.

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:07:48 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 whats one sided?

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:32:17 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:37:13 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Imagination or thought is where the concept is, so to speak. If you start with a single isolated concept as a beginning, then how do you progress without adding something to it in a synthetic reflection?

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:37:28 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:37:42 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Judgement produces two one-sided proposition: that being and nothing are the same, and that being and nothing are two different

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:38:12 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 If it includes thinking then thought is imagination

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:38:25 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:38:30 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    And so the concept

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:39:42 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 no sorry it doesnt include thinking itself, i meant the list of mental faculties of whic imagination is a part includes thinking, its a seperate faculty

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:40:36 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    The same is the case with nothing, only contrariwise, and this familiar reflection on it has been made often enough. Nothing, taken in its immediacy, shows itself as affirmative (shows itself as being), for according to its nature it‚Äôs the same as being. Nothing is thought of (imagined of, spoken, of) and therefore is, in the thinking, imagining, and speaking. Further, this being is also distinguished from it. Therefore, although there is nothing in thought (it is said), yet it is for that very reason that it is not nothing that is. Being does not belong to this nothing as such, but this being is only thought (or imagination). With this distinguishing, it is equally not to be denied that nothing stands ins relationship to being, but in a relation (even though it contains the difference) there is present a union with being. In whatever way nothing is indicated (enunciated), it shows it‚Äôs connected with (or in contact with) a being (unseparated from a being) ‚Äî- that is to say, in a determinate being.

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:40:38 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    i thnk imagination is just free form association

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:42:12 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I‚Äôm not quite sure on the distinction there, but yes I think the faculties of reason and understanding also are thought.

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:44:10 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    I think reason and understanding are yes, not so sure about imagination although it does seem common sense that it involves thinking

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:46:09 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    and when he says above "but this being is only thought (or imagination)" it seems like hes equating them!

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:46:31 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    or is he saying being can be in either thought or imagination

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:46:49 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 Yes but it could be that my notes are wrong and it should be written as thought *or* imagination. A mutually exclusive or, you know? Idk

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:47:06 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 ok

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:50:13 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Just searched imagination in the pdf of the logic and got this in the glossary > Vorstellung. The normal translation of this term is ‚Äúrepresentation.‚Äù But > Hegel uses it in different contexts in two quite distinct senses ‚Äì in a generic > sense that would include the specific type of representation which is the > concept; and in a narrower sense which is normally associated with > ‚Äúimagination‚Äù and is opposed to ‚Äúconcept.‚Äù In this last sense, it can be > translated in a variety of ways ‚Äì for instance, as ‚Äúordinary representation,‚Äù > ‚Äúfigurative representation,‚Äù or ‚Äúrepresentation of the imagination.‚Äù

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:52:24 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 So I‚Äôve been thinking about it in the general sense ü§î

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:53:02 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    haha i thought you meant herbal then, hegel talks about herbs at one point üòÑ

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:53:21 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    > But I must admit that such an abstract perfection > of presentation must generally be renounced; the very fact that the logic > must begin with the purely simple, and therefore the most general and > empty, restricts it to expressions of this simple that are themselves > absolutely simple, without the further addition of a single word; only > allowed, as the matter at hand requires, would be negative reflections > intended to ward off and keep at bay whatever the imagination or an > undisciplined thinking might otherwise adventitiously bring in.

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:53:50 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    So in the narrow sense there can be representations of the imagination, but not concepts.

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 02:54:10 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    this bit mention imagination as like undisciplined thinking so im thinking when he talks about the christians this is the meaning of imagination hes using

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 02:55:51 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    The ‚Äòwithout an addition of a single word‚Äô is referencing that sort where he discusses Hegel considering the proposition ‚ÄòThe One is‚Äô, and finding two things synthetically joined together in it: The One and being (is).

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:06:23 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    There‚Äôs a bit more towards the end of remark 3 that I want to bring up. It‚Äôs when he says the transition of being and nothing into each other is is to be understood with no further elaboration of the transition by reflection. It‚Äôs immediate and quite abstract, because the determinateness of either moment is not yet posited in the other. Nothing is not yet posited in being, even though being essentially nothing. That makes it impermissible to say being is the ground of nothing and vice versa, or nothing is the cause of being and so forth. Or that the transition from one to the other can only occurs under a condition that something is or under the condition of non-being. The kind of connection can‚Äôt be further determined without both sides being further determined. The connection of a ground to a consequent no longer has merely being and nothing as its two sides which it connects, but expressly being is a ground, and something (although merely posited and self-subsistent), is yet not the abstract nothing.

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:07:29 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It is therefore inadmissible to employ more developed forms of mediation here and to hold being and nothing in any kind of relationship ‚Äî the transition in question is not yet a relation.

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:11:39 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 posited has always been a confusing word for me, I think it means made explicit but im not sure

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:12:18 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    what are you most interested in about this quote tho?

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:12:49 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    i think i also read posit means generally bring to mind

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:13:22 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    usually posit means to propose but i dont think thats the meaning for hegel

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:13:57 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 The interesting part is that being is the ground, because even though it is essentially the same as nothing, nothing is not yet posited.

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:14:16 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    i thought he said being couldnt be the ground of nothing?

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:14:42 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:20:51 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:22:10 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:28:58 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:29:08 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:29:26 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    This from the part about the two moments of becoming ceasing to be and coming to be

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:29:36 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I‚Äôve been thinking about it as the foundation

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:30:07 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    Which has no presuppositions

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:31:13 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    hmm yeah but the ground is supposed to be the end, absolute knowing or soemthing

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:31:57 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    being as foundation?

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:34:02 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    It‚Äôs that becoming contains two unities. Each of which is a unity of being and nothing. The one is being as immediate and as relation to nothing, and the other nothing as immediate as relation to being. The determinations are of unequal values in these unities.

  • headphon3jackWed Apr 02 2025 03:34:29 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @minimaltom#0 I think that everything is supposed to be grounded in the science and not presupposed or added synthetically

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:35:28 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 yes but the logic is circular, it goes backwards and forwards and the beggining is grounded in the end

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:36:54 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    @headphon3jack#0 i believe coming-to-be and ceasing-to-be are the moments of becoming. will look that up

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:40:35 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    yes i think thats right, and the reason becoming turns into determinate-being is because coming-to-be and ceasing-to-be logically cancel each other out

  • minimaltomWed Apr 02 2025 03:43:11 GMT+0100 (British Summer Time)

    ¬ß 179 Both are the same, becoming, and although they differ so in direction they interpenetrate and paralyse each other. The one is ceasing-to-be: being passes over into nothing, but nothing is equally the opposite of itself, transition into being, coming-to-be. This coming-to-be is the other direction: nothing passes over into being, but being equally sublates itself and is rather transition into nothing, is ceasing-to-be. They are not reciprocally sublated ‚Äî the one does not sublate the other externally ‚Äî but each sublates itself in itself and is in its own self the opposite of itself.
